DOC.HEAD: NTSB Begins Amtrak Derailment Probe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE passenger and injury figures from NTSB briefing; quotes; DELETES extraneous material; picks up 19th graf pvs, `Amtrak and American...'
DOC.TEXT: Federal investigators found ``slight indications'' of rail movement Tuesday where an Amtrak passenger train derailed, and the fireman at the controls felt the 16-car train drag moments before it crashed. Investigators said the train apparently was traveling within the speed limit when eight cars left the tracks Monday afternoon, injuring 95. About a dozen people remained hospitalized Tuesday. There were no deaths. Amtrak's California Zephyr with 396 passengers and a crew of 24 was headed to Chicago from the West Coast when it derailed in southeastern Iowa on track owned by the Burlington Northern Railroad. The number of passengers and injured was revised from Monday. Susan Coughlin, vice-chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board, said investigators discovered ``slight indications'' of rail movement, either from lack of ballast or wet soil, as the train entered a crossing grade at Batavia. She declined to draw any conclusions. ``They are looking for evidence of movement in the track structure,'' Ms. Coughlin said at a news conference. ``We are not in a position at this point to interpret any of the findings.'' She said a fireman who also was a qualified engineer was at the controls when the train derailed, which ``is not an abnormal situation at all.'' ``The fireman who was operating as the engineer felt the train drag. Up to that point, they detected nothing abnormal in the performance of the train. ``He looked back and saw that the rear cars were swaying. He put his train then into an emergency braking,'' she said. Ms. Coughlin declined to say whether the braking action was the correct procedure, or if it saved lives and kept injuries to a minimum. An eight-member team from the NTSB is leading the investigation, which involves about 40 officials from the Federal Railroad Administration, the Iowa Department of Transportation, Amtrak, the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and Burlington Northern. The 24-member crew, including a conductor, two assistant conductors, an engineer and the fireman, was tested for drug and alcohol use and those results were expected in about two days, she said. The NTSB will concentrate its efforts Wednesday to a switching device in Batavia and a 1,240-foot stretch of track from where the train passed the grade crossing to where it derailed, she said. Behind the investigators, crews went to work on the twisted rail and gouged right-of-way in this town of 525 people, 90 miles southeast of Des Moines. The double-track route was not expected to be reopened until late Wednesday. Ms. Coughlin the crash caused $1.7 million damage to the train and $75,000 to the track. The damaged cars were taken to Fairfield, about 15 miles east of Batavia, for inspection and repair. The three locomotives and eight other undamaged cars headed east to Chicago. Amtrak and American Red Cross representatives loaded two buses with about 40 passengers who stayed overnight in Ottumwa, about 10 miles west of Batavia, and sent them to Chicago. Carol Grant, field service manager for the Red Cross, said those were the last of the passengers who were aboard the Zephyr. At Jefferson County Hospital in Fairfield, a spokeswoman said two of the nine patients admitted overnight were released Tuesday morning. The remaining patients were all in good, stable condition. Skip Deskin, vice president of Ottumwa Regional Medical Center, said at least three of the nine patients who stayed overnight were discharged Tuesday morning with more expected to be released soon.

DOC.HEAD: Report: U.S. Cuts Back Spy Missions Over Colombia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 5th, `The Pentagon...' to UPDATE with comment from U.S. Embassy spokeswoman in Bogata. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Unidentified sources...'
DOC.TEXT: The United States curtailed spy flights focused on Colombian drug traffickers after allegations that a U.S. aircraft nearly collided with two Colombian planes, a newspaper reported Tuesday. The Defense Department scaled back the program under pressure from the Colombian government, which had approved the missions on condition they be kept secret, the Los Angeles Times reported, citing unidentified sources. Information from the spy flights has been used in a Colombian manhunt for Pablo Escobar, the reputed head of the Medellin cocaine cartel, the Times said. The alleged near-collisions became public in Colombia on March 29 when the pilot of an SAM airliner was quoted by newspapers as saying the military aircraft had passed within several hundred feet of his plane over southern Colombia. Sociedad Aerea Medellinense, a subsidiary of Avianca, normally flies domestic routes and to Central America. The Pentagon has said that a Panama-based Air Force EC-130 flying at 18,500 feet had been in the area on March 28, but denied that a near-collision had occurred. A spokeswoman for the U.S Embassy in Bogota, Lauren Hale, on Tuesday told The Associated Press that the only U.S government flights in Colombia had been to practice search and rescue missions with the approval of the Colombian government. She said the United States decided to suspend the flights to prevent any further misinformation. Unidentified sources told the Times that the EC-130, a variation of the C-130 cargo plane that carries electronic surveillance equipment, is based at Howard Air Base outside Panama City. Bush administration officials said they believe the U.S. pilot erred by allowing his plane to be spotted. But they said the alleged near-collision may have been conceived by Colombians sympathetic to the drug traffickers, according to the newspaper. The Pentagon has since ordered its spy plane pilots to avoid detection over Colombia. One official said it was possible the pilots may have to stay out of Colombian airspace altogether. The orders are believed to affect the operations of Oklahoma-based Air Force AWACS radar planes that monitor air traffic over Colombia and attempts by the Panama-based EC-130s to pick up communications among drug traffickers. Administration officials said the cutback could hurt intelligence gathering but that they were determined to maintain cooperation with Colombian authorities in the drug war. ``There will be a limit on what we can do, but the bottom line in the long run is that we have to work with the Colombians,'' one source told the newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: Chamorro to Take Office Wednesday, Gen. Ortega Said to Head Army
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with source saying Gen. Ortega to stay on as head of Nicaraguan army, edits thereafter to trim and conform. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MGA1,8
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro takes office Wednesday already facing division in the ranks of her victorious coalition over government posts and treatment of Nicaragua's outgoing Sandinistas. A source said late Tuesday one of those outgoing Sandinistas, Gen. Humberto Ortega, President Daniel Ortega's brother, will remain in charge of the army but answer to Mrs. Chamorro, who as both defense minister and president will be supreme commander of the armed forces. ``There are some extremists who want the Sandinistas wiped out in one fell swoop,'' the source close to Mrs. Chamorro said, describing some factions in the United National Opposition. ``That can't be. He (Ortega) will be eased out, but not for a while.'' Keeping on Gen. Ortega as army commander likely will heighten divisions inside Mrs. Chamorro's ruling coalition and make it more difficult for her to persuade the U.S.-backed Contra rebels to disarm. Contras and members of her coalition have demanded Sandinista loyalists be purged from the army. Meanwhile in a show of support for the new administration, congressional and administration sources in Washington said Tuesday that President Bush will invoke emergency authority to send $2.6 million in medical aid in time for Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration. The maneuver gives Vice President Dan Quayle the chance to deliver the good news as the United States' top representative at the swearing-in ceremony, scheduled for 2 p.m. EDT Wednesday. UNO faces a test of unity in the National Assembly while cabinet appointees, due to be sworn in shortly after Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration, have yet to be officially announced. The 14-party coalition brought together everyone from communists to conservatives in the successful effort to oust President Ortega's Sandinistas, in power since 1979. The first test came Tuesday afternoon, when the new National Assembly met to elect a president. UNO's official choice is Myriam Arguello, a 64-year-old lawyer from the People's Conservative Alliance. Ms. Arguello earlier received 28 votes at a caucus of UNO's 51 deputies, to 23 for Alfredo Cesar, a close adviser to Mrs. Chamorro, a former member of the Contra rebels' directorate and a man with his sights set on running for president in the 1996 elections. Ms. Arguello is backed by Vice-President elect Virgilio Godoy, and the Sandinistas have hinted their 39 deputies might vote for Cesar to encourage a split in UNO ranks, even though Cesar is not a Sandinista favorite because of his Contra connections. The legislature's opening session began as scheduled at 4 p.m., a noteworthy event that marked a new era in Nicaraguan politics. Daneil Ortega, who has an assembly seat as a presidential candidate, sent a message to Mariano Fiallos, the Supreme Electoral Council president, who presided over the first assembly until they chose a president, saying he would not be able to attend the legislative sessions until further notice. Lame-duck Vice President Sergio Ramirez, who is Ortega's alternate, is expected to fill the role of minority assembly leader. Ms. Arguello was officially nominated for the presidency. However, a Sandinista deputy made a motion for a secret vote. A debate over the secret vote motion followed but the assembly went into recess late Tuesday. Mrs. Chamorro, who showed up 20 minutes after the session began and left after all the deputies got their credentials, got a standing ovation from both sides of the aisle when she arrived and again when she left. Barricada, official newspaper of the Sandinista Front, ran an editorial Tuesday saying the Sandinistas would of necessity play a critical role in the emerging political landscape in this nation of 3.5 million residents. ``The Sandinista Front, although it is not part of the new government, and placing itself strictly within the terrain of a committed opposition, cannot renounce playing the role of a national arbiter and a decisive force in the crisis from which the new government emerges,'' the editorial said. Many in UNO's political council, which represents the 14 parties, consider Cesar an opportunist. They fired him as campaign manager when both he and Mrs. Chamorro were out of the country six months ago. As soon as Mrs. Chamorro returned, she named Cesar her personal adviser. News on Gen. Ortega wasn't entirely unexpected. La Prensa, the Chamorro family newspaper, said Monday the president-elect would probably assume the defense ministry herself to avoid upsetting the UNO council and high echelons of the Sandinista People's Army. Mrs. Chamorro's advisers have signed an agreement with the Sandinistas that would depoliticize the Sandinista army. On Monday the Sandinistas announced army officers were stepping down from party posts; that included Humberto Ortega, one of nine members of the Sandinista directorate. Radio Corporacion, a pro-UNO radio station, broadcast a call-in show Tuesday with citizens saying ``the electorate voted for a total change'' and ``all Sandinistas must go.'' Many of the thousands of armed Contras in the countryside also maintain that position, and say they will not disarm as agreed by June 10 unless the army is purged. Meanwhile, President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela arrived Tuesday in Managua for the inauguration. Other heads of state expected include presidents Oscar Arias of Costa Rica; Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador; Guilio Andreotti of Italy; and Guillermo Endara of Panama.

DOC.HEAD: Chernobyl at a Glance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Soviet-Chernobyl
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief review of the Chernobyl nuclear accident and its aftermath:

THE ACCIDENT _ On April 26, 1986, a fire started in one of the four 1,000-megawatt reactors of the nuclear power station at Chernobyl, 80 miles north of Kiev, captial of the Ukraine. A core meltdown and explosion followed, sending huge quantities of radiation into the atmosphere. The Soviets did not report the accident until two days later, after Scandinavian complaints of unsually high radiation levels.

EVACUATION _ About 116,000 people were evacuated from contaminated parts of the Ukraine and Byelorussia, most from a 9-mile radius of the plant. A pass is required to enter the area. Last year, the government decided to evacuate 85 more villages in Byelorussia, 31 in Russia and 14 in the Ukrain.

DEATHS _ Two people were killed in the accident and 29 are officially reported to have died of radiation sickness later. Yuri Scherbak, a Ukrainian member of the national parliament, and others say up to 250 have died. An official report commissioned in 1986 estimated 5,300 people would die over 70 years from cancer resulting from radiation exposure.

COST _ Current estimates of cleanup costs are 30 times the original $8 billion rubles ($13 billion at the official exchange rate). Surveys by the three republics affected indicate the cost may reach 250 billion rubles ($405 billion) over the next decade.

PLANS FOR CHERNOBYL _ The Ukrainian legislature decided this year that the plant, whose other three reactors are still functioning, should be closed by 1995. Specialists say shutting it down may take up to 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: Crime Increasing in Taiwan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Two thieves shot Yeh Yung-chuan to death, in front of other investors, as he left the trading floor of a brokerage house with nearly $100,000. Crime has come to Taiwan on the heels of affluence. Yeh, a 32-year-old accountant, turned to run when the men stopped him. They shot him once in the back and once in the head, took his 2.5 million Taiwan dollars and fled on a motorcycle parked outside. Such brutal crimes are becoming common. Wealthy businessmen hire guards and use bulletproof cars. ``Taiwan is not safe anymore,'' said Rebecca Yen, a 28-year-old employee of a trading company. ``Most of my friends plan to emigrate.'' Increased violence stems from a get-rich-quick mentality on this island of 20 million people, abetted by guns smuggled from mainland China, officials say. Police said a record 5,839 cases of violent crime were reported last year and they confiscated 9,770 firearms, more than the total of the previous five years. Robberies increased 39 percent and kidnappings 53 percent from 1988, they said.. ``Violent crime has jeopardized our social stability,'' said Jaw Shau-kong, a popular legislator who wore a bulletproof vest in his December election campaign. ``We don't feel as secure as before.'' President Lee Teng-hui acknowledged increasing crime ``has had a grave impact on social stability and the people's confidence in the nation.'' One-third of entrepreneurs responding to an Economics Ministry survey said they had been targets of harassment or extortion by gangsters. Last year, Taiwan's richest shipping company executive paid nearly $2 million ransom for his kidnapped 32-year-old son, who was released unharmed. Police later arrested three suspects and retrieved the money. Many of the 145 kidnappings reported last year ended tragically. Captors killed several victims after ransom was paid. Four masked men armed with Israeli-made Uzi machine guns shot up Ho Cheng Securities in Changhwa, central Taiwan, in March, apparently because the company did not pay $1.2 million in extortion money. ``I don't think we can do any business when our lives and property are unprotected,'' said Kao Ching-yuan, a Taiwan business leader. ``It may be safer to move our business abroad.'' Emigration appears to be growing along with the crime statistics. ``Thanks to soaring crime, our business doubled last year,'' said C.C. Tai of Domini International Consulting Corp., which helps people emigrate to Australia, New Zealand and Canada. Tai estimated that about 40,000 Taiwanese left in 1989, up from 30,000 in 1988. Luxury cars, seen as invitations to kidnapping and robbery, no longer are in demand. Eric Fang, assistant sales manager of the largest Mercedes-Benz agency, said his company sold only 290 cars in December, down from the 1988 monthly average of 650, and predicted a drop in sales of 15 percent for 1990. ``Many businessmen have postponed purchases because they do not want to drive the `dangerous cars','' he said. Authorities report a dramatic increase in smuggled guns from China. Police said they seized 687 Chinese-made shotguns last year, up from 57 in 1988. Official statistics say smuggled Chinese guns were used in 91 killings in 1987, including those of four policemen. Premier Lee Huan has proclaimed 1990 ``Anti-Crime Year'' and proposed that gun possession, now punishable by 10 years in prison, be made a capital crime. Thousands of inexpensive guns are believed to be in the hands of gangsters. Some legislators say the only way to stop the influx from the mainland is for the government to hold direct talks with Beijing. The ruling Nationalists fled to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war to the Communists, and still refuse to negotiate directly with the Beijing government. Lin Chia-cheng, a sociology professor at Soochow University, believes one reason for the crime wave is ``the widened gap between the rich and the poor.'' Taiwan's export-led economic boom has made its per capita gross national product the fourth highest in Asia, but good fortune has not been shared equally. The income of the top 20 percent is nearly five times that of the bottom 20 percent. People also seem more inclined to seek quick riches than to work for a better life. Stock speculation has been the favored tactic, but many have turned to crime. ``Traditional values have faded,'' Lin said. ``Fewer people believe in hard work and saving. Most envy those who have gotten wealthy fast from speculating, and some think it is all right to get money from those rich people.''

DOC.HEAD: Despite AIDS Concerns, Tattoo Convention A Blaze Of Color
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Contents may be objectionable to some readers.
DOC.HEAD: By JEROME SOCOLOVSKY
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Art came to life at the Paradiso nightclub as this year's Amsterdam Tattoo Convention got under way, with the only inhibition in evidence a growing concern about AIDS. Swarms of male and female tattoo-bearers, some half-naked to show off their intricate body art, clustered around tattoo artists creating fire-breathing dragons and Indian chiefs on their living canvases. The convention drew tattooers, tattoo-wearers, camera-bearing voyeurs and the just-curious from around the world, with one Samoan pricking his customer with traditional parallel line motifs from his South Pacific homeland. The convention, which opened Monday, is the third organized in the last decade in this tourist Mecca by the 55-member Dutch Union of Tattooers, whose president, Henk Schiffmacher, runs the Amsterdam Tattoo Museum. ``Usually tattoo enthusiasts can only get together in small groups. This is mainly a social event,'' said Schiffmacher, whose tattoos poured out of his modest T-shirt. By contrast, 47-year-old Isobel Varley of Hertfordshire, England, posed topless with Jack Yount Jr., 63, of Crystal Springs, Fla., to give onlookers a better view of their scenic torsos. The more modest wore bathing suits to show as much as possible. The convention also provided a stage for devotees of more exotic forms of jewelry like nose rings. Yount, who wears silver horns through his nose, runs Silver Anchor Enterprises, specializing in ``Exotic Body Jewelry'' and ``Piercing by Appointment,'' according to his business card. But taking center-stage were tattoos, designs made by puncturing the skin with a needle and inserting indelible pigment. Despite the number of people who opted to get tattoos in the dozens of booths at the convention, the sound was of conversation and cameras clicking, not gasps of pain. ``It's a matter of meditating to bear the pain,'' said Schiffmacher, 38. An increased awareness of AIDS was apparent among the practitioners and devotees of the sometimes bloody art painted with needles. Containers of sterilized needles at each tattoo artist's booth evinced the Amsterdam Health Department's toughened safety requirements since the last show three years ago. Every tattooist was required to wear gloves and use a freshly sterilized needle on each new client. Convention organizers provided sterilization facilities. ``The safety precautions are stricter than ever,'' said tattooist John Hus, adding that the municipal health authority was conducting regular checks at the convention. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is transmitted via the exchange of infected blood. The fatal disease attacks the body's immune system, leaving it susceptible to cancers and other infections.

DOC.HEAD: Intruders Break into Soviet Trade Office in Seoul
DOC.TEXT: Intruders broke into the Soviet trade office, yanked drawers out of desks and scattered documents on the floor, officials and news reports said today. Staff members at the Soviet trade office and its adjoining consular department office discovered the break-in shortly after 9 a.m. Monday as they arrived for work, said the Chosun-Ilbo newspaper. The lock on the office's front door was ripped off, drawers were pulled out and documents scattered on the floor, it said. A Soviet representative, requesting anonymity, confirmed the break-in and said today that ``at first glance'' nothing appeared to have been removed from the office. He said there was no serious damage to the premises. The Soviet Union and South Korea agreed to exchange consular departments in each other's capitals in December. The Soviet trade office had opened several months earlier. South Korea's governing party has said it hopes to establish formal diplomatic ties with the Soviet Union by the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Syria Seeks to Lose `Terrorist' Image With Hostage Effort
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Syria, long portrayed as the ogre in Lebanon and the godfather of terrorist groups, is making a high-profile effort to free American hostages and to improve its relations with the West. The Syrians clearly played a key role in securing the release of U.S. hostage Robert Polhill on Sunday, 39 months after he was kidnapped in Lebanon by Shiite Moslem militants. Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa, Syria's point man in the campaign to free the Westerners held in Lebanon, said: ``I'm sure his release will pave the way for the release of the rest of the hostages.'' Seventeen Westerners, seven of them Americans, remain in captivity, most of them held by Shiite extremists in Lebanon. Sharaa staked his reputation on the tug-of-war between the U.S. government and the Iranian-backed Shiites that led to Polhill's release. When the kidnappers postponed the release because Washington would not send a senior envoy to negotiate, Sharaa said the hostage would appear Sunday. Polhill was turned over to U.S. Ambassador Edward Djerejian as scheduled. Syria's actions are part of a foreign policy strategy to move back into the Arab mainstream after years of radical isolation and to seek better economic ties with the West. Syria's relationship with its traditional backer, the Soviet Union, is changing as Moscow pursues detente and reforms at home, leaving it little choice but to trim its sails to the winds of moderation. The Syrians clearly hope to improve their image in the West by being seen as the saviors of the hostages. In return, Syria hopes to be taken off the U.S. list of states that Washington says sponsor terrorism and to reap the political and economic benefits from Western countries who have shunned Damascus in recent years. Countries on that list are denied U.S. aid and credit. Diplomats said that getting off the U.S. terror list would provide a much-needed tonic for Syria's beleaguered economy and provide political respectability to President Hafez Assad's government in Western eyes. Damascus would like to purchase everything from high-tech computers to wheat from the United States at less-than-commercial rates. Improved relations would also ensure that Syria's voice is heard at any U.S.-sponsored Middle East peace talks. Toward that end, Assad reestablished ties with Egypt in December to end a lengthy rift over Cairo's 1979 peace treaty with Israel. The United States and Syria have already reached agreement on trying to bring peace to Lebanon, with both supporting the accord reached by Lebanese parliamentarians in Taif, Saudi Arabia, in October. The accord, which outlines a gradual withdrawal of Syria's 40,000 troops from Lebanon, still gives Damascus an important role in the affairs of its war-shattered neighbor. It is that influence that allowed Syria to play the role of mediator between Iran and the United States on the hostage issue. Arab news reports have said that Assad hinged a state visit to Tehran on hostage releases. Syria was Iran's main Arab ally during Iran's 1980-88 war with Iraq, Syria's main rival in the Arab world. Iran depends on Syria for access for its Revolutionary Guards to Lebanon, the only place outside the Islamic republic where the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Shiite revolution has taken hold. Syria is the dominant military power in Lebanon. Its troops are deployed in three-quarters of the country. So far, it has not overtly used that muscle to force the Shiite militants to hand over hostages, apparently seeking to avoid an open confrontation with Iran's proxies that could ignite a wider conflict in Lebanon. The Syrians have played a role in securing the release of hostages in the past because of their ties with Tehran. But their influence has increased since Hashemi Rafsanjani, leader of Tehran's so-called pragmatists who also seek improved ties with the West, became Iran's president in July. Rafsanjani's power struggle with Tehran's anti-Western radicals has been mirrored in a rift among the Lebanese Shiites, and it was Syria's ability to exploit that which apparently played an important part in Polhill's release. There has been little American goodwill toward Syria in the last few years. Washington recalled its ambassador to Damascus in 1986 after Britain broke relations with Syria, accusing Syrian intelligence of sponsoring a plot to smuggle a bomb aboard an Israeli airliner in London. Assad eventually expelled the Palestinian group led by terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal which was linked to the abortive bombing and other attacks. Washington recently pressured Assad to expel Ahmed Jibril, leader of the Damascus-based Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command. Western Intelligence agencies list the group as the prime suspect in the bombing of a Pan Am jetliner over Scotland in 1988 that killed 270 people. Assad said he would act if positive proof of involvement in the Pan Am bombing was provided. ``Maybe the United States would overlook Jibril's presence if Syria helps get the hostages out,'' a Western diplomat speculated.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Neil MacFarquhar has covered the Middle East for The AP for two years. He is based in Nicosia.

DOC.HEAD: LORAIN: years later.
DOC.TEXT: Dean Kahler has only to look down to remember that day. A rifle bullet made him a paraplegic and put him in a wheelchair for life. ``I know why I'm sitting in it,'' Kahler said. ``I'll never really forget Kent State.'' Kahler, then a 20-year-old freshman from Canton, Ohio, had worked nearly a year in a steel mill to help pay for school. When rifle fire crackled over the shouts of his fellow students, he fell to the ground to take cover. He felt a sensation like a bee sting; it was a bullet ripping into his spinal cord. Kahler, a conscientious objector, was the most seriously injured of the nine persons wounded. He finished school seven years later then built a career in state government, working for the secretary of state and attorney general. He was elected an Athens County commissioner in 1984 and re-elected four years later. Kahler, divorced in 1984, married a counselor he met in a pub last August. He frequently drives the 340-mile round trip to Kent State for sports and alumni events. He is a guest lecturer for a regularly offered course that examines the Kent State shootings and their aftermath. ``Kent State is not something I carry around as a burden,'' he said. ``Just because I had one bad day at Kent doesn't mean the whole university should be condemned. ... To me what's more important is the county budget ... and my family and the rest of my life.'' But for Sarah and Martin Scheuer, much of their life died in a 13-second volley of gunfire. ``It ruined our lives,'' said Scheuer, now 79 and suffering from Parkinson's disease. As the seasons come and go, so do May 4 wedding anniversaries _ unmarked, uncelebrated. Nor can Mrs. Scheuer bear the fragrance of springtime lilacs. ``I'd like to bring them all inside. I love them all so much,'' Sandy told her mother when Mrs. Scheuer visited her apartment two days before she died. Those were the last words her mother ever heard her speak. ``I try not to look at them,'' said Mrs. Scheuer. ``It just makes me feel sad.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Special Correspondent George Esper is the AP's Northeast Regional Reporter, based in Boston.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf of b0212 of April 23, ``Inspector Morse ... May 3,'' to CORRECT that Morse is an Oxfordshire detective, not retired Oxford don; SUBS 4th graf, ``The `Inspector ... at Oxford,'' to CORRECT spelling of Whateley to Whately; PICKS UP 5th graf, ``Created by ... Sgt. Lewis.''; ``Settling'' in 4th graf is cq.
DOC.HEAD: John Thaw Jumping to Conclusions Again as `Inspector Morse'
LaserPhoto LA1 sent April 21.
DOC.TEXT: That craggy, silver-haired, enigmatic sleuth played by John Thaw is coming back to PBS' ``Mystery!'' for another go at solving brainy murders in the academic confines of Oxford, England. ``Inspector Morse,'' an Oxfordshire detective with a passion for puzzles, returns for a third season on Thursday, May 3. This is the 10th year for ``Mystery!,'' which is hosted by Diana Rigg and presents such characters as John Mortimer's ``Rumpole of the Bailey,'' Agatha Christie's Hercule Poirot, P.D. James' Adam Dalgliesh and Arthur Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes. The ``Inspector Morse'' series opens with the two-part mystery, ``The Settling of the Sun,'' in which Morse and Sgt. Lewis (Kevin Whately) of the Thames Valley Police solve a revenge killing involving a group of foreign students attending summer school at Oxford. Created by Colin Dexter, the character of Morse is harder to pin down than the crimes he compulsively tackles. Morse is a detective who leaps to conclusions, very often the wrong ones, but always is put back on the right path with the help of plodding Sgt. Lewis. ``He's a bachelor, while Lewis has a young family,'' said Thaw, an English actor who was on a brief visit to this country. ``At the end of the day, Lewis is anxious to get home when he's off the clock. Morse would work a 24-hour day. Morse doesn't treat him too kindly. He thinks he should put being a detective first. It's not a buddy-buddy relationship. ``The relationship's not like Holmes and Watson, where Watson will come up with something that will change the whole case. Morse leaps from one theory to another and comes to the wrong conclusion at first. Lewis could come up with something obvious that gets him back on track.'' Morse lives alone and, apart from police work, is devoted to music, crossword puzzles and drinking beer. Thaw calls him ``a sad man in a lot of ways.'' The English-made series, funded by Mobil, is filmed in Oxford, around the colleges and the Thames River. It's done entirely on location, with no studio work. Later this year, the show will film in Australia, where Morse gets sent on a case. ``Most of the murders are committed by someone who's a friend,'' Thaw said. ``There are no gangs or criminals _ mostly just old-fashioned murders that Sherlock Holmes was solving at the turn of the century. ``We're beginning to get out of the colleges,'' he said. ``I thought it was silly to have all the murders at Oxford University. I said I didn't want my daughter to go to Oxford if they had that many murders.'' The series is based on the novels by Dexter, who also was a leading creator of crossword puzzles. He named his detective, whose first name never is mentioned, after Sir Jeremy Morse, chairman of Lloyds Bank and a friend who's also a crossword addict. The episodes all are from Dexter's novels or from stories he has outlined for the script writers. In the May 17-24 episode, the inspector investigates the disappearance of some valuable erotic paintings. Patricia Hodge, who stars as Phyllida Erskine-Brown on ``Rumpole of the Bailey,'' is the guest star. The series concludes May 31-June 7 when Morse and Lewis look into deceit, corruption and ruthless ambition among the Oxford dons. Thaw, who co-starred with Glenda Jackson in ``Business as Usual'' and also appeared in ``Cry Freedom,'' often is seen on English police shows. He played a peg-legged villain in one of the ``Sherlock Holmes'' stories. ``Between series, I usually go back on stage,'' he said. He met his wife, actress Sheila Hancock, when they co-starred in ``So What About Love'' in London's West End. They have three daughters, one of whom is studying drama at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts.

DOC.HEAD: Ketchup Death Threats in Otherwise Boring Real-Life Setting of Twin Peaks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
Eds: `duelin' in the 19th graf cq.
DOC.TEXT: Aside from ketchup-splattered death threats, this town that serves as the setting for the slightly surreal ``Twin Peaks'' TV series could hardly be more ordinary. Nothing could be further from Snoqualmie's real life than the hot new television series in which teen-age drug dealers, obsessive-compulsive housewives, Satanic cultists and others figure in the murder of a cocaine-crazed homecoming queen. ``I think you can describe this better as Mayberry,'' the quiet town in the old ``Andy Griffith Show,'' said Baldwin Galloway, opening Smokey Joe's Tavern for the day. ``It's a pretty ho-hum town.'' Snoqualmie, pronounced snow-KWAL-mee, a logging and tourist town of about 1,500 residents 30 miles east of Seattle in the foothills of the Cascade Mountains, was the location for filming ``Twin Peaks'' and some locals got jobs as extras. Local reaction to the ABC series has been mixed. ``I love it, the whole thing, all the weird people, the straight people and all,'' said Janine Simmons, tending the cash register at Big Edd's drive-in. ``I don't know any weird people, and I've been here 26 years,'' she said. ``We're just having a lot of fun with it.'' ``Everyone just kind of laughs about it,'' said Rita Lessard, 48, helping to arrange a display case at Dave's Jewelry. ``I haven't talked with anyone that thinks it's just wonderful,'' she said. ``I can't believe it's getting good ratings. The acting is horrid.'' Jean Priestman, 43, director of Good Neighbor Child Care at the Methodist Community Church, was undecided. ``At first I thought it was a murder mystery. Then somebody told me it was a comedy,'' she said. In real life, police are trying to identify the source of death threats against town council members who support Weyerhaeuser Co. plans for a 2,000-home development. Investigators said the worst threat was last month against council member Colleen Johnson. Draped over her car was a bedsheet with threats like, ``Wear your vest,'' a reference to the bulletproof vest she wears when working as a reserve police officer. Also on the sheet was a sketch of Mount Si with ketchup dripping from it, and a trail of ketchup led from the car to her front door. In general, however, ``it's a sleepy little town,'' said Barbara Harkey, assistant principal at Mount Si High School. Ed Lamb, 48, a barber and lifelong resident who charges $8 for adults, $7 for youngsters under 12 and seniors, and $3.50 for beard trims, said the first sign of notoriety for the town was a supermarket tabloid article that suggested it was infested with chain saw-dueling maniacs. The article was illustrated with a photograph of neighboring North Bend. Lamb, a volunteer firefighter for 28 years, and others said they had never heard of anyone running amok with a chain saw. Before long, however, a sign outside Big Edd's said, ``Please check your chainsaws in before entering'' on one side and ``Twin Peaks Burger $2.85 Little Leaguers Welcome'' on the other. Next door, at Valley Saw & Lawn Center, the sign said: ``Buy your duelin chainsaws here!'' Aside from chain saw jokes, residents say little has changed or is likely to change. Bookings have remained steady at the Salish Lodge near the top of the 268-foot Snoqualmie Falls, a 91-room establishment that appears as a trysting place and scene of low intrigue in the series, said general manager Loy Helmly. There are no plans to use ``Twin Peaks'' in a marketing campaign, said assistant manager Stan Kott. ``We are thinking about having Thursday night parties to watch the show,'' Kott said, ``but that's fairly low-key, something more for the locals.''

DOC.HEAD: Dominating The Dial In Post-Revolutionary Nicaragua
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Dominating the dial is a key element of the Sandinista game plan for post-revolutionary Nicaragua. The Sandinistas have gutted the state-run radio network rather than turn the stations over to the conservative government that takes over Wednesday. They have also broken up their government-owned network of 16 advertising and publicity firms. For the most part, the radio stations and the publicity firms are now in the hands of Sandinista loyalists. Party loyalists have also been given licenses for the first private television since the 1979 revolution. Members of the United National Opposition transition team and the pre-revolutionary owners of the radio stations are indignant. So is Nicaragua's only opposition paper, La Prensa, which is published by President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. La Prensa says the Sandinistas are trying ``to leave intact their enormous propaganda apparatus.'' When the Sandinistas were the state, they believed in state ownership and firm control of the mass media. The 17-station radio network and the chain of advertising firms were assembled from confiscated companies. Under Sandinista rule, Nicaragua has had only two TV stations, both of which are state-run and are to be turned over to the new administration. The Sandinistas also censored the media, closing La Prensa often, sometimes for months at a time. Sandinista dominance of the media appeared to begin easing a bit last year when prior censorship ended; the Sandinistas also gave the opposition a bit of television time during the campaign. After they lost the Feb. 25 election, the Sandinistas lifted the ban on private television and began moving to ensure themselves a firm grip on the public eye and ear. ``They are trying to dominate the dial,'' said Frank Arana, a member of the UNO transition team for media matters. One of the new TV licenses went to the vehemently pro-Sandinista publishers of the newspaper El Nuevo Diario, which now sports a graphic of a television set on its masthead. ``END TV-18. In Your Home Soon,'' the legend on the tiny screen says. Another, Channel 4, will be run by a top Sandinista official, Tourism Minister Herty Lewites, who said he also plans to start an airline. Meanwhile, a new transmission tower has sprouted at what used to be the Sandinista campaign headquarters, the home of a new Sandinista radio station, Radio Ya (Radio Now!). Once Radio Ya begins broadcasting, the party or party loyalists will control choice frequencies ranging from 600 to 840 on the AM dial. The UNO transition team only learned last week that the state-run radio network had been dismantled, Arana said. ``We were morally deceived,'' he said. ``But not surprised.'' Nicaragua has been rife with rumors and reports that state property was mysteriously evaporating in the wake of defeat. The Sandinistas insist they will hand over the machinery of the state intact. But UNO officials say that they won't know precisely what they are inheriting until Mrs. Chamorro takes office Wednesday. UNO doesn't even know whether there is enough money in the treasury to meet the state payroll at the end of the month, Mrs. Chamorro's top economic adviser, Francisco Mayorga, said Monday. In the case of the radio network, Sandinista officials told the UNO transition team that some of the radio stations were turned over to individuals and others to municipal officials. Barricada, the Sandinista party's official newspaper, said the idea was to put the stations in the hands of people ``concerned with promoting culture and ethical values and morals that benefit the great majority'' and to ensure ``the continuation of participative radio and guarantee communication for ordinary people.'' Arana said the UNO team hasn't been able to confirm who the new owners of the radio stations are but plans to investigate. ``They were state property. They can't just give them away,'' Arana said in an interview Monday. Arana said the Sandinista loyalists who worked for the state advertising and publicity firms are the new owners. ``It's not an isolated case. Things like this are happening in a lot of the ministries,'' he said. The Sandinistas confiscated 66 privately owned radio stations after the revolution, took over the government station, La Voz de Nicaragua, and turned ousted dictator Anastasio Somoza's station into the Sandinista party's Radio Sandino. Some of the stations were stripped of their equipment, others were renamed, many simply vanished. Only 17 were left when the network was dismantled after the election. The pre-revolutionary owners want their stations _ or what is left of them _ back, said broadcaster Mariano Valle, whose family lost 11 stations and plans legal action to claim its stations. Like the government TV stations, La Voz de Nicaragua appears intact, Arana said.

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Have No Credible Challenger for New York's Cuomo
DOC.TEXT: A winter of discontent has turned into a dry spring for New York Republicans seeking a credible candidate to challenge Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo. No major GOP figure has been willing to step forward to take on Cuomo's expected re-election bid. The New York Democrat is widely viewed as a potential 1992 presidential contender should he survive the 1990 state election. ``I'm not a kamikaze,'' Sen. Alfonse D'Amato said last August as he became the first of many Republicans to keep their hats out of the ring. Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, the former Buffalo-area congressman who once quarterbacked the Buffalo Bills, officially moved to Maryland. State Assembly Minority Leader Clarence Rappleyea put on an ``I'm Not Running For Governor!'' campaign-style button following a published report that he might be interested. Rudolph Giuliani, the former federal prosecutor who narrowly lost the race for mayor of New York City last year, told party leaders to look elsewhere. The 1986 Republican candidate, Westchester County Executive Andrew O'Rourke, said he would need ``a frontal lobotomy'' before he'd run again. He suffered the worst defeat in modern New York gubernatorial elections. It's not that Cuomo is invulnerable. This is the third straight year of budget deficits for New York, the second straight year of $1 billion tax increases and the sixth straight year Cuomo has been unable to deliver a budget by the April 1 start of the fiscal year. At the end of March, Wall Street dropped New York's credit rating to its lowest level ever. Only Louisiana and Massachusetts were in worse shape. Proclaiming him ``Loser of the Week,'' Time magazine said ``Cuomo is only one polluted harbor away from becoming the next Michael Dukakis.'' It didn't matter. New York Republicans still couldn't find a candidate. ``This is depressing me,'' President Bush said recently of the situation. While admitting Cuomo was ``a formidable political opponent,'' the president said New York Republicans should ``find a strong opponent for him.'' Shortly thereafter, White House chief of staff John Sununu telephoned former New York Rep. Guy Molinari to encourage the newly elected Staten Island borough president to challenge Cuomo. Molinari said he was too busy with his new job. Meanwhile, in neighboring Massachusetts, Connecticut and Vermont, incumbent Democratic Govs. Dukakis, William O'Neill and Madeleine Kunin all have decided against seeking re-election. They also were facing severe state fiscal problems. No such luck for New York Republicans. ``This is no time to be quitting as governor,'' Cuomo said earlier this month, referring to New York's fiscal problems and his re-election plans. With the state GOP nominating convention scheduled for the end of May, the only announced Republican candidate is little-known Rockland County insurance broker Herbert Holland. Evan Galbraith, a former U.S. ambassador to France who is chairman of the Moet-Hennessy champagne and cognac company, had planned to run until a state court ruled that he didn't meet New York's five-year residency requirement. This year was supposed to be different for Republicans. With the help of Jonathan Bush, the president's brother, and other major New York Republicans, J. Patrick Barrett was elected state GOP chairman last June. Barrett, a millionaire former chairman of the Avis car rental company, vowed to revitalize the party, have a strong candidate for governor by the start of this year and build a multimillion-dollar campaign war chest. Last week, the bipartisan state Board of Elections unanimously voted to investigate whether the state Republican Committee had intentionally filed an incomplete campaign finance report in January. The filing failed to list the GOP committee's unpaid bills of more than $365,000. That debt has since grown to about $750,000, according to party officials. A recent GOP fundraising event brought in about $115,000, a third of what had been expected. Shortly thereafter, Barrett fired three state committee employees, or one-quarter of his entire staff. Meanwhile, Cuomo's campaign bank account has grown to more than $7 million and a recent statewide poll had the governor's job-approval rating at 62 percent. The poll was commissioned by New York Republicans.

DOC.HEAD: After Peru, U.S. Drug Agreements with Bolivia, Colombia Expected
DOC.TEXT: After concluding an aid agreement with the Peruvian military to curb narcotics trafficking, the Bush administration is about to complete similar pacts with Colombia and Bolivia, U.S. officials say. The $35 million aid package with Peru was announced over the weekend in Lima and will involve the Peruvian military in the anti-drug effort for the first time. Negotiations with the three Andean countries have taken place since shortly after President Bush announced his anti-drug strategy last September and disclosed his intention to increase military cooperation with each country. Consistent with earlier announcements, the Colombian program will be $40.3 million and Bolivia's will be $33.7 million. The U.S. officials, who insisted on anonymity, said the signings of the agreements are imminent. The United States will provide the Peruvian military with training and refurbishing of aircraft. Some aid also will be given to the Peruvian Navy. Contrary to some reports, there will be no U.S. involvement in the construction of a military base, but assistance will be offered in selecting a site for a new base, the officials said. The agreement signifies a renewal of U.S. cooperation with the Peruvian military, which has had close ties with the Soviet military for many years. In contrast to Bolivia, where there is no significant insurgency, the U.S. programs in Peru and Colombia have a counter-insurgency component to them in addition to their principal goal of curbing narcotics flows. In a letter earlier this month to Rep. Dante Fascell, D-Fla., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, the State Department's top aide for congressional relations, Janet Mullins, said: ``While the ultimate purpose of the military assistance, including equipment and training ... is to combat narcotics trafficking and production, it is inevitable that counter-narcotics activities will at times require counter-insurgency efforts to regain government control over certain areas.'' Among the principal backers of the coca leaf growers in the Upper Huallaga Valley of Peru are the Shining Path guerrillas, the powerful leftist movement that seeks to bring about a worker-peasant state. The valley is the source of the raw material for about half the world's cocaine. Some members of Congress, including Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., have expressed concern that a U.S. role in support of counter-insurgency operations in Peru could get the United States involved in a civil war. In response to those allegations, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Monday that U.S. military personnel will not participate in operations. ``No additional Defense Department personnel will be stationed permanently in Peru,'' she said. ``There will be rotating teams of Defense personnel visiting Peru during the next several months to conduct training, particularly in connection with the new equipment agreed to by the government of Peru.'' Ms. Tutwiler said that at any given time, there will be between 10 and 15 personnel working on various projects on temporary duty in Peru.

DOC.HEAD: Syria, Iran Will Remain on List of Terrorism Supporters
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Despite their apparent help in liberating American hostage Robert Polhill, Iran and Syria will remain on the State Department's list of countries that sponsor terrorism, U.S. officials say. Meanwhile, in a series of messages passed to Tehran by intermediaries, the Bush administration has notified Iran it cannot expect an improvement in relations until all seven Americans held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian militants are freed, the officials said Monday. Remaining on the terrorism list means Iran and Syria will continue to be deprived of U.S. backing for international bank loans and sophisticated American technology. The department's annual terrorism report is due to be released next Monday. It was finished two weeks ago, before Polhill was freed by the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine. Even so, the report could have been revised. But a U.S. official said, speaking Monday on condition of anonymity, ``we are not calling it back from the printers.'' Six countries in all are on the list. Besides Iran and Syria, they are Libya, South Yemen, Cuba and North Korea. The last change was the removal of Iraq in 1984. Getting off the list requires a renunciation of terrorism and six months of good behavior, among other tests. The officials said Iran and Syria had not qualified. President Bush on Monday called President Hafez Assad of Syria to thank him for assisting in the release of Polhill, whose 39 months of captivity in Lebanon ended on Sunday. Syria informed the United States that its ally, Iran, also helped. No details were provided to support the claim. The administration, in messages passed by Switzerland, Algeria, Japan and other governments, has informed Iran over the last several months that release of the hostages would improve relations with Washington, U.S. officials said. Iran, in the meantime, has said through intermediaries that it would like to improve relations and said a second hostage might be set free, according to the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The exchanges were described by one official as ``intermittent,'' continuing through the days before Polhill's release. The U.S. reply, the official said, was that all the hostages must be freed before the United States would renew ties with Tehran. The Carter administration suspended relations in April 1980 while 52 Americans were held hostage in the U.S. Embassy in Tehran. Iran is believed to have considerable influence with militants holding the seven Americans in Lebanon. ``I hope the Polhill release means something for the future and they got our message,'' said a U.S. official. Meanwhile, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said ``our hostages should be released unconditionally, safely and immediately, and this barbaric practice should end.'' He made the statement in response to Iranian demands that the United States exert influence on a Christian group in Lebanon to release Iranian captives and on Israel to free a pro-Iranian Shiite cleric, Abdul Karim Obeid, seized last summer in Lebanon. ``We are not going to deal and we're not going to negotiate,'' Baker said at a news conference. ``We remain hopeful. We will continue to call on the world community to do what they can to obtain the release of all hostages.'' At the same time, Baker said, ``We do not support hostage-taking. I don't think hostage-taking serves any useful purpose.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said that only the unconditional release of all American hostages would ``open the door towards better relations with Iran.'' He pointed to what he said were encouraging remarks by Syrian officials and to a Tehran Times editorial saying all hostages ought to be freed. But he also said the United States had no solid evidence that the release of Polhill would necessarily lead to freedom for the other Americans. State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler, when asked if officials had reason to expect another American would be set free, said, ``No, we do not.''

DOC.HEAD: Bennett Rejects Direct Anti-Drug Aid to Cities
DOC.TEXT: Federal drug policy chief William Bennett is rejecting suggestions by the nation's mayors for direct anti-drug aid to their cities and for more emphasis on education and treatment. Bennett told mayors gathered for a conference on drugs and crime Monday that it is too soon to redirect spending on drug enforcement and interdiction efforts to domestic prevention and treatment. His remarks drew a blast from a frequent critic, Boston Mayor Raymond L. Flynn, as ``well-intentioned but off the mark.'' ``The choice for our young people cannot be either poverty or selling drugs,'' said Flynn, a Democrat. ``An essential alternative has to be jobs and education. As long as the White House continues to feel that the answer is in law enforcement alone at the local level, the war will never be won.'' Bennett, director of drug policy in the Bush administration, repeated the administration's opposition to sending federal anti-drug money directly to cities, rather than through the states. Many mayors contend the money isn't reaching them and want federal aid that bypasses the states. But Bennett said direct aid would ``create a confusing and disorderly hodge-podge'' and might slow the distribution of aid even more. Mayor Bill Harris of Lincoln, Neb., a Democratic candidate for governor, suggested a greater portion of federal anti-drug money be spent on prevention efforts. ``I think not yet,'' Bennett replied. ``I wouldn't shift resources from interdiction yet.'' The mayor of Bogota, Colombia, Andres Pastrana, told his U.S. counterparts that the war on drugs has brought havoc and bloodshed to his country. He said Colombia should respond to invitations for plea-bargaining from Colombian drug leaders known as ``extraditables,'' who have offered to give up production and submit to Colombian law. ``If we continue to pursue the Wild West model, thousands of Colombians and thousands of Americans will die,'' Pastrana said. The Bogota mayor, who himself was kidnapped and held for eight days in 1988 by drug kingpins, said he supports proposals for finding a way to permit plea-bargaining, not now allowed in his country. ``We have to decide which is best: to gradually eliminate the production, commercialization and sale of narcotics and the wealth they generate, or to have the picture of a Colombian national rotting in a Miami prison,'' Pastrana said. Washington Mayor Marion Barry, awaiting trial on cocaine possession and perjury charges, made brief mention of his own problem in welcoming the group. He thanked the mayors ``for your sincere and deep, honest prayers during my difficult time.'' ``And believe me, they have been answered,'' Barry said. ``I feel better, I'm back here in good spirits and high self-esteem, clearer vision and glad to see a number of you.'' Barry later said he didn't feel uncomfortable addressing a conference on drugs, despite his arrest and subsequent treatment for substance abuse at two clinics. ``You assume a person is innocent until proven guilty, and that's my attitude about all of this,'' he said. ``It will come out in the court ... I'm still the mayor.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA: `Everything is Go' for Launch of Space Telescope
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, `Loading of ...' to DELETE reference to storm, which has moved out.
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle Discovery stood ready once again, weather willing, to ferry the Hubble Space Telescope into orbit Tuesday to seek answers to two questions: how old is the universe, and how big? At the Kennedy Space Center on Monday, officials expressed confidence the liftoff, scheduled for 8:31 a.m. EDT, will occur. But there was little of the excitement of two weeks ago when hundreds of astronomers gathered, with their families, only to see the launch scrubbed with four minutes to go in the countdown. ``Here we are once again,'' said William Lenoir, head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's space flight program. ``We think once again we are ready.'' The unstable weather during launch preparations on Monday was more of a concern than Tuesday's. NASA delayed by an hour the rollback of the service structure which had protected the shuttle from the elements. Loading of more than a half million gallons of hazardous fuel began at 12:11 a.m. Tuesday as scheduled. For Tuesday, there was the prospect of an hour's delay for early morning fog but little else to worry about. The crew of five, commanded by Loren Shriver, spent the day making last minute changes in flight plans, undergoing equipment checks and relaxing. One member, Steven Hawley, had a special reason for wanting the mission to begin on Tuesday. Hawley holds the record among shuttle astronauts for climbing into the shuttle cockpit, dressed for flight, only to have the liftoff delayed. On his first flight, Hawley underwent three scrubs; on his second, it was six times. The aborted countdown on April 10 was his 10th. Since then, another change has come to this seaside launch area. For the first time since January 1986 _ and only the second time ever _ there was a shuttle on pads A and B in Complex 39. Then, too, one of the shuttles was Columbia. The other was the Challenger which exploded 73 seconds after launch because of a leak in its right booster rocket. This time, Columbia is scheduled to make its 10th flight in mid-May with another scientific payload, the Astro observatory. For now, it was Discovery, the shuttle on pad B, that commanded attention. The $1.5 billion Hubble telescope, the finest ever made, is expected ``to give us a new set of eyes and ears,'' said Lenoir. ``I can't say what we are going to learn, but I will be astounded if we don't learn many new things.'' Lennard Fisk, the head of NASA's science activities, said ``astronomers are starting to tingle again in anticipation of what the Hubble will be able to accomplish.'' The telescope will provide astronomers with 10 times better resolution and 25 times more sensitivity than any ground-based telescope and one-half billion times more sensitivity than the human eye. ``We are going to have the ability to observe the most distant objects in the universe, and therefore among the earliest, and therefore probe the secrets of creation,'' he said. ``We are ready to begin that new era in astronomy that Hubble will usher in.'' During the first launch attempt, NASA and its contractors set up two huge tents at the press site and had experts on hand to describe their work on various aspects of the telescope. The tents came down after the scrub, the astronomers left, and only a small cadre of experts was about. The attempt was in the week before Easter and many of the scientists had planned vacations around the event, a milestone in astronomical research. ``Today I bring you only good news,'' NASA test director Al Sofge said Monday. ``The launch vehicle is in good shape. The Hubble Space Telescope is in good shape. The flight crew is ready ... and the weather looks good. So at this point, everything is go.'' Discovery will aim for an altitude of 380 miles, the highest a shuttle has ever gone, so the telescope can be placed in its proper orbit far above Earth's distorting atmosphere. Hawley will guide the shuttle's 50-foot long crane as it lifts the 24,250-pound telescope out of the cargo bay and drops it overboard on the second day of the five-day mission.

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter: Farmers Will Have to Look to Marketplace for More Income
DOC.TEXT: Budget-cutting pressures on Capitol Hill are making it more important for farmers to get a bigger income slice from the marketplace, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter says. For example, he said a new spending package announced last week by Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee, would hold spending on farm income support under federal commodity programs to $9.8 billion in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. An administration budget plan sent to Congress in January called for $10.2 billion, a reduction of $1.5 billion from the increase that normally would occur if annual ``baseline'' spending trends were followed. Yeutter told a meeting Monday of the National Association of Agricultural Journalists that the administration and he, in particular, had come in for severe partisan criticism for the proposed $1.5 billion spending reduction. The budget figures by Panetta will be even harder for the House Agriculture Committee to reckon with because those amount to a $1.9 billion cut from the baseline, he said. ``We now have a much different situation in farm legislation than we did a few days ago,'' Yeutter said. However, the situation also depends on whose baseline is being used. The current USDA baseline is $11.7 billion, which was based on crop indications last fall. Thus, a $1.5 billion reduction would be required to needed to lower fiscal 1991 spending to the $10.2 billion cited by Yeutter as the Bush proposal. The Panetta figure of $9.8 billion was derived from a Congressional Budget Office baseline of $10.6 billion computed as of February. Under that computation, the Panetta budget reduction would be only $800 million, not the $1.9 billion Yeutter said. Regardless of whose figures are used, farm commodity programs are in for some more paring. And Yeutter made the point that it will be even more urgent for the United States to seek a favorable conclusion to the on-going Uruguay Round negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, he said. The GATT talks, scheduled to conclude at the end of this year, are aimed a liberalizing world trade. The U.S. position on agricultural trade calls for the gradual elimination of all trade-distorting policies and subsidies over a period of years. Yeutter said there is a feeling in some U.S. agricultural circles that the GATT talks are being overemphasized and that farmers would be better off relying on Congress to write generous price and income support provisions in the new farm bill. But there will ``not be a lucrative price package'' in the farm bill, Yeutter said. Therefore, farmers will have to generate more of their income from the marketplace. ``We're simply not going to have the flow of federal tax dollars into agriculture in the coming year that we've had in the past,'' he said. Yeutter said a two-price dairy plan approved last week by a House Agriculture subcommittee has some ``very negative'' features and would put a heavier cost burden on consumers. Members of the House wheat, soybeans and feed grains subcommittee also faced grim financial reality last week when Panetta announced the budget figures. The lawmakers' plans for price supports would cost $16 billion more over the five-year life of the bill than the budget would allow, committee staff said. Sections of the farm bill dealing with those commodities were put on hold until this Thursday while the lawmakers find places to cut.

The Agriculture Department says the Soviet Union has bought an additional 149,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices for delivery next month under a long-term grain supply agreement. Christopher E. Goldthwaite, acting general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said Monday the wheat was sold by two private companies, which will receive subsidies under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. Goldthwaite said 563,950 tons of wheat remain in the Soviet Union's current EEP allocation. Only wheat has been approved for sale to the Soviets under the price subsidy program. The seventh year of the U.S.-Soviet grain agreement began last Oct. 1. With the latest sales, the Soviet Union has bought more than 3.2 million tons of wheat for 1989-90 delivery and more than 13.1 million tons of corn, plus soybeans and soybean meal. All of the wheat was sold under EEP arrangements. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. The 149,000 tons are equal to nearly 5.5 million bushels, worth about $19 million at recent U.S. farm prices. Goldthwaite reported the subsidies at an average of $28.87 per ton, or about 79 cents per bushel. The EEP arrangement allows private exporters to sell wheat and other designated commodities to specified countries at reduced prices in order to meet foreign competition. The exporters then collect free government surpluses of grain or other products as bonuses, or subsidies. Goldthwaite said the latest wheat was sold by Continental Grain Co., 99,000 tons; and J. Aron & Co., 50,000 tons.

Western states will have low water supplies this summer in many areas, according to an Agriculture Department report. ``With snowfall virtually over and snowmelt beginning, it looks like spring and summer streamflows will be below average for most of the West,'' Wilson Scaling, chief of the department's Soil Conservation Service, said Monday. ``The wise use of water will be more important than ever.'' Streamflows are forecast to be less than 70 percent of average in California, Nevada, Arizona, most of Oregon, Utah and New Mexico, southern Idaho, southwestern Wyoming and western Colorado. The only western areas where streamflows are expected to be above average are most streams in southern Alaska, the Cache la Poudre River in Colorado, and the headwaters of the Tongue River in Wyoming and the Kootenai River in Canada and Montana, the report said. Western states depend on snowmelt for about 75 percent of their water supply.

DOC.HEAD: Prognosis Good For Girl Who Got Twin Brother's Heart
DOC.TEXT: The parents of a newborn who received the heart of her brain-dead twin brother may be able to take their daughter home within weeks. Alison Paige Whisman, believed to be the first recipient of a heart from an infant twin, wriggled on her hospital bed in pink booties Monday as Timothy and Paula Whisman watched a sonogram of their dead son's heart beating inside her. ``She acts normal and is quite well,'' said Dr. Randall L. Caldwell. ``I'd say her prognosis is good, but all patients that have had a heart transplant you have to watch.'' The baby, called Paige by her parents, may be able to leave the Riley Hospital for Children in 10 days to two weeks, Caldwell said. Her growth could be delayed some by the drugs she has to take, said Caldwell. But she already has gained almost a pound from the 4 pounds, 13 ounces she weighed at birth 14 days ago. Their daughter's progress is uplifting to the parents, whose ordeal after their twins' birth April 10 ``was a roller coaster ride and it was all downhill for about four days,'' Whisman said. Four weeks premature, Paige was born a minute before her brother, Tyler Joseph, and appeared normal. Tyler asphyxiated in the womb just before birth for unknown reasons. The next morning, Paige's coloring changed, tipping off doctors that she had a fatal heart defect. While one child lay ill and the other brain dead on a life-support system, Mrs. Whisman wondered whether Tyler's heart could be transplanted into Paige. Because the twins were not identical, the chances of an organ match were uncertain. The Whismans, who are Roman Catholics, had their babies baptized during Easter week as they waited for test results on their children. On Good Friday, Whisman remembered, he drove 20 miles home to Cicero to work on the couple's tax return and called back to the hospital to talk to his wife. ``Honey, honey, Tyler's heart is compatible,'' he recalled her saying. The next day, Tyler's heart was transplanted into Paige. His liver was later transplanted into a 3{-month-old girl in Wisconsin, Whisman said. ``We needed a reason to let people know that Tyler was here,'' said Whisman. ``They said he was dead at birth, but he lived long enough to help two children.'' Now the couple, married less than three years, say they are going to have to buy clothing for a girl; although Tyler's gender was determined in the womb, doctors did not know whether his twin would be a boy or a girl, said Mrs. Whisman. ``So everything we have is either yellow or blue,'' she said. The Whismans also look forward to the day when they'll be able to tell Paige about her brother. ``We're very happy little Tyler will be remembered,'' said Whisman. ``She deserves to know about her brother.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Experts' View of Their Economy `Between Pessimism and Depression'
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Soviet economists participating in a unique conference with their U.S. counterparts took an even gloomier view of their country's economy than Western experts, according to the event's chairman. ``The range of opinion for the Soviet group was somewhere between pessimism and depression, as far as the prospects for turnaround'' for the Soviet economy, said Nicholas Eberstadt, an American Enterprise Institute scholar who was conference chairman. The Soviet analysts offered grim pictures of their country's standard of living, the size of its economy relative to other world powers, and the burden its military places on the overall economy, Eberstadt said. And he said at least one irony emerged from the four-day meeting: Soviet officials chiding the Central Intelligence Agency for being taken in by Soviet propaganda that overstated the country's economic performance. ``It was the sense of the group that the old official Soviet estimates are not plausible,'' he said. The meeting was the first at which high-level Soviet economists have held frank exchanges with their U.S. counterparts. The conference report reinforced a downbeat view of the Soviet economy released last week by the CIA. In congressional testimony, agency Deputy Director for Intelligence John Helgerson called the economy's 1989 performance ``abysmal'' and cited price increases and shortages of consumer goods. Although comparisons between market and non-market economies are difficult at best, Soviet economist Victor Belkin estimated his country's gross national product is only 14 to 28 percent that of the United States. That would rank it as low as eighth in the world, behind the United States, Japan, West Germany, France, Great Britain, Italy and perhaps even India. Official estimates by the CIA have ranked the Soviet economy second after the United States, putting it at about half the U.S. gross national product of 5.3 trillion. Another Soviet analyst, Vladimir Tikhonov, said his country's agricultural statistics substantially overstate Soviet food output. Meat production is barely half the officially reported figure, he said. Grain output in 1988 was less than 140 million tons, rather than the 195 million officially reported. Oleg Bogomolov, another conference participant, put Soviet military spending at 20 to 25 percent of GNP, roughly 200 billion rubles a year. That compares with the 77 billion rubles officially reported. The CIA estimate has been 15 percent. ``The Soviet level of military burden is more or less what North Korea's is, which means that it is a highly militarized society, on a war footing,'' Eberstadt said. Another Soviet researcher, Yuri Dykhanov, said the living standard of Soviet citizens averages about 20 percent that of the United States; the CIA puts the figure at one-third the U.S. level. ``The idea that the Soviet living standard might be as much as one-third that of the U.S. standard struck the Soviet group as utterly fanciful,'' Eberstadt said. The Soviet Union is beginning new research in cooperation with Austria and West Germany aimed at finding better, more accurate measures for its economy, he said.

DOC.HEAD: `Republicans for Choice' Aims to Eliminate Anti-Abortion Platform Plank
DOC.TEXT: The internal Republican Party debate over abortion is heating up with formation of a grassroots drive to eliminate the strong anti-abortion plank from the party platform. Ann Stone, a conservative activist, said Monday that Republicans for Choice has recruited more than 200 GOP officeholders as part of its $3 million drive to elect pro-choice delegates to the 1992 convention. ``Our party will face defeat in the 1990 congressional and gubernatorial elections,'' said a prospectus mailed by the group to Republicans around the country. ``President Bush's re-election could even be endangered.'' Stone, who described herself as ``pro-choice and pro-life,'' said she had no expectation that the man expected to dominate the 1992 convention, President Bush, will change his position. ``Our party is a big tent and George Bush and all of us sit under it,'' she said. If the drive fails to get the convention to put pro-choice language in the 1992 platform, Stone said she would try to drop abortion from the document. The 1988 platform said that ``the unborn child has a fundamental individual right to life which cannot be infringed. We therefore reaffirm our support for a human life amendment to the Constitution, and we endorse legislation to make clear that the Fourteenth Amendment's protections apply to unborn children. We oppose the use of public funds for organizations which advocate or support abortion.'' But in the 1989 elections, held months after the Supreme Court gave states far greater leeway to place restrictions on abortion, Republicans lost races for governor of Virginia and New Jersey, contests in which the GOP candidates were attacked for their anti-abortion views. Stone, who said she personally opposes abortion, contended that the party would suffer far greater losses this year and in 1992 unless it changes its position. ``The 1988 Republican National Platform included a right-to-life plank that we believe is not representative of a majority of Republicans or most Americans,'' said the group's prospectus. The document went on to cite the 1989 elections as proof that ``this position on abortion is dangerous politically and will cost us the votes of many traditional Republicans as well as the vote of a majority of young voters 18 to 35.'' The three goals cited were to fight to change the platform; elect pro-choice Republicans as delegates and to ``fight efforts within the Republican National Committee or within state Republican committees to force our party to oppose the option of legal abortion.'' Leslie Goodman, a spokeswoman for the Republican National Committee, said, ``We certainly would advocate people getting out there and working both sides of the issue. ... We think there is a dialogue that needs to take place.'' But she declined to speculate on whether the platform might be changed. ``I can't even look that far ahead,'' she said. The group claims more than 200 recruits for its advisory board, including Reps. Tom Campbell of California, Nancy Johnson of Connecticut and Jim Kolbe of Arizona. Stone has her own direct-mail fundraising firm and has long been active on behalf of conservative candidates and causes. She said her views on abortion had never been known because ``no one ever asked me.'' She said she didn't oppose the party's shift to an anti-abortion position at the 1980 convention because that was what the nominee, Ronald Reagan, wanted. ``I voted for him and I worked hard for him,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Groups at Odds Over Cost of New Apartments for Handicapped
DOC.TEXT: The government and home builders and groups of the handicapped are split over whether proposed guidelines guaranteeing disabled people access to new apartments would price many of them out of housing. A task force formed by the National Coordinating Council on Spinal Cord Injury and the National Association of Home Builders said Monday that the guidelines would put new apartment rents out of reach of many low- and medium-income people, including the handicapped. ``If design guidelines result in significant increases in the cost of housing, then we have defeated the purpose of the Fair Housing Amendments Act of 1988 and created another barrier to accessibility,'' said R. Jack Powell, president of the spinal injury group and executive director of the Paralyzed Veterans of America. But Gordon Mansfield, assistant HUD secretary for fair housing and a former Paralyzed Veterans official, contended in an interview that the guidelines are within Congress' intent and would add only 1 percent to apartment rents. Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack Kemp ``has instructed us to pay attention to affordability'' and ``probably what we are proposing is less than the home builders,'' said Mansfield, a paraplegic from a spinal cord injury suffered in the Vietnam war. Bonnie Milstein, co-chairman of the Housing Task Force of the Consortium for Citizens with Disabilities, agreed. She said the Task Force on Handicap Accessibility set up by the home builders and spinal injury group is basing its estimates on expenditures not required by the Fair Housing amendments. Congressional amendments to the Fair Housing Act require HUD to insure that disabled people have easy access to new multi-family apartments first occupied after next March 13. The guidelines involve such things as the width of doors and halls, the size of bathrooms and walk-in pantries and the grading and ramping of steeply sloped sites.
