The home builders and spinal cord council contended that the proposed guidelines ``will increase significantly'' the cost of apartment construction, ``further slowing an already depressed multi-family industry and exacerbating the affordability crisis currently confronting millions of low- and moderate-income households.'' Powell told a news conference at National Association of Home Builders headquarters that the cost of meeting the proposed guidelines would range from $1,300 to $3,700 for walk-up units and from $3,200 to $4,250 for mid- to high-rise apartments. That cost, he said, will be passed on to consumers, resulting in monthly rent increases of $13 to $37 for walk-up units and of $32 to $43 for mid- or high-rise units. But Mansfield said the HUD guidelines would increase the cost of a $50,000 apartment by just 1 percent, or $500, which both HUD and the handicap accessibility task force agree is within the cost that Congress intended. In addition to the disagreement over the effects of the new law, the uncertainty over the guidelines has severely disrupted the multi-family construction industry, said Kent W. Colton, executive vice president of the home builders. He said the industry finished 1989 with only 373,000 building starts, down nearly 50 percent from 1985 and the lowest level since 1975, Mansfield said the draft guidelines are being considered by the Office of Management and Budget, which much approve many government regulations before they take effect. ``We would like to see the guidelines as soon as possible,'' he said. The home builders group is a federation of more than 800 construction associations with more than 157,000 members. The coordinating council is composed of 17 organizations associated with spinal cord injuries, of which the largest is the Paralyzed Veterans of America. The consortium includes in its membership United Cerebral Palsy, the American Foundation for the Blind and the Easter Seal Society. All three organizations supported the Fair Housing amendments.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Challengers Press for End to Incumbent Advantages
DOC.TEXT: A collection of political have-nots is out to accomplish collectively what its members couldn't do individually: Defeat the powers of congressional incumbency. ``Our country is suffering from an imperial, permanent Congress. It is a Congress that cannot solve the problems we have,'' complained Paul Jurgens, a Decatur, Ill., Republican who ran unsuccessfully for the House in 1988. He was one of more than three dozen past and current congressional challengers who gathered Monday on Capitol Hill to call for a political housecleaning. ``Our federally elected officials have so rigged the process that they are impossible to unseat,'' said Harold Coker, a Chattanooga, Tenn., Republican and losing candidate in 1988. That complaint was the central theme at a meeting of the Coalition to End the Permanent Congress, a grassroots organization formed out of frustration with the 1988 elections, in which 98.5 percent of House incumbents won re-election. Coalition members from at least 18 states advocated a long list of reform proposals. Among them were a ban on taxpayer-paid mass mailings by members of Congress; prohibiting lawmakers from accepting honoraria or speaking fees; eliminating political action committees, which contribute mostly to campaigns of incumbents; and imposing a 12-year limit on how long members can serve in the House and Senate. Lionel Kunst, a Kansas Democrat who helped found the group, urged coalition members to return to their states and vigorously push the issue of congressional reform among voters. ``This thing is hot right now. We can make a greater impact,'' said Kunst. The group has met about a half dozen times in other cities since its first gathering last year in Kansas City, Mo. The coalition's latest assault on incumbency came as the Senate prepared to consider legislation to overhaul the system of financing congressional campaigns. But Kunst denounced the legislation as ``pablum'' and said it would do little for challengers.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Peruvians Fearful Since Presidential Vote
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Fear of racial violence has swept anew through Peru's 60,000-member Japanese community since Alberto Fujimori, the son of immigrants, stunned the nation by rocketing from unknown to presidential frontrunner. People of Asian descent, including the large Chinese community, have increasingly been threatened, insulted in public, and denied entry to restaurants since Fujimori's surprisingly strong finish in the April 8 vote. For many, it's a nightmare relived. Fifty years ago, just before the outbreak of World War II in the Pacific, Juan Iida watched mobs loot the homes and businesses of Japanese Peruvians. ``It was the worst experience of my life,'' said Iida, the 77-year-old founder of the Japanese-language daily newspaper Peru Shimpo. ``I don't even want to think about it happening again.'' Anti-Japanese fever peaked with a recent statement by Sen. Enrique Chirinos Soto, a spokesman for rival candidate Mario Vargas Llosa. He said Peru is not ``ready to have as president a first-generation Peruvian.'' Vargas Llosa dismissed the spokesman and decried the racial incidents. People in other circles, including outgoing President Alan Garcia and Lima's Roman Catholic archbishop, have also spoken out against the hatred. Fujimori, an agronomist born of Japanese parents, won nearly 30 percent of the vote in the April 8 balloting to 32 percent for Vargas Llosa, forcing a runoff. Backed by left-of-center voters, the political independent is expected to prevail over the conservative novelist in voting expected in early June. ``Fujimori is as Peruvian as I am and as you are,'' Vargas Llosa shouted at supporters who chanted anti-Japanese slogans outside his home the night after the election. Even so, some critics have accused members of his center-right Democratic Front coalition of deliberately fanning the fires of racism to cut into Fujimori's support. ``It was a primitive response by frustrated people,'' said Amelia Morimoto Hayashi, of the Japanese Peruvian Cultural Center. However, in the long run, it may be Vargas Llosa who suffers if race becomes an important issue in the campaign, according to some analysts. Eighty-five percent of Peru's population is Indian and mestizo. Another 5 percent is black. In addition, Vargas Llosa is viewed by many as part of the white caste that has traditionally ruled this Andean country from coastal Lima. An urbane man, he lived and wrote for 16 years in Europe before returning to Peru in 1974. Critics accuse him of being out of touch with Peruvian reality. ``The final stretch of the campaign revealed the racist and class character of Vargas Llosa's entourage,'' said Fernando Rospigliosi, a columnist for the independent news magazine Caretas. Indeed, Rospigliosi said Fujimori's success so far has stemmed in great measure from deeply rooted anti-white prejudices: ``The high vote obtained by Fujimori can be explained in part, in my opinion, by the racial factor.'' Fujimori's own reaction has varied with the moment. Sometimes he has joked. ``Some people fear that during my government they will have to eat with chopsticks,'' he said soon after the elections. Later, he blamed the racial outbursts on ``certain discontented groups that are making use of whatever weapons available to create problems.'' Fujimori's own campaign may actually have helped bring the racism to the surface. Throughout the race, he played on Peruvians' stereotype of orientals as ``hard-working and honest.'' He has repeatedly referred to himself as ``el chinito,'' the little Chinaman. Many voters thus came to view him as a foreigner, and this worked largely in his favor. Public opinion polls show that voters regard foreigners as less corrupt and more efficient than Peruvians. Racism has long played a part in Peru's history. Peru's television stars and news announcers are generally white, as are people in most advertisements. The winner of the Miss Peru pageant invariably is white. The Maoist guerrilla known as the Shining Path is to some extent an outgrowth of anti-white sentiment among the Quechua-speaking Indians of Peru's highlands. Most Japanese Peruvians are the children of pre-World War II immigrants who came to work on coastal plantations. Most later moved to cities and many started their own businesses. On May 13, 1940, dozens of their stores and homes were looted by mobs driven by anti-Japanese war propaganda. Most businesses that survived the looting were seized later by the government. More than 1,400 Japanese Peruvians were deported to camps in the United States, where other Japanese Americans were detained. After the war most Japanese Peruvians had to start over with nothing. Many spent the next four decades ``just trying to integrate, to become Peruvian, so it wouldn't happen again,'' Ms. Morimoto says. Most Japanese Peruvians have been successful. Many own large businesses and factories. Others are doctors, lawyers, and engineers. But the memories remain. ``What I fear most is that Mr. Fujimori will not make a good government, which is a very difficult task in Peru today,'' said 61-year-old Gerardo Maruy, retiring president of the Japanese Peruvian Association. ``The same people who thought him a miracle worker,'' said Maruy, ``will be the first to turn against him, and against us.

DOC.HEAD: Quakers Object to `Popeye the Quaker Man' Ads
DOC.TEXT: ``I yam what I yam,'' says Popeye the Sailor Man, but the peace-loving Quakers don't like his brawling ways and object to the use of the cartoon character in ads for Quaker Oats. Not only that, toot toot, but Olive Oyl is too submissive, say members of the Religious Society of Friends, better known as the Quakers, a longtime champion of women's rights. Popeye began popping up last year in TV commercials and in comics inserted in instant oatmeal packages, dispatching his nemesis Bluto with a swift swing of an oversized forearm. ``I eats me oatmeal and I'm stronger than steel, I'm Popeye the Quaker Man,'' he sings to an adoring Olive Oyl. Elizabeth Foley, spokeswoman for the Philadelphia Yearly Meeting, the biggest Quaker group in the East, said Monday, ``They had Popeye resolving dispute and conflict through violence. This is completely obnoxious and offensive.'' ``We are an organization of pacifists. We have a peace testimony that is more than 300 years old,'' she said. ``To portray us as a church that beats up on other people is not OK.'' Quaker Oats Co. _ which has no connection with the religious group _ apologized and said it deleted the phrase ``Popeye the Quaker Man'' from commercials, which ran through the ``oatmeal season,'' September through March. References to ``Popeye the Quaker Man'' will be taken out in future printings of the comics in oatmeal packages, the Chicago-based company said. ``Obviously, we looked at it as a humorous way in which to promote the product and certainly never intended to create any controversy,'' said company spokesman Ron Bottrell. However, he said Quaker Oats hasn't decided whether to drop Popeye as a spokesman. In Chester County, near Philadelphia, Quaker children at the Willistown Monthly Meeting First Day School suggested an alternative plot. ``They have Popeye and Bluto coming together and saying, `Our fights have never resolved anything. Let's try something new _ let's work together for the betterment of all,''' Foley said. ``And they build a homeless shelter.'' Paul Hendricks, who edits the Popeye strip for King Features Syndicate, said the concept of Bluto and Popeye working together isn't too farfetched. ``I think it'd fly. As long it's not saccharine sweet, it'd be OK,'' Hendricks said. ``Basically Popeye's a nice guy. He just beats up on bad guys.''

DOC.HEAD: University President Resigns Over Personal Behavior
DOC.TEXT: American University officials say President Richard Berendzen resigned over allegations of improper personal behavior, but they're not saying what Berendzen is alleged to have done. Berendzen, who announced his resignation April 10, could not be reached for comment on Monday. A published report said his whereabouts were unknown even to university officials. Edward Carr, president of the university's board of trustees, said the allegations had nothing to do with Berendzen's job. ``Despite the private nature of Dr. Berendzen's problem, it was concluded that his resignation would be in the best interests of the university,'' Carr said in a statement. ``In the interim, he has not been on campus and he will not be returning to campus.'' The Washington Post quoted a university vice president, Anita Gottlieb, as saying that Berendzen has called people at the school but that ``we have no way of reaching him back.'' Berendzen, 51, has been American University president for 10 years. The former astronomy professor came to the university in 1974 as the dean of the College Arts and Sciences and became provost three years later. He announced on Apr. 10 that he was leaving at the end of the current academic year because he was exhausted by the job.

DOC.HEAD: Don't Say Yuck: Oat Bran Ice Cream Is on Its Way
DOC.TEXT: Impossible as it sounds, a food scientist says he's invented just what the world's been waiting for: Ice cream that's good for you. Not only does this stuff contain almost no fat, it might actually lower the body's cholesterol level instead of raising it. The secret ingredient is a fluffy white powder made from that darling of the food conscious, oat bran. Its principal inventor, George E. Inglett of the U.S. Department of Agriculture's research labs in Peoria, Ill., calls it Oatrim. If his predictions are correct, in two or three years it will be an ingredient in all sorts of otherwise high-fat foods, including mayonnaise, cheese spreads, salad dressings and margarine. ``It has a double whammy,'' Inglett said. ``It will replace animal fat, such as cream, in desserts. And it acts in the body to lower blood cholesterol.'' To be successful, Oatrim will have to compete against other fat substitutes that have been under development longer, and it will have to overcome doubts that have arisen about the powers of oat bran to lower cholesterol. The first of the substitutes, called Simplesse, was approved by the Food and Drug Administration last month. It is made from egg whites and milk protein. Others, made by Kraft and Procter & Gamble, are also under consideration by the FDA. Whether oat bran actually lowers blood cholesterol was called into question by a study conducted last year at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. Doctors concluded that cholesterol levels fall when people eat lots of oat bran _ but only because they are too full to eat high-fat foods that raise cholesterol. Oatrim is produced when enzymes are used to remove water-soluble fiber from oat bran or oat flour. When mixed with water, it takes on the consistency of cream cheese but has almost no taste. Inglett unveiled his product Monday at a meeting of the American Chemical Society. He handed out samples of English muffins covered with an Oatrim cheese substitute. It was sweet and bland with a mild taste of cheddar cheese. While he did not show off Oatrim ice cream, he said that in taste surveys people rate it between ice milk and ice cream. When whipped up by a soft-serve machine, tasters describe it as ``delicious, excellent, wonderful and marvelous,'' he said. In one respect, it is clearly different. Four ounces of fancy premium ice cream contain about 300 calories, 22 grams of fat and 85 milligrams of cholesterol. Oatrim ice cream has 135 calories, virtually no fat and four milligrams of cholesterol. No studies have been done to see what effect the product has on people's cholesterol. However, Dr. Rosemary K. Newman of Montana State University tested it on chicks and found that it lowered their cholesterol levels 18 percent. ``It certainly was effective in chicks,'' she said. ``I'm excited about it'' as a food for people. Oatrim cannot be used as a fat substitute in baked goods, such as cookies, because it loses its fat-like consistency when heated. Inglett said Oatrim powder could also be stirred into powdered breakfast drinks to provide the same amount of oat bran fiber as a bowl of oatmeal. ``Instead of eating your oatmeal,'' he said, ``there's no reason why you can't drink it in the morning, and then you're off to work.''

DOC.HEAD: Eight Kidnappers and One Kidnapping Victim Killed in Medellin
DOC.TEXT: In two rescue operations in the cocaine center of Medellin, eight kidnappers and a hostage were shot to death but police rescued a second kidnap victim without injury, authorities said. In one of Monday's raids, police rescued Diego Barrientos while killing three of his abductors and capturing three others, police said in a communique. They did not give details about Barrientos nor his abduction. In the other operation, police shot and killed five kidnappers but not before the suspects shot and killed their hostage, Carlos Sierra, who had managed a brickmaking firm, the police communique said. Medellin has suffered a wave of kidnappings of business leaders and other wealthy citizens in recent months. Authorities have blamed many of the abductions on drug traffickers. The powerful Medellin cocaine cartel has declared war on the country's political and economic elite in retaliation for a government anti-drug crackdown that began August. As part of the crackdown, President Virgilio Barco decreed a policy of extraditing Colombian drug suspects for trial in the United States. The traffickers often escaped justice at home by bribing or threatening court workers. The Colombian Justice Ministry most recently ordered the extraditions of Rafael Juliao Fernandez and Luis Carbacas Acosta, authorities said Monday. The government has already extradited 15 suspects as part of the crackdown, and is holding 15 others awaiting extradition. More than 230 people have been killed in shootings, bombings and other attacks blamed on drug traffickers in the last eight months.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Got $96 Million From PACs In 1983-1988
DOC.TEXT: Incumbent U.S. senators collected $96.2 million in political action committee donations from 1983 through 1988, and four senators topped $2 million in PAC receipts, a group seeking an overhaul of campaign finance laws said today. Common Cause, one of several self-styled public interest groups lobbying for restrictions on PAC donations, said 44 of the 99 incumbent senators received at least $1 million in PAC money during the six-year period. The totals were compiled from Federal Election Commission data. Not included was the Hawaii Sen. Spark Matsunaga, who died earlier this month. The four senators whose PAC donations from 1983-88 exceeded $2 million were Sens. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, $2.5 million; Pete Wilson, R-Calif., $2.3 million; Slade Gorton, R-Wash., $2.2 million; and Phil Gramm, R-Texas, $2 million. Common Cause said finance industry PACs _ those associated with banks, savings and loans and other financial institutions _ were the top contributors during the six-year period. Common Cause said the top recipient of finance-industry PAC donations was Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, who received $344,000 in such donations.
DOC.HEAD: Federal Officials Defend Use of Animals in Experiments
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials say animal rights activists may derail important medical advances with their campaign against the use of animals in experiments. Undersecretary of Health and Human Services Constance Horner told scientists at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., on Monday that ``extremists'' are cultivating ``a climate of fear'' throughout the scientific research community. Her pep talk came a day before an animal rights rally at NIH scheduled for today. ``Animal studies ... have been and continue to be an indispensable part of the great biomedical revolution that has brought freedom from disease and suffering to millions of human beings,'' she said. ``We must not permit the activities of a handful of extremists to deprive millions of life-sustaining and life-enhancing fruits of biomedical research,'' she said in prepared remarks. Horner said scientists, including those at NIH, have long discouraged and condemned animal research that is unnecessary or cruel.
DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Hate Crime Bill
DOC.TEXT: President Bush calls a new bill that requires the government to track crimes against minorities ``a significant step to help guarantee civil rights for every American.'' Bush signed the bill on Monday, saying ``hate crimes cannot be tolerated in a free society.'' Under the legislation, the Justice Department will keep statistics on offenses related to race, religion, sexual orientation and ethnicity as part of the FBI's annual uniform crime report. ``Bigotry and hate regrettably still exist in this country and hate breeds violence, threatening the security of our entire society,'' Bush said. ``We must rid our communities of the poison we call prejudice, bias and discrimination.'' The president also said the Justice Department would establish a toll-free number for reporting complaints of such crimes.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Denies Pope To Visit
DOC.TEXT: Cuba says there are no plans for Pope John Paul II to visit the Communist Caribbean island nation in December, contradicting a weekend announcement by the Vatican. Papal spokesman Joaquin Navarro said Sunday as the pope wound up a trip to Czechoslovakia that the Polish-born pontiff would visit Cuba in December before Christmas, though not date has been set. But the official Cuban news agency, Prensa Latina, on Monday quoted the Foreign Ministry as saying there is no such plan for a papal visit. The dispatch was monitored in Mexico City. The Vatican last year accepted an invitation to visit from Cuban leader Fidel Castro. In March, while on a visit to Brazil, Castro said a visit by the pope was ``practically agreed upon.'' However, he also criticized the Catholic Church in Cuba at that time, saying it should dedicate itself to the people instead of ``assuming an anti-revolutionary position.'' The pope encouraged the toppling of unpopular Communist regimes in Eastern Europe and is now warning that region's newly freed peoples to be wary of what he calls the spiritually impoverished materialism of the capitalist West. Castro has staunchly defended his brand of Communism and the improved living standards it has meant for Cubans, refusing to embrace free market reforms encouraged by Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican President Protests Doctor's Arrest In Camarena Case
DOC.TEXT: Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari denounced the alleged U.S. kidnapping of a Mexican doctor to face charges in the slaying of a narcotics agent, declaring, ``You do not uphold the law with illegal acts.'' The Mexican president delivered his attack on U.S. actions below the border at Monday's annual luncheon of The Associated Press in Century City. The luncheon followed the news cooperative's annual meeting. The meeting and luncheon, attended by publishers and editors representing the AP's 1,486 newspaper members, were the opening-day events at the 104th annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association. Salinas, who arrived under heavy guard, pointed to Mexican arrests and convictions of 28 defendants in the 1985 slaying of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena as proof that Mexico needs no help in apprehending the guilty. Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain, who was brought to El Paso, Texas, on April 3 from Guadalajara, Mexico, is one of 18 people under indictment in the Camarena murder. A federal judge in Los Angeles has demanded an explanation of how Alvarez came to the United States. If the doctor was kidnapped, Salinas said, the incident could undermine the international drug-fighting effort. ``This runs the risk of creating illegal habits among those who have the obligation of defending the law and could create a problem much larger than the one we are trying to combat,'' Salinas said. The Mexican government has complained about the arrest of the gynecologist, alleging the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration offered money for the kidnapping and may have been in on the actual plot. Alvarez is alleged to have been present when Camarena was tortured and murdered at a Guadalajara house. Prosecutors allege that the doctor gave Camarena drugs to revive him for additional torturing before he was killed. ``The battle against narcotics traffickers requires unprecedented international cooperation,'' Salinas said. ``But that cooperation, in order to be effective and real, has to be accomplished with the strictest international respect and no unilateral action against the law and rights of other nations,'' he said. ``It is not with arbitrary acts by the pursuers that we are going to combat the illegality of the narcotics traffickers.'' U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has called for an investigation into the doctor's arrest. DEA officials have denied allegations by Alvarez' lawyer, Robert K. Steinberg of Los Angeles, that his client was kidnapped by bounty hunters who were paid as much as $100,000. The AP annual meeting included a report to the membership by William J. Keating, chairman of the AP's board of directors, and Louis D. Boccardi, president and general manager of the AP. Keating is chairman and publisher of The Cincinnati Enquirer. Boccardi said that AP technology is advancing to meet the needs of its growing membership, now at a record level. AP's electronic darkroom, which will replace the current photo reception system, is on schedule and meeting pre-production testing goals, Boccardi said. Full-scale installation of the AP Leaf darkroom is to begin in September after summer field-testing. An installation schedule is to be announced in June, he said. Boccardi compared the new technology for electronic handling of photos to the computer terminal revolution in handling words. He said it will mark a major step forward for newspapers. ``We will train your staff, and AP's service reliability will stand behind the AP Leaf darkroom. It is the right step at the right time,'' Boccardi said. He noted that darkrooms from sources other than AP could be used with the AP Leaf, which will fully conform to ANPA standards. Other technological advancements are imminent, Boccardi added. By July 1, the AP expects to complete the conversion of its entire highspeed system to deliver AP and supplemental copy to members at 9,000 words a minute, Boccardi said. A customized stocks service that allows members to localize market table pages is in print in a dozen member newspapers, and the installation schedule for SelectStocks will be accelerated through the rest of the year, he said. Boccardi touched on the plight of Terry Anderson, AP's chief Middle East correspondent, who was taken hostage in Lebanon five years ago last month. ``We continue to search for an end to his ordeal and pray that recent optimistic comments will lead to his release,'' Boccardi said. Also at the meeting on Monday, David J. Whichard II of the Greenville (N.C.) Daily Reflector was elected to the board of directors of The Associated Press, and five incumbents were re-elected. They were James K. Batten, chairman and chief executive officer of Knight-Ridder, Inc., based in Miami; J. Stewart Bryan III, chairman and publisher of the Richmond (Va.) Times-Dispatch and The Richmond News Leader; Ruth S. Holmberg, publisher of The Chattanooga (Tenn.) Times; Tom Johnson, chairman of the Los Angeles Times; and Joe D. Smith Jr., president of the Alexandria (La.) Daily Town Talk.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 29,501.38, down 177.69 points, or 0.59 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Sammy Davis Jr., recuperating at home from chemotherapy, got a boost from the birth of his second grandchild and words of encouragement from Frank Sinatra. ``He told Sammy he wishes he was on the road with him again,'' said Susan Reynolds, spokeswoman for the two entertainers. Asked how Davis was doing, she said only, ``He's resting.'' Sinatra and his wife, Barbara, visited Davis on Monday. Davis' grandchild Sam Michael Garner was born Friday. Davis' daughter, Tracy Garner, delivered the 7-pound, 1-ounce boy at a Los Angeles hospital, Ms. Reynolds said. Davis, 64, was diagnosed with throat cancer in September. He underwent radiation treatment, but the cancer recurred and he turned to chemotherapy, which he completed March 13.

Hundreds of people flocked to the 3,200-acre ranch of pitcher Nolan Ryan to watch him sell off his beefmasters. The Texas Rangers hurler signed autographs and posed for snapshots with fans Sunday as about 500 head of his cattle were sold. When he isn't pitching, Ryan is a rancher, but he decided to sell a purebred herd because he can't devote the time it requires. Baseball, a growing family and a move to Arlington prompted Ryan to sell the beefmasters. ``I could tell things weren't going to slow down where I could give it the time and attention I needed to,'' Ryan said. He said he will keep less demanding commercial herds on two other Texas ranches he operates. Several hundred people _ some from as far away as California, Tennessee, Kentucky, Oklahoma and Louisiana _ came to consider buying the beefmasters. Gross sales: more than $500,000.

Moaning merchants and gawking passers-by greeted Hollywood's arrival in the Bronx for filming of ``The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' starring Tom Hanks as a bond dealer brought low by the Big Apple. There were cranes, trucks, traffic jams and plenty of stars Monday during filming at the courthouse. The movie is based on Tom Wolfe's best-selling novel of avarice, ego and corruption. And the flames of discontent did leap Monday as a 200-person movie crew worked. ``It's making everybody's life miserable,'' groused Nick Kavalos as movie trucks jammed the street outside his delicatessen. ``The bread guy had to park two blocks away and carry in my delivery.'' The courthouse and its players take a prominent role in the book, Wolfe's depiction of New York's lowlifes and high brows. Ed McCarthy, who works in the district attorney's office, couldn't find a parking space during the movie hubbub. ``I'm parked at a bus stop where some idiot will give me a ticket,'' he said. Bruce Willis, Morgan Freeman and Melanie Griffith are also in the movie.

Patti Page, whose 1950 recording of ``Tennessee Waltz'' is the second-biggest selling record ever, has been hospitalized with a sinus infection, her spokesman says. Page, 62, was admitted to Scripps Memorial Hospital last week after develping a high fever from dental surgery, Alan Eichler said Monday. She was listed in good condition. ``This not anything life-threatending by any means ... but it became so bad she had to go into the hospital,'' he said. The infection forced Page to cancel an appearance as a presenter in Wednesday's network TV broadcast of the Academy of Country Music Awards. Page is scheduled to be married May 12 to retired aerospace engineer Jerry J. Filiciotto. Page has sold more than 100 million records, including 8 million copies of ``Tennessee Waltz,'' which trails only Bing Crosby's ``White Christmas'' as the best-selling record ever.

The New Kids on the Block got a court order barring three companies from using the pop group's name and photographs in contests and promotions run on a 900-number telephone service. The order Monday from U.S. District Judge William D. Keller applies to Investex Investment Exchange Inc. and Media Promotions Inc., both of Florida, and clothing boutique operator Merry-Go-Round Enterprises Inc. of Delaware. New Kids on the Block still will pursue legal action against the companies, along with Star magazine and USA Today, to collect $81 million in damages for alleged trademark infringement, said the group's attorney, Philip Heller. Heller contends the companies used facts about the group and the group's name during telephone calls made to a 900 number. Star and USA Today stopped using the group's name before the injunction proceedings and were not part of the judge's order, Heller said.

Jimmy Stewart was treated to reverential speeches and affectionate anecdotes during a tribute to his wonderful life on film. ``I'm just grateful to you all,'' Stewart said after the Film Society of Lincoln Center show Monday night. ``It's so much more than I ever dreamed of,'' said the 81-year-old Stewart, who has won two Academy Awards. ``I ask God to bless all of you. And when he takes your lives into his editing room, I pray that he will be as kind to each of you as you've been to me tonight.'' George C. Scott, Dorothy Lamour, Maureen O'Hara, Janet Leigh, Robert Stack, June Allyson, Jack Lemmon, and Kim Novak paid tribute to Stewart. Scott said Stewart had the gift of making his roles unique. ``Can you imagine me, for instance, with a trombone, trying to convince somebody I was Glenn Miller?'' Scott asked. ``Not only have you filled our hearts but you've uplifted our spirits and you've nourished our souls.'' The tribute included clips from 23 of Stewart's films in which he sang, confessed to murder, talked to an invisible rabbit, kissed women and fought men.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks End Lower, Dollar Gains
DOC.TEXT: Shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange made up some of their early losses but ended lower Tuesday, while the dollar edged up against the Japanese yen. The dollar finished trading at 158.15 yen, up 0.60 yen from Monday's 157.55-yen close. It opened at 157.88 yen and ranged between 157.85 yen and 158.15 yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average, which was down 333.66 points at the end of the morning session, narrowed its loss to 177.69 points, or 0.59 percent, in the afternoon, ending the day at 29,501.38. On Monday, the index lost 156.37 points. The Nikkei index began recovering in the afternoon as market players began buying issues of Suzuki Motor Co., following a report that the company has invented a new substance to detect the AIDS virus, said Kazuhiro Nomura, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. ``There was little incentive to sell in the afternoon,'' he added. Toshiyuki Nishiguchi, a trader with Daiwa Securities, Co., attributed the morning decline to an upswing in Japanese government bond yields, as well as the market's wait-and-see mood ahead of a week of holidays that starts Apr. 28 for most Japanese companies. The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond fell to 86.01 Tuesday morning from 86.17 Monday. That raised the yield to 7.365 percent from 7.33 percent. Nishiguchi said the Nikkei fell as much as about 340 points within one hour during the morning when arbitrageurs sold spot issues in an attempt to take profits from price gaps between the spot and the futures markets. ``But after that, the index stopped falling any further, partly because there was no market-affecting news to move in either direction after a series of sellings,'' Nishiguchi said. Other traders said the the yen's weakness against the dollar and a decline on the New York stock market overnight depressed the Nikkei. In currency dealings, the dollar-yen rate was moving narrowly after the higher opening, which followed overnight gains by the dollar on overseas markets, said Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. The yen also weakened in tandem with the West German mark against the dollar, she said. ``But the dollar failed to rise further because many investors are inclined to sell it around the 158-yen line,'' she said. Many players sold marks against the dollar following Monday's announcement by West Germany that salaries and pensions denominated in East German marks would be converted to Western marks at a one-for-one rate, Takeuchi said. The plan was more generous than West Germany had indicated previously and has aroused concern about the possibility of higher inflation in Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Elizabeth Taylor in Intensive Care Unit
DOC.TEXT: A seriously ill Elizabeth Taylor battled pneumonia at her hospital, her breathing assisted by a ventilator, doctors say. Hospital officials described her condition late Monday as stabilizing after a lung biopsy to determine the cause of the pneumonia. Analysis of the tissue sample was expected to take until Thursday, said her spokeswoman, Chen Sam. The 58-year-old actress, who won best-actress Oscars for ``Butterfield 8'' and ``Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf,'' has been hospitalized more than two weeks. She was in the intensive care unit at St. John's Hospital and Health Center. ``She is seriously ill,'' her doctors said in a statement. ``After surgery, her breathing is now being assisted by a ventilator. Her condition is presently stabilizing and her physicians are pleased with her progress.'' Another spokewoman for the actress, Lisa Del Favaro, said Miss Taylor's family was at her bedside. She did not identify the family members. Miss Taylor entered Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital on April 9 with a persistent fever and sinus infection, doctors said. Her condition worsened and she was transferred April 16 to St. John's and moved into intensive care on Friday. ``It is serious, but they are really pleased with her progress. She's not well. She's not on her deathbed or anything,'' Ms. Sam said late Monday. While it is unusual to put a pneumonia patient on a ventilator, it does not mean that person is near death, said Dr. John G. Mohler, a University of Southern California lung disease expert who emphasized he had no direct knowledge of Miss Taylor's condition. Doctors may put a patient on a ventilator simply to restore oxygen in the blood to proper levels if pneumonia-related breathing difficulties have reduced those levels, Mohler said. ``It may be that because she is such a prominent person, they are taking a conservative course,'' he added. Miss Taylor has been plagued with health problems for years, particularly back troubles from filming of ``National Velvet' in 1945, when she fell off a horse. In 1983 she acknowledged a 35-year addiction to sleeping pills and painkillers. Miss Taylor has been treated for alcohol and drug abuse at the Betty Ford Clinic. During a nearly fatal bout with pneumonia in 1961, Miss Taylor underwent a tracheotomy, an incision into her windpipe to help her breathe. She appeared at the 1961 Academy Awards with a bandage over her scar as she accepted the ``Butterfield 8'' Oscar.

DOC.HEAD: Ralph David Abernathy Laid to Rest Amid Praise
LaserPhoto AX2
DOC.TEXT: A mule-drawn wagon carried the Rev. Ralph David Abernathy to his final resting place as his colleagues praised him for shouldering the burden of the civil rights movement for the past two decades. The famous and the humble crowded shoulder-to-shoulder into a church Monday for the four-hour service for the Martin Luther King Jr.'s chief lieutenant and closest friend. Abernathy died of a heart attack April 17 at age 64. State Rep. Tyrone Brooks said Abernathy ``was nailed to the cross'' in his efforts to hold King's coalition together after the civil rights leader's assassination in 1968. ``The assassination of Ralph David Abernathy began on April 5, 1968,'' Brooks said. ``He was crucified for 22 years.'' Afterward, two mules, pulling a wooden wagon bearing Abernathy's casket, set out from West Hunter Street Baptist Church, where Abernathy was pastor, for Lincoln Cemetery. King's body was carried to its resting place by a mule-drawn wagon in 1968 at the suggestion of Abernathy, who considered it symbolic of humility. Family members said Abernathy wanted the same for himself. Groups of people, some with children and pets, lined sidewalks as the wagon inched along amid 150 marchers, including Abernathy's sons, Kwame and state Rep. Ralph David Abernathy III, and civil rights associates Andrew Young and Jesse Jackson. More than 3,000 people were on the cemetery grounds waiting to file through a chapel there to touch the casket and lay flowers beside it before it was placed in a mausoleum. At the chapel, mourners cheered as one of Abernathy's daughters, Donzaleigh Abernathy Bosley, told them her father's last words were, ``I'm alive, I'm alive, I'm alive forevermore.'' Some of Abernathy's colleagues who had branded him a Judas months ago for writing of King's alleged marital infidelity in his memoirs were themselves rebuked during the funeral. Brooks said the civil rights movement should be proud instead of embarrassed by Abernathy's autobiography, ``And The Walls Came Tumbling Down.'' Brooks, a student activist during the 1960s, stood in the pulpit above Abernathy's rose-covered coffin and waved a copy of the book. He urged the crowd of 2,500 to read it. ``It was not a mistake,'' Brooks said. ``It is the truth. All 636 pages.'' Among those present were King's widow, Coretta Scott King, and three of her children; Benjamin Hooks, head of the NAACP; U.S. Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga.; Robert Kennedy Jr., and Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan. Jackson said Abernathy's accomplishments far outweigh any disagreement that came as a result of his memoirs. ``One cannot judge a player by one exceptional play ... nor can a player be judged by an error,'' Jackson said. ``Ralph Abernathy is in the hall of fame. We must pay homage and thanks.'' Ralph David Abernathy III, his voice breaking with emotion, compared his father to the Bible's David, saying he slew ``the Goliath of racism.'' ``I am the son of a giant slayer,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``The United States is going to have to make its position ... absolutely clear. We can't be fuzzy about this.'' _ House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Dante Fascell on an independent Lithuania.

``I said to myself, `There goes that Amtrak making that stupid noise. But instead of going clickety, clickety, clack, it was making a clickety, clickety, clunk. I looked out the window and thought, `Lord, I hope nobody was killed.''' _ Paula Stater, who lives near the Batavia, Iowa, tracks where an Amtrak train derailed, injuring at least 91 people.

``Instead of eating your oatmeal, there's no reason why you can't drink it in the morning, and then you're off to work.'' _ federal food scientist George E. Inglett, principal inventor of a new, low-fat ice cream made with oat bran.

DOC.HEAD: Harvard Law Professor Threatening to Leave Until Black is Hired
DOC.TEXT: Derrick Bell, Harvard Law School's first black tenured professor, is threatening to take a leave of absence without pay until a black woman is added to the faculty. Bell, who first taught at what is considered the nation's premier law school in 1969, was expected to announce his leave today, said Keith Boykin, a spokesman for the student Coalition for Civil Rights. Students at the law school have been staging protests demanding more minority faculty members. Harvard Law has five black professors, three of them tenured, out of a faculty of more than 60, Bell said Monday. ``I cannot in good conscience continue in a role that limits rather than expands faculty diversity,'' he said in a statement for release today. ``I cannot continue to urge students to take risks for what they believe if I do not practice my own precepts.'' Prior to the noon rally at which Bell was to make his announcement, he and the law school administration were to hold talks over the hiring of a black woman. Bell said Harvard has only five female law professors, none black. Bell and the student coalition are urging the school hire Regina Austin, a black woman who is a visiting professor at Harvard. Austin has been offered a permanent post at the University of Michigan, Boykin said. Bell is a former member of the Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee, a civil rights group. He first taught at the law school in 1969 but left in 1980 to become dean of the University of Oregon Law School. Bell returned to Harvard in 1986 as the law school's only tenured black professor. Last May, during student sit-ins to protest what they called a lack of diversity on the faculty, some students pushed to have Bell named dean of the law school. Bell put the number of minority students at the school at 400, with fewer than 200 of those black. Harvard Law School has about 1,500 students. ``The students have been urging greater diversity. I guess it's been happening in many other places around the country,'' he said Monday. ``Thus far, there has not been very much in the way of positive response to demands given the administration a couple of months ago.''

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Officials, Farm Workers Group Sign Benefits Pact
DOC.TEXT: An agreement that would provide dependents of migrant workers with government health care in Mexico has been signed by the Mexican government and the United Farm Workers. The pact was signed by UFW President Cesar Chavez and Ricardo Garcia Sainz, director general of the Mexican Social Security Institute, in the presence of Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. Salinas was in Los Angeles on Monday to speak at the annual Associated Press luncheon. ``It has not been possible for the union to protect members' families in Mexico with the union's medical plan here,'' Chavez said. ``Now, with this pact, they are able to get universal medical care at a very reasonable price.'' Chavez said he had worked on the proposal for 17 years and believes at least 100,000 dependents of migrant workers will be covered by the Mexican government in the first year of the agreement. The worker, the spouse, the children and worker's parents or grandparents in their absence will be covered, Chavez said. Each worker will pay between $160 to $200 a year to help defray the health care costs in Mexico, he said. The services will include primary health care, specialists, surgery, hospitalization, dental and vision care, obstetrics, medication, X-ray and other diagnostic tests. ``This places on us the responsibility to respond with work, with determination, with the full recognition that the well-being of their families rests on our shoulders and that we must always watch over it,'' Garcia said. ``With the protection which the Social Security will give to their families, wherever they may live, the quality of life will be enhanced and great opportunities for development will be opened,'' he said. Chavez said the agreement will be extremely beneficial to thousands of workers who legally cross the border into the United States for work daily and who are not covered in Mexico. ``I think this will be a good thing if it works,'' said migrant worker Ramon Perez, who has a wife and two children in Morelia, Mexico, about 200 miles northwest of Mexico City. ``Right now, we send them money any chance we can so they can buy food and clothes and for medical care,'' said Perez, who was among 50 UFW workers who witnessed the signing of the agreement in a hotel conference room.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Roll in Plains, Fair Skies in Central United States
DOC.TEXT: Fair skies prevailed over much of the nation today, but summer-like weather got thunderstorms rolling in the Great Plains and the Mississippi Valley. Warm and humid weather in the central United States on Monday produced temperatures in the 80s and 90s and hail in parts of Texas, Arkansas, Minnesota, Oklahoma and Florida. A thunderstorm in Minnesota spawned a tornado near the town of Benson. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered across the upper Mississippi Valley, with the strongest stretching from Iowa into Wisconsin. The northern Rockies and the central Pacific Coast also got rain Monday, but skies were fair from the Carolinas to the northern Atlantic Coast. Thunderstorms were forecast in Kansas, western Texas and Oklahoma today after tennis ball-size hail fell in Garden City, Texas, and golf ball-size hail dropped on the Texas town of Dryden and Swan Lake in Arkansas. A thunderstorm hit Minneapolis-St. Paul early today. Skies were cloudy in Miami; Fort Worth, Texas; San Antonio; Fairbanks, Alaska, and Las Vegas. Temperatures climbed Monday into the 90s in North Dakota, Minnesota and Texas. The nation's high was 94 in Presidio, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Emergency Operation Can't Save Infant Elephant
LaserPhoto SUC2
DOC.TEXT: Veterinarians undertook an emergency Caesarean section on a 36-year-old Asian elephant, but the 266-pound calf was removed dead. Officials at the Burnet Park Zoo said Monday they weren't sure why the calf, a male, died. The position of the calf's head had prevented the mother, Babe, from delivering naturally, making the C-section necessary. ``Until the fetus came out of the uterus, it was a coin toss,'' said Zoo Director Dave Raboy, who gave the go-ahead for the four-hour operation Monday by a medical team from Cornell University and zoos around the country. The 7,700-pound Babe would have been been the oldest first-time elephant mother to give birth in a North American zoo. She went into labor Wednesday. It was the third C-section tried on an Asian elephant, and only one of the operations was successful, said zoo spokeswoman Yvette Pelletreau. In preparation for surgery, Burnet Park had gathered two king-size mattresses, a one-ton chain hoist to lift the calf and two five-ton chain hoists to lift Babe. The zoo world followed Babe's pregnancy because of the rarity of captive births by Asian elephants, an endangered species that numbers fewer than 45,000 in the wild. There have been just 62 births in captivity. Raboy said it was possible Babe, who was back on her feet hours after the operation, could give birth again. Female elephants can breed into their 60s. ``We have high hopes for the future. She's in superb condition,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: End-of-the-World Group Ordered to Stop Building Fallout Shelters
DOC.TEXT: A religious sect girding for apocalypse has been ordered by a judge to stop building fallout shelters near Yellowstone National Park after thousands of gallons of fuel leaked from underground tanks. The order Monday came on the day that began what the church's spiritual leader says is a 12-year ``dark cycle'' of global danger and catastrophe, from which the shelters are to protect 750 followers. The order, requested by the state Friday, bars the Church Universal and Triumphant from continuing construction on the shelters near Corwin Springs, where the church has its headquarters. District Judge Byron Robb set a hearing May 3 on the matter. An estimated 31,000 gallons of diesel and gasoline leaked recently from three tanks at the shelter complex. State officials want work to stop pending an environmental review. The complex is surrounded by at least 35 underground tanks that can hold 634,500 gallons of diesel, gasoline, heating oil and antifreeze. Church spiritual leader Elizabeth Clare Prophet has prophesied that planetary karma _ ``the cumulative weight of mankind's sins'' _ has been building for 25,800 years and would fully descend on Earth as of Monday to begin a ``dark cycle'' of danger that will last 12 years. In the past, Prophet said, cataclysm occurred when enough bad karma accumulated. She said she remembers in a previous life the continent of Lemuria ``breaking up in flames'' and sinking beneath the Pacific Ocean. This time, she said, the bad karma could manifest itself in economic collapse, nuclear war or accident, plague or great earthquakes.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down, Dollar Up in Japan
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index closed lower today despite an afternoon rally, while the dollar rose against the Japanese yen after a three-day decline. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average, down 333.66 points at the end of the morning session, ended with a loss of 177.69 points, or 0.59 percent, closing at 29,501.38. On Monday, the index fell 156.37 points. The Nikkei began recovering in the afternoon as investors bought shares in Suzuki Motor Co. after a report that it had invented a new blood testing machine to detect the AIDS virus, said Kazuhiro Nomura, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. Suzuki said today it developed the machine jointly with Dinabot, a Japanese subsidiary of Abbott Laboratories, a major U.S. pharmaceutical company. ``There was little selling incentive in the afternoon, when some investors picked up issues of companies with positive prospects,'' Nomura said. But trading was thin, with first section volume estimated at 480 million shares, up from 330 million the previous day. Toshiyuki Nishiguchi, a trader with Daiwa Securities Co., attributed the index's early decline to a rise in Japanese government bond yields, as well as the market's wait-and-see mood before a week of holidays that starts April 28 for most Japanese companies. The price of the benchmark No.119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 85.82 points, down from Monday's close of 86.17. Their yield reached 7.405 percent, up from 7.330 percent on Monday. Traders said arbitrageurs also were selling spot issues in an attempt to make profits from price gaps between the spot and the futures markets. Issues that attracted investors included food and pharmaceuticals. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 158.15 yen, up 0.60 yen from Monday's 157.55-yen close. It opened at 157.88 yen and ranged between 157.85 yen and 158.15 yen. The dollar had declined 2.32 yen in the previous three trading days. The yen weakened slightly as market players sold the West German mark against the dollar after West Germany's announcement Monday that salaries and pensions denominated in East German marks would be converted to West German marks at a 1-for-1 rate in the planned monetary unification, dealers said. ``But the dollar did not rise quickly as many investors sold the currency for profit-taking at around 158 yen,'' said Hisashi Matsuda, a dealer with Daiwa Bank. He said some investors bought dollars based on news of growing oil shortages in Lithuania caused by a Soviet economic embargo, but most market participants were more interested in East-West German developments. The dollar is considered a safe investment refuge in times of economic or political uncertainty. The mark is still attractive to many investors because of expectations of higher West German interest rates in the near future, dealers said.

DOC.HEAD: City Makes Accordion San Francisco's Official Instrument
DOC.TEXT: The much-maligned accordion is the official instrument of San Francisco. The Board of Supervisors voted 6-4 Monday in favor of the raspy squeezebox despite a last-minute bid by violin fanciers. Fans of the accordion said the instrument is just what the city needs after the October earthquake. The message is ``we're a lighthearted and bohemian city,'' said accordion player ``Big Lou.'' Accordion players, who started their pitch several months ago by wheezing away on the steps of City Hall, wanted their instrument recognized for historical reasons. ``The first piano accordion made in America was made in San Francisco,'' said Normal Kaline, whose Italian immigrant father, Finau Piatanesi, claimed credit for the feat in 1908. The instrument plummeted in popularity with the advent of rock `n' roll but is now making a comeback, said Tom Torriglia, who plays with the local group Those Darn Accordions! He noted that the group Aerosmith features an accordion in a new song and that Billy Joel used one in recent San Francisco Bay area concerts. But all was not harmony among the music lovers. ``With all due respect to the accordion and to all my ancestors who came here with the accordion, we also are the home of the oldest violin factory in the United States,'' said Supervisor Angela Alioto, who voted against the resolution. The resolution needs Mayor Art Agnos' signature to become official, but press secretary Scott Shafer said, ``How could he object to the accordion?''

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Premier Meets With Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: Premier Li Peng, the first Chinese head of government to visit Moscow in 26 years, met today with Mikhail S. Gorbachev after stressing that both countries have the right to tailor reforms to their own needs. Li's four-day trip is meant to promote good relations and ease border tensions at a time when both countries, longtime rivals for leadership of the communist world, are confronted with serious domestic problems. On Monday, the 61-year-old premier noted in a speech at a Kremlin dinner given in his honor that the Soviet Union and China share a 4,300-mile-long border. ``Both are socialist countries and conduct reform and perestroika in accordance with the realities of their countries,'' Peng said in remarks reported by Tass, the official Soviet news agency. He went on to tell the dignitaries gathered in the Grand Kremlin Palace that his country was committed to developing friendly ties with the Soviet Union, despite differences. ``The reality in China and the Soviet Union are different, and both sides have dissimilar views on a number of questions,'' he acknowledged. Peng did not identify the areas of disagreement, but Western diplomats in Beijing said China has stressed it will never again be the docile Soviet ally it was in the 1950s, and they noted that China's suspicions of Soviet aims have grown with Gorbachev's reform policies. The ideological hard-liners who now rule China reportedly blame Gorbachev for the fall of Communist regimes in Eastern Europe and see perestroika _ Gorbachev's reform program _ as leading to the demise of socialism. Li was expected to hold at least two rounds of talks with Gorbachev, who went to China in May. It was the first visit by a Soviet leader in three decades. Tass said on this trip, the two delegations would sign an agreement on cooperation through the year 2,000 in nuclear energy, space exploration, wood processing, agriculture and metallurgy. Gorbachev's historic visit to China was overshadowed by student-led pro-democracy demonstrations in Beijing, which ended weeks later when Li and other Chinese leaders sent in troops to crush the movement. In Moscow, Gorbachev now is contending with the crisis in Lithuania, which declared independence March 11. China and the Soviet Union split over ideological differences in 1960 and fought a brief border war in 1969. In 1972, China restored relations with the United States, in part because then-leader Mao Tse-tung saw the Soviet Union as China's most serious military threat. The last Chinese premier to visit Moscow was Li's foster father, Chou-En-lai, who met Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev in 1964.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Pledges $3.6 Million For Holocaust Survivor Counseling
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's health minister says his country will contribute $3.6 million to an Israeli foundation that provides psychological counseling for Holocaust survivors. The announcement came Monday as East Germany ended two days of remembrance for the six million Jews killed by Nazis during World War II. ``We remember in this moment that six million Jews were murdered in Germany's name,'' Health Minister Juergen Kleditzsch said in an address to nearly 400 people in East Berlin's Synagogue Rykestrasse. ``The uniqueness of the murder of the Jews, which defies comparison or settling of accounts, poses an obligation for the politics of our country.,'' He said his government would contibute $3.6 million toward the establishment of an East German committee of Israel's Amcha foundation, which provides counseling for Holocaust survivors. For decades, Communist East German governments refused to accept responsibility for the Holocaust, saying Communists fought against the Nazi regime and had themselves been victims of Nazi persecution. But on April 12, the country's first freely elected Parliament said the state was prepared to make reparations to Holocaust victims and urged the establishment of diplomatic ties with Israel. West Germany has apologized for Nazi atrocities and paid about $49.7 billion in reparations to Jews. Israel has demanded that East Germany likewise accept moral responsibility for the Holocaust, and agree to pay reparations before diplomatic relations can be established. Holocaust Remembrance Day began Sunday when Jews around the world gathered to mourn the death of the six million.

DOC.HEAD: McKernan Launches Re-Election Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Gov. John R. McKernan has announced he will seek re-election, boasting he has accomplished more than his Democratic predecessor and would-be successor. ``Being governor is knowing where you want the state to go, and it's delivering results,'' the Republican said Monday. He said his administration had done more in four years to protect the environment, help working families and fight drugs than was achieved in the previous eight years under Democrat Joseph E. Brennan, who is seeking a comeback. Neither McKernan, 41, nor Brennan, 55, is opposed for nomination in the June 12 primary elections. Brennan is ending his second term in Congress. Maine Democratic Chairwoman Keron Kerr issued a statement calling McKernan's administration ``the most incompetent ... in modern Maine history.'' Kerr said the taxpayers are ``on a financial rollercoaster,'' with rebates followed by a severe revenue shortfall.

DOC.HEAD: Discovery Readied for Launch With Space Telescope
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 4 grafs with all astronauts aboard, pickup 5th bgng ``The $1.5 billion,'' inserts new graf after 8th bgng ``Columbia, which'' to include that Hubble has been delayed since 1983; minor editing changes below.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto covering
DOC.TEXT: Five astronauts boarded Discovery today for a second try at sending the Hubble Space Telescope into orbit to scan the outermost reaches of the universe for clues to the beginning of time. ``Astronomers are starting to tingle again in anticipation of what the Hubble will be able to accomplish,'' said Lennard Fisk, head of NASA science activities. Air Force forecasters said there was a 90 percent chance the weather would be favorable for launching the shuttle at the scheduled time of 8:31 a.m. EDT. More than a half million gallons of liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen were pumped into the space ship's fuel tanks after midnight. The astronauts, wearing bright orange flight suits, climbed into the crew cabin just as dawn was breaking over the Kennedy Space Center. The $1.5 billion telescope, NASA's costliest cargo, will give astronomers ``a new set of eyes and ears that we don't have,'' said William Lenoir, head of NASA's space flight program. ``It's going to change our perspective altogether. I can't say what we're going to learn, but I'll be astounded if we don't learn many new things.'' Discovery was aiming for an altitude of 380 miles, the highest a shuttle has ever gone, so the telescope can be placed in its proper orbit far above Earth's distorting atmosphere. It is the 35th shuttle mission. Columbia, which journeys into space next month with the Astro observatory, sat on a launch pad 1.6 miles from Discovery, only the second time both pads have been occupied; the first was in 1986 just before the Challenger explosion. Hubble has been waiting to take its place in space since 1983, delayed by technical problems and the Challenger accident. The latest postponement occurred April 10, when Discovery's launch was scrubbed four minutes before liftoff because of a faulty power unit on the shuttle. The mood at the Kennedy Space Center was considerably less festive than during the first launch attempt, when hundreds of astronomers gathered with their families. The day after launch, mission specialist Steven A. Hawley will use the shuttle's mechanical arm to lift the 24,250-pound telescope into space. Veteran spacewalkers Bruce McCandless II and Kathryn Sullivan will assist if a problem develops. Discovery will follow Hubble from 40 miles away for two days until after its lens cap is opened, exposing the finely polished 94.5-inch mirror to starlight. Hubble is not expected to start providing scientific data by satellite for a month or more after liftoff. However, NASA said it will release its first image _ an open star cluster in the constellation Carina _ a week after launch. In addition to the $1.5 billion cost of Hubble, $500 million has been spent on spare parts, astronaut training and computer software to operate the instrument. The European Space Agency contributed $250 million for 15 percent of the viewing time. NASA estimates it will cost $200 million a year to operate and maintain the telescope in space. During its 15-year working lifetime, the telescope will provide astronomers with 10 times better resolution and 25 times more sensitivity than ground-based observatories. As a result, they will be able to study stars and galaxies so distant their light has been traveling toward Earth for 14 billion years. Astronomers hope to learn whether the universe was created 15 billion years ago as believed and uncover some of the mystery surrounding galaxies, black holes and quasars. Hubble also is expected to shed light on how and when the universe might end. The telescope is named for the late astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, who discovered during the 1920s that the universe is expanding. His work gave rise to the Big Bang theory that the universe was created by a tremendous explosion. In addition to Hubble, Discovery carries a human skull filled with sensors to measure the space radiation that astronauts receive. It is the skull's third trip into space. The shuttle is to end its five-day mission with a landing at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Garbo Named Niece as Sole Beneficiary
DOC.TEXT: Greta Garbo named her niece as her sole beneficiary, the actress' law firm disclosed. The niece, Grae Reisfield, the daughter of Garbo's only brother, Sven, is the wife of a gynecologist and a resident of Passaic, N.J. She was described Monday as Miss Garbo's ``closest surviving relative, friend and confidante'' by Theodore A. Kurz, head of the trusts and estates department at the law firm Debevoise & Plimpton. The body of the 84-year-old Miss Garbo was cremated April 15, the day after she died. The law firm said in a statement that no funeral had been held and that final arrangements were incomplete. Kurz disputed published reports the reclusive screen star had left no will. No details of the will were released except that it will be filed in New York City. The New York Post has said Garbo's fiscal prudence helped her build up a sizable estate, consisting of several buildings in Beverly Hills, an extensive art collection and the Manhattan co-op where she lived. Film scholar Raymond Baum, one of Garbo's few friends, said Garbo's seven-room co-op was filled with 18th-century antiques, fine rugs, damask curtains and many pieces of art, including a Renoir.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Stable, Gold Up, in Quiet Trading
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was stable in quiet trading today. Gold prices rose slightly. Traders said they were waiting for new U.S. first quarter gross national product figures to be released on Friday. The figures were expected to confirm strong growth, and scope for higher U.S. interest rates. On the political front, President Bush was expected to focus international attention to the problems in Lithuania by announcing limited sanctions against the Soviet Union later today. The increase in tension between the United States and the Soviet Union was likely to propel the dollar higher as a safe haven currency, some traders said. A stronger trend for the dollar ``is very much the tone of the market,'' said Paul Brewer, a senior dealer at Salomon Brothers in London. However, he noted that turnover remains fairly subdued and there is little sign that investors are prepared to start taking any large positions at this stage. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.60 yen to a closing 158.15 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 158.67 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: _1.6977 West German marks, up from 1.6960 _1.4895 Swiss francs, down from 1.4925 _5.6945 French francs, up from 5.6930 _1.9130 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9090 _1,245.00 Italian lire, up from 1,244.00 _1.1625 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1610 In London, the dollar rose against the British pound, which was quoted at $1.6333, compared with $1.6365 late Monday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $377.75 a troy ounce, up from $376.25 bid late Monday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $377.95. In Zurich, the bid price was $377.75, up from $375.85 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.99 to close at a bid $378.97. Silver was unchanged in London at a bid price of $5.09 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Union to Organize Flights For Moslem Pilgrims to Mecca
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has ordered special flights this year for Moslems who want to travel to Saudi Arabia for the annual pilgrimage to Mecca, a government spokesman said. Monday's announcement was the latest move by the Soviet leadership to placate the country's 50 million Moslems _ a group that has become increasingly strident as it grows in size. The Soviet Union has no diplomatic relations with Saudi Arabia, but Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze has been asked to contact the Saudi government make final arrangments for the flights and visas, said presidential spokesman Arkady Maslennikov. Speaking at a briefing for foreign journalists on Monday, Maslennikov said Gorbachev had asked Aeroflot, the Soviet carrier, to arrange special flights from Moscow, Kazan, Baku, Tashkent and other cities in Soviet Central Asia for the Moslem pilgrims. Millions of Moslems from around the world make the hajj pilgrimage to Mecca during the annual rites that take place in late June and early July. However, only a handful of Soviet Moslems have been allowed to make the hajj in past years, usually specially selected worshipers, and not on direct flights to the oil-rich kingdom. There have been outbreaks of violence between Moslems and Christians in the Soviet Union, most notably in territorial disputes between the republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan. Militant Azerbaijanis have rioted along the nearly 500-mile border with Iran, demanding reunification with their ethnic brethren in northern Iran. Since the 1979 revolution in Iran, Soviet officials have expressed concern about Islamic fundamentalism creeping across the border. However, in 1989, the Kremlin agreed to foster contacts between religious leaders in the Soviet Union and those in Iran. Maslennikov said diplomatic relations between the Soviet Union and Saudi Arabia were not necessary for the special arrangement, ``but if diplomatic relations are established in the future, I would consider it to be of mutual benefit to both sides.'' Saudi Arabia and Moscow had full diplomatic relations until 1938, when dictator Josef Stalin closed his embassy in a cost-cutting move. Several attempts during the 1980s to re-establish ties faltered over what Saudia Arabia called a ``belligerent attitude'' toward Soviet Moslems.

DOC.HEAD: Chamorro Also Will Hold Defense Minister's Post
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs to UPDATE with Ortega comment.
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro will also take over as defense minister when she assumes power on Wednesday, according to her family's newspaper. The paper, La Prensa, said the move would ``calm the spirits'' of both the ledership of Mrs. Chamorro's coalition and the Sandinista army's high command, which would find it ``very difficult to swallow the naming of another person.'' Questions have persisted about whether the Sandinistas, who dominated the country's political life for a decade until their defeat in Feb. 25 elections, are truly willing to forgo control of the military and security forces. On Monday, the Sandinista Front said in a statement that Defense Minister Humberto Ortega had quit the party's nine-member directorate. That left open the possibility that the brother of outgoing President Daniel Ortega might be allowed to remain army chief. The Sandinista statement said that all other officers in the Sandinista People's Army and the Interior Ministry, which controls security forces, had quit leadership posts in the party. A March 23 agreement between Mrs. Chamorro's advisers and the Sandinistas banned military officers from holding posts in political parties. At the same time, the incoming administration agreed to ``respect the professional status'' of the Sandinista army. The idea was to prevent the Sandinistas from keeping control of the military. The Contra rebels, who have been fighting the Sandinistas for nine years, have resisted demobilizing unless the army is purged of Sandinista functionaries. Leaders of the U.S.-backed rebels have agreed to heed Mrs. Chamorro's call and disband by June 10, but there is some dissent in the ranks. Many Contras have expressed fear that the president-elect will not have firm authority over the army, that the latest changes will not remove the army from Sandinista control. Some Contras want their officers to replace Sandinista officers, which could lead to conflict with still-militant Sandinistas. An estimated 9,000 Contras are inside Nicaragua and are expected to move into cease-fire zones, where they are to turn in their weapons under U.N. supervision. In Monday's report, La Prensa listed the makeup of Mrs. Chamorro's Cabinet, which it said was chosen on Sunday during a daylong closed meeting of the leadership of the president-elect's United National Opposition coalition (UNO). The newspaper said the ministers would include Enrique Dreyfus, the former president of the Superior Council of Private Enterprise, as foreign minister; Antonio Lacayo, the president-elect's son-in-law and close aide, as presidential minister; and Carlos Hurtado as interior minister. Others listed were Francisco Rosales, as labor minister; Silvio de Franco, finance; Jaime Cuadra, agriculture; Gilberto Cuadra, construction and transport; Sofonias Cisneros, education; Ernesto Salmeron, health; Silviano Matamoros, social welfare; and Francisco Mayorga, central bank president An official announcement of Cabinet positions was expected later today. That Cabinet will inherit an economy in shambles that was hurt over the years by a now-ended U.S. embargo and ineffectual Sandinista policies. Inflation last year was 1,800 percent, and the foreign debt is $7 billion. Further complicating the task is the absence of consensus on how to approach such problems among leaders of UNO _ a coalition of 14 parties spanning the political spectrum and generally united only in their pre-election desire to topple the Sandinistas. The Sandinistas, who received 40 percent of the vote in the February elections, are still the country's biggest single political party. Nicaragua has been ruled by autocratic and oppressive governments much of the time since it gained independence in 1821. Today, outgoing president Daniel Ortega said of political changes in Nicaragua: ``I am happy because we are forging a democratic process that was not previously known in Nicaragua.'' But, in an interview with NBC, he said leaving office was tough: ``It does hurt, not so much for me but for my party.'' ``There are some people who believe we gave up too much. ... but it seems to me that only time will tell if what I have done as president was correct,'' Ortega said.

DOC.HEAD: Nevada Ranchers Await Crickets as Spraying Delayed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `The insects...' to CORRECT to foot sted inch.
DOC.TEXT: Millions of ravenous Mormon crickets so big and barbed-legged that they stick in the craw of predator birds have invaded Nevada in the worst infestation since the 1930s, worrying ranchers and farmers. The federal government has joined the battle to protect the region's alfalfa but had to postpone the start of aerial spraying Monday because of rain. ``I got my own guy out there killing crickets because I don't want to wait for the government to help,'' said Eldon Crawford, a rancher near Golconda whose fields sit below canyons thick with the insects, which can grow to the size of a mouse. ``I've had them for the past three years, but this is the worst. I don't know how strong they're going to get. They're just babies now.'' The insects cover some 700,000 acres in five counties of north-central Nevada in the worst infestation since the '30s, with crickets counted at 100 per square foot in the worst areas, near Winnemucca, said Dick Rowe, coordinator for the Nevada Department of Agriculture's Plant Industry program. Rowe said the crickets are about three quarters of an inch long but will grow up to two inches within the next month as they start a hungry march across Nevada, eating everything in sight. ``They haven't damaged any cropland yet,'' he said. ``But the federal government is putting on another crew to poison them within a couple of days. Right now things are looking good. But it can very easily get out of hand pretty quick.'' Several dry winters and a lack of natural predators _ the crickets get caught in the craw of gulls and other birds _ created perfect conditions for the infestation, experts said. The juice-spitting insects, which can bite humans if disturbed, got their name from an infestation in Utah in the 1800s. Legend has it gulls from Salt Lake City ate the crickets to save the area from destruction. For the past couple of weeks, the state Agriculture Department has spread poison bran bait near hatching sites at the mouths of canyons near Winnemucca, 160 miles from Reno. Martin Larraneta, department district chief, said ground and aerial poisoning should control the crickets. ``The idea is to stop them before they get to the farms and come into town,'' he said. ``I don't think it'll get that bad.'' George Nash, head of the federal Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service plant disease and quarantine operation, estimated it would cost $15 per acre for control measures. Farmers and ranchers will pay half the cost on private land; the U.S. government, which controls most of the affected land, will pick up the tab on public property.

DOC.HEAD: EDITORS:
DOC.TEXT: NASA has stopped the clock at 31 seconds before launch. We will advise.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Museum Pulls Famed Lennon Photo from Art Exhibit
DOC.TEXT: A photograph of the late singer John Lennon showing him nude and in a fetal position was pulled from an art exhibit by museum trustees, who said it clashed with the show's theme. The portrait, taken in 1980 by photographer Annie Leibovitz, shows the ex-Beatle next to his wife, Yoko Ono, who is fully clothed. Trustees at the city-owned Muckenthaler Cultural Center decided to remove it from an exhibit that opened Saturday. Beverly Gunter, chairwoman of the center's board of trustees, said Monday the trustees decided the work was not appropriate to the exhibit's theme, ``Heroes, Heroines, Idols and Icons.'' ``It doesn't express `hero,' it expresses `anti-hero,''' Gunter said. ``To me, to fit the hero show, something about the work should be somehow a character strength.'' The Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati and its director, Dennis Barrie, have been indicted on misdemeanor obscenity charges for an exhibit there of photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe that include homoerotic images and naked children. ``I realize it might raise some questions, but it has nothing to do with the Mapplethorpe issues,'' Gunter said Monday. ``I was just trying to think of the appropriateness of the show. It only had to do with a question on content of the show and my criterion was the theme.''
