Norman Lloyd, the show's curator, said he wanted to include the Lennon photograph because it illustrated an argument by the late philosopher Joseph Campbell that the process of maturing is itself a heroic act. ``It shows John Lennon in a very vulnerable position,'' Lloyd said. ``It's basically that he hasn't grown up. It's a very elegant photograph and shows that struggle people have of breaking away.'' A portrait of the late artist Keith Haring, nude but covered with body paint that matches the background, was included in the show. The Muckenthaler show includes artwork by 25 artists, including Thomas Hart Benton, Andy Warhol and Jasper Johns. Fullerton is a city of 110,000 people about 25 miles southeast of Los Angeles in affluent Orange County.

DOC.HEAD: Factory Orders Jump 6.7 Percent in March
DOC.TEXT: Orders to U.S. factories for durable goods jumped 6.7 percent in March, the sharpest increase in two years, the government said today. The Commerce Department reported that orders for durable goods _ ``big-ticket'' items expected to last at least three years _ totaled a seasonally adjusted $128.8 billion in March following a 2.3 percent upward bounce in February. It was the largest increase in orders since a 7.4 percent gain in December 1988. And it continued for a second month the rebound from January's 10.5 percent decline, the steepest drop ever recorded. The department said most of the boost was due to increased orders for transportation equipment, saying that excluding transportation, the advance was only 2.0 percent. ``The increase in transportation equipment in March of ... 21.0 percent to $36.2 billion was mostly attributable to aircraft and parts, although motor vehicles and parts also had a significant increase,'' it said. The gain in transportation orders was the sharpest since a 22.1 percent advance in December 1988. The closely watched non-defense capital goods sector, often a barometer of business investment plans, jumped 14.9 percent to $41.4 billion after diving 6.1 percent in February. Sharp drops in airplane and automobile orders were responsible for the record decline in January, the department reported. Aircraft orders continued to slide in February, but a resumption in autobuilding helped pushed total orders up. The department counts car orders and production as the same. The auto industry had laid off more than 90,000 workers during January to ease bloated inventories. Most of those workers returned to production lines in February. The January report had been viewed as another sign of weakness in the manufacturing sector of the economy. That sector has been particularly affected by high-interest polices of the Federal Reserve since many of the ``big-ticket'' items are financed by loans. But the March report shows that most of that loss has been regained. New orders for defense capital goods, a highly volatile category, fell 4.5 percent to $7.3 billion after gaining 18.4 percent in February. Excluding defense, orders rose 7.5 percent. Orders for primary metals were up 7.0 percent to $11.7 billion. Non-electrical machinery orders rose 1.6 percent to $22.7 billion while orders for electrical machinery gained 1.1 percent to $20.1 billion. Shipments of durable goods were up 1.5 percent to $125 billion while unfilled orders rose 0.8 percent to $496.7 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Thousands Mark Armenian Genocide
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of thousands of Armenians flocked to a hillside memorial in Yerevan today to mark the killing of more than a million of their people 75 years ago under Ottoman Turkish rule, residents said. Meanwhile, in Jerusalem's Old City 300 Armenians marched to mark the anniversary. About 1.5 million Armenians were killed between 1915 and 1923, citizens of the Soviet republic say. Beginning at dawn today, Armenians marched toward the memorial in Yerevan, the republic's capital, waiting up to three hours to lay flowers near its eternal flame, said Raffi Hovannisian, of the Armenian Assembly of America. Black flags and red-orange-and-blue Armenian national flags flew from many of the city's buildings, he said from Yerevan. ``These people are looking into the past at the genocide, seeing in some respect that it's been repeated in Sumgait and Baku and elsewhere, and yet still looking into the future,'' Hovannisian said. ``There's a combination of grief and commitment.'' Scores of Armenians died in ethnic attacks in the Azerbaijani cities of Sumgait two years ago and Baku this winter. Sporadic fighting continues between Armenians and Azerbaijanis in the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh. About 3 million Armenians live in the Soviet republic, and 1.5 million live abroad. Hovannisian said as many as 2 million were expected to participate in memorial processions and ceremonies. In Jerusalem, marchers carried wreathes and candles as they walked from the walled Armenian quarter to the community's nearby cemetery. Armenian Church Patriarch Torkum Manoogian, wearing a black hood and a crimson robe, led the procession. Dozens of teen-age marchers wore shirts emblazoned with the words ``April 24, 1915,'' and many carried posters with slogans such as ``End Turkish occupation of Armenia'' and ``Struggle is born with every Armenian.'' About 7,000 Armenians live in Israel, the occupied West Bank and the community's walled quarter in Jerusalem's Old City. The campaign to exterminate the Armenians began late in the 19th century under Ottoman Sultan Abd Al-Hamid II. It was stepped up in 1915 when the Armenians were accused of helping Russian invaders during World War I. The Turkish government has a different account of the Armenian deaths. Turkish officials maintain that between 300,000 and 600,000 Armenians died, most of famine or disease during forced deportation to Syria and Iraq. The issue, dormant for decades, was resurrected in the 1970s when Armenian extremists began more than a decade of attacks against Turkish diplomats abroad, saying they were avenging the massacre of their ancestors.

DOC.HEAD: Liberty Island Concessioner Dead At 88
DOC.TEXT: Evelyn Hill, who ran concession stands at the Statue of Liberty for over 50 years and once lived at Liberty's feet, has died at the age of 88. She died Monday at St. Joseph's Hospital when her heart stopped, authorities said. Mrs. Hill became a concessionaire on Liberty Island, then called Bedloes Island, after World War I, when she and her husband, Aaron G. Hill, obtained a trinket concession stand. Hill was in the Army and they lived in Army housing at Fort Wood on Liberty Island until 1934, when the Department of the Interior took over the island and demolished the Army houses. Mrs. Hill, who was born in Warsaw, Poland, became proficient in several languages because of her contact with foreign tourists who visited the Statue of Liberty, said her daughter, Charlotte Libauer. Mrs. Hill's husband died in 1943. She is survived by a son and daughter, two brothers, four grandchildren and a great-granddaughter.

DOC.HEAD: Police Break Up Anti-Communist Demonstration
DOC.TEXT: Club-wielding police broke up a demonstration today by several hundred anti-Communist protesters who blocked a downtown square for the third straight day. The demonstrators, mostly young people, erected barricades from wooden advertising panels and vowed to remain in University Square until the government of interim President Ion Iliescu resigned. Some 400 steel-helmeted paramilitary police moved into the square at 5 a.m. to disperse about 200 protesters, and began beating them with clubs. Several demonstrators were injured, witnesses said. It marked one of the few times since last December's bloody overthrow of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu that Romania's interim leadership has used force against anti-Communist demonstrators. The demonstrators have occupied the square in varying numbers since Sunday and blocked traffic in the city center. The square was the scene of heavy fighting during the revolution that led to Ceausescu's execution. The protesters contend that Iliescu and other former members of the discredited Communist Party hold too much influence in the country's interim government. Romania will hold parliamentary elections on May 20, the first free multiparty elections in more than 40 years. After the police action, protesters began to reassemble on the square and by mid-afternoon, about 3,500 people had gathered and began erecting the barricades again on the square outside the Intercontinental Hotel. The demonstrators chanted various slogans, including ``Down with Communism!'' and ``Down with assassins!'' ``We came here to put communism down!'' a 73-year-old man, who declined to be identified, shouted at the major commanding the police who ringed the square at the end of a tree-lined boulevard. Meanwhile, Iliescu branded the protesters as ``thugs'' who were inciting people ``to violence and hatred.'' He spoke at today's session of the Provisional Council for National Unity, the country's makeshift parliament. ``With such violent groups of thugs we cannot find (the road to) democracy and impose (a new) civilization,'' said Iliescu, 60, a former Communist Party secretary who was demoted to lesser jobs after falling into disfavor with Ceausescu. Iliescu's remarks prompted shouts of ``Shame, shame, shame!'' from some members of the council who said he was resorting to the same kind of terminology used by Ceausescu to describe opponents. ``You made a terrible mistake Mr. Iliescu,'' said Ion Lup, deputy secretary general of the Peasant Party. Nica Leon, president of the Liberal Democratic Party and a member of the ruling Council, said the protesters ``want the (former) Communists toppled from the leadership.'' In his speech, Iliescu appealed to leaders of the more than 70 political parties that have emerged since December to assume responsibility and respect public order. Iliescu is head of the National Salvation Front and its candidate for president in the May 20 elections. The Front's leading members are former Communists who now described themselves as reformers. The Front, which claims some 800,000 members, is widely seen as the leading contender in the elections, drawing support from industrial workers and former Communist Party members. Opposition parties accuse the front of advocating ``neo-communism'' or ``communism with a human face,'' saying its leaders are following the policies of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: Mobutu Legalizes Opposition Parties
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to CORRECT date that new government will be in place to April 24, sted April 30, INSERTS year opposition parties banned; Edits to trim.
DOC.TEXT: President Mobutu Sese Seko today announced plans to lift a 20-year-old ban on opposition parties, following weeks of pressure from all sectors of society and Western supporters. Mobutu said his Popular Movement for the Revolution, since 1970 the only official party, no longer would hold special status. Initially, three parties would be allowed, Mobutu said. He also said the country's constitution will be rewritten and a transition government set up to run the country until elections can be held. The new government would be in place by April 24, 1991, he said. Mobutu made the announcement in a speech to the nation, which was carried by the official Zairean news agency. In recent weeks, Mobutu had been battered by a wave of unprecedented criticism, the culmination of his own campaign to gauge popular opinion. The country's Roman Catholic bishops compared his rule to a monarchy. In January, Mobutu began a tour of Zaire, which is as large as the United States east of the Mississippi, seeking public comment on his rule. Thousands of replies came from business groups, churches, unions, students and individuals. Many bitterly criticized the government and Mobutu, accusing the president and his cronies of corruption and monopolizing power. Mobutu did not reply directly to the criticisms in his speech, but promised: ``the will of the majority will be respected. We will proceed together on the changes wanted by the majority.'' Mobutu, a 59-year-old former journalist and army sergeant, has ruled the former Belgian Congo since Nov. 24, 1965. He renamed the country, and made it almost into an image of himself. Although the Popular Movement became the only legal party in 1970, in the years after he took power Mobutu dissolved Parliament and virtually eliminated opposition parties. Like most African presidents, Mobutu asserted one-party rule was the only way to avoid tribal conflict. In the country's first five years of independence, more than 100,000 people died in fighting attributed to ethnic or regional conflicts. All Zaire citizens were made members of Mobutu's party, were told to renounce their Christian names for African ones, and men were required to replace Western-style ties with a high-necked jacket. Under a policy of ``authenicity,'' Mobutu himself changed his name from Joseph Desire Mobutu to Mobutu Sese Seko, translated as ``the all powerful warrior who...'' Mobutu also nationalized key industries and replaced foreigners with Zaireans at their helm. Production collapsed, along with much of country's infrastructure. Mobutu was accused of plundering Zaire's wealth. His critics say he amassed several billion dollars. Twice he needed major Western military intervention to put down rebellions. International organizations and opposition leaders said he brutally repressed any opposition. But the United States and other Western governments supported Mobutu, who opposed the expansion of Marxism in the region. Zaire has been a conduit of U.S. aid to anti-Communist guerrillas in Angola, Zaire's southern neighbor. Mobutu's critics in the U.S. Congress, however, have said that under better East-West relations, the U.S. no longer needs to cultivate Mobutu.

DOC.HEAD: Nepal Police Leave Posts, Stay Home After Six Officers Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Cabinet meeting postponed, quotes, no violence, few police taking up posts, curfew; Minor editing; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of policemen deserted their posts or stayed home today after anti-monarchist mobs beat to death six of their colleagues in daylong rioting, government sources said. At least three police stations in the capital were seen to be empty. Almost none of the capital's 4,000 policemen were walking the streets. A few armed policemen entered deserted police stations late today but allowed no one to enter. A 10-hour curfew restricting people to their homes began at 7 p.m. and some policemen in jeeps and trucks patrolled the city. Monday's violence was the worst since April 6, when police opened fire on pro-democracy demonstrators, and threatened the fledgling pro-democracy movement in this Himalayan kingdom. Until this month, King Birendra had exercised virtually absolute power. Five civilians were killed by police gunfire in Monday's unrest and, according to the state-owned Rashtriya Samachar Samiti news agency, 15 policemen were missing. Only one policeman had been found by late today. The mobs accused police of condoning and sometimes joining an underground pro-monarchist group blamed for a wave of crime since a new government headed by pro-democracy forces took office last week. Two policemen captured early Monday were beaten for more than six hours before they died. Four more policemen were dragged from a police station and lynched by hundreds of people. The crowds also set afire the zonal commissioner's office, which houses a police station. Today, two policemen in riot gear stood guard outside the charred building. They were the only policemen seen on foot during an hour-long tour of Katmandu. ``There are no policemen anywhere in the city,'' said a taxi driver who said he had been driving the streets for six hours. ``Even traffic policemen are absent today.'' One government source said the policemen were either ``unofficially withdrawn or are too scared to come out.'' Senior police officials could not be located for comment. But shops opened and streets were clogged with traffic today after a ten-hour curfew clamped on Monday night was lifted at 6 a.m.. There were no reports of violence. ``The tremendous amount of confidence the people have in this government is compensating for the absence of police,'' said Home Minister Yog Prasad Upadhyay. ``This is apparent from the fact that ... the country is peaceful.'' Prime Minister Krishna Prasad Bhattarai met with King Birendra today to discuss the situation, officials said. No details of the meeting were available. A scheduled meeting of the Cabinet was postponed, officials said on condition of anonymity. There had been indications a shake-up in the top ranks of the police force might be forthcoming after the Cabinet meeting. Bhattarai and his government, a coalition of democrats, Communists, royalists and independents, took office last Thursday after an eight-week campaign against the previous regime, which was subservient to the king. King Birendra caved in to the campaign on April 8, two days after police shot and killed 200 demonstrators as they marched on the palace, according to witnesses. The government said 10 people were killed and 107 wounded in all of Nepal on that day, but two days later Birendra lifted a 29-year ban on political parties. Within 24 hours of the new government taking office, the capital of 250,000 people was faced with a rash of arson, mugging and looting, which residents blamed on a right-wing pro-monarchist group called Mandale. The Mandale, an abbreviated form of Nepal Vidyarthi Mandal, or Nepal students group, went underground in 1979 after Birendra officially banned the group because of its violent tendencies.

DOC.HEAD: Train Went `Clickety, Clunk' Before Derailing; 91 Hurt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to expand description of train's origin, UPDATE with investigators on scene, cars being removed, picking up 7th graf, `The crew....' Deletes now redundant 18th graf pvs, `Sections of...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY16
DOC.TEXT: An Amtrak train was lurching from side to side and going ``clickety, clickety, clunk'' before it jumped the tracks, witnesses said. At least 91 people were reported injured, three seriously. ``Last night it seemed like the train just wasn't going right. It was kind of swaying so much it woke me up,'' Ruby Hall of Forrest City, Ark., one of the California Zephyr's 394 passengers, said Monday. The train, made up of sections that originated in Seattle, Los Angeles and Oakland, Calif., was on its way to Chicago with a crew of 24 when it derailed at the edge of this town of 500, about 90 miles from Des Moines. Investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board visited the derailment site early today but would not speculate on the cause of the crash, ``not even rhetorically,'' said Dave Watson, investigator in charge. Larry Allen, assistant transportation superintendent for Amtrak's Midwest division, said investigators would try to make a preliminary determination of the cause today, but cautioned: ``It'll take some more work before it gets nailed down.'' Jasonna Gibson of Schenectady, N.Y., said she was holding her 2{-month-old baby when the train left the tracks. ``The baby fell,'' she said. ``I tried to get him and a lady fell on me.'' Eight passenger or baggage cars jumped the tracks: four remained upright; three were leaning, and one, a sleeper car, was on its side, said Amtrak spokeswoman Sue Martin. Crews today righted the derailed cars and were shipping them to Fairfield, about 15 miles east, for inspection and repair. Crews also went to work on the twisted rail and gouged right-of-way. An Amtrak official said the double-track route would be open to regular train traffic later in the day. The crew reported to local hospitals for drug and alcohol tests, as required under federal regulations, said Michael Turner, Amtrak supervisor of on-board services. Test results were not immediately available. Kathy Hood of Littleton, Colo., said the ride was rough before the derailment. ``This is my first train ride, but I didn't think they were supposed to sway so much,'' she said. Paula Stater said she was in her home near the tracks just before the accident and knew knew something wasn't right. ``I said to myself, `There goes that Amtrak making that stupid noise,''' she said. ``But instead of going clickety, clickety, clack, it was making a clickety, clickety, clunk. ``I looked out the window and thought, `Lord, I hope nobody was killed.''' Asked about reports of swaying and noise, Gerry Hester, transportation superintendent for Amtrak's Midwest division, would not speculate on the cause of the accident. Mike Wenninger, a spokesman for Burlington Northern Railroad, on whose line the train was operating, said investigators would interview the crew and witnesses, check if signals were working and examine the train's speed. Wenninger said the Burlington Northern line is kept in ``tiptop condition and is inspected daily.'' Ms. Martin said she does not know how fast the train was traveling but its ``black box'' data recorder should help investigators. The train is authorized to travel up to 79 mph in the area of the crash, she said. Ms. Martin said 91 people, most of them suffering bumps and bruises, were taken to hospitals, including 10 crew members. Fourteen were admitted. ``None of the injuries has been described as life-threatening,'' she said. Three seriously injured passengers were taken by helicopter from the crash scene to hospitals, officials said. One was admitted to a cardiac unit with chest pains, one had chest injuries and the third a badly fractured arm, officials said. Ms. Martin said the train was running two hours late because one section had to detour between Oakland and Sacramento because of a gasoline spill. One car in the train had a car-length gash from hitting a freight car parked on another track, witnesses said. Amtrak arranged for buses to take passengers to Chicago, where other travel arrangements would be made. ``I got to go all the way to New York. I'm not taking a train back,'' said Ms. Gibson, who joined dozens of other shocked passengers at a community center where they were given food and drinks.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Officials: Polhill Was Held With Fellow Americans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with new details on Polhill captivity, pickup 5th graf pvs, ``According to ...'; Edits thereafter to tighten and add new details on Polhill.
DOC.TEXT: Freed American hostage Robert Polhill spent most of his captivity in the same room as two fellow hostages and probably in the same building as other Western captives, U.S. officials said today. Some details of Polhill's captivity emerged as a special team of U.S. investigators began questioning him today about what he knows of other captives in Lebanon and the Shiite Moslem militants who hold them. The 55-year-old business professor was reunited with his two sons today for the first time in more than three years. They shared a lunch of spare ribs, serenaded by a German accordionist, the officials said. Polhill, a New Yorker, has been staying in a VIP suite at the U.S. Air Force Hospital in Wiesbaden with his wife, Feryal. His sons, Stephen, 26, and Brian, 23, arrived this morning from the United States. U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Polhill was held in the same room with American educators Jesse Turner, 42, of Boise, Idaho, and Alann Steen, 51, a Boston native. All three were seized on Jan. 24, 1987, from the American University in Beirut campus, where they had taught. Indian-born U.S. resident Mitheleshwar Singh, who was also kidnapped from the campus with the three professors, shared the room until his release on Oct. 3, 1988, the officials said. ``There's a possibility he (Polhill) was held in the same building with other hostages,'' one U.S. official said. ``We're fairly certain of that.'' The official said he did not know which of the 17 Westerners still in captivity might have also been held in the building. Seven Americans are among those held. ``We know from various sources where the hostages have been held,'' the U.S. official said, explaining that they were moved regularly. Elsewhere, there were indications a second hostage might soon be freed, though U.S. officials said they had ``no information'' on that. And a London newspaper, The Independent, reported that several dozen Shiite prisoners held in southern Lebanon by an Israeli-backed militia would be released in the next few days as part of a deal that won Polhill's release. Sources close to the militia said Monday its leader would decide today whether to free some of the group's estimated 300 prisoners to mark the end of the Islamic Ramadan fast. ``According to the latest information that we have received from Lebanon, maybe after a few days another hostage will be released,'' Iran's foreign mnister, Ali Akbar Velayati, told CNN in an interview Monday. He did not specify the nationality of the hostage who might be released. Hussein Musawi, a leading pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem cleric in Lebanon, also said another of the 17 remaining Western hostages might be freed soon. Musawi is thought to have influence over the group that held Polhill. ``The possibility of another release is in the cards, but I don't know when, how of for what,'' he told the Communist-run Voice of the People radio in Lebanon. ``Such a step (Polhill's release) has to have a reciprocation. It is not feasible that all releases would be made as goodwill gestures,'' Musawi said. Tehran state radio in Iran said Polhill's release might be a prelude to the release of other hostages but that Washington and other Western governments ``must show goodwill.'' At the base hospital, doctors said Polhill appeared to be in good shape for a man who had been in captivity for more than three years, but he was malnourished, mildly dehydrated and quite tired. Polhill's diabetes, which he has had for 25 years, ``is well under control,'' the hospital said in a statement today. The hospital's medical director, Col. Dr. Kenneth R. Koskinen, said Polhill suffered ``muscle wasting'' in captivity. He added that Polhill was eating four meals a day to combat his malnutrition and ``emptying our kitchen.'' He added, however, ``He is intellectually very sharp, has a great sense of humor, and considering his ordeal has a reasonably positive mental status.'' Polhill, an avid sports fan, has asked a lot of questions about the World Series and Super Bowl, U.S. officials said. During his captivity he had only sporadic reading material. Asked whether Polhill ever felt there was a moment he would be killed, one U.S. official said: ``My understanding is that he never felt that.'' Polhill will spend several more days at Wiesbaden before returning to the United States, Koskinen said. Polhill, frail and weary, carefully stepped out of a U.S. Air Force helicopter at the American military hospital in Wiesbaden on Monday to a tumultous welcome from medical personnel, soldiers and civilians. A U.S. official denied any deals were made for Polhill's release and said the United States had no information that a second hostage might soon be freed. The official also said he was unaware of any payments from Iran or Syria to the kidnappers to win his release. In a Monday editorial, the Tehran Times, a paper close to President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran, appealed for the release of another U.S. hostage. In Lebanon, a pro-Syrian militia leader said today he was working for the ``speedy release'' of two kidnapped Swiss Red Cross workers. Mustafa Saad, leader of the leftist Sunni Moslem Popular Liberation Army that controls the southern port of Sidon, told reporters: ``We're in contact with several parties concerned to ensure the speedy release of the Swiss captives.'' The two Swiss, Emmanuel Christen, 33, and Elio Erriquez, 24, were kidnapped by unidentified gunmen Oct. 6. Police and other security sources blamed Palestinian terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal, whose movement has denied the charge. However, the group admits holding four Belgians seized in November 1987 aboard a yacht in the eastern Mediterranean. Beirut's al-Liwa newspaper said today in an unattributed report the Belgians would be released next week in a deal with their government to free convicted Palestinian terrorist Said Nasser. Nasser, believed to be a member of Abu Nidal's faction, is imprisoned in Belgium for a 1980 grenade attack on a synagogue. A Jew was killed.

DOC.HEAD: Precede EAST BERLIN
July 2 Set as Target Date for Unification
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with target unification date set; Changes byline, precedes; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere today set July 2 as the target date for the economic, monetary and social union of their countries. While early July has frequently been mentioned as a goal, this was the first bilateral announcement of a specific date. The announcement, read by West German government spokesman Dieter Vogel, came as de Maiziere met with Kohl in his first visit to Bonn as East Germany's prime minister. Delegations from East and West Germany will meet in East Berlin on Wednesday to begin negotiations on monetary union, the Bonn government announced earlier. Monetary union is a major step toward uniting the two German states. The talks will cover Bonn's proposal Monday to allow a 1-1 exchange rate on wages, salaries and pensions. The 1-1 rate also would apply to savings accounts of up to 4,000 marks, or about $2,300, said Kohl spokesman Dieter Vogel. Savings over that amount would be traded at two East German marks for every West German mark. There had been reports West Germany was considering the poorer rate for most savings. The East German government had demanded the 1-1 rate to protect workers from higher living costs in a unified Germany and the loss of huge subsidies that existed in the former socialist system. East German politicians applauded the wage concession but criticized the limit on savings accounts. West German opposition parties said the plan would cost billions, erode the West German mark and lead to inflation. West German stocks plunged to their lowest level of the year after the announcement. West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel said his country will spend $35 billion to $58 billion over the next two years on unification. Many West Germans, who vote in national elections on Dec. 2, are worried they will bear the brunt of absorbing the crumbling East German economy. The West German proposal is an ``important contribution'' to ending the disagreements between the nations, East German government spokesman Mathias Gehler said. But Wolfgang Ullmann, vice president of East Germany's Parliament, said: ``If this is the final decision, there should be sharp protest, because a large part of savings will not be considered here.'' Meanwhile, in East Berlin Monday, East Germany sent tons of its own money to the trash-burner to make room in its treasury for the crisp new West German currency it hopes will bring prosperity. Soldiers stuffed sacks filled with old, out-of-circulation East German currency taking up space in the main treasury in East Berlin. The marks were carted off to the incinerator on Monday so the government will have room for the new currency, expected to begin officially circulating in the country by July 2. ``The East German mark will not be needed with the introduction of the monetary union,'' said the East German treasury's chief cashier, Horst Boettcher. In another step toward a single Germany, government sources in Bonn said Monday the four World War II Allies _ the Soviet Union, United States, France and Britain _ will meet with the two Germanys for talks May 5 on international aspects of German unification.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Guam May Not Be Sued Over Civil Rights Law
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. territory of Guam and its officials may not be sued for allegedly violating a much-used federal civil rights law, the Supreme Court ruled today. The justices, by a 6-2 vote, threw out part of a lawsuit filed by six Guam residents who said police punched, kicked and threatened them to get them to confess to drug-related crimes. Writing for the court today, Justice Harry A. Blackmun said Congress was most concerned about the Ku Klux Klan's influence and race relations in Southern states when it passed the 1871 law. The law allows those who prove government actions or policies violated their constitutional rights to collect monetary damages. ``Our review of (the law's) history uncovers no sign that Congress was thinking of the territories when it enacted the statute,'' Blackmun said. The six residents who sued Guam and various officials are Palauan, natives of the island of Palau. They have their own culture, language and physical characteristics. Their lawsuit alleged that racial bias sparked police brutality. A federal appeals court dismissed the residents' claims against the Guam government, the Guam Police Department and the individual defendants in their official capacities. Today's decision upheld the appeals court ruling, and effectively reduces the amount of money the Palauans may recover if they eventually win their lawsuit. The Palauans had sought $100 million in damages. The case is Ngiraingas vs. Sanchez, 88-1281.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bush Will Give $2.6 Million in Medical Aid to Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will use his emergency authority to provide $2.6 million in medical aid to Nicaragua as a show of support for new President Violeta Chamorro when she is inaugurated Wednesday, congressional and administration sources said today. Bush's request for $300 million in economic aid to Nicaragua, including money needed for spring planting of crops and for fuel, is snarled by unrelated disputes on Capitol Hill and is unlikely to be approved in time for Wednesday's swearing-in ceremony. The medical aid will provide a visible gesture that can be announced by Vice President Dan Quayle when he attends the ceremony in Managua. Mrs. Chamorro was elected overwhelming in February elections to replace President Daniel Ortega of the leftist Sandinista party. The medical assistance would be the first U.S. aid to the Central American country in nine years, since President Reagan cut off aid shortly after taking office in 1981. Mrs. Chamorro will take control of a country that is among the most impoverished in the hemisphere and has been battered by a decade of civil war and U.S. trade sanctions. Officials of the new government say they face a difficult challenge in meeting the expectations of the electorate for peace and a better standard of living. Bush is seeking $300 million as a first installment of aid for the country, along with $500 million for Panama, which also is suffering economic ills. But the aid package, a version of which has been passed by the House, is being held up in the Senate by a dispute over unrelated child-care legislation. The medical aid is being provided under a little-used section of the foreign assistance law that permits the president to use up to $10 million a year for ``any emergency purposes,'' so long as Congress is notified.

DOC.HEAD: Precede NEW YORK
Interior Department Proposes Shift in Oil Leasing Policy
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Interior Department is proposing a new offshore oil leasing strategy it hopes will overcome congressional opposition to oil development and open the way for more drilling, department officials said today. The proposal was expected soon to be presented to President Bush as part of a new five-year offshore oil leasing plan, beginning in 1992. The revised proposal is aimed at breaking the political deadlock over expanded offshore drilling since President Reagan opened the entire 1.4 billion-acre Outer Continental Shelf for potential development, prompting outcries from environmentalists and many congressmen. The new approach ``will be a lot more restrictive and lease sales will go a lot slower than in the past,'' said Barry Williamson, director of the department's Minerals Management Service. ``It will be a 180 degree change of what we've seen.'' ``We're taking a paring knife and we're going to narrow and hold the process (of offering leases) down. We'll do away to a large degree with the large area-wide leasing concept,'' Williamson said in an interview. ``The policies of the 1980s as they relate to offshore leasing are not working into the 1990s,'' said Interior spokesman Steve Goldstein. He called the new approach ``much more realistic'' and said Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan hopes it will open the way for more offshore oil development. The policy change was first reported in today's edition of the New York Times. Williamson said that instead of considering vast expanses of offshore areas for oil development, the department would ``draw boxes'' around areas that would be off-limits because of environmental concerns. It would also single out areas where development should be pushed because of indications the prospects of finding oil would be good. Because the new concept would be more restrictive, it may ease congressional opposition to the overall leasing effort, Interior officials said. They said the areas that would be considered prime for development have yet to be determined, nor how many acres would be considered for drilling. Only a small portion of the country's Outer Continental Shelf is used for oil and gas exploration, mostly in the Gulf of Mexico. Congressional action has blocked development in vast areas along the Atlantic and Pacific coasts and off Alaska. Bush is expected soon to announce his decision on whether to proceed with oil leases in three of the most controversial areas off the western coast of Southern Florida and off the California coast. Environmentalists and local citizen groups have strongly opposed drilling in the three areas. Officials said the new five-year plan would not be considered by the president until after his decision on the California and Florida leases. Under Interior's new approach, the initial step of any leasing process would be to determine whether oil drilling or ship traffic would harm marine life, and those areas would be withdrawn from consideration. Only areas where there is strong geological evidence of a potential oil strike would be put up for leases. The plan also would share revenues from the leasing with coastal communities near the drilling sites in hopes of easing local opposition, officials said. The outer continental shelf, a submerged ridge of land, begins three miles offshore. The petroleum industry has for years pushed for offshore development but efforts repeatedly have been blocked in most areas except in the Gulf Coast because of local opposition and freezes on lease sales imposed by Congress.

DOC.HEAD: KGB Reportedly Tightens Lithuania's Borders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with KGB reinforcing units on Lithuanian border, Kremlin refusing to meet delegation; Pickup 9th, `Cheblakova said...'; Changes byline.
DOC.TEXT: The KGB has reinforced its units on the Lithuanian border and increased patrols offshore, an official said today, less than a week after the Kremlin cut oil and gas to the Baltic republic. Also today, a five-member delegation dispatched from Lithuania's capital, Vilnius, to meet with Soviet representatives in Moscow failed to win an audience, one representative said. A Soviet government spokesman, meanwhile, warned that any U.S. sanctions imposed on Moscow because of its economic embargo of Lithuania could end up hurting the breakaway republic. Moscow imposed the embargo on Lithuania for refusing to rescind laws meant to bolster its March 11 declaration of independence. The republic was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. KGB Lt. Anatoly Parakhin, chief of the secret police's border guard, indicated tighter security along the Lithuanian frontiers was justified by fears weapons might be brought into the republic, the Tass news agency said. Since Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev imposed the blockade on the republic, Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimeira Prunskiene has been seeking supplies of petroleum from other countries. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Vadim Perfiliev warned that any U.S. sanctions imposed on the Soviet Union over Lithuania could raise false hopes in Lithuania and have ``negative consequences'' on the international scene. ``Such types of actions could play into the hands of unrealistic, ultra-nationalistic feelings, and they could hurt the interests of Lithuania itself,'' Perfiliev said without elaborating. Perfiliev spoke before President Bush announced today what were expected to be economic penalties against Moscow. On Monday, Prunskiene said Lithuania might have to sell some of its gold reserves to buy the fuel needed to reopen stalled industrial operations. The Soviet economic embargo forced the Lithuanians to close their only oil refinery Monday and try to raise cash to buy fuel from abroad. The refinery at Mazheikiai had been operating on reserves, dispatcher Lidiya Cheblakova said from the refinery. Cheblakova said that with production stopped, the refinery's 2,000 workers were now idle. ``The mood is tense, worrisome,'' she said. Soviet officials shut off the oil pipeline feeding the plant from the Russian city of Polotsk last week and curtailed natural gas supplies and shipments of other products. It was the toughest move taken in Gorbachev's effort to make the republic of 3.8 million people rescind the laws seeking to promote Lithuania's independence decree. The refinery produced gasoline for the republic as well as for Estonia, Latvia and Byelorussia, processing about 12 million tons of petroleum products a year of which Lithuania used one quarter. Lithuania has virtually no foreign currency to buy oil, but Mrs. Prunskiene said Monday that the republic might cash in gold reserves it has in France. She told reporters in Moscow, however, that the idea had not been approved yet, according to Interfax, a news service of Radio Moscow. Lithuania needs about $55 million worth of oil a month. The Bank of France said last month that it would return the gold in its vaults to Lithuania if the French government recognizes the independent state. Lithuania transferred gold now worth about $28 million to France as a precaution in the years before World War II. Mrs. Prunskiene told reporters in Sweden on Monday that she opened an account at a Swedish bank to deposit foreign donations for Lithuania. In Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, some bus routes were cut and the main thoroughfare, Gedimina Street, was practically devoid of vehicles as Lithuanians struggled with gasoline rationing that limits them to about eight gallons a month for private cars. The Lithuanian government has urged all citizens to begin conserving everything. A group of Western journalists who had been allowed to visit Vilnius returned to Moscow on Monday. Virtually all foreign correspondents were expelled from Lithuania on April 1, but about 20 to 25 Moscow-based Western journalists returned Friday on a trip sponsored by the Soviet Foreign Ministry. Lithuania's small Communist Party faction loyal to Moscow apparently was behind the special trip, hoping to win coverage of its party congress on Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Distributors of ``Rear Window'' Must Share Profits
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court, in a ruling that could affect millions of dollars in movie industry profits, said today distributors of the Alfred Hitchcock thriller ``Rear Window'' must share with a literary agent earnings from the film's re-release. The 6-3 ruling was a defeat for actor Jimmy Stewart and Hitchcock's heirs. Some film producers claimed it could limit availability of movie classics. Stewart, Hitchcock's heirs and others sought to prevent literary agent Sheldon Abend from receiving a share of profits from ``Rear Window's'' re-release in 1983. Abend paid Chase Manhattan Bank $650 in 1971 for the copyright to the short story on which ``Rear Window'' was based. He sued in federal court seeking a share of the more than $12 million in revenue that the film has generated since 1983 when the 1954 classic was released again in theaters and for the first time on rented video casettes and over cable television. ``Rear Window'' is based on a short story, ``It Had to be Murder,'' by Cornell Woolrich that was first published in 1942 in Dime Detective Magazine. The motion picture, starring Stewart and Grace Kelly and directed by Hitchcock, had many elements not contained in the original short story. Woolrich sold the movie rights to his story in 1945 for $9,250. When he died in 1968, his property _ including the copyright to his story _ was left to a trust administered by Chase Manhattan. Abend said the re-release of ``Rear Window'' infringed on his copyright, and he also said the film distributors interfered with his plans to contract with Home Box Office cable TV for a new play and TV version of the story. The Supreme Court today upheld a federal appeals court ruling in Abend's favor. The case now goes back to a lower court to determine how much money Abend will receive. The justices reached their decision by interpreting federal copyright law. Before 1976, a 1909 law permitted a copyright to be renewed for 28 years after the initial 28-year copyright period ended. The law was amended in 1976 to provide for copyright protection for the life of the author plus 50 years _ but only to works copyrighted after Jan. 1, 1978. The high court said Abend is entitled to copyright renewal protection even though Woolrich died before the short story copyright was renewed. The law is aimed at giving an author a second chance to make a profit on a creative work _ and to leave the money to one's heirs or executors in case the author dies before the copyright is renewed, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote for the court. Today's ruling does not let Abend block distribution of ``Rear Window.'' Nonetheless, some of the nation's leading motion picture producing companies who supported the appeal by Stewart and Hitchcock's heirs said a victory for Abend could mean that thousands of films based on books, plays and short stories might have to be withdrawn from distribution. More likely, it means they could have to share profits from the films with copyright holders. O'Connor was joined by Justices William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and Anthony M. Kennedy. Dissenting were Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices John Paul Stevens and Antonin Scalia. The case is Stewart vs. Abend, 88-2102.

DOC.HEAD: Man Gets Life for 1957 Killing of Cousin
DOC.TEXT: More than 32 years after an 11-year-old boy was sodomized and hanged, the victim's cousin has been sentenced to life in prison for the murder. ``We're very relieved that it's over,'' Mildred Ruff, the victim's mother, said after Monday's sentencing of Richard Ruff. ``May God have mercy on his soul.'' Ruff, 53, was convicted on March 23 of first-degree felony murder for the death of 11-year-old William Ruff Jr. William Ruff was killed on Aug. 31, 1957, and was found the next day hanging from a tree in a wooded area near his home in the Albany suburb of Colonie. Prosecutors said the conviction concludes the longest homicide investigation in New York state history. Ruff maintained his innocence during the sentencing. ``I just never sodomized nobody. I never killed anybody,'' he said. ``... And that's the truth.'' Albany County Court Judge Thomas Keegan ordered the sentence to run consecutively with a 4- to 12-year stretch Ruff is serving for sexually abusing two young daughters of a woman he lived with in Rensselaer County. Keegan turned down a motion by Public Defender Joseph McCoy to dismiss the conviction on the grounds of insufficient evidence. McCoy said his office would appeal. ``We're elated that the judge gave the maximum sentence,'' Chief Assistant District Attorney Daniel S. Dwyer said outside the courtroom. Dwyer said he would write a letter urging that the state parole board keep Ruff in state prison when he becomes eligible for parole in 22 years. ``This man's shadow should never be cast in society,'' he said. Ruff was not even considered a suspect in the killing until two years ago. In 1988, Christopher Ruff, a brother of the victim who is now an Albany County sheriff's deputy, noticed a police bulletin indicating his cousin was wanted in connection with a child sex-abuse case in Rensselaer County. Police found Ruff in Florida and questioned him for both the William Ruff case and the Rensselaer County sexual abuse case before he was brought back to Albany. Dwyer based much of his case on statements Ruff made to police in Florida in which he confessed killing his cousin. ``This defendant summarily executed this boy,'' Dwyer said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Allows States to Execute Murderers With No Appeals Court Review
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 13-18, In other action, with other cases.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court, ruling today in the case of an Arkansas mass murderer, allowed states to execute convicted murderers even if no appeals court reviews the validity of their convictions or death sentences. By a 7-2 vote, the justices threw out an appeal filed for _ but not by _ R. Gene Simmons, sentenced to death for killing 16 relatives and acquaintances in 1987. The court said such an appeal cannot be filed by a fellow death row inmate. Simmons says he wants to be executed, and refuses to appeal his murder convictions or death sentence. Lawyers for Arkansas death row inmate Jonas H. Whitmore argued that state appeals courts must review all death sentences, even when not asked to do so by the condemned murderer. Writing for the court today, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist said Whitmore lacks the proper legal standing to mount a challenge in Simmons' behalf. The court rejected arguments by Whitmore's lawyers that the uniqueness of the death penalty and society's interest in its proper imposition justifies some kind of relaxed legal-standing standard. ``The short answer to this suggestion is that the requirement of a ... case or controversy is not merely a traditional rule or practice but rather is imposed directly by the Constitution,'' Rehnquist said. ``It is not for this court to employ untethered notions of what might be good public policy to expand our jurisdiction in an appealing case,'' he said. Justices Thurgood Marshall and William J. Brennan, who oppose capital punishment under all circumstances, dissented. Writing for the two, Marshall said, ``The court today allows a state to execute a man even though no appellate court has reviewed the validity of his conviction or sentence.'' ``The court does not address the constitutional claim presented by (Whitmore) _ whether a state must provide appellate review in a capital case despite the defendant's desire to waive such review,'' Marshall said. ``Rather, it decides (Whitmore) does not have the standing to raise that issue before this court.'' In other action today, the court: _ Said, in a ruling that could affect millions of dollars in movie industry profits, that distributors of the Alfred Hitchcock thriller ``Rear Window'' must share with a literary agent earnings from the film's re-release. The 6-3 ruling was a defeat for actor Jimmy Stewart and Hitchcock's heirs. Some film producers claimed it could limit availability of movie classics. _ Ruled that the U.S. territory of Guam and its officials may not be sued for allegedly violating a much-used federal civil rights law. The justices, by a 6-2 vote, threw out part of a lawsuit filed by six Guam residents who said police punched, kicked and threatened them to get them to confess to drug-related crime. The law allows those who prove government actions or policies violated their constitutional rights to collect monetary damages. In what prosecutors called a murderous rampage in the little town of Russellville, Simmons gunned down his wife, three sons, four daughters, a son-in-law, a daughter-in-law, four grandchildren and two acquaintances within a few days of Christmas 1987. Simmons, 49, refused to appeal his convictions and death sentence, saying he wanted to die by lethal injection as quickly as possible. Three days before Simmons was to die March 16, 1989, Whitmore sought to challenge the state's death penalty law in Simmons' behalf. On the eve of the execution, the nation's highest court postponed Simmons' death to study Whitmore's argument that the Constitution requires state appeals courts to review all death sentences, even when the convicted defendant asks to die. By ruling that Whitmore lacked the legal standing to appeal in Simmons' behalf, the court cleared the way for Arkansas authorities to execute Simmons without the validity of his conviction or sentence ever being reviewed by an appeals court. After rejecting Whitmore's standing to press the appeal in his individual capacity, the court rejected his attempt to press it as a ``next friend'' of Simmons. The legal concept of ``next friend'' is employed by the courts when prison inmates are incapable, usually because of mental incompetence, to appeal in their own behalf. ``We hold that Whitmore, having failed to establish that Simmons is unable to proceed on his own behalf, does not have standing to proceed as `next friend' of Ronald Gene Simmons,'' Rehnquist said. The death-appeal case is Whitmore vs. Arkansas, 88-7146.

DOC.HEAD: 28 Officers Executed After Coup Attempt
DOC.TEXT: A military firing squad executed 28 officers, including three retired generals and a brigadier, after a summary court-martial on charges of trying to seize power in a coup, official media reported. A statement broadcast on the government's Radio Omdurman said a colonel was acquitted but a court-martial was continuing for other officers alleged to have participated in the two-stage coup attempt. Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir's ruling junta, which took power in its own coup last June 30, said an attempt crushed Monday was the second phase of a coup plot originally put down in March. Government spokesmen said 30 officers were brought before the court-martial after their arrest Monday. They said 20 officers and civilians arrested after the March incident also were on trial. In announcing the firing-squad executions of the 28, Radio Omdurman did not specify how many remained in the dock. ``Death by firing squad has been implemented, and the trials are still going on for the rest of the participants'' in the alleged coup plot, said the statement read on Radio Omdurman and distributed by the Sudan News Agency. The statement did not say where the death sentences were carried out. It also was unclear why Col. Hassan Abdalla Atta, a pilot, was acquitted. There were reports that he was granted clemency in exchange for testifying against the others. The executed officers included the two retired senior officers accused by the government of being leaders of the alleged plot. They and the others were charged with ``high treason and mutiny against the legitimate government.'' First word of the summary court-martial came late Monday night in a statement read over official government television. It interrupted regular broadcasts to say the tribunal ``already started trying the plotters'' captured after their failed power grab on Monday in the northeast African country. The government said the coup leaders were retired Maj. Gen. Abdul-Kadir al-Kadaru and Brigadier Mohammed Osman Hamid Karrar. Other retired flag officers reported executed were retired Gens. Khalid al-Zain Ali, a pilot, and Osman Idris Balol. In addition, four colonels, one retired, and five lieutenant colonels, two of whom were retired, went before the firing squad. The junior officers on the list were three captains. Seventeen of the 28 were on active duty. The others were retired.

DOC.HEAD: Grenade Attack, Blockade Violence at Indian Reservation
DOC.TEXT: A hand-grenade attack at a police station injured three people, and five men were arrested after a car ran a blockade in separate incidents on the St. Regis Mohawk Reservation, state police said. The grenade was thrown Monday night into a crowd outside the Mohawk police station on the Canadian side of the reservation, which straddles the U.S.-Canadian border, said Mohawk representative Tim Thompson. There has been sporadic violence on the reservation since last summer, when state police and FBI agents raided St. Regis' illegal casinos and arrested 13 people. Anti-gambling forces last month set up blockades to keep out visitors who come by the busload. The five men arrested after driving into a blockade late Monday were charged with criminal possession of a weapon, state trooper Jay Plumb said in Massena. He said the men _ Alex Garrow, 19; Kenneth King, 22; Paul Thomas, 22; James Davis Jr., 29; and Robert Skidder, 53 _ were members of the Warrior Society, a self-proclaimed security force that supports gambling. No arrests were made in the grenade incident, which hospitalized a 16-year-old boy with a severe wrist injury, Thompson said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Indicted in Letelier Assassination Wants Lawyer Who Won Other Acquittal
DOC.TEXT: A man indicted in the assassination of onetime Chilean Ambassador Orlando Letelier wants to be represented by a lawyer who won acquittal for another defendant in the case. Jose Dionisio Suarez Esquivel appeared in U.S. District Court today, accompanied by New York attorney Paul Goldberger. Assistant U.S. Attorney Eric Marcy said Goldberger's entry into the case would present ``a very serious'' conflict of interest. Goldberger represented Guillermo Novo Sampol, who was tried and acquitted in the Letelier case eight years ago. Marcy said Novo is a potential government witness against Suarez, but Goldberger said he doubted prosecutors would call his former client, who lives in the Miami area. U.S. District Court Judge Aubrey Robinson said he will address the question of conflict of interest once Suarez's family decides that they want to hire Goldberger. A decision is expected in the next week. Currently, court-appointed lawyer Ed Sussman is representing Suarez. Suarez, arrested April 11 in St. Petersburg, Fla., had been a fugitive since his indictment in 1978. He is accused of murdering a foreign official and of four other charges in the 1976 car bombing of Letelier, Chile's ambassador to Washington from 1970 to 1973 under the Marxist government of Salvador Allende. Also indicted were the two top officials in Chile's intelligence service during the military rule of Gen. Augusto Pinochet. The Chilean courts have refused to extradite the two ex-intelligence officials.

DOC.HEAD: Reports: Swiss, Belgian Hostages To Be Freed
With PM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A pro-Syrian militia leader said today he was working for the ``speedy release'' of two kidnapped Swiss Red Cross workers amid newspaper reports that they and four Belgian captives will be freed soon. Speculation about the release of more Western hostages intensified after American hostage Robert Polhill was released Sunday after 39 months in captivity in Lebanon. Seventeen Western hostages, including seven Americans, are believed held in Lebanon. Mustafa Saad, leader of the leftist Sunni Moslem Popular Liberation Army that controls the southern port of Sidon, told reporters: ``We're in contact with several parties concerned to ensure the speedy release of the Swiss captives.'' The two Swiss, Emmanuel Christen, 33, and Elio Erriquez, 24, who ran an orthopedic center for Lebanese civil war victims for the International Committee of the Red Cross in Sidon, were kidnapped by unidentified gunmen last Oct. 6. Saad appealed to the kidnappers to free the Swiss hostages by the end of the holy Moslem fasting month of Ramadan, which is expected to end Wednesday or Thursday, depending on when the new crescent moon marking the end of the lunar month is sighted. In Geneva, Switzerland, Juerg Bischoff, a spokesman of the all-Swiss International Committee of the Red Cross, said today that ``our hopes are rising'' for the release of the pair. ``Saad is our main contact in Sidon, he is the most influiential political leader there and he knows what's going on,'' Bischoff said. Saad, who has helped mediate earlier hostage releases in southern Lebanon, did not specify which groups he has contacted regarding the release of the Swiss. Police and other security sources have blamed Palestinian terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal for kidnapping the Red Cross workers. Their abduction is believed to be linked to the imprisonment in Switzerland of Hussein Hariri, 22, a Lebanese Shiite, who hijacked an Air Afrique jetliner in 1987 and killed a French passenger. Abu Nidal's group has denied involvement in the abduction of the two Swiss. But it admits holding four Belgians seized in November 1987 aboard a yacht in the Mediterranean Sea. The Belgians are Emmanuel Houtekins, 43, his wife Godlieve Kuts, their son Laurent and daughter Valerie, both in their teens. Beirut's al-Liwa newspaper said in an unattributed report that the Belgians would be released next week in a deal between Abu Nidal's group and the Brussels government. As part of the deal, Belgium would release convicted Palestinian terrorist Said Nasser, who was imprisoned for a 1980 grenade attack on a Jewish synagogue. Al-Liwa said Nasser ``completes half of his prison sentence in mid-May'' and noted that the Belgian government will refer his case to the Supreme Court which ``would release him by May 17.'' Abu Nidal's group, the Libyan-backed Fatah-Revolutionary Council released three other hostages captured with the Belgians on the yacht on April 10 following an appeal from Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi.

DOC.HEAD: Khashoggi Overpaid for Marcoses' Paintings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Further testimony...' with two grafs to UPDATE with today's testimony shifting focus to building transaction. Picks up 7th graf, `Prosecutors claim...'.
DOC.TEXT: Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi may have paid too much when he bought 38 paintings from Imelda Marcos for $6.5 million, an art expert testified. Ian Glenn Kennedy, a senior vice president at Christie's auction house, testified Monday at the fraud trial of Mrs. Marcos and Khashoggi that 26 of the paintings had a combined value in 1986 of $1.7 million to $2.7 million. Khashoggi has said he paid Mrs. Marcos $6.5 million for the paintings as a favor because she and her late husband, former Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos, needed money. Twenty-six of the paintings were seized in 1987 in France at the urging of the United States. The financier said he did not have the paintings appraised and acknowledges paying more than they were worth. He said in an interview last week, ``If you saw the paintings you wouldn't buy them for a dollar. You wouldn't hang them on the walls tastewise.'' None of the works' painters or titles has been identified in court. As the trial resumed in U.S. District Court today, a lawyer, Peter W. Williams, explained the process through which the Marcoses acquired the Crown Building on Fifth Avenue in 1981 for $51 million. Williams said the deal was conducted through a series of banks and corporations in the United States, Switzerland, the Netherlands Antilles, Panama and the Philippines. Prosecutors claim the Marcoses bought the paintings, as well as four Manhattan buildings, with money embezzled from the Philippine treasury. Khashoggi is accused of forging documents to help the Marcoses conceal their ownership of the paintings and real estate in violation of a 1986 U.S. court order freezing any transactions involving Marcos-owned properties. Khashoggi's attorneys say his dealings with the Marcoses occurred prior to the injunction; prosecutors allege Khashoggi backdated the documents to skirt the court order. Kennedy, an expert in Old Master paintings, said that the value of the 26 works of art had risen in 1990 to between $4.1 million and $6.1 million. Kennedy testified after Christian Rene LeBeau, an officer with the French Judicial Police's art theft unit, identified 26 of the 38 paintings as the ones seized in 1987 in Paris and Cannes. Mrs. Marcos is charged with racketeering, conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction. Her husband, who also was charged in the 1988 indictment, died in September. Khashoggi is charged with obstruction and mail fraud.

DOC.HEAD: Group Claims Responsibility for Sabotage Disrupting Power to 92,000
DOC.TEXT: An underground environmental group claims responsibility for vandalism that cut power to 92,000 Pacific Gas & Electric customers. Hand-written messages delivered Monday to several media organizations apologized to those who were without power for six hours Sunday and early Monday in Santa Cruz County but asked for understanding for the action by the Earth Night Action Group. The message, delivered in a plain white envelope, blamed PG&E for ``recent buy-outs of solar energy companies (and) exposes PG&E's attempt to shelter the public from environmentally safe sources of energy ... E.N.A.G. apologizes for inconvenience, but asks public to consider the destruction the earth endures to provide electricity.'' A young male caller to The Associated Press telephoned a few minutes after delivery of the message to ask if it had been received. Similar copies of the message went to Bay City News Service and the San Francisco Examiner. The caller refused to give his name or his telephone number. The vandalism, in which a wooden utility pole was cut and a steel transmission tower toppled, was the first sabotage directed against PG&E since a series of power substation bombings in the mid-1970s, said utility spokesman Ron Rutkowski. ``Our only comment is that PG&E and various law enforcement agencies aim at identifying apparent sabotage to PG&E power lines ..., and (the power outage) inconvenienced thousands of families, businesses, schools and government offices,'' PG&E spokeswoman Jan Stewart said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Kosovo Communist Leader, 13 Other Ethnic Albanians Acquitted
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen prominent ethnic Albanians, including the former Communist Party leader of troubled Kosovo province, were acquitted today on charges of inciting anti-government protests. It was considered the biggest political trial in this Balkan nation in four decades. The trial had been widely criticized by Yugoslav and Western human rights groups. Chief judge Ismet Emra acquitted Azem Vlasi, Kosovo's former Communist Party chief, and the 13 other defendants. He cited a lack of evidence. Public prosecutor Spasoje Zamfirovic indicated he would demand a retrial, the official Tanjug news agency reported. Thousands of ethnic Albanians, chanting ``Azem, Azem!'' celebrated the acquittals, as riot police stood by. Police also patrolled other major towns in the province to prevent ethnic clashes between Albanians and Serbs. No major incidents were reported, although some Vlasi supporters reportedly threw stones at police. Serbs, who represent a minority in Kosovo, received the verdict ``with disappointment,'' Belgrade radio reported. Ethnic Albanians have been seeking more autonomy for Kosovo, which is part of the Yugoslav republic of Serbia. Vlasi's acquittal was seen as a defeat for Serbia's hard-line Communist President Slobodan Milosevic, a key advocate of holding the trial. The government had originally accused Vlasi and the other defendants of ``counter-revolutionary activities'' for instigating a wave of protests by ethnic Albanians last winter. The indictment charged that the protests eventually led to an armed insurrection that resulted in many deaths. Last week, the charges against the 14 defendants were modified to remove the threat of the death penalty. Vlasi, who was arrested in March 1989, was released after the sentence was announced. ``This is a victory for justice in Yugoslavia,'' a tearful Vlasi said, as he embraced his wife after hearing the verdict. During the six-month trial, Vlasi denied charges that he had instigated the unrest among ethnic Albanians. He claimed the proceedings represented a political trial orchestrated by Milosevic. Ethnic Albanians comprise 90 percent of the population of Kosovo, which borders Albania. The region had enjoyed broad autonomy, but constitutional changes last year gave Serbia control of Kosovo's police, judiciary and education. At least 60 people have died in violent protests by ethnic Albanians over the past year. The Slav minority, consisting mainly of Serbs and Montenegrins, contends the changes were necessary to protect them from harassment by the ethnic Albanians. The Slavs contend the ethnic Albanians are trying to force them from the region.

DOC.HEAD: The Crew of Shuttle Discovery
DOC.TEXT: Here are brief sketches of the five Discovery crew members: Air Force Col. Loren J. Shriver is making his second trip into space as commander of Discovery on its mission to deploy the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope. Shriver heads a crew of space veterans on the flight. The last time the National Aeronautics and Space Administration flew a crew of shuttle veterans was on the first post-Challenger flight, in the fall of 1988. As commander, Shriver is responsible for guiding the shuttle back to the telescope should a problem occur after it is put in orbit. Other crew members then would spacewalk to fix the telescope. The 45-year-old astronaut first flew into space as pilot of NASA's first secret shuttle mission for the Pentagon. That January 1985 flight lasted three days. The excitement surrounding the long-awaited mission continued to mount as the launch day neared, Shriver said in a recent interview at the Johnson Space Center. ``This is a major milestone,'' he said. ``I think they're (scientists using Hubble) going to make some discoveries and answer some questions we've got now and probably raise a lot more than we know about right now.'' Shriver was born in Jefferson, Iowa, and grew up in Paton, Iowa, where his parents still live. He graduated from Paton Consolidated High School. He graduated from the Air Force Academy with a bachelor's degree in aeronautical engineering. He earned a master's degree in astronautical engineering from Purdue University. He attended the Air Force test pilot school at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., and worked on development test and evaluation of the F-15 fighter aircraft. In 1978, he was selected for astronaut training. He and his wife, Susan, have four children.

Marine Col. Charles F. Bolden Jr., pilot of Discovery, says he is awed at the prospect of helping deploy a telescope so important to scientists and the study of the universe. ``There's a lot of sentimental attachment to this thing for me,'' Bolden, a veteran of one previous shuttle mission, said in a recent interview. Bolden noted that although the five Discovery astronauts actually will put the Hubble Space Telescope in orbit, thousands of people have worked on the project. ``I can't even begin to imagine how good we're going to feel'' when its deployed. Bolden, a Vietnam combat veteran, insists he has no unique skills over other NASA pilots that earned him a seat on the celebrated flight. ``I'm just lucky and thankful to be here,'' Bolden said. ``From my standpoint, there's nothing special that I bring other than my own unique personality, and the ability not to be quite as serious as you could possibly get on a flight of this magnitude.'' Bolden, 43, was born in Columbia, S.C., where he graduated from C.A. Johnson High School. He received a bachelor's degree in electrical science from the U.S. Naval Academy and a master's in systems management from the University of Southern California. He also is a graduate of the Navy's test pilot school at Patuxent River, Md. While in Southeast Asia, Bolden flew more than 100 missions as an A-6 attack plane pilot. Bolden was selected for astronaut training in 1980. He was a pilot on his first trip into space _ a January 1986 mission that was the last shuttle to fly before Challenger exploded shortly after liftoff. He and his wife, Alexis, have two children.

Mission specialist Steven A. Hawley will use Discovery's 50-foot robot arm to hoist the Hubble Space Telescope out of the cargo bay and place it in space. As an astrophysicist, Hawley has a special interest in the telescope. He even went to graduate school with some of the scientists who will use Hubble once it is in orbit. ``It's unquestionably a major step,'' the 38-year-old astronaut said. ``It's not unfair, I think, to speculate that the kind of things the Hubble telescope may see will be revolutionary in terms of what we know about the universe.'' ``We know a lot now, we think,'' he said. ``There are some very important questions, however, that just have been beyond our grasp because'' scientists have not been able to see distant areas clearly. Hawley, one of three mission specialists on Discovery, also is the flight engineer _ the crew member who sits on the flight deck during ascent and landing to assist the commander and pilot. Hawley first flew on a seven-day mission in 1984 in which three satellites were deployed. His current crew member, Charles Bolden, also was on board Hawley's second mission, a January 1986 flight that was the last to fly before the Challenger explosion. He was born in Ottawa, Kan., and grew up in Salina, Kan., where he graduated from Salina High School. Hawley received a bachelor's degree in physics and astronomy from the University of Kansas and a doctorate in astronomy and astrophysics from the University of California. Before he was selected for astronaut training in 1978, Hawley was a postdoctoral research associate in Chile. He is married to the former Eileen Keegan.

Mission Specialist Bruce McCandless II, a Navy captain and an astronaut since 1966, is one of two crew members who would perform a spacewalk should a problem occur on the Hubble Space Telescope. McCandless' first space flight was a February 1984 mission aboard Challenger. During that flight, he and crew member Robert L. Stewart pioneered the use of NASA's manned maneuvering unit _ a backpack device that allows an astronaut walking in space to propel himself from the shuttle. The 52-year-old astronaut is low key about his spacewalking experience, saying only that ``it's very nice.'' ``The biggest problem is you do have limited mobility,'' he said. McCandless was born in Boston. He moved to California and graduated from Woodrow Wilson Senior High School in Long Beach. He graduated from the U.S. Naval Academy, earned a master's degree in electrical engineering from Stanford University and a master's in business administration from the University of Houston at Clear Lake in 1987. He was a naval aviator who participated in the Cuban blockade in the 1962 missile crisis. McCandless was selected for astronaut training during the Gemini program, and he was a backup pilot for the first manned Skylab mission in 1973. McCandless and his wife, Bernice, have two grown children. He is a member of the National Audubon Society and once was president of the Houston Audubon Society.

Mission Specialist Kathryn D. Sullivan is the second crew member designated to walk in space if necessary during the Discovery mission. Sullivan was the first U.S. woman to perform a spacewalk as she and fellow crewman David Leetsma demonstrated satellite refueling techniques in space in 1984. It was her first trip into space. The 38-year-old astronaut said she enjoyed her spacewalk, but she would prefer a problem-free mission to another opportunity to spacewalk. ``I'm there, I'm ready,'' Sullivan said. ``I'm the center fielder who moves over to cover the right fielder.'' Sullivan was born in Paterson, N.J. She grew up in Woodland Hills, Calif., where she graduated from Taft High School. She earned a bachelor's degree in earth sciences from the University of California, Santa Cruz, and a doctorate in geology from Dalhousie University in Halifx, Nova Scotia. Before joining NASA in 1978, she concentrated on academic study and research. Since she came to NASA, her research interests have included planetary geology. In 1985, she became an adjunct professor of geology at Rice University in Houston. Sullivan is a private pilot, rated in powered and glider aircraft. She is single.

DOC.HEAD: Agency Rejects Proposal to Tax Children's Social Security Benefits
DOC.TEXT: The Social Security Administration has rejected a proposal that it collect income taxes on many Social Security benefits paid to children claimed as dependents by their parents. The agency rejected the proposal, made by the inspector general of the Health and Human Services Department, as ``anti-family'' and contrary to President Bush's goal of a ``kindler, gentler America.'' Inspector General Richard Kusserow recommended, in an audit released Tuesday, that the taxes be paid by most of the 334,000 middle- and upper-income families whose children how receive tax-free benefits. Even as the children were receiving the tax-free benefits, about 4.5 million retirees and disabled beneficiaries and their spouses at the same income levels were paying income taxes on as much as one-half of their Social Security benefits. Kusserow's report was based on a study of benefits and taxes in 1986. He called the present Social Security policy ``inequitable'' and said it will cost the government more than $1 billion in lost revenues over the next five years. Children pay no income tax on their Social Security benefits unless their income exceeds $25,000 a year. In a memo included in the report, Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn King rejected the proposal, saying she was concerned about how it would be perceived by Congress and the public. Congress did not intend for children's benefits to be taxable income to anyone other than the children who receive them, she said. Also, she said, taxing the benefits of children claimed as dependents by parents could be considered anti-family, and taxing disabled children's benefits ``could appear harsh and contrary to a `kinder, gentler America.'''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
Astronomers Thrilled at Liftoff of Discovery, Telescope
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 5 grafs recasts to separate partial quote in lead from full quote, pickup 4th pvs bgng ``Discovery's liftoff'' and deletes last 2 grafs original.
DOC.TEXT: Jubilant astronomers saw decades of work take wing Tuesday as the Hubble Space Telescope was boosted high above Earth to launch ``a great adventure for mankind.'' Charles Robert O'Dell, a Rice University space physicist who has worked 19 years on Hubble, said seeing it hurled into orbit aboard the shuttle capped an experience that was ``comparable to raising a child. I've been with the program since it was a concept. ``There is nothing better than to see 19 years of my work and five of my friends thrust into orbit,'' he said. Colin Norman, a physics and astronomy professor at Johns Hopkins University and academic affairs director of the Space Telescope Science Institute there, called the launch ``the perfect start to a great adventure for mankind. ``It was incredibly beautiful. The power of the launch was awesome and the telescope has an awesome power,'' Norman said. Discovery's liftoff was especially gratifying since it ended seven years of delays. The $1.5 billion telescope originally was scheduled for launch in 1983 but remained grounded by technical problems and the Challenger explosion.
