Two weeks ago when hundreds of scientists crowded into the Kennedy Space Center, the launch was scrubbed four minutes before liftoff. Only a few dozen of them returned Tuesday, but they were just as excited. ``There were times when we were deeply depressed. There were times when we were elated'' about Hubble's progress, said William H. Jeffreys, a University of Texas astronomer and Hubble's astrometry project leader. Jeffreys said. ``This is one of those times when we are thrilled beyond belief.'' Ed Weiler, NASA program scientist for Hubble, said watching the liftoff was ``a double whammy'' because ``it was my first shuttle launch and the launch of the HST. It really gets to you.''

DOC.HEAD: Migrant Farm Workers Still Face Harsh Life
DOC.TEXT: Migrant farm workers face conditions so harsh that their average lifespan is only 50 years, the chairman of the House Select Committee on Aging said Tuesday. ``It has now been 30 years since Edward R. Murrow's famous television documentary on American farm workers, `Harvest of Shame,''' said Rep. Edward R. Roybal, D-Calif. ``Unfortunately, little has changed in the past 30 years.'' Witnesses who provide health care and housing for migrant farm workers in Florida, California and the Southwest said workers are housed in deplorable conditions, face exposure to dangerous pesticides and have difficulty getting medical treatment. ``Farm workers are old at 40, decrepit at 50,'' said George L. Ortiz, president of the California Human Development Corp. ``And only 2 percent collect Social Security payments. They do not live long enough.'' The average lifespan for an American is 75 years. Roybal said the committee was relying on a 1977 study estimating 3.5 million to 5 million farm workers and dependents live in the United States. However, he called on the federal government to make more complete studies of farm workers.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil's President Goes Shopping to Confirm Lower Prices
DOC.TEXT: President Fernando Collor de Mello paid a surprise visit to a supermarket Tuesday to prove that his anti-inflationary plan has reduced prices. Accompanied by security guards, Collor spent an hour at the supermarket, armed with a list of staple goods whose prices have been frozen since the plan took effect March 16. Onlookers applauded as Collor put 19 items in his shopping cart, including chicken, beef, coffee, rice, sugar, and toilet paper. He paid the equivalent of $28 for the goods and then donated them to a boy who was begging in front of the store. Collor told reporters he had confirmed prices had fallen by 11.5 percent since March 15, when inflation was running at more than 80 percent a month. Government officials are predicting zero inflation for April. However, two private institutions say the Collor administration has drastically underestimated inflation. The prestigious Getulio Vargas Foundation and the Interunion Department of Statistics and Socio-Economic Studies say the cost of living will rise by more than 20 percent this month.

DOC.HEAD: Police Find Body of Colombian Priest Kidnapped Last Week
DOC.TEXT: The mutilated body of a Catholic priest kidnapped a week ago was found Tuesday near the western town of Roldanillo, police said. The priest, Tiberio Fernandez, was kidnapped Thursday along with three other people traveling with him in a car near the town of Trujillo, 185 miles west of Bogota. He was in charge of the parish in Trujillo, a town of 23,000 people. Police said the body of the 53-year-old priest was ``totally mutilated.'' Authorities have neither identified the kidnappers nor discovered any motive for the crime. Right-wing death squads backed by drug traffickers and leftist guerrillas are active in the area of the crime, and both groups have been known to kidnap priests. Fernandez's abduction was one of a series near Trujillo in recent weeks. Unidentified groups have abducted 20 of the town's residents, and five of the victims, including Fernandez, have been killed. Several Catholic priests have been assassinated in Colombia in recent years. On Oct. 3, gunmen killed the Catholic bishop for the eastern state of Arauca, Jesus Emilio Jaramillo. The army blamed leftist guerrillas of the National Liberation Army.

DOC.HEAD: Tank Cars Rupture, Burn at Derailment Site
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to update with fire under control, health advisory lifted, last evacuees, coal fire fought.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Crews today controlled a fire that burned two train tank cars of crude oil at the site of a derailment and turned their attention to the threat of an oil and chemical spill to drinking water. ``Everything looks super,'' said Don Grafton, chief of the Worthington Volunteer Fire Department. ``It looks like we have it licked.'' Except for intermittent flames, firefighters had brought the blaze under control with foam fire retardant, Grafton said. The two cars exploded into flames late Monday night and 15 officials and firefighters monitoring the derailment narrowly escaped injury, authorities said. The explosion came a full day after 29 cars of a 97-car Buffalo & Pittsburgh Railroad freight train plunged into a ravine along Buffalo Creek. The popular fishing creek in this rural community about 45 miles northeast of Pittsburgh is a tributary of the Allegheny River, the source of drinking water for several Pittsburgh-area communities. About 100,000 gallons of oil leaked from four railcars and up to 10,000 gallons of sodium hydroxide, a caustic chemical used to clean drains, leaked from one car, said John Bell, the railroad's general manager. He said some of the oil and a small amount of the chemical spilled into the creek. Booms were set up to skim globs of oil from the water surface. Twelve of the derailed cars carried crude oil, said Don Grafton, chief of the Worthington Volunteer Fire Department. In addition to the two brought under control today, he said the oil burned off from five cars, and one containing more than 26,000 gallons of crude oil had been close enough to be in danger of exploding, Grafton said. Work crews planned to wait until the hot cars cooled before beginning the tedious task of cleaning up the site, Grafton said. Firefighters will pump out crude oil left in tanker cars to prevent more fires and explosions, he said. An advisory recommending that elderly residents, young children and people with respiratory problems stay indoors was lifted shortly before noon, said Betsy Mallison, spokeswoman for the state Department of Environmental Resources. The advisory was issued Monday because of sulfur dioxide emissions from burning coal. About 50 people evacuated from their homes may be allowed to return today if the situation remains stable, Grafton said. Firefighters had hoped to avoid an explosion by cooling the tank cars with water. But they stopped spraying at the request of State Department of Environmental Resources officials who feared that a dike built to contain the runoff would overflow. Firefighters and officials retreated just before the tankers burst into flames, Allegheny County Fire Marshal John Kaus said. ``We just started to come off the hillside, and we heard a loud hissing and then a rumble ...,'' Kaus said. The tankers exploded moments apart, he said. ``The only thing we saw _ in front of us, in back of us, on top of us _ was fire. ... I never want to go through it again. The only thing I could attribute it to was like walking through hell,'' Kaus said. ``If it had happened five to 10 minutes earlier, we would have lost 15 to 20 men.'' Two carloads of smoldering coal were moved to a field about 150 yards from the track, Bell said. The coal was spread on the ground and sprayed with water to cool it. About 200 people had been evacuated late Sunday, but most were allowed to return home Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Arson Investigators Probing Greyhound Bus Fires
DOC.TEXT: A man has been charged with setting fire to two Greyhound Lines buses, but investigators say he was not employed by the strike-bound carrier that has been plagued by violence. Shots have damaged 36 buses and three terminals since Greyhound's 6,300 drivers and 3,000 maintenance and office workers walked out over wages and job security at America's only nationwide bus system, the company says. Clifton Wayne Kendrick, 28, was arrested late Monday in connection with the weekend bus fires and another blaze at a residence, police said. He was a drifter with no association with the strike-bound carrier, fire department investigator Alfredo Castro Jr. said. Several striking workers outside the San Antonio bus terminal Sunday had said they believed transients started the blazes. The bus fires, reported late Saturday, were started by emergency flares taken from a compartment on one of the vehicles, officials said. The fires burned out before destroying the buses because of a lack of oxygen, said fire Capt. Dan Davila. Damage was estimated at $40,000. It was the second bus arson attack since the strike began March 2, authorities said. Flares were used similarly in Boston about two weeks ago to set two buses afire, Greyhound spokesman George Gravley said.

DOC.BYLINE: Embargoed for 6:30 p.m. EDT; time set by source ^Refugees Said to Top 15 Million World-Wide ^By CARL HARTMAN
DOC.TEXT: There were more than 15 million refugees last year despite the easing of international tension, the U.S. Committee for Refugees said Tuesday. ``The number of refugees worldwide has increased by 50 percent in the last five years _ from 10 million in 1985 to 15 million in 1989,'' Robert P. Winter, director of the private group, said in a statement. ``That does not take into account at least that many more persons who have fled their homes for the same reasons as refugees, but who remain within the boundaries of their countries.'' The committee had estimated the total number of refugees at 14.4 million the previous year. The opening of the border between East Germany and West Germany brought a large westward flow at the end of 1989. However, the committee said its numbers didn't include 720,000 ethnic Germans who went to West Germany from Eastern Europe, three times as many as the year before. The committee says its annual report contains the most comprehensive statistics available. Precise figures cannot be obtained in many remote areas, however. The number of refugees in Sudan are estimated at from 2 million to 3.2 million. Most of the 1989 increase came in Africa. Malawi, one of the world's poorest countries, shelters 812,000 refugees from Mozambique, which is even poorer. The refugees have fled civil war in Mozambique and their numbers were increasing as 1989 ended. Another 80,000 fled civil war in Sudan and 40,000 left Angola for Namibia. Hundreds of thousands have been displaced within Burma during 40 years of civil war, the committee said. More than a million refugees come from each of four areas: Afghanistan, Mozambique, Ethiopia and Israel. Despite the Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan, the biggest single source of refugees, the report said 5.9 million Afghans remained outside their homeland. Most are in Pakistan and Iran. Between 1975 and 1988 the United States accepted the largest number of refugees: 1,249,608, or one for every 199 Americans. Canada was second, with 252,225, but the proportion was larger _ one for every 104 Canadians. Sweden, Australia and Denmark also took proportionally larger numbers than the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Norman Cousins Wins Niwano Peace Prize
DOC.TEXT: Norman Cousins, who in 1957 founded the U.S. National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy, received the Niwano Peace Prize from a Buddhist group Tuesday for his work on behalf of nuclear disarmament. The Niwano Peace Foundation awards the $126,000 prize each year to an individual or group deemed to have made an outstanding contribution to world peace through inter-religious cooperation. ``Cousins devoted himself to the nuclear disarmament movement almost since the inception of nuclear weapons, campaigning tirelessly for the reduction of nuclear arsenals both in the United States and elsewhere,'' the foundation said. In 1949, Cousins established a foster care program for 400 children orphaned by the atomic bombing of Hiroshima. He also arranged for people badly burned in the bombing to receive medical treatment in the United States. An estimated 140,000 people were killed in the U.S. atomic attack on the city in the closing days of World War II. ``His combination of theory and practice have won him worldwide respect as a humanist impelled by love and compassion for humanity,'' the foundation said. The foundation was established in 1978 by Rissho Kosei-Kai, a Japanese lay Buddhist organization. Cousins was editor of the U.S. magazine Saturday Review for 35 years until his retirement in 1977. Since then, he has taught at the University of California, Los Angeles. He is also president of the World Federalists' Association of the United States. ``It has not been easy, I recognize, for Japan to resist both national and external pressures to join the arms race of the superpowers,'' Cousins said in an acceptance speech. Cousins was selected from among 728 nominees from 121 nations.

Here, at a glance, are highlights of actions taken Tuesday by the Supreme Court.
DEATH APPEAL
The court, ruling in the case of an Arkansas mass murderer, allowed states to execute convicted murderers even if no appeals court reviews the validity of their convictions or death sentences. By a 7-2 vote, the justices threw out an appeal filed for _ but not by _ R. Gene Simmons, sentenced to death for killing 16 relatives and acquaintances in 1987. The court said such an appeal cannot be filed by a fellow death row inmate. The case is Whitmore vs. Arkansas, 88-7146.
REAR WINDOW
The court said, in a ruling that could affect millions of dollars in movie industry profits, that distributors of the Alfred Hitchcock thriller ``Rear Window'' must share with a literary agent earnings from the film's re-release. The 6-3 ruling was a defeat for actor Jimmy Stewart and Hitchcock's heirs. Some film producers claimed it could limit availability of movie classics. The case is Stewart vs. Abend, 88-2102.
GUAM
The court ruled that the U.S. territory of Guam and its officials may not be sued for allegedly violating a much-used federal civil rights law. The justices, by a 6-2 vote, threw out part of a lawsuit filed by six Guam residents who said police punched, kicked and threatened them to get them to confess to drug-related crime. The law allows those who prove government actions or policies violated their constitutional rights to collect monetary damages. The case is Ngiraingas vs. Sanchez, 88-1281.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Cautious on Durable Goods Report
With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Orders for big-ticket durable goods in March posted their best showing in more than a year, but analysts gave the government report a subdued review. ``It's pretty much in line with what we have been seeing all quarter,'' said Michael K. Evans of Evans Economics Inc. in Washington. ``The economy is picking up. Clearly there's no sign of a recession. On the other hand, it's not a boom either.'' The Commerce Department said orders for durable goods _ items expected to last more than three years _ jumped 6.7 percent to a seasonally adjusted $128.8 billion. It was the largest increase since a 7.4 percent gain in December 1988. However, analysts noted that most of the growth was consigned to the aircraft industry. Excluding the transportation category, orders rose 2 percent. ``It's not nearly as good as the 6.7 percent would suggest because most of it was just a turnaround in aircraft orders,'' Evans said. Aircraft orders had declined for two consecutive months. ``I'm not going to denegrate this number,'' said Robert G. Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Co. in Chicago. ``But at the same time ... you're talking about a durable goods sector that's still in the same sort of sideways drift that it's been in for a number of months.'' Economist Thomas Runiewicz of the WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., noted that orders rose in all categories _ ``a sign that economic growth will be more positive for the remainder of 1990.'' ``This definitely supports that we are coming out of the economic slowdown,'' Runiewicz said. Another bright spot in the March report was a 14.9 percent jump, to $41.4 billion, in the closely watched non-defense capital goods orders. That sector often is a leading indicator of future business investment plans. The March report was the second monthly rebound from January's record 10.5 percent decline brought about by sharp drops in aircraft and automobile orders. Aircraft orders continued to fall in February, but a resumption in automobile orders helped push overall orders up 2.3 percent. However, that was weaker than the 3.3 percent gain originally reported last month. But transportation orders advanced 21 percent in March, mostly because of aircraft orders although demand for automobiles also rose significantly, the Commerce Department said. It was the largest transportation gain since a 22.1 percent increase in December 1988. Smaller increases were posted elsewhere: primary metals, up 7 percent to $11.7 billion; non-electrical machinery, up 1.6 percent to $22.7 billion; and electrical machinery, up 1.1 percent to $20.1 billion. The often-volatile defense orders fell 4.5 percent, to $7.3 billion, after rising 18.4 percent in February. Excluding defense, however, orders rose 7.5 percent, the largest increase since an 8.3 percent jump in September 1980. Shipments of durable goods were up 1.5 percent to $125 billion, while unfilled orders rose 0.8 percent to $496.7 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Shooting at Suburban Atlanta Mall Kills One
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with police charging and identifying suspect. Restores time element. Picks up 4th graf, ``Todd Smith...''
DOC.TEXT: A man in a business suit opened fire today in the food court of a suburban shopping mall, killing one man and wounding at least three other people, authorities said. James Calvin Brady, 32, of Atlanta was charged with one count of murder and three counts of aggravated assault, DeKalb County Public Safety Director Thomas Brown said. As officers led Brady away he muttered, ``You don't know what all these people have done to me,'' Brown said. He said police had not established a motive for the attack. ``We don't believe it was directed toward the individuals who were shot; we think it was directed toward people in general,'' Brown said. Todd Smith, assistant manager of a deli at Perimeter Mall, said he looked up when he thought he heard a balloon pop about 11:30 a.m. and saw a man in a suit firing off about four rounds. ``It appears to be random,'' he said, adding that the diners in the area panicked. ``Everybody just ... dispersed. He threw the gun in the trash can and then he walked off.'' One man, wounded in the chest, was taken to Northside Hospital, where he died about 1{ hours after the shooting, hospital spokeswoman Carol King said. His identity was not released. Three more victims _ two women and a man _ were taken to Shallowford Hospital. Hospital spokeswoman Cathy McAfee said the man, in his 20s, suffered a leg wound that was not life-threatening and was listed in stable but critical condition. The two women were in stable condition. One, in her 50s, had a pelvic wound and the other, in her 70s, suffered an abdominal wound, she said. There was some confusion over the number of people shot. Police at first said four, then five, but hospital officials said only four people were taken to the two hospitals. The food court was not crowded, said Willie Edwards, a delivery driver for a men's store in the mall. ``This was like pre-lunch hour; it really hadn't got as crowded as it could have been,'' he said. Mary Jo Cullinan, manager of Brentanos bookstore, said she and four customers heard the gunfire. ``I suddenly heard six shots fired,'' she said. ``We ran into the back of the store. We came out when we couldn't hear anything. Two of the customers asked to leave out the back door because they didn't want to go back out into the mall, understandably.''

DOC.HEAD: Keating Re-Elected AP Chairman, Daniels Chosen as Chairman-Elect
DOC.TEXT: William J. Keating was re-elected chairman of the board of directors of The Associated Press on Tuesday, and Frank A. Daniels Jr. was elected vice chairman and chairman-elect by the board. Keating is chairman and publisher of The Cincinnati Enquirer. His term as a director will expire in 1992. Daniels is president and publisher of The News & Observer of Raleigh, N.C. Louis D. Boccardi was re-elected president and general manager. The AP board's reorganization meeting also included the seating of one new director and five incumbents and the election of two new vice presidents. The AP management officers newly elected to one-year terms as vice presidents were William E. Ahearn, executive editor, and James R. Williams, director of AP Broadcast Services. In addition to Boccardi, AP management officers re-elected to one-year terms were James F. Tomlinson, vice president and secretary; Patrick T. O'Brien, vice president and treasurer, and vice presidents Claude E. Erbsen, Walter R. Mears, John W. Reid and Wick Temple. Also re-elected from the AP were assistant secretaries Lilo Jedelhauser and Lee Perryman, and assistant treasurers Frederick R. Barberi, Paul H. Jenssen and Roger P. Sturm. At the AP's annual meeting Monday, the news cooperative's membership elected one new director to the board and re-elected five incumbent members. David J. Whichard II, president and editor of The Daily Reflector of Greenville, N.C., was elected to represent a city of under 50,000 population, succeeding retiring director John O. Emmerich Jr. of The Greenwood (Miss.) Commonwealth. Emmerich was not eligible for re-election because he served the maximum of three consecutive three-year terms on the board. The incumbents re-elected to new three-year terms on the AP board were James K. Batten, chairman and chief executive officer of Knight-Ridder, Inc., based in Miami; J. Stewart Bryan III, chairman and publisher of the Richmond (Va.) Times-Dispatch and The Richmond News Leader; Ruth S. Holmberg, publisher of The Chattanooga (Tenn.) Times; Tom Johnson, chairman of the Los Angeles Times, and Joe D. Smith Jr., president of the Alexandria (La.) Daily Town Talk. The board of directors also reappointed Robert Morse of WMAQ-TV, Chicago, as a representative of the broadcasting industry. He will serve a two-year term.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Prefer No Challenge to GOP Sen. John Warner
DOC.TEXT: Democrats have decided against nominating anyone to oppose Republican Sen. John W. Warner. The decision blocks a Democratic bid by a Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. supporter, the state Democratic chairman said Tuesday. The party chairman, Paul Goldman, said he had reports on about 1,500 of the 1,800 delegates elected at mass meetings around the state Saturday and Monday. ``About 90 percent of the people have been elected for no candidate,'' Goldman said. Slightly less than 10 percent were uncommitted and four delegates supported former U.S. Rep. Joseph Fisher, who has not decided whether to run. Nancy Spannaus, a follower of LaRouche, received no support for her bid for the Democratic nomination, Goldman said. ``This is an unprecedented repudiation of political extremism,'' he said. ``I'm really proud of the Democratic Party all across the state.'' To block Mrs. Spannaus' candidacy, the Democratic state central committee agreed that the party convention would be canceled if more than 50 percent of the Democrats attending the mass meetings did not want a candidate. The committee still could select a nominee by a two-thirds vote before the June 12 filing deadline. ``I don't know what will happen,'' Goldman said. ``Maybe a candidate will come forward, maybe one won't.'' He declined to say whether the committee would support Fisher. ``I'm not going to prejudge anything,'' Goldman said. Mrs. Spannaus has said she may run as an independent. She has described herself as a Democrat, but Goldman said he did not think she would confuse voters. With Warner, 63, well-financed and heavily favored for re-election to a third term, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder said in January he would rather his fellow Democrats nominate no one than a weak candidate. Bu Goldman said Democrats would continue to criticize Warner's record in Washington. ``We still have a case to be made against Warner,'' he said. ``We're just looking for somebody to make the case.''

DOC.HEAD: New York Lawyer Wants to Defend 2nd Assassination Suspect
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer who won acquittal for a defendant in the 1976 assassination of former Chilean ambassador Orlando Letelier said Tuesday he wants to represent another man charged in the killing. New York attorney Paul Goldberger appeared in U.S. District Court with Jose Dionisio Suarez Esquivel, a Cuban exile arrested April 11 in the car bombing that killed Letelier. Suarez had been a fugitive since his 1978 indictment. Ed Sussman was appointed by the court to represent Suarez, who was arrested in St. Peterburg, Fla. Suarez's family and friends will decide whether to retain Goldberger, who earlier represented Guillermo Novo Sampol. Novo, indicted for conspiracy, killing a foreign official and five other charges, was acquitted in the Letelier case eight years ago. Assistant U.S. Attorney Eric Marcy said Goldberger's entry into the case would present a serious conflict of interest because Novo is a potential government witness against Suarez. Goldberger said he doubted prosecutors would call Novo, who he said did not intend to cooperate with the government. Raising the conflict issue ``might be a way to get us out of the case,'' Goldberger said in a brief interview outside the courtroom. U.S. District Court Judge Aubrey Robinson said he would address the question of conflict of interest if Goldberger is hired. Suarez is accused of murdering a foreign official and four other charges in the death of Letelier, Chile's ambassador to Washington from 1970 to 1973 under the Marxist government of Salvador Allende. Also indicted were the two top officials in Chile's intelligence service during the military rule of Gen. Augusto Pinochet. The Chilean courts have refused to extradite the two former officials.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says No Sanctions Against Soviets At This Time
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 4 grafs after 5th graf pvs, Administration officials... to UPDATE with Fitzwater comment; picks up 6th graf pvs, I'm not...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he will not impose sanctions on the Soviet Union in response to the Kremlin's crackdown in Lithuania, saying such steps at this time could backfire. ``I'm concerned that we not inadvertently do something that compels the Soviet Union to take action that would set back the whole case of freedom around the world,'' Bush said after a meeting with congressional leaders. Bush told a group of agricultural writers that while he was not ready to announce penalties at this time against the Soviet Union, ``If there were anything done, it would ... be on the economic side.'' Bush also said he would not consider imposing a grain embargo on the Soviet Union in response to its actions in Lithuania. Administration officials said Bush, who appeared a day ago to be on the brink of imposing economic penalties, decided to wait after reports from Moscow that U.S. sanctions could wind up making the situation worse in Lithuania. White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said that Bush decided to hold off on any sanctions at this time after consultations with leaders of ``at least 20 countries.'' There was a ``confluence of voices,'' particularly from allies in Western Europe, against strong U.S. steps against Moscow, Fitzwater said. He cited concerns of Soviet countermoves, not only against Lithuania and other Baltic states, but in Poland and other fragile new Eastern European democracies. Still, Fitzwater said, Bush still retains the right to impose economic sanctions to protest Soviet tactics in Lithuania _ and might do so at any time. ``I'm not going to give up trying to get the Soviet Union and the Lithuanians into a dialogue,'' Bush said. ``I would encourage the Soviet Union and the Lithuanians to go forward right now with dialogue,'' he said. ``Let's hope they can start talking. This results in a great deal of potential for the freedom that we seek for the Lithuanians.'' ``Therein lies the answer,'' Bush said. ``I will let the American people know, and the Congress know, when I decide to take certain action. And the decision has not been made,'' he added. Administration officials had said earlier that Bush was near a decision on a package of economic penalties. But participants at today's congressional meeting said the president voiced repeated concerns over Soviet retaliation against Lithuania should the United States step up its pressure on Moscow. Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I, said Bush told congressional leaders he was not prepared to announce sanctions at this time because ``the action could precipitate an escalation. We don't want to see that happen.'' Pell, speaking to reporters on the White House driveway after the hour-long session, said that there emerged from the session ``a general feeling of support for the president.'' Rep. Dante Fascell, D-Fla., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, suggested one factor in Bush's hesitancy to act could be because that U.S. allies in Western Europe ``are not willing to consider stiff economic sanctions.'' Fascell said he told Bush that a better response would be to postpone the May 30-June 3 superpower summit. ``That would send a message all around the world,'' Fascell said. He said the president did not respond to the suggestion. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., gave Bush a vote of confidence following the White House meeting. ``I think the president is proceeding carefully, and think that is the appropriate course,'' Foley told reporters. ``I am not at all critical of the president. I think he's approaching it appropriately.'' Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, said that Bush indicated he wanted to ``consult with members of Congress'' on the situation and added, ``I don't think any decisions were arrived at.'' Bentsen called the crisis in Lithuania a situation ``where a great deal of discretion'' would be given to the president. A report from Moscow quoting Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Vadim P. Perfiliev suggesting that U.S. sanctions could wind up backfiring and hurting Lithuania may have been a factor in Bush's decision, an administration official said. The measures under consideration included delaying or withholding a variety of planned trade, investment and other economic concessions that the United States had been prepared to grant the Soviet Union, said officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The would, in effect, put a hold on U.S.-Soviet trade liberalization talks, which were scheduled to get under way today in Paris. The Kremlin says sanctions could hurt both Lithuania and the overall international situation. Perfiliev said that Moscow's dispute with Lithuania was ``a problem which is purely an internal affair, and any actions which could pull the sides in the argument even further apart could have negative consequences, not only for the Soviet Union but for the international situation.''

DOC.HEAD: Hubble Out of this World _ At Last
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: Seven years late, the Hubble Space Telescope is where it belongs, out of this world and in search of others so distant that they may have been formed at the beginning of time. Less than five hours after it rode into space aboard the shuttle Discovery on Tuesday, the $1.5 billion telescope sent its first test radio signal. At the sign of life, applause and cheers erupted in Mission Control in Houston. ``As near as we can tell, everything looks perfect,'' said astronaut Steve Hawley from the shuttle. Hawley's job on Wednesday will be to drop the telescope overboard for a 15-year stay in space. Discovery, trailing an arc of white smoke into a brilliant blue sky, carried the silver-colored telescope to an orbit 380 miles above Earth _ higher by 70 miles than any previous shuttle. There the Hubble will stay to search for yet-unseen wonders of creation with instruments that can look 14 billion years backward in time. ``Our window on the universe!'' NASA launch commentator George Diller exulted as the Discovery rose off its seaside launch pad. ``It's a beautiful day to have Hubble Space Telescope in orbit instead of here on Earth like it's been for so many years,'' said NASA administrator Richard Truly. ``Hubble's in its element and I'm delighted.'' The telescope was supposed to be launched in 1983, but technical problems and the Challenger accident delayed its deployment. It suffered a further delay two weeks ago when the countdown was stopped at the four-minutes-to-go point because of a faulty hydraulic unit on the shuttle. While it remained on Earth, the telescope cost $7 million a month to exercise and keep in readiness. In its first day in space, that checkout and testing continued remotely under control of the Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland. On hand to watch the Discovery launching was a contingent of scientists who have hailed the Hubble as the greatest advance in astronomy since Galileo raised a small telescope to his eyes nearly 400 years ago. Truly referred to the early-day astronomer when he was asked about the long delays in getting the telescope to its working station. ``Somebody the other day said, `Who remembers the day that Galileo picked up his telescope to look at the stars?''' said Truly, a former shuttle astronaut. ``It doesn't matter what day we launch Hubble, it matters that we do it right.'' The telescope is 43 feet long and 14 feet in diameter, about the size of a railroad tank car. When it flies free, it will receive electrical power for its six scientific instruments from two wing-like solar arrays that extend outward on each side. It is named after the late astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, who theorized that the universe was expanding and that the farther away a galaxy is, the faster it is traveling. That gave support to the theory that a massive explosion _ the Big Bang _ created the universe 10 to 20 billion years ago. The Hubble is expected to help provide the answer to two major questions: How old is the universe? How big is it? The telescope has two mirrors, one 94.5 inches in diameter, the other 12 inches. Two of the instruments are cameras, two are spectrometers and one is a photometer. In addition, the fine pointing system acts as a sixth instrument by providing precise measurement of distances. On Wednesday, Hawley is to grapple the 12{-ton telescope with the shuttle's mechanical arm, lift it out of the cargo bay, point it, and _ after a long checkout _ drop it overboard to orbit on its own. In the cargo bay, the telescope receives electrical power from the shuttle. But the juice is cut when the instrument is lifted out and it will depend on internal batteries until the solar panels are extended to receive light from the sun. Should the solar panels not deploy, mission specialists Bruce McCandless and Kathryn Sullivan will be standing by, partially dressed in space suits, ready to go into the open cargo bay to unfurl the arrays manually. Discovery's launch was not without its problems. With 31 seconds left in the countdown, the computer that runs the final moments before liftoff refused to close a fuel valve and stopped the launch process. The problem was overcome and the shuttle lifted off at 8:34 a.m. EDT, about three minutes late. The shuttle is scheduled to land Sunday at 9:49 a.m. EDT at Edwards Air Force Base in California. ``On the way uphill,'' as Commander Loren J. Shriver put it, the shuttle's windshield was splattered with ``several flecks of things.'' He said the windshield was streaked by the debris and that it also was smeared when the spent booster rockets fell off during the climb to orbit. The astronauts also had problems with their UHF radio circuit, and one of the ship's small rear thrusters was inoperative. Neither problem was considered serious.

DOC.HEAD: Zaireans Pour Into Streets to Celebrate Democracy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with second party legalized, opposition leader released from prison; Picks up 6th graf, `He said ...'
DOC.TEXT: Bowing to weeks of pressure, President Mobutu Sese Seko said Tuesday he had lifted a 20-year ban on opposition parties and would let a multiparty government replace his in a year. Thousands of Zaireans chanting, singing and waving branches poured into downtown Kinshasa, the capital, and blocked the streets to cheer the president's decision. Mobutu, absolute ruler since taking power Nov. 24, 1965, announced in a nationally broadcast speech that he was setting up a transitional government to rule until free elections could be held. No election date was set. ``I am taking leave of the Popular Movement for the Revolution (MPR),'' said Mobutu, 59. He said he would no longer be head of the party that supplanted the government in 1970, but would remain as president ``at the request of the people of Zaire.'' Mobutu said three parties will be allowed at first. His Popular Movement for the Revolution, which under Zaire's law was the country's government, no longer will hold any special status, he said. Mobutu said one leading opposition figure, Etienne Tshisekedi, was released from detention Tuesday and his Union for Democracy and Social Progess party legalized. He did not say which of several other opposition groups, whose leaders are in exile, would be selected as the third legal party. He said the constitution will be rewritten and a transitional government established until elections are held. The elections will produce a new government by April 24, 1991, he said. In recent weeks, Mobutu had been battered by a wave of unprecedented criticism. He began a tour of the nation in January, seeking public comment on his rule. Thousands of replies were sent in from business groups, churches, unions, students and individuals. Many bitterly critized the government and Mobutu himself, accusing the president and his cronies of corruption and monopolizing power. The country's Roman Catholic bishops compared Mobutu's rule to a monarchy. Mobutu did not reply directly to the criticisms but promised ``the will of the majority will be respected. We will proceed together on the changes wanted by the majority.'' The former journalist and army sergeant has ruled the former Belgian Congo since Nov. 24, 1965. He renamed the country and ran it almost as a personal fiefdom. Like most African presidents, Mobutu has asserted one-party rule was the only way to avoid tribalism. In the country's first five years of independence, more than 100,000 people died in fighting attributed to ethnic or regional conflicts. Since 1970, every citizen of Zaire has been automatically registered as a member of the official party. Opposition groups were brutally repressed, and Mobutu claimed 99.99 percent of the vote in presidential elections. He renamed the country Zaire and ordered Zaireans to replace their Christian names with African names. Men were required to replace Western-style suits and neckties with high-necked jackets. As part of Mobutu's campaign to replace European influences, he ordered that people address each other as ``citizen,'' rather than ``sir'' or ``madame.'' Mobutu himself changed his name from Joseph Desire Mobutu to Mobutu Sese Seko, translated as ``the all powerful warrior who ... '' Perhaps most symbolic about Mobutu's announcement Tuesday was his declaration that Western-style suits would no longer be banned, and people could again call each other ``sir'' or ``madame.'' After taking power, Mobutu nationalized key industries, including copper production, and replaced expatriate advisers and experts with Zaireans. Production collapsed, along with much of country's infrastructure. Mobutu was accused of using his plan to plunder the country's wealth. His critics say he amassed several billion dollars. Twice he needed major Western military intervention to put down revolts, and international organizations and opposition leaders said he brutally repressed any opposition. But the United States and other Western governments supported Mobutu, who was committed to opposing the expansion of Marxism in the region. Zaire has been a conduit of U.S. aid to anti-Marxist guerrillas in Angola, Zaire's southern neighbor. Critics of Mobutu in the U.S. Congress say the radical decline in East-West tensions has made cultivation of Mobutu unnecessary.

DOC.HEAD: Five Instruments Give the Telescope Its Flexibility
DOC.TEXT: Later this week, a command radioed from Earth will open the lens cap on the Hubble Space Telescope and allow the first light from space to strike its mirror. If telescopes have a most-important moment, that will be it. It will mean that Hubble, flying free 380 miles above the world, has opened its eyes to the heavens and is ready to make discoveries not yet imagined. NASA is so concerned about that lens cap opening, it is keeping the shuttle Discovery in the neighborhood just in case. Astronauts Bruce McCandless and Kathryn Sullivan will be suited up, ready to walk in space to open the cap _ formally called an aperture door _ by hand. Opening that door is step 65 in a sequence NASA laid out to activate and check out the $1.5 billion telescope and its five instruments before the shuttle pulls away and leaves the Hubble to its own devices. The instruments themselves, mounted behind the telescope's 94.5 inch mirror, were warmed up Tuesday, soon after the shuttle lifted into a sunny Florida sky. Their ability to communicate with the ground was checked one-by-one. One of the instruments, the Wide-Field and Planetary Camera, operates in two modes as its name implies. In the wide-field mode, the camera can photograph a giant galaxy 60 million light years from Earth. How far is that? Light travels 5,900,000,000,000 miles in one year. With this instrument, astronomers plan to look into crowded centers of galaxies and search for disk-shaped formations of gas and dust around young stars where new planetary systems may be forming. If they discover a star like our sun and planets like our Earth, they may be on the trail of other life in the universe. In its planetary mode, the camera can photograph entire hemispheres of any planet in our solar system in a single exposure. Scientists will be able to take photographs of Neptune as sharp and detailed as those taken by the two Voyager spacecraft when each was only five days away. A second instrument is the Faint-Object Camera, provided by the European Space Agency. It is designed to detect distant objects and extends the reach of the telescope to the greatest possible distance. This camera will photograph stars seven times farther away than any before it. ``Many stars and galaxies that are considered faint by present standards will be almost blazing light sources to the Faint-Object Camera,'' says a NASA brochure. A third instrument, the Faint-Object Spectrograph, will analyze the light from individual stars and nebulae in our galaxy and those nearby and provide data to deduce their physical and chemical properties. It will investigate more distant galaxies and study light from quasars and whole galaxies. The spectrograph also will be used to study erupting stars _ supernova _ and determine the rate at which the expansion of the universe has been slowing over billions of years. Its conclusions will help settle a scientific argument over nothing less than the likely fate of the universe: If the deceleration rate is small, then the universe will continue to expand forever. If it is as fast as some scientists maintain, then the expansion will come to a halt eventually and the universe will begin to contract. A fourth instrument, the Goddard High Resolution Spectrograph, sees only ultraviolet light to examine physical and chemical conditions in objects it looks at. It will be able to observe trace substances in interstellar space that can't be detected any other way. When the telescope is tracking a bright comet, the spectrograph will search for evidence that comets were formed from interstellar matter. And it will measure temperatures of explosion in the upper atmospheres of red dwarf stars. The simplest instrument on the Hubble, containing no moving parts, is the High-Speed Photometer, a light meter that measures the intensity, wavelength and other properties of light. It will measure the structure and ongoing physical processes in interacting binary stars _ including those that may contain black holes. With this instrument, astronomers will study many of the exotic phenomena in the ring systems of Saturn, Jupiter and Uranus and also will determine the diameters of stars. There is, effectively, a sixth instrument on the Hubble _ fine guidance sensors that point the telescope with precision. From Washington, claim scientists, the sensors could spot a dime in the window of the World Trade Center in Manhattan _ and hold it steady in sight for 24 hours.

DOC.HEAD: German Leaders Set July 2 as Date for Economic, Social Unification
LaserPhoto BON4
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl and East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere on Tuesday named July 2 as the day for economic and social union of the two Germanys, a West German spokesman said. Union in those areas will bring the divided nation a long way toward full unification after more than four decades of separation following the horror of the Nazi dictatorship and defeat in World War II. The issue of political union, or holding an election to form a single government, remains to be worked out. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, joined by their colleagues from Britain, France and the two German states, are scheduled to meet in Bonn on May 5. There, they will try to resolve difficult international aspects of unification, including Germany's future military stance. While early July has frequently been mentioned as a goal for economic, monetary and social union _ meaning the coordination of social benefits, such as unemployment and old age pensions _ Tuesday's statement was the first confirmation of a specific target date. Delegations from both Germanys are to meet in East Berlin on Wednesday to negotiate over how to best introduce the powerhouse West German mark into East Germany's battered economy. The basis of the talks will be Bonn's proposal for monetary union, which calls for a basic 1-1 exchange rate of East German marks for West marks for wages, salaries and pensions in East Germany. The announcements, made by West German government spokesman Dieter Vogel, followed three hours of private talks between Kohl and de Maiziere. De Maiziere was visiting Bonn for the first time as East Germany's prime minister. Vogel said Kohl and de Maiziere spoke in a friendly atmosphere. De Maiziere, talking to reporters after the meeting, was asked whether he had accepted the West German government's latest proposal for monetary union. ``There was nothing for me to accept. The chancellor presented the government's suggestions, and we'll negotiate about them,'' de Maiziere said. He said hammering out a monetary union would require ``many talks and negotiations.'' The West German monetary union proposal, announced Monday, represented a surprising concession to East German demands. East Germans had feared that the exchange rate would be one West German mark for two East German marks _ a rate that was initially proposed by West Germany's central bank. The 1-1 rate will be limited, however, in the case of savings to $2,300 per person. This angered East Germans. Initial steps also were taken Tuesday toward a political union between the two countries. Kohl assigned a working group to put together a proposal for conducting the first all-German elections, government spokesman Hans Klein announced. The group will include representatives from all parties in the coalition _ the conservative Christian Democratic Union, the Christian Social Union and the centrist Free Democrat Party. Kohl's conservative Christian Democratic Union favors holding the first all-German elections at the end of 1991, after West Germany's national elections in December 1990. The Free Democrats, however, want an all-German election in early 1991, skipping the West German national elections this year. In another development, East German Foreign Minister Markus Meckel arrived in Bonn for a meeting with his West German counterpart, Hans-Dietrich Genscher. The talks focused on the merging of Germany within the framework of a united Europe and the so-called ``two plus four'' talks on May 5 between the two Germanys, the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France. One of the main stumbling blocks is the military status of a united Germany. The United States has insisted that Germany be a member of NATO, while the Soviets have demanded that a united Germany be neutral.

DOC.HEAD: Arson Suspected in Fire at Journalist's Home
DOC.TEXT: A preliminary investigation indicates arson caused the fire that killed the wife of a Solidarity journalist who investigated the secret police, a prosecutor told Polish television. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki established a commission to monitor the investigation into the fire that broke out Sunday in the suburban Warsaw apartment of Jerzy Jachowicz, an editor at the daily Gazeta Wyborcza, and his wife, Maria. Mrs. Jachowicz, 49, died after awaking to find the hallway in flames and jumping from a third-floor window, authorities said. Jachowicz escaped serious injury. The couple's 14-year-old daughter was hospitalized after jumping with her mother. Deputy General Prosecutor Aleksander Herzog told state television Monday that investigators have concluded ``with a probability close to certainty that the cause of the fire was criminal arson.'' He said the fire appeared to have been started by a petroleum product. On the prime minister's commission with Herzog are top officials of the interior and justice ministries. Jachowicz has written numerous articles about the Interior Ministry, long used by the Communist authorities to repress dissent in Poland and widely distrusted. Steps have been taken by the Solidarity government to make the ministry adjust to post-Communist Poland. Earlier this month, the parliament voted to restructure the ministry and disband the secret police. The Interior Ministry is still headed by Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak, a former Communist who was retained by the new government.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Commander Predicts Nuclear Talks Could Begin `Sooner Than Later'
DOC.TEXT: NATO's top military commander said Tuesday negotiations to reduce tactical nuclear arms in Europe could begin soon after the expected signing this year of an accord slashing tanks, troops and other non-nuclear forces. U.S. Gen. John Galvin, the supreme allied commander in Europe, also indicated he still supports a new generation of short-range nuclear missiles, but he acknowledged the difficulty in deploying them in Europe. ``In my opinion, there is not unanimous political acceptance at this time of the (missile) in Europe,'' Galvin said in an interview at the headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. With declining East-West tensions, the Bush administration said last week it was postponing development of the weapon, a more powerful version of the aging Lance surface-to-surface missile. The weapon has become increasingly unpopular in West Germany, where most of the missiles would be based. Galvin said he believes the new weapon ``would be an excellent way to support the mission of nuclear deterrence and nuclear defense.'' ``But I would have to say, in all objectivity, that one weapon doesn't make or break an alliance,'' he said. ``If the question is, can I carry out my mission without the follow-on-to-Lance, the answer is yes.'' The Lance was introduced in 1972, and military analysts have said it will become obsolete in 1995. Its maximum range is about 75 miles. Its replacement would be designed to hit a target more than 250 miles away, just under the limits of the 1987 Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces treaty. Galvin predicted that East-West negotiations to pare battlefield nuclear weapons in Europe ``would begin sooner rather than later.'' President Bush and other NATO leaders agreed last spring that bargaining on nuclear arms would not occur until implementation had begun of a treaty on reducing tanks, artillery, troops and other conventional forces in Europe. ``The question becomes what does implementation actually mean ... That probably leaves room for some negotiating as to when it would begin,'' Galvin said. He predicted that bargaining ``could begin very soon after they signed a (conventional arms) treaty.'' Negotiators for the 16 NATO nations and the seven Warsaw Pact countries are pressing at talks in Vienna to try to wrap up a conventional arms accord by the end of the year, possibly in the fall. Galvin ruled out a further reduction in the number of Soviet and American troops stationed in Europe in the current round of Vienna talks. Moscow and Washington have agreed to equal ceilings of 195,000 soldiers stationed outside their national territory in Central Europe. The United States would maintain an additional 30,000 soldiers outside that zone, in Britain and southern Europe. ``There is no other program,'' Galvin said. ``It doesn't mean that I don't think that sometime in the future we might be in a different situation, but right now 195,000 is it.'' He also said he doubted that France would return to NATO's integrated military command despite recent calls from Britain for it to become a full participant in the alliance. ``France has said with great definition that it will not rejoin the military structure,'' Galvin said. France pulled out of the joint military command in 1966, although it still remains a member of the organization.

DOC.HEAD: Andrew Young Files for Georgia Governor
DOC.TEXT: Former Mayor Andrew Young formally entered the Democratic gubernatorial race today, calling his campaign to become the nation's second black elected governor the ``beginning of a new day'' in Georgia. Young, the fifth Democrat to qualify for the ballot, brought a large entourage of well-wishers to the statehouse for the occasion. Young paid homage to Georgia's powerful House speaker, Tom Murphy. He said he looks forward to working with Murphy, who supports rival Democratic candidate Lauren ``Bubba'' McDonald, because ``I think I know where we need to go ... he (Murphy) knows how to get there.'' Young is viewed as a front-runner, but likely to be forced into a runoff with Lt. Gov. Zell Miller. ``If it were held today, that's what we would have,'' Young said. ``But I'm just getting started. And I'm going to use these next three months. I don't run to come in second and I don't run for ties. I run to win.'' Other Democrats who have qualified for the race are state Sen. Roy Barnes and former Gov. Lester Maddox. State Rep. Johnny Isakson is generally considered the Republican front-runner.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: When two hot-air balloon passengers got hungry, their pilot obliged. He dropped in on a fast-food restaurant. As car and truck horns honked and construction workers clapped and whistled, Dan Stone, owner of Balloons Over Charlotte, landed the 100-foot-tall balloon in a field Monday morning near a McDonald's. Karen Hinson ran in for the food, saying, ``Could you hurry up my order? My balloon's running.'' The trio then ascended to eat their meals aloft. ``I've been flying for 17 years,'' Stone said. ``But I've never landed at McDonald's for breakfast.''

City officials say Scooter, a one-winged Rhode Island Red, can return home, where the chicken sleeps in its owner's waterbed. However, the fight for the hen's house rights isn't over. Pembroke Pines' Code Enforcement Board voted 4-1 on Monday that Scooter is a pet, not a farm animal. City codes prohibit the latter in residential areas. Candy Weichbrodt, 42, has been separated from Scooter since April 11 to avoid a possible $250-a-day fine. ``She hasn't eaten and hasn't laid any eggs since I took her to my mother's in Ocala, and I'm afraid she may pine herself to death,'' said Weichbrodt, an animal rights crusader whose other house pets include rabbits, cats, love birds, dogs and a 4-foot-long iguana named Merlin. Several people had complained to city officials about the chicken, but no one showed up to testify against Scooter. Weichbrodt is building a fence in her back yard in anticipation of bringing Scooter home. But Weichbrodt, who lives in a Broward County development, has been notified by her homeowner association that its rules prohibit fowl. ``Now I'm going to fight my homeowner association,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Cowboy Character Actor, Wife Found Shot To Death
DOC.TEXT: Albert Salmi, who made a career out of portraying cowboys in television Westerns such as ``Gunsmoke,'' and his wife were found shot to death in an apparent murder-suicide, police said today. Salmi, 62, apparently shot his 55-year-old wife, Roberta G. Salmi, and then killed himself, said police spokesman Lt. Robert Van Leuven. A friend who had gone to check on Mrs. Salmi on Monday night peered through a window and saw her legs, said Lt. Jim Hill. Officers forced their way into the home and found Mrs. Salmi dead on the kitchen floor. Albert Salmi's body was found in an upstairs den. Police also found two guns they believe were used late Saturday night or early Sunday, Van Leuven said. He said the couple had been separated and that Mrs. Salmi had been living in the house alone. ``I don't know whether they were in the process of a divorce or not, but it appears there had been some domestic problems,'' he said. Salmi had roles in several Broadway plays, at least 20 feature films and more than 150 television dramas. His portrayal of Bo Decker, the Montana Romeo, in the 1955 Broadway production of `Bus Stop'' helped launch his professional acting career. It earned him several major awards and led to his being offered the part of Bo in the film version. Salmi turned it down because _ like most of his friends in Lee Strasberg's Actors' Studio _ he thought Hollywood actors were turncoats who sold out for fast money. A New Yorker born in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn, Salmi cherished most the Western Heritage Award from the National Cowboy Hall of Fame for his portrayal of a cowpoke on television's ``Gunsmoke.'' Salmi sought out Western character roles and played them with gusto. He appeared on TV shows such as ``General Electric Theatre,'' ``Wagon Train,'' ``Man Called Shenandoah,'' ``Bonanza,'' ``The Virginian,'' and ``Have Gun Will Travel.'' Salmi moved to Spokane in the 1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Government, Business Attacked on Metric System
DOC.TEXT: U.S. businesses may find they are unable to sell American goods in Europe if they don't adopt the metric system, the chairman of a House subcommittee said Tuesday. ``Within the next three or four years the European Community will have a unified economy, larger than our own, with unified product standards based on metric,'' said Rep. Tim Valentine, D-N.C., chairman of the House Science subcommittee on science, research and technology. ``U.S. manufacturers who cannot produce metric goods may then find the European door closed to their products.'' Japanese importers, Valentine said, are already rejecting American wood products not measured in metric. Wood has been a major issue in recent U.S. trade negotiations with Japan, which prefers to import lumber and do its own manufacturing. President Bush, after his most recent talks on trade with Japanese leaders, repeated support for U.S. conversion to metric standards, Valentine said. However, the congressman questioned whether Bush has supported his words with action. J. Dexter Peach, assistant comptroller general, testified that a General Accounting Office study found little preparedness for a 1988 law requiring government agencies to be using the metric system as much as possible by the end of September 1991. ``The Department of Commerce, as the lead agency, has not demonstrated a real commitment to guiding it and making it happen, nor have the other federal agencies demonstrated a serious commitment to make the transition,'' Peach said. He said the GAO study requested by the Science Committee found only two government agencies that have prepared transition plans: the Department of Defense and the General Services Administration, which does household tasks for many other agencies. Six other agencies have completed guidelines. But 27, including 13 of the 14 major federal departments, told Peach that more than three-quarters of the transition work remains to be done.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Investigators Recommend That Homeport Spending Stop
DOC.TEXT: The General Accounting Office recommended Tuesday that spending on new homeports be suspended until the Navy can justify the program in light of changing world conditions and cuts in defense spending. Martin M. Ferber, director of the GAO's national security and international affairs division, told a House armed services subcommittee that the Navy still is relying on a 1982 analysis to justify the strategic homeports in six Gulf Coast cities and in Staten Island, N.Y., and Everett, Wash. ``We believe it is even more important to revisit that analysis now because of the changing worldwide threat, declines in the size of the Navy, and budgetary pressures,'' Ferber said. ``The Navy is no longer planning a 600-ship fleet,'' he said. ``The current fleet is less than 550 ships and further reductions are likely.'' According to the GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, the Navy had obligations of $488 million for the homeports as of March, and had spent a total of $298.7 million. Of the estimated $799 million cost of developing the eight homeports, $624.7 million already has been appropriated by Congress and an additional $25.7 million had been requested for fiscal 1991. In addition to the $799 million in federal outlays for the program, the GAO said, state and local governments have contributed $198.7 million. An additional $173.6 million in federal funds is slated for projects at the new homeports because of recommendations of the base closure commission. ``The costs of construction and operating the new homeports will exceed $1 billion, while the cost of not proceeding with the homeports has been estimated by the Navy as $636 million,'' Ferber said. ``However, some of these sunk costs may be recoverable through alternative uses of the facilities built.'' Jacqueline Schafer, assistant secretary of the Navy for installations and environment, said the Navy believes the new homeports are still ``a valid military objective'' because they are needed to maintain naval forces in a state of readiness during peacetime.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Billboard Legislation Introduced
DOC.TEXT: Legislation to ban new billboards along federal highways and to empower localities to remove existing signs was introduced in the Senate on Tuesday. The ``Visual Pollution Control Act of 1990'' would place a moratorium on construction of new billboards on interstate and federal primary highways, would call for an accurate count of existing billboards, and would allow states, cities and towns to decide whether to remove existing roadway advertising along those highways. ``Billboards all too frequently constitute a blight on a community,'' said Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I., author of the ``Visual Pollution Control Act of 1990.'' He said they have ``a tremendous impact on neighborhoods and therefore neighborhoods should have the ability to regulate them.'' The legislation, co-sponsored by Sens. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., Lloyd Bentson, D-Texas, and Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., among others, would amend the 1965 Highway Beautification Act. Although that law was originally designed to control billboards, Chafee said the it ``has become so watered-down that the only people who support it are the billboard industry.'' Chafee's bill drew the endorsement of Houston Mayor Kathy Whitmire, president of the National Conference of Mayors, and Alberta Tinsley-Williams, a county commissioner from Detroit. In Houston, work on Interstate 610 has been delayed because the state has refused to buy a billboard which is in the way. The sign is valued at $19,042 by the state and $288,000 by the company which owns it. Tinsley Williams said that in Detroit's poor, largely black neighborhoods, 60 percent of the billboard advertising is for cigarettes or alcohol. ``We want it out of the faces of our children,'' she said. An investigation in North Carolina found that 500 billboards still stood a year after their permits had been revoked. According to Scenic America, a group supporting the bill, the typical billboard in 1965 was 15 feet tall and 300 square feet. Today the typical billboard stands 50 feet tall, usually on platforms, and is 672 square feet. Chafee acknowledged that overcoming the opposition of the advertising lobby will require a concerted effort and he said he did not expect his bill to pass this year. The Outdoor Advertising Association branded the bill unconstitutional, saying it would violate the fifth amendment by allowing states to take down billboards after five years without compensating the owner. According to a Federal Highway Administration Survey, there are 394,000 billboards on federal and interstate highways across the country compared to 1.1 million in 1965.

DOC.HEAD: Lava Torches 91st and 92nd Homes
DOC.TEXT: Lava from Kilauea Volcano torched two more homes in this coastal Hawaii Island community, bringing to 92 the number of homes destroyed since the current eruption began more than seven years ago. A fiery river of molten rock moving through Kalapana Gardens Subdivision early Tuesday incinerated a one-story, wooden home belonging to a couple from Tempe, Ariz., Civil Defense spokesman Bruce Butts said. The flow overran another a home Monday evening, Butts said. Lava continued to move east toward the heart of the subdivision. The nearest home was 300 feet away, Butts said. An evacuation order remained in effect for 50 homes in Kalapana Gardens. Authorities said 120 homes in the area are threatened. Another flow was rolling down the volcano's slopes toward Kalapana, Butts said. That flow was about a mile north of the community early Tuesday. Three homes were destroyed Sunday, making it 11 homes destroyed in the last week, 15 this month and 17 this year, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Says Exxon Isn't Providing Needed Assessment Money
DOC.TEXT: Exxon has balked at providing additional money to assess the long-term damage from the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska, federal officials said Tuesday. ``The trustees have requested that Exxon fund the remaining $20 million (of 1989 costs), but so far Exxon has declined to respond to that request,'' Alan Raul told the House subcommittee on water, power and offshore energy resources. Raul, general counsel of the Agriculture Department, is a member of the inter-agency trustee council trying to determine the environmental damages caused by the massive spill. Trustees said the first year of studies has cost $35.4 million, more than twice the amount provided by Exxon. Additional damage assessment studies this year could cost $30 million, according to an internal trustee council document made public by the House Interior and Insular Affairs subcommittee. C.M. Harrison, executive vice president of Exxon Co. USA, told the subcommittee that Exxon doesn't plan to make further payments for damage assessments. ``The process has not worked as Exxon anticipated,'' Harrison said in prepared remarks, adding that Exxon has not had access to data collected as part of the assessment process. Exxon agreed shortly after the March 24, 1989, spill in Alaska's Prince William Sound to provide $15 million for long-term damage assessments. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan at the time characterized the payment as a first step, with additional money to be sought from the oil company if needed. The minutes of a March meeting of the trustee council quoted Justice Department officals as advising the council it ``should not expect further money from Exxon,'' according to a transcript released by the subcommittee. The costs of damage assessment will be borne by the federal government, although some of the money likely will be recovered as part of the damages sought in a civil suit expected to be filed against Exxon. The oil company has spent more than $1 billion to clean up the spill, which contaminated miles of Alaska coastline. The Justice Department is pursuing criminal charges against Exxon that could lead to fines and penalties of more than $600 million. Meanwhile, several environmental groups called the federal damage assessement process inadequate and said that money shortages are causing the trustees to curtail some studies essential to determining overall damage to wildlife and natural resources. The trustees decided at their March meeting not to proceed with 24 of the 63 damage assessment studies. ``The lawyers and not the scientists have driven the assessment process,'' said Erik Olson of the National Wildlife Federation. He contended that some of the studies were halted because they were too expensive and likely would not produce large payoffs in damage recovery as a result of the eventual civil suit against Exxon. ``Apparently, decisions on which studies to continue are based at least in part on financial considerations,'' said Robert Adler, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council. Members of the trustee council are officials of the Agriculture and Commerce departments and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

DOC.HEAD: Union Activist Warns That Solidarity Must Break With Government To Surive
LaserPhoto GDA50
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity cannot survive unless it makes a clean break with the government it created, a prominent union activist warned Tuesday as the labor federation's congress neared its conclusion. During the six-day congress, delegates have sharply differed over what the union's role should be in a post-Communist Poland _ whether it should remain actively involved in national politics or return to its trade union roots defending workers' interests. The union finds itself losing support among workers because of harsh austerity measures introduced by the Solidarity-led government under Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a former union adviser. The congress was scheduled to end Tuesday, but organizers said it might stretch into Wednesday as debates continued on proposals for the union's draft constitution and program. Andrzej Slowik, a Solidarity leader from the textile center of Lodz, said the labor movement must limit itself to purely union issues and cease trying to protect the government. During the congress, Slowik has emerged as the chief rival to union leader Lech Walesa, who has advocated a mixed role for the union, combining politics with trade union issues. His views appear to be gaining support among the 487 delegates, even though he finished a distant second to Walesa in Saturday's election for the union chairmanship. Slowik has said it is clear that Walesa intends to use the union chairmanship as a stepping stone to the presidency of Poland. ``The sooner Walesa leaves us and goes to Belvedere (the presidential palace), the bigger the chances to save Solidarity,'' Slowik told The Associated Press in an interview Tuesday. ``Otherwise, Solidarity may end its existence at the moment of the fall of the Mazowiecki government.'' Walesa has waffled on whether he intends to launch a bid for the presidency, now held by former Communist Party leader Wojciech Jaruzelski. Slowik said the union risks losing support if it remains too closely linked to the Mazowiecki government's economic ``shock therapy'' program. The reforms are aimed at reviving Poland's crisis-ridden economy and introducing capitalism. The government has reduced inflation, but nearly 300,000 people, or 2 percent of the workforce, have lost their jobs so far this year as unprofitable state-owned enterprises are forced to close. ``During the six days of the congress, several more hundred unemployed were added'' in Lodz, he said. Mazowiecki's Solidarity-led coalition was installed as a result of a political compromise struck by Walesa in August to give Poland the East bloc's first non-Communist-led government. But recent opinion polls have shown that Solidarity's popularity is falling as the union is being blamed for unpopular government economic measures, which have hit hard at industrial workers, the union's traditional base of support. Slowik said the union is suffering from sagging membership because of its leadership's decision ``to take care of the Mazowiecki government instead of protecting the workers'' and its continued involvement in ``grand politics.'' Since regaining its legal status a year ago, Solidarity has recovered only 2.2 million of the 10 million members it claimed before the December 1981 martial law crackdown that forced the union underground for seven years. Slowik said he generally agrees with the government's reforms but wants Solidarity to do more to protect workers from its effects, including providing more job retraining programs and fighting for alternative factory cost-saving steps to avert layoffs. Solidarity leaders close to Walesa argue that the 10 million membership figure was exaggerated. They attribute the membership decline to the emergence of many new political parties and associations during the past year. On Monday, delegates to the congress endorsed a middle road, passing up the opportunity to either remove the union totally from politics or immediately form a political party. They approved a program plank that gives the union the option to eventually create its own political party and support candidates for parliament. ``The union cannot leave politics totally but it should become more like a trade union, especially in the present economic situation,'' said delegate Andrzej Kunkiel from Wroclawek in western Poland. Solidarity, which emerged as the East bloc's first independent trade union during a 1980 strike wave, held its only previous congress in the fall of 1981, just months before the military crackdown.

DOC.HEAD: Government Executes More Than Half Of Mutineers
DOC.TEXT: Sudan's military government on Tuesday executed more than half of the participants in an alleged coup attempt less than 24 hours after their coup was crushed. A statement broadcast by official Radio Omdurman said 28 officers, including three retired generals and a brigadier, were executed by firing squad after a summary court-martial. Military tribunals continued to work. A colonel was acquitted but the trial of other officers alleged to be involved in the coup was still going on. Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir's ruling junta, which took power in its own coup last June 30, said the coup attempt crushed Monday was the second phase of a coup plot originally put down in March. Government spokesmen said 30 officers were brought before the court-martial after their arrest Monday, and that 20 officers and civilians arrested after the March incident also were on trial. The statement did not specify how many suspects remained awaiting trial. On Monday, el-Bashir said the abortive coup was masterminded by ``the alliance in coalition with the outlaws.'' ``The alliance'' was possibly a reference to political parties disbanded by el-Bashir after his junta took control of the country June 30. The government has often used the term ``outlaws'' to refer to the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army, which has been waging a seven-year insurgency seeking autonomy and greater economic reforms for the country's three southern provinces. The government statement Tuesday also did not make clear why Col. Hassan Abdalla Atta, a pilot, was acquitted. There were reports he was granted clemency in exchange for testifying against the others. ``Death by firing squad has been implemented, and the trials are still going on for the rest of the participants'' said the statement read on Radio Omdurman and distributed by the Sudan News Agency. The executed officers included the two retired senior officers accused of leading the alleged plot. They and the others were charged with ``high treason and mutiny against the legitimate government,'' the official statement said. The alleged coup leaders were identified as retired Maj. Gen. Abdul-Kadir al-Kadaru and Brigadier Mohammed Osman Hamid Karrar. Other retired flag officers reported executed were retired Gens. Khalid al-Zain Ali, a pilot, and Osman Idris Balol. In addition, four colonels, one retired, and five lieutenant colonels, two of whom were retired, went before the firing squad. A member of el-Bashir's 15-officer military council, Brigadier Osman Ahmed al-Hassan, promised ``a fair but prompt trial to anyone involved in the abortive coup attempt.'' He spoke in an interview published Tuesday in the newspaper Al-Sudan Al-Hadith. Mohamed Khogali Salihein, the information minister, insisted the alleged plotters were persuaded to surrender with no bloodshed or casualties. But informed sources in Khartoum on Monday reported limited gunfire exchanges when the plotters tried to take over Khartoum International Airport and Radio Omdurman, the official government station. A third group of officers who tried to enter the downtown headquarters of the armed forces general command shot a guard in the hand before they were overpowered, the sources said. That group apparently was searching for el-Bashir. The coup attempt started around midnight Sunday. The government closed the airport, cut communications with the outside and blocked bridges for several hours. By 7 a.m. Monday, life was back to normal in the capital. On Tuesday, Radio Omdurman broadcast a stream of telegrams in support of el-Bashir. A pro-government demonstration was announced for Tuesday night.

DOC.HEAD: China Agrees To Give Credits To Soviets For Imports
DOC.TEXT: China agreed Tuesday to provide credits to the Soviet Union to pay for the import of Chinese consumer goods, the official Soviet news agency Tass said. The announcement came on the second day of Premier Li Peng's visit here, the first by a Chinese head of government in 26 years. The Soviet Union suffers from a chronic shortage of basic consumer goods ranging from toothpaste to matches, and has increasingly turned to foreigners for help. Tass did not say what goods China would provide or give the monetary value of the deal. For its part, the Soviet Union will extend a credit to China for building a nuclear power station in China, Tass said. The news agency also did not say how much that deal was worth or where the plant would be built. The agreements on the credits were signed by Soviet External Economic Relations Minister Konstantin Katushev and Chinese Deputy Foreign Trade Minister Li Lanqin, Tass said. Li met Tuesday with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who visited China last May.
