Li's four-day trip is intended to ease border tensions and improve relations between the longtime rivals for leadership of the Communist world. ``A good and interesting meeting, that's how it was assessed by the participants,'' Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Vadim Perfiliev told a Moscow briefing. Perfiliev said the leaders discussed further military cutbacks on the Soviet-Chinese border and plans for strengthening economic ties. Tass said Li and Soviet Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov signed an agreement on cooperation through the year 2,000 that covers fuel and power, metallurgy, transport, communications, agriculture, electronics, forestry and environmental protection. Coooperation also is planned in health and space exploration. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and his Chinese counterpart, Qian Qichen, signed an agreement on mututal reduction of armed forces and military confidence-building measures along the two countries' border. The two countries have been negotiating the troop reductions for several years. Tuesday's agreement said Soviet and Chinese armed forces would be kept to a ``minimum corresponding to normal good-neighborly relations.'' In their meeting, Gorbachev and Li agreed that there is no single model for realizing socialist ideas. ``Each country has its own history, own specifics, own starting level of development, and it's impossible not to consider it,'' Tass said. That theme was also evident Monday, when Li made a speech emphasizing that his country and the Soviet Union have the right to tailor reforms to their own needs. ``Both are socialist countries and conduct reform and perestroika in accordance with the realities of their countries,'' Peng said in remarks reported by Tass. Western diplomats in Beijing said China has stressed it would never be a docile Soviet ally as in the 1950s. The ideological hard-liners who now rule China reportedly blame Gorbachev for the fall of Communist parties in Eastern Europe and consider perestroika _ Gorbachev's program of political and economic reform _ as a threat to socialism. China and the Soviet Union split over ideological differences in 1960 and fought a brief border war in 1969. In 1972, China restored relations with the United States, in part because then-leader Mao Tse-tung saw the Soviet Union as China's most serious military threat.

DOC.HEAD: US `Ready To Pursue' Ties with Hard-Line Albania
DOC.TEXT: The State Department, responding to an overture from Albania's hard-line, Marxist government, said Tuesday it is ``ready to pursue'' discussions with that country on normalizing diplomatic relations. In a speech last week, Albanian President Ramiz Alia had expressed interest in establishing relations with both the United States and the Soviet Union. The United States and Albania have had no diplomatic ties since 1939. Albania is one of a handful of countries with which the United States does not have such ties. Since Alia came to office in 1985, he has slowly attempted to end the isolationist policies imposed by his predecessor, Enver Hoxha. Albania broke relations with the Soviet Union in 1961 because Hoxha felt that Moscow was deviating from Marxist ideology. After noting Alia's expression of interest in restoring ties, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said, ``As the United States has stated in the past, our door is open to the resumption of diplomatic relations and we are ready to pursue discussions toward this end.'' Alia's speech last week followed a six-month period in which Albanian officials had been sending out ``feelers'' through third parties expressing interest in broader contacts with the United States, a State Department official said. The third parties included foreign diplomats and Albanian Americans who visited Albania. The officials were unable to cite any direct discussions between U.S. and Albanian officials. Another sign of the more flexible Albanian attitude was its decision to permit Rep. Joseph P. Kennedy, D-Mass., to visit. Kennedy's office said Tuesday he expects to visit there in the first week of June. The Albanian overtures to the United States apparently began after other communist regimes in East Europe collapsed. Unlike those other governments, however, Albania has never been an East Bloc member, instead pursuing a policy of self-sufficiency. In his speech last week, Alia noted the ``wide gap'' that has existed between Albania and the superpowers and said that ``we meet friendship with friendship.'' He said that as a result of recent international developments, ``the problem of the re-establishment of diplomatic relations with the United States of America and the Soviet Union is on the agenda.'' lia also expressed interest in joining the so-called Helsinki process, the 35-nation conclave that meets to discuss issues related to European security and cooperation. Albania is the only European country that is not a member of the Helsinki group. A State Department report on human rights conditions worldwide, released in February, described Albania as a Marxist-Leninist dictatorship where the 3.3 million residents are permitted ``only very limited political and civil rights.'' In her statement, Ms. Tutwiler said that diplomatic relations do not constitute an endorsement of the policies of a given government. ``Establishment of diplomatic relations would create the opportunity for dialogue through which we would be able to communicate our concerns and encourage respect for human rights in Albania,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Young Qualifies, Says Bid is Start of New Day
DOC.TEXT: Former Mayor Andrew Young filed Tuesday as a Democratic candidate for governor, saying his bid to become the nation's second black elected governor _ and Georgia's first _ is the start of a new day. Young joins a race in which four other Democrats qualified Monday. Many observers expect a runoff between Young and Lt. Gov. Zell Miller. ``If it were held today, that's what we would have. But I'm just getting started,'' Young said. ``And I'm going to use these next three months. I don't run to come in second and I don't run for ties. I run to win.'' Virginia's Douglas Wilder last year became the nation's first elected black governor. The other Democrats in the Georgia race are state Rep. Lauren McDonald, state Sen. Roy Barnes and former Gov. Lester Maddox. Republican candidates are state Rep. Johnny Isakson, generally considered the GOP front runner, businessman Bob Wood and Lincoln Veazy, a retired military man. Former Superior Court Judge Greeley Ellis also is campaigning for the nomination. The fee to qualify for the governor's race is $2,600. The primary election is July 17 and the general election Nov. 6.

DOC.HEAD: Chamorro: Unlikely President
With AM-Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is an unlikely president, a slim, elegant homebody thrust into public life by widowhood and civil war. One of her first official acts as president will be a tribute to her slain husband, Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, whose assassination helped spark the 1979 revolution that brought the outgoing Sandinista government to power. Directly after her inauguration as Nicaragua's president on Wednesday, Mrs. Chamorro will place flowers on her husband's grave. The gesture sums up Mrs. Chamorro's political biography: a martyr's widow, a woman whose divided family symbolizes the conflicts that have split this nation of 3.5 million. Peace and reconciliation are Mrs. Chamorro's promise to Nicaragua, which is emerging from nine years of civil war that claimed 30,000 lives and left the economy in tatters. Mrs. Chamorro, 60, was chosen to run against leftist President Daniel Ortega because of her powerful symbolic value. She was the one person on whom all sectors of the loose opposition coalition could agree. She showed mettle, if not political sophistication, throughout a tough campaign. She stumped the country despite a broken knee. Invariably dressed in white, Mrs. Chamorro was lifted onto platforms at rallies in her wheelchair. One political analyst described her as a Virgin Mary figure in his post-mortem of her Feb. 25 landslide victory. Mrs. Chamorro, the youngest daughter of a provincial landowning family, never envisioned herself in a political role. She was raised to be a wife and mother, a role she gladly embraced after marrying Chamorro. ``He was my first love, my first boyfriend,'' said Mrs. Chamorro, who visits his grave every week. Chamorro, publisher of the daily newspaper, La Prensa, was also one of the most prominent opponents of the Somoza family dictatorship. Mrs. Chamorro stayed in the background. Chamorro was assassinated in January 1978, presumably on orders from dictator Anastasio Somoza. When Somoza was ousted the following year, Mrs. Chamorro was a member of the first ruling junta. She quit after nine months, later saying the leftist Sandinistas betrayed her husband's democratic ideals. She enjoys the comparison to another political widow who led a movement that ousted an entrenched government, Corazon Aquino of the Philippines. Like many Nicaraguan families, the Chamorros were divided by the revolution. Daughter Claudia and son Carlos Fernando, publisher of the Sandinista party newspaper Barricada, are dedicated Sandinistas. Another son, Pedro Joaquin Chamorro Jr., was a leader of the U.S.-backed Contras and daughter Cristiana is the editor of La Prensa, an opposition newspaper during Sandinista rule. In many ways, family is still the center of Mrs. Chamorro's life. She relies for political advice and counsel on a tight inner circle that includes Pedro Joaquin Jr. and Cristiana's husband, Antonio Lacayo. She has taken very little direct hand in transfer-of-power negotiations with the Sandinistas, and is known for preferring to discuss her grandchildren while aides huddle over policy. But the prominence of her family advisers has created divisions within the United National Opposition, the 14-party coalition she led to victory. One of Mrs. Chamorro's greatest problems as president may be navigating the political thicket of warring interests within UNO. Other challenges that might daunt even the most skilled politician await her. She must rebuild a shattered economy and contend with the Sandinistas in their new role as a solid opposition force. After years of war, revolution and poverty, Nicaragua is like a divided family. Mrs. Chamorro may lack political sophistication, but she understands divided families. When Ortega came to visit her after his election defeat, he was not at all sure how she would receive him after the bitter campaign. ``Papito, come here, I love you,'' Mrs. Chamorro exclaimed, hugging her defeated opponent. Her mission, she says, is to reconcile the nation, to bring it peace. And one of the first steps toward this goal, she said this week, will be the declaration of a general amnesty. ``Peace, reconciliation and pardon will be the parameters of my government,'' she said. ``I pardon my husband's killers.''

DOC.HEAD: French and Romanian TV Networks Argue Over Ceausescu Execution Tape
DOC.TEXT: A dispute has flared up over the rights to a videotape showing the execution of Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu, pitting the head of Romanian television against a French TV network that broadcast the footage. The 90-minute tape aired Sunday by the private TF1 network depicted the secret trial, execution and burial of the Romanian Communist dictator and his wife Dec. 25 at a military base outside Bucharest. The network claims a Sunday-night record 10 million people watched the broadcast, ``The Ceausescus' Final Hours.'' TF1 says it paid $9,000 to an unidentified Romanian for the tape after an Austrian network rejected it. Network officials called the price ``cheap'' and billed the broadcast Sunday as a world exclusive. But Razvan Theodorescu, head of state-run Free Romanian Television, said Monday that TF1 had purchased an illegal copy of the tape, undercutting a deal being negotiated with a French sales agent over world rights to the film. ``The rights to this cassette belong to the Romanian government,'' Theodorescu said in Bucharest, before leaving on a trip to Paris. ``It's immoral to want to make money with a historic document reflecting the drama lived through by the Romanian people.'' He said TF1 was duped into buying a ``pirate cassette'' and accused those who sold it of criminal behavior. Patrick Le Lay, president-director general of TF1, denied that any illegal act was committed. ``What was proposed to us was the uncut cassette of the trial, and we haven't pirated anybody,'' he said Monday. The tape shows Ceausescu weeping and his wife screaming for mercy as guards tied their hands shortly before their execution. The camera focused on Elena Ceausescu lying in a stream of blood after a firing squad gunned down the couple. Extracts of the tape first aired in December. But the long version broadcast by TF1 showed for the first time the full trial of the couple by the secret military-civilian tribunal that sentenced them to death. The show-trial atmosphere and the brutal, graphic images of the execution drew criticism in the French media. The conservative daily Le Figaro called it ``a political trial that bears no relation to justice. It would doubtless have been better to kill the Ceausescus right away than to put on this macabre farce.'' The TF1 broadcast scooped Free Romanian Television, which aired the footage later Sunday to mark the four-month anniversary of the revolution that ended Ceausescu's 25-year rule. The French network billed its version as the complete, definitive account of the couple's final hours. But Theodorescu claimed after arriving in Paris late Monday that a more complete tape contains additional debate among the tribunal members over charges that the Ceausescus committed genocide against the Romanian people. The Romanian government will continue distribution negotiations over the longer tape with French agent Jean-Loup Sulitzer, Theodorescu said. Earnings will go toward technological improvements in Romanian television.

DOC.HEAD: House Backs Resolution on Jerusalem
DOC.TEXT: The House approved a non-binding resolution Tuesday asserting that a united Jerusalem is the capital of Israel, a position at odds with official U.S. policy. The 378 to 34 vote, with six members voting ``present,'' came despite arguments that such a statement by Congress would cause resentment among Arab states and complicate Bush administration efforts to achieve a Mideast peace. The resolution was identical to one approved March 22 by the Senate. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., later complained that the move had damaged peace efforts and said he regretted his support for it. Jerusalem, regarded as a holy city by Christians, Moslems and Jews, has since the 1967 Arab-Israeli war been under Israeli control, and unfettered access to all holy sites is allowed. U.S. policy holds that Jerusalem's status must be determined through negotiations among all parties and does not recognize it as the Israeli capital. Rep. Eliot Engel, D-N.Y. and the chief House sponsor of the resolution, said he acted because President Bush had called into question Jerusalem's status by linking predominantly Arab East Jerusalem to the occupied West Bank in a statement about Israeli settlements. ``Jerusalem is the heart and soul of Israel,'' Engel said during a brief debate on the resolution. ``If the Israelis are willing to take risks for peace, they need to know the United States will stand by them, not pull the rug out from under them.'' But Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., said any attempt by Congress to give formal institutional support to Israel's claim that Jerusalem is its capital would unnecessarily inflame an already hostile situation. ``For America to play a constructive role, we need to have good relations with a number of parties in the Middle East, not just one. ... We must be credible to all parties, not just one.'' Obey said the non-binding resolution was nothing more than ``an institutional press release.'' Rep. David Bonior, D-Mich., said Congress should be discussing the Likud Party's efforts to provide aid for settling Jews in the Christian sector of Jerusalem ``while lying, lying about the action.'' Lawmakers should be debating the wisdom of approving $400 million in U.S. loan guarantees to house new Israeli settlers, he said. The resolution is ``an affront to the Arab community, the Christian community and the Greek Orthodox community. ... We should be seeking to bring the parties together instead of polarizing the situation,'' Bonior said. Similar comments by Dole last week touched off a dispute among Republicans, with a group of House GOP leaders criticizing the senator for not supporting Israel strongly enough. In Beirut, a group calling itself Islamic Jihad Movement-Jerusalem threatened to launch attacks against Americans worldwide unless the Senate reverses its action. ``The American Senate should reverse its decision in 10 days, or else every American inside and outside Moslem countries will be a target of terrorism and revenge,'' the group said in a statement delivered to a Beirut newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: Kerrey Predicts Farm Crisis Without More Monetary Support
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., said Tuesday that there will be a farm crisis in two years if government support for agriculture isn't increased. President Bush, however, disagreed. ``There are many things I respect about Senator Kerrey,'' Bush said. ``Sometimes we have a philosophical difference of opinion. I have a different view on this.'' Kerrey has introduced legislation being used by the Senate Agriculture Committee to prepare its commodities section of the 1990 farm bill. He made his comments to the National Association of Agricultural Journalists; Bush addressed the group later in the day. Farm economy, Kerrey said, has improved considerably since the early 1980s. However, he said the recovery was fragile and that $12 billion is needed annually over the five-year life of the farm bill to assure stability. ``If you don't provide this level of funding, in two years you are going to see this recovery vanish,'' Kerrey said. The budget the administration sent to Congress in January calls for $10.2 billion to be spent on commodity programs in the next fiscal year. The crops protected by those subsidies are the big money crops _ wheat, corn, cotton, soybeans and rice. Kerrey said that failed farming operations brought on by insufficient government support would cost more taxpayer money in the long run than the annual $12 billion he's advocating. He criticized Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter as an advocate for the free market instead of the farmer. Yeutter, who has a family farm in Kerrey's home state, said farm income need not be dependent on the government. ``There's a market out there,'' said Yeutter, who appeared with Bush. ``All of us are concerned about farm income.'' Yeutter said it was impossible to predict the agricultural economic situation in the United States beyond the next fiscal year because the outcome of international trade talks _ the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT _ are not complete. The Bush administration has been working through GATT to open the international marketplace by removing subsidies, which Yeutter and other officials say distort prices.

DOC.HEAD: Justices Hear Arguments in Ohio Libel Case
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For an hour Tuesday, the Supreme Court grappled with an important libel law issue contained in a former high school wrestling coach's 15-year-old lawsuit against an Ohio newspaper. The court is being asked to decide whether the Constitution's free-speech protections immunize all expressions of opinion, as opposed to assertions of fact, from libel lawsuits. First, however, the justices may have to tell judges nationwide how to distinguish fact from opinion. The fact-opinion distinction is important. Courts traditionally have barred libel suits over expressions of opinion even though the high court never has said explicitly that such protection is constitutionally required. The justices spent much of Tuesday's argument session trying to figure out whether to put a ``fact'' or ``opinion'' tag on a 1975 sports column that accused Michael Milkovich of lying under oath. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy asked the most questions. All three seemed to consider the sued-over statement an assertion of fact. Questions from Justices John Paul Stevens, Sandra Day O'Connor and Byron R. White were more difficult to characterize. Justices William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall and Harry A. Blackmun asked no questions. The sued-over column was written by Ted Diadiun and appeared in the News Herald of Lake County, published by the Lorain Journal Co. Milkovich was coaching Maple Heights High School's wrestling team at a 1974 home meet against Mentor High School when a melee involving both teams and spectators erupted. Several wrestlers were hospitalized. Diadiun, who was at the meet, wrote several articles criticizing Milkovich's conduct. In a Jan. 8, 1975, column, Diadiun accused the coach and H. Don Scott, then superintendent of the Maple Heights public schools, of lying to a judge who overturned disciplinary measures against the Maple Heights team. During extensive litigation, Milkovich won two preliminary rounds before the Ohio Supreme Court. In a 1984 decision, the state court ruled that Diadiun's statements about Milkovich were reported as fact, not opinion. But in ruling on Scott's related libel suit two years later, the Ohio Supreme Court reversed its 1984 ruling and said Diadiun's statements were expressions of his opinion. In an unusual move, the Ohio court used its Aug. 6, 1986, decision in Scott's case to doom as well Milkovich's suit against the newspaper and Diadiun. Holding up a 1975 headline that said Milkovich ``Beat the Law with the Big Lie,'' Milkovich attorney Brent English of Cleveland told the justices, ``This is quintessentially an assertion of fact.'' But Richard Panza of Lorain, Ohio, argued for the newspaper and Diadiun that ``when people read sports columns they expect to read opinion.'' Gusts of laughter filled the courtroom after Justice Kennedy responded, ``I gave up reading sports columns because there's nothing but legal news in them.'' Panza's most persistent interrogator was Justice Scalia, who at one point asked him, ``Doesn't it trouble you that people's reputations can be destroyed this way?'' Panza said, ``Yes, it does trouble me.'' He then quickly added that the column at issue was not libelous. Diadiun, 42 and now an editor with The Cleveland Plain Dealer, watched the session from the courtroom's press section. Milkovich, 68 and recovering from triple bypass heart surgery, did not attend. In a recent interview, he told The New York Times he was too weak to make the trip from his Maple Heights home. A decision is expected by July. The case is Milkovich vs. Lorain Journal Co., 89-645.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Communist Demonstrators Demand Iliescu Resignation
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of anti-Communist demonstrators regrouped in a main Bucharest square hours after being dispersed by riot police Tuesday to demand the resignation of Interim President Ion Iliescu. About 3,500 demonstrators waved their fists and cheered as one speaker equated the National Salvation Front _ Iliescu's party _ with the Soviet KGB. Many shouted, ``Down With Communism!'' It was the third day of nearly constant protest against Iliescu and the Front, which are linked in the minds of many Romanians with past Communist excesses. Iliescu was appointed interim president in the wake of the bloody December revolution that overthrew dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. He served under Ceausescu but fell out of favor and was demoted to lesser jobs in the Communist Party. His Communist past and that of other Front officials makes them suspect in the eyes of those Romanians who claim the Front has been infiltrated by Marxists paying only lip service to democracy. In a morning session of parliament, Nica Leon, president of the Liberal Democratic Party and a member of the governing Council of National Unity, said the protesters rejected what they considered the Communist elite still leading the country. ``Those people want the (former) Communists toppled from the leadership,'' he told the Council. The Council, in which the Front shares power with opposition groups, is acting as a makeshift parliament until elections scheduled for May 20. Iliescu described the protesters as ``thugs.'' That drew protests from opposing legislators who noted that Ceausescu used such language to label his political opponents. The demonstrations at University Square began Sunday and lasted uninterrupted until Tuesday at dawn, when club-wielding, helmeted riot police forcibly dispersed about 200 protesters who had remained in the square. Protesters began reassembling during the morning and continued their rally into Tuesday evening. It was the first time since Ceausescu's overthrow that police force was used to break up an anti-Communist street protest. The demonstration was the chief topic during a session of the interim parliament that continued into the evening and was broadcast live by state television. The inspector general of police, identified only as Gen. Diamandescu, said nobody was beaten during Tuesday's police intervention, but three policemen were hospitalized after being injured by demonstrators. That assertion was disputed both by legislators and by demonstrators who said in interviews that they had been beaten. ``This morning the policemen came and clubbed us into the ground,'' Silviu Galniceanu, a 23-year-old photographer told The Associated Press. In a related development, Ion Ratiu, the presidential candidate of the National Peasants Party in the May 20 elections, said his life had been threatened by a mob instigated by the Front. Ratiu, a Romanian millionaire who returned from decades of British self-exile this year, said he had to be spirited out of a police station in Buzau, about 120 miles northeast of Bucharest, in a milk van after an angry crowd threatened to storm the station. ``I thought, `We'll be lucky if we get away with our lives,''' said Ratiu, 72. He said he planned to take a personal physician along on future campaign trips because of fears of similar threats. The fervently anti-Communist National Peasant Party claims about 600,000 members, making them the chief rivals of the Front, which asserts it has 800,000 followers.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Extends Wool, Honey Programs
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Agriculture Committee voted Tuesday to extend government programs for wool, mohair and honey for five years with virtually no changes. ``The wool and mohair title (of the 1990 farm bill) is essentially a five-year extension of the program for wool in the 1985 farm bill,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt. The measure: _Authorizes loans, purchases and payments by the Agriculture Department to help the wool and mohair industry. _Sets a payment rate that would be the difference between the national average of all domestic wool receipts and the price the government predetermined that producers should get. Each producer's payment from the government would be calculated by applying this rate to net proceeds for wool sold the preceding year. The honey section of the farm bill also would be little changed from current policies. The price support for honey has dropped an average 5 percent each year for five years. Under the new legislation, support prices would be frozen at 56.86 cents a pound through 1995. Loan repayment rates would be unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: Sasser Says Bush Not Yet Serious About Budget
DOC.TEXT: Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser told his divided panel Tuesday that President Bush wasn't yet serious enough about cutting the deficit to warrant a White House budget summit. ``Summitry simply doesn't make sense unless all sides are serious,'' said Sasser, D-Tenn., as his committee began work on its version of the $1.2 trillion fiscal 1991 spending plan. ``At this point, at least, the administration isn't serious about it.'' Sasser presented the committee with a series of budget options cutting the deficit up to $50 billion in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The Pentagon would account for up to $20 billion of that savings _ a level conservatives appear unwilling to accept. ``The Congress is not going to adopt those numbers,'' said Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas. He and most other Republicans, led by Sen. Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the senior Republican on the panel, made clear the GOP won't support the Democrats' budget. Domenici said he hoped the committee would act quickly so talks with the White House could begin. ``We are not going to be obstructionist on this side,'' Domenici said. The spectre of a summer White House summit was raised on the Senate floor Tuesday as the two parties settled a dispute that was holding up action on the child care and Central American aid bills. Senate Republicans backed off a threat to force a vote on Bush's capital gains tax cut as part of the child care bill. In exchange, Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, assured Minority Leader Bob Dole of Kansas that the tax cut would be part of any summit on the big issues. ``If such discussions do occur ... I would urge that any and all matters be put on the table,'' Mitchell said. White House budget director Richard Darman has been agitating for a budget summit, apparently in part because of a deteriorating economic picture. Darman last week criticized the plan passed by the House Budget Committee as inadequate _ because it relied on the administration's own, faulty economic projections. ``He's getting nervous in the service,'' Sen. Ernest F. Hollings, D-S.C., said Tuesday of Darman's maneuvering away from his own position. Hollings described the Senate committee as ``all over the lot'' in its efforts to draft a budget, with several Democrats _ including himself _ proposing their own plans. Sasser expressed confidence a consensus would emerge on a plan with about $40 billion in deficit reduction, enough to satisfy the requirements of the Gramm-Rudman budget law. He declined to say what he thought would make up the package. The House could begin debate as early as Wednesday on its budget. The House plan envisions about $295.5 billion in military spending next year, more than $3 billion more than Sasser is proposing. Bush asked for about $303 billion. Sasser, like the House and Bush, is proposing about $14 billion in new taxes next year. While Bush says the capital gains cut would raise a big chunk of his revenue, the Democrats aren't saying which taxes they would raise.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Say Elizabeth Taylor Improving
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with doctor's comments; editing to conform; picks up 10th graf pvs, ``She is ...''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos pursuing
DOC.TEXT: Pneumonia-stricken Elizabeth Taylor's spirits were good despite an uncomfortable ventilator that helped her breathe after surgery to determine the cause of her illness, her doctor said Tuesday. Dr. Michael Roth, a longtime friend and Miss Taylor's physician for 10 years, said the 58-year-old actress was ``certainly stable for the moment with the very slightest bit of improvement.'' ``It started with viral pneumonia,'' Roth said in a telephone interview after seeing Miss Taylor in the intensive care unit at St. Johns Hospital and Health Center. In addition to the ventilator, intravenous lines were connected to the actress. ``We are trying to prevent infection so we are using IV drugs,'' Roth said. ``Her spirits are good and she's feeling a little bit better.'' The Academy Award-winning actress has deteriorated markedly since what was initially described as a sinus infection. Miss Taylor's three doctors and her publicist Chen Sam, who flew in from New York on Tuesday, scheduled a Wednesday afternoon news conference to discuss the case. ``It's the most sick she's been under my care,'' Roth said late Monday. ``Right now she's on an even plane. We are guardedly optimistic. It's a non-specific virus. We haven't been able to isolate it.'' Miss Taylor's condition had stabilized after surgery Sunday to remove a piece of lung tissue for biopsy, doctors said. Test results were expected Thursday. People keeping a bedside vigil included her four children, Maria Burton-Carson, Liza Todd-Tivey and Christopher and Michael Wilding. Television news crews and reporters outside the hospital were prevented by security officers from entering the hospital. Hospital spokeswoman Roxanne Yamaguchi referred inquiries to the publicist for the actress, who won Oscars for ``Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' and ``Butterfield 8.'' ``She is seriously ill,'' Miss Taylor's doctors said in a statement released Monday. ``After surgery, her breathing is now being assisted by a ventilator.Her condition is presently stabilizing and her physicians are pleased with her progress.'' Miss Taylor entered Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital on April 9 with a persistent fever and sinus infection. When her condition worsened, she was transferred April 16 to St. Johns. In a statement after arriving at the larger hospital, the actress issued a statement denying rumors that she was suffering from an AIDS-related condition. Miss Taylor was moved to the intensive care unit on Friday, her physicians said in a statement without elaborating on her deteriorating health. ``She's not well. She's not on her death bed or anything,'' Ms. Sam said. Miss Taylor has been plagued with health problems for years, particularly recurring back troubles from the filming of the 1945 movie ``National Velvet,'' when she fell off a horse. In 1983, she acknowledged a 35-year addiction to sleeping pills and pain killers prescribed for a range of health problems. Miss Taylor has been treated for alcohol and drug abuse problems at the Betty Ford Clinic in Rancho Mirage. During a nearly fatal bout with pneumonia in 1961, Miss Taylor underwent a tracheotomy, in which an incision was cut into her windpipe to help her breathe. She appeared at the 1961 Academy Awards with a bandage over her tracheotomy scar as she accepted the ``Butterfield 8'' Oscar. Dr. Patricia Murray, an infectious disease specialist treating the actress, said last week that Miss Taylor had pneumonia and was ``being treated intravenously with antibiotics and will remain hospitalized'' indefinitely.

DOC.HEAD: Court Would Allow Some Executions Without Appeal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf pvs `Simmons, 49 ... with 1 graf to CORRECT details of killings _ most occurred in Dover, Ark., victims were shot or strangled, not all killed before Christmas
DOC.TEXT: Condemned murderers who waive their right to appeal and say they want to die may be executed even if no appeals court reviews their cases, the Supreme Court ruled Tuesday. The decision will let Arkansas authorities execute a man who killed 16 relatives and acquaintances during a 1987 rampage. No state appeals court has reviewed the validity of his convictions or sentence. By a 7-2 vote, the justices ruled that only convicted mass murderer R. Gene Simmons _ and not fellow death row inmate Jonas Whitmore _ has the legal standing to challenge Simmons' death sentence. Whitmore mounted his challenge even though Simmons prefers death to end ``the torture and suffering in me.'' Whitmore had asked the justices to rule that state appeals courts must review all death sentences _ even when not asked to do so by the condemned murderer. In fact, many states provide automatic appellate review in capital cases, regardless of the defendant's wishes. But Whitmore, trying to stand in for Simmons, had argued that such review is constitutionally required. The court did not address the constitutional issue, ruling instead that Whitmore cannot make such an argument in Simmons' behalf. ``Whitmore, having failed to establish that Simmons is (mentally) unable to proceed on his own behalf, does not have the legal standing to proceed,'' Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote for the court. In other decisions, the court: _Ruled 6-3 in case that could affect millions of dollars in movie industry profits that distributors of the Alfred Hitchcock thriller ``Rear Window'' must share with a literary agent earnings from the 1954 film's re-release. _Ruled 6-2 that the U.S. territory of Guam and its officials may not be sued for allegedly violating a much-used federal civil rights law. The decision in the death penalty case lifted a stay the justices had imposed on the eve of Simmons' scheduled execution last year. Arkansas officials will be free to schedule a new execution date as soon as they officially receive word of the court's ruling, 25 days from Tuesday. Justices Thurgood Marshall and William J. Brennan, who oppose capital punishment in all circumstances, dissented from Tuesday's ruling. ``The court needlessly abdicates its grave responsibility to ensure that no person is wrongly executed,'' Marshall wrote for the two. Simmons, 49, killed his wife, three sons, four daughters, a son-in-law, a daughter-in-law and four grandchildren at his home near Dover, Ark. He killed two acquaintances in the nearby town of Russellville. The victims, all slain in the days surrounding Christmas 1987, were shot or strangled. He consistently has refused to appeal his convictions and death sentence. ``We are free to execute Mr. Simmons as long as he wishes to be executed,'' James Lee, a spokesman for state Attorney General Steve Clark, said after learning of Tuesday's ruling. The sister of Simmons' slain wife, Becky, said she was relieved by the decision. ``All I can say is I know he wants to die, and it's now one chapter I know will be closed,'' said Viola O'Shields of Fort Payne, Ala. ``It's been a most long, very hard three years.'' Mrs. O'Shields said she won't tell her mother, 81-year-old Maye Novak of Briggsdale, Colo., about the ruling until a new execution date is set. ``She has not been well since all this happened, and maybe this will relieve some of the stress and pain she's gone through,'' Mrs. O'Shields said.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Receives Education Budget Ideas
DOC.TEXT: Five grade school youngsters wearing crisp white uniforms bowed stiffly before members of a House Appropriations subcommittee Tuesday and recited ``Four Daily Affirmations'' from their lessons in discipline _ lessons that committee members applauded. ``I am smart because I always learn something good everyday. I am perfect because I never make mistakes knowingly. I like myself because I always take action to make things happen. I am happy that I am me,'' the children said. The youngsters from Washington's Amidon Elementary School gave a brief demonstration of what they have been learning in a ``Joy of Discipline'' program at their school offered by Jhoon Rhee, who describes himself as the father of Tae Kwon Do, a Korean style of unarmed combat, in the United States. Rhee interspersed his testimony before the subcommittee on labor, health and human services, education and related agencies with the demonstrations. He said he wants to help restore ``the forgotten good old American custom'' of respect, as well as classroom discipline and motivation, by getting schools to offer ``attitude'' classes. ``I sincerely believe that the first thing we should teach our children is the purpose of life; and the second, the way to reach that purpose; and the third, how to enjoy the process.,'' Rhee said. Also performing was Rhee's star pupil, Marvin White, who demonstrated his skills of breaking boards without the benefits of arms and with only one leg. The subcommittee room exploded into applause with various congressmen offering words of praise. ``Master Rhee, you're good for this country,'' said Subcommittee Chairman William Natcher, D-Ky. Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass., added, ``You're helping to instill confidence in youngsters. That's something that's really needed.'' Rhee, who has instructed members of Congress in martial arts for 25 years, said his program was developed through trial and error and is saturated with the philosophies and strategies of Tae Kwon Do. The children learn to pay ``undivided attention'' to the teacher, love and respect the teacher, and are taught to separate license _ ``an act approved by the animal instinct'' _ from freedom _ ``an act approved by a conscience,'' he said. Rhee, who became an American citizen in 1973, suggested that American schools teach the attitude class an hour a day. ``Children are taught self-discipline and self-respect which are the foundations for all learning. Our children must be taught to respect their parents, teachers, elders, peers and evertying in the universe,'' he said. The House subcommittee hearing was one of a series on the proposed budgets for the Labor, Health and Human Services and Education departments for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The proposed Education Department budget is $24.6 billion, up from $24.1 billion in the current year.

DOC.HEAD: Foreigners Say German Unification Spawning Racism
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Pedro Mahumane walked through a crowd on a busy square Tuesday and, for once, failed to draw stares from the people around him. ``People see me, they know I am a foreigner'' said the 28-year-old Mozambican. ``Today, we are all foreigners.'' Mahumane was among an estimated 1,500 Africans, Vietnamese, Arabs and Germans who marched through the East German capital to protest what they say is a surge in racism spawned by the push to unification. East Germany is home to 800,000 so-called ``guest workers,'' most of them Vietnamese, Mozambicans or Cubans sent by their countries years ago. Many were sent as part of agreements made between their governments and the former Stalinist regime that was toppled in October. Some were promised skilled jobs but now work as laborers. German newspapers have reported that as East German enterprises begin to feel the effects of the free market, they have begun laying off foreigners before Germans. Some foreigners say that although they always have been stared at or withstood racial comments, the hostility has heightened since East Germans embraced unification with West Germany. ``We feel German unity has led to an upsurge in racism,'' said Ginga Eichler, an East Berlin activist and rally organizer. ``It has become a purely German process with no thought given to the other people who live here.'' She said East Germans fearing widespread unemployment have vented their frustrations on dark-skinned foreigners. A hefty loss of jobs is expected in East Germany as government-created jobs and obsolete factories are phased out by a free market. A group of skinheads shouting neo-Nazi slogans and racial and anti-homosexual epithets rampaged Friday night through the city's main square, Alexander Place. At least 10 people were injured in beatings. On Tuesday, the crowd gathered on the square and marched a few blocks to the stately, red-brick city council building of old Berlin. Speakers from political parties and activist organizations demanded more protection for foreigners living in East Germany. Hundreds of foreigners listened, although the largest group in the crowd was made up of Germans. ``Many foreigners are afraid to take part in demonstrations,'' Ms. Eichler said. ``They played very little role in the revolution.'' Germany was divided into Communist East and capitalist West following the 1945 defeat of Adolf Hitler's Nazi regime in World War II. The hard-line Communist regime of Erich Honecker in East Germany was forced out last October by mass demonstrations, and the rush toward unification began. East Germans were pleased when West Germany said on Monday it would trade most of the worthless East German marks at a 1-1 rate for West German marks as the first step of the unification process. Although detailed discussions still have to be held, foreigners fear that they may not be given the same favorable trade on their East German marks. ``I work hard, as hard as anybody, but I will face economic hardship,'' said Pham Son, 32, a computer engineer sent by the Communist government in Vietnam to East Germany in 1982. He said he has been the target of racial comments from East German youths. ``Unemployment now is here so there is social conflict.'' Ingeburg Kleine, a nurse in a hospital ward for foreigners, said many are afraid to speak out. ``Many speak no German,'' she said as she marched with the crowd. ``The educated ones have it not so bad. But the workers live together and must live in small flats.'' She said clerks in stores sometimes will refuse to sell particularly scarce items to foreigners, occasionally removing the items from their baskets when they try to pay. Justino Chana, 29, was sent to East Germany from Mozambique in 1981 and has worked in a slaughterhouse since then. ``It is very difficult to live here sometimes,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Female Infantry Recruits `Ran Out of Gas,' Canadian General Says
DOC.TEXT: Most of the 48 young women who tried out for the Canadian Forces infantry last year ``simply ran out of gas'' and were unable to make it through the grueling training, the general in charge of the program said Tuesday. ``It's not strength; it's a question of stamina and endurance,'' Brig. Gen. Dan Munro told a Pentagon-sponsored conference on women's issues. Only one women graduated from the infantry school, while two others are still in training, he said. ``Most of those young women simply ran out of gas,'' Munro said, describing the effect of the 10-week basic course, topped by 16 weeks of infantry training that ends with a 10-day drill offering recruits little sleep amid constant maneuvers. But Canada's military _ which was ordered last year to open all units to women _ has had far more success integrating women into combat-related jobs in the Navy, Air Force and other Army units such as artillery or the signal corps, Munro said. In 1987, the general said, Canada's defense minister announced plans to evaluate combat units in which women would serve with men. Last year, however, Canada's Human Rights Tribunal, acting on several complaints of discrimination, ordered that the tests be stopped and that women be integrated into all areas of the nation's forces except submarines. Munro is the director of Canada's Office for the Combat Related Employment of Women. He spoke to the annual meeting of the Defense Advisory Committee on Women in the Services, which advises the Defense Department on issues relating to women and the military. The panel is holding its annual conference the week after the Army announced it had rejected the group's proposal that the service undertake a four-year study of placing women in all combat-related fields. The recommendation is similar to legislation submitted by Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo. By U.S. law, women are barred from serving on combat ships and planes in the Navy, the Air Force and the Marines, but it is Army policy that bars women from serving in the combat-related fields such as infantry, armor and some artillery units. Munro told the panel that Canada's female sailors serving on board destroyers ``are happy and their commanding officers report satisfaction in their performance. ... The Navy is moving toward a complete integration of women into the fleet in a positive way and at a pace faster than ever had been foreseen.'' The Air Force had moved more swiftly to open more slots to women, and in the last three years the number of female pilots has doubled. Now, two women are flying fighter jets, he said. The general said that even though no one knows what will happen in combat, ``we train for war all the time, and we in Canada have no intention of withdrawing women'' from combat units simply on the basis of their sex. Mistakes were made in the recruiting process when women who didn't understand the rigors of infantry life were recruited, as well as women who didn't have the proper physical training, he said. There are 86,000 members of the Canadian armed forces and about 10 percent are women, the general said.

DOC.HEAD: 27 Arrested in Animal Rights Protest
DOC.TEXT: More than two dozen animal rights activists were arrested Tuesday at the National Institutes of Health during a demonstration protesting the use of animals in medical research, authorities said. Charges against the 27 people arrested included trespassing, assault on a police officer and resisting arrest. About 300 demonstrators gathered at the NIH campus at midday. After speeches criticizing institute's role in animal experimentation, the group marched to the Veterinary Resources Branch. The demonstrators chanted ``Let us in, let them out.'' NIH security officers formed a line around the building, and protesters were warned that anyone crossing police lines would be arrested.

DOC.HEAD: House Correcting Last Year's Ethics Law
DOC.TEXT: The House on Tuesday voted to correct mistakes in the new federal ethics law, including one that would have allowed officials to avoid disclosing information on last year's finances. Congress thought it voted last year for a strong, new ethics law, but the technical experts who drafted the language weren't quite up to the task. DOC.HEAD: The AP
Commission Urges Presidential Involvement In AIDS Response
DOC.TEXT: The National Commission on AIDS on Tuesday called on President Bush to coordinate the federal government's response to the epidemic and remove restrictions on use of federal AIDS education and prevention funds. The commission also urged support for federal housing aid and support for legislation that would bar discrimination against people with AIDS and would pump money into areas hard hit by the epidemic. ``All across the country there is a cry for leadership from the federal government and partnership between different levels of government,'' the commission said in its second report to the president. The commission, which also delivered its report to leaders of Congress, has had nine days of hearings in Washington and Los Angeles and four working sessions in Boston and St. Paul, Minn. since it began its work last August. Panel members also spent time in New York City, Newark and Jersey City, N.J., and in rural Georgia, visiting drug treatment centers, homeless shelters and other places where people with AIDS can be found, including subway tunnels in New York City. ``Nowhere was it more evident that the care of human life must be a priority for our government than in the streets of New York City,'' where an estimated 10,000 homeless people may have AIDS or AIDS-related diseases, the five-page report said. But the commission found desperate need for care in California, as well. In some areas of that state, ``there are six- to eight-week waits for outpatient services,'' the report said. ``Across the country, the commission also heard tales of health care denied unless it required acute hospitalization,'' the panel said. Commissioners also found that restrictions on the use of federal education and prevention funds were prolonging the AIDS epidemic. Restrictive language in regulations governing use of the funds was preventing states and communities from putting out effective messages about such things as use of condoms as a safety precaution and bleach to clean needles, commissioners said. Dr. June Osborn, commission chairwoman, said the federal government needs some sort of ``flexible and responsive mechanism'' to coordinate the actions of the different federal departments and agencies that provide services for people with AIDS. ``The president can be most helpful in creating such a coordinating body to provide focus at the top,'' Osborn said. The commission urged House support for a Senate-passed bill titled Americans with Disabilities Act, which would protect people with AIDS from discrimination, and the panel called on states and local governments to pass anti-discrimination laws. The administration also supports the legislation. Panel members also urged passage of a measure that would provide $600 million to areas that have been hardest hit by the AIDS epidemic, and said more federal funds are needed to provide housing for people with the disease. The commissioners praised Bush for his March 29 speech in which he said compassion not discrimination was needed in the fight against AIDS. The panel called it ``important and historic.'' ``Now the president's commitment needs translation into action,'' the commission said. The 15-member commission includes five people appointed by the House, five appointed by the Senate and two by the president. The secretaries of Health and Human Services, Defense and Veterans Affairs are non-voting members.

DOC.HEAD: 2 Salvadorans Cited for Efforts to Promote Peace
DOC.TEXT: Two Salvadoran human rights workers were honored on Capitol Hill Tuesday for their efforts in promoting peace in their war-torn country. ``The people, especially the peasants, have suffered,'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said at a ceremony at which Bishop Medardo Gomez and Maria Julia Hernandez received the Oscar Romero Award. Sen. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., said the two were ``willing to sacrifice in order to preserve the dignity of the individual.'' The senators made their comments amid growing congressional efforts to use U.S. financial aid as a way of ending the war between the U.S.-backed Salvadoran government and leftist rebels. Some 70,000 people have been killed over the last decade. Mitchell said the negotiations now underway between the two parties offer hope that the war may end soon. ``We must persuade ourselves that a military solution is not the path to protecting peace and establishing democracy,'' said Ms. Hernandez. Hernandez is director of Tutela Legal, the Catholic archbishop's legal aid office. The group conducts investigations of human rights in El Salvador. Gomez, of the Lutheran Salvadoran Synod, has been a staunch advocate of peace in his country. In 1983 he was captured and tortured, but later released. He said he planned to use the award to create a foundation to keep alive the Christian faith. Gomez and Hernandez are recipients of the $10,000 Oscar Romero Award, sponsored by the Rothko Chapel in Houston, founded by John and Dominique de Menil. Mrs. de Menil, a French-born heiress to the Schlumberger conglomerate that developed oil drilling, named the Romero awards after a Roman Catholic archbishop who was murdered in San Salvador a decade ago. On Capitol Hill, meanwhile, there have been proposals to tie future U.S. military aid to improvements in the government's human rights record. Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., has proposed, for instance, withholding an anticipated $90 million in military aid this fiscal 1990 and using the escrow funds as leverage to encourage negotiations. Some lawmakers are awaiting a report into the slaying of six Jesuit priests last November. A congressional task force has investigated the deaths and is expected to release its findings next week.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Partners Could Derail Super Collider, Senator Warns
DOC.TEXT: Deals with Japan and other foreign partners to absorb cost overruns of the $8 billion superconducting super collider could kill the project, the chairman of the Senate Energy Committee warned on Tuesday. ``The way to get this thing in political trouble is to give away the cream of the technology,'' Sen. J. Bennett Johnston, D-La., said of the high-energy physics particle accelerator that President Bush wants to build near Dallas. Johnston made the remarks as House leaders postponed until next week action on a bill that would cap federal spending on what would be the world's largest and most powerful accelerator at $5 billion and require foreign partners, Texas or private money to cover any cost above that level. The bill by Rep. Robert Roe, D-N.J., chairman of the House Science Committee, is a response to opponents in Congress who claim the $1 billion a year the government anticipates spending on the collider when construction gets into full swing will squeeze out other worthy science endeavors. The project essentially involves building two circular underground tunnels 54 miles around to accelerate beams of protons in opposite directions at nearly the speed of light and then make them collide. Through the collisions, scientists hope to find previously unobservable subatomic particles that could provide clues on how the cosmos was created. Rep. Joe Barton, R-Texas, in whose district the project would be located, said that Roe's bill _ over opposition from the Bush administration _ would limit foreign participation in any aspect of the project to 50 percent. Johnston quoted senior officials in the Energy Department as telling him, that because of the limit, the administration is looking at contracting with Japan to supply the 10,000 supermagnets for the project. ``I would hate for us to give away the most valuable thing in the project, the supermagnets ... and let somebody else develop the manufacturing technology,'' he said. ``That's what we did with the auto industry.'' Meanwhile, northern lawmakers opposed to the project said they would offer amendments when Roe's bill comes before the House floor to increase the foreign funding share from 20 percent to 25 percent and require annual reviews by congressional auditors of spending and changes in cost estimates. Rep. Dennis Eckart, D-Ohio, said the audits would provide an ``objective, independent assessment to back up our claims'' that the project will be plagued by continuing cost overruns and should be scuttled. ``This is an incremental process,'' Eckart said. ``As a trial lawyer I know I have to have an arsenal of evidence to refute the claims of opponents. Clearly last year, they had more evidence than we had.'' The administration said Tuesday it would support changes in the bill to require the successful testing of 10 prototype magnets before allowing construction of the tunnels to begin. In a statement of policy, the White House Budget Office also said it wants deleted from the bill a provision that would refund to Texas _ if the project is canceled in the future _ the $1 billion it has pledged toward its costs. Sen. Wendell Ford, D-Ky., who as chairman of the Senate Energy panel's subcommittee on research has backed the project, warned its supporters against trying to defuse opposition by spreading contracts for its components around the nation. ``If this becomes just another big public works project, you could be on dangerous ground,'' he said. ``Funding then becomes a question of how much does your state get and how much does my state get.''

DOC.HEAD: Britain's Great Train Robber Shot to Death in Spanish Resort
LaserPhoto LON1
DOC.TEXT: A member of the gang that carried out Britain's great train robbery of 1963 was shot to death by a young assailant who fled on a bicycle, police in this seaside resort said Tuesday. Investigators believe the slaying of Charles Wilson, 58, may have been drug-related, said a Marbella police spokesman who asked not to be identified. A young man in a track suit opened fire Monday afternoon on Wilson after calling at the door of the Briton's apartment in this Costa del Sol resort, the spokesman said. Neighbors told police they spotted the suspect fleeing on a yellow bicycle shortly after hearing gunshots coming from Wilson's apartment, the spokesman said. Wilson was pronounced dead on arrival at the Marbella Clinic. Another police spokesman in the resort, favored by European vacationers, said the motive for the shooting was not immediately clear but that investigators believed it may have been related to drug trafficking. Wilson and 14 other members of a gang took part in what has been called the ``great train robbery'' on Aug. 8, 1963, when they held up the Glasgow to London mail train near Aylesbury, 40 miles northwest of London. They stole 2.6 million pounds, then worth $7.2 million. At the time, it was the biggest robbery in Britain. Police recovered less than $966,000, but Wilson and most of the other gang members were captured and jailed. Wilson was sentenced to 30 years in prison in 1964 and released in 1978. Costa del Sol on Spain's Mediterranean coast has been a haven for suspected British criminals, but in recent months the Spanish government has sent a number of suspects back to Britain. Wilson had lived in Marbella for several years. He was suspected of links to gangs that every year smuggle thousands of pounds of hashish from North Africa through Spain to northern Europe, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Inspectors General Use Contractors to Look For Waste And Abuse
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 7th graf, In at, to show contractor asked to review department-wide contracts, not just inspector general's
DOC.TEXT: The watchdogs charged with policing federal programs for fraud and abuse often farm out work to private shops, leaving government oversight of a wide array of contractors in the hands of fellow contractors. The government's inspectors general, in reports to Congress and in public statements, attribute the hiring of private auditors and other contractors to severe staff shortages. And they say most of the outside work is satisfactory. But critics inside and outside the government say having private firms monitor private firms creates a weak link in government oversight of millions _ if not billions _ of dollars in contracts for programs ranging from running nuclear plants to job training to Medicare. Documents obtained under the Freedom of Information Act and from congressional investigators and other sources, and information from recent interviews show that a handful of accounting firms led or heavily staffed by former government auditors get the bulk of the big-money contracts from the inspectors general. A review by the Labor Department's inspector general said that in most cases it would be cheaper to hire a government worker. Most of the government's inspectors general use private firms working under contract to some degree, and a handful have even used them to target other contractors for audits or possible prosecution. In at least two cases, both at the Department of Energy, a private firm has been asked to review procurement to determine whether contracts the department awarded were wasteful or paid contractors too much. ``For the most part the work is good but the standards are not always being met,'' said a top aide to one inspector general. ``It's clear that having some of these audits was worse than having no audit at all. It creates an impression of integrity that may not be there,'' said the aide, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Inspectors general were added government-wide in the 1980s, in part because of congressional efforts to improve oversight as the Reagan administration pushed to cut government payrolls and have more work performed by private contractors. However, inspectors general also faced staffing limitations, leading them to turn to private firms to help police the growing number of private firms involved in government work. One firm that does audits for several inspectors general also has provided three of five lecturers for a course in which contractors are taught to rebut government audits. The firm, Leonard G. Birnbaum & Co., recently ended its relationship with the seminar after congressional investigators brought it to the attention of the Energy Department. Several companies that receive Energy Department funding have sent employees to past seminars. But a department official said he did not believe Birnbaum's role posed a possible conflict. ``I don't see it has any relationship with anything they do for us,'' said Gordon Harvey, Energy's assistant inspector general for audits. ``They must be able to certify under the rules that there are no conflicts.'' A recent review by a department panel, however, supported findings of a Senate subcommittee that several contractors who certified they had no potential conflicts had also submitted documents listing work for firms that could pose conflicts. In a letter to subcommittee chairman Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., the department said the review panel ``perceives a significant danger of a contractor being called upon to analyze its own or a former client's work product.'' And Energy is the only department to require written disclosure; other agencies rely on a contractor's word. Often, inspectors general use specialized outside help for detailed chores. The IG at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, for example, uses private appraisers to assess the value of properties involved in larger contract audits. And the Postal Service's inspector general has hired hypnotists to help witnesses recall events. But several agencies' whose inspectors general rely heavily on contractors have them perform not only routine audits but also policy and strategy development, raising the issue of whether the contracted work is ``inherently governmental.'' General Accounting Office and Office of Management and Budget guidelines frown on using contractors for work meeting that standard, but the definition is interpreted differently within the government. The Labor Department inspector general has agreements with 27 contractors and has awarded more than $18 million in contracts in the past two years, according to records provided to a congressional subcommittee. Among the tasks Labor's IG has assigned contractors were compiling a target list of contractors for audits and recommending cases for prosecution under wage and hour laws. The Energy Department IG has contracts with a half-dozen private firms and has spent $17 million on such contracts since January 1988, according to department figures. Other agencies whose inspectors general have contracted out more than $2 million and as much as $8 million in work in the past two years include the departments of Agriculture, Education, and Health and Human Services, the Agency for International Development and the Environmental Protection Agency. Some examples of work inspectors general have authorized private companies to perform: _Energy this year asked a contractor to review contracts to determine if the department was paying contractors too much. _Labor hired a private firm to determine if an employee compensation program was being administered as Congress intended. Labor's IG also paid a contractor to oversee two other contractors providing related work. _The Justice Department IG hired a contractor for tasks including legislative research, ``preparation of proposed policies and procedures'' and developing suggested audit procedures. The Energy Department's Harvey, in comments echoed by representatives of other inspectors general, said the government auditors review the contractors' reports and that firms staffed with former government auditors offer vital experience to short-staffed IG offices. ``We do not have enough in-house resources to meet the audit needs,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Publishers Contemplate Declining Readership
DOC.TEXT: The nation's newspaper publishers on Tuesday watched videotaped interviews with Americans who say they don't read newspapers very much, then debated how to change that. An advertising consultant advised the publishers to adopt a more local focus, suggesting that international issues such as the push for independence in Lithuania don't sell advertising. A publisher countered that newspapers still reach a larger audience than any other news medium. The comments were made during a panel discussion at the American Newspaper Publishers Association 104th annual convention. The discussion, moderated by Jeff Greenfield of ABC News, was called ``Ozzie and Harriet Are Gone _ Who Do You Think You're Writing For?'' Virginia Dodge Fielder, vice president of research for Knight-Ridder Inc., expressed industry frustration in trying to pinpoint the cause of declining readership. ``I wish people hated us more,'' she said. ``I wish they expressed more dissatisfaction because if they did we'd know how to tackle it. ... What the public is saying is not `I hate you' but `I don't need you. You're a great electric company, but I live in an all-gas house.''' The session opened with videotaped interviews in which subjects were asked if they read a newspaper. ``I don't have time,'' was a common response. Several said that TV news was ``easier.'' One man said he felt less connected to his local newspaper since big business had taken it over. The comment echoed a message emphasized by Laurel Cutler, vice chairman of FCB-Leber Katz partners and vice president of consumer affairs for the Chrysler Corp. ``The only specialized thing about a newspaper is its locality,'' she told the audience. Localness is what you have to sell. That's why USA Today is a very peculiar animal. I guess it's the local newspaper for people on airlines.'' Frank A. Daniels Jr., president and publisher of The News & Observer of Raleigh, N.C., interjected that ``a newspaper traditionally has been a smorgasbord. You have something in there for everybody.'' But Ms. Cutler warned against newspapers trying to be ``all things to all people'' and suggested specialization was more appealing to advertisers. ``The more generalized, the more all things to all people, the less we care about you,'' she said. Daniels suggested that newspapers might have to follow the lead of American Express, which created different categories of cards for different income brackets. He noted that a newspaper subscription is costly and perhaps different price brackets for different incomes would encourage more readership. ``How do we create a platinum card newspaper?'' he asked. Greenfield suggested that the puzzle of declining readership may not be complex. ``Is it possible that the reason people read newspapers so devotedly in 1940 is there was nothing else to inform them?'' he asked. ``And maybe this age of newspapers is like the buggy whip manufacturers in 1910.'' Publishers and editors on the panel disagreed. ``One thing you may be overlooking is how adaptable newspapers are,'' said C. Shelby Coffey III, editor and executive vice president of the Los Angeles Times. He noted that the Times has numerous regional bureaus to keep the paper local but has inaugurated a new ``World Report'' section to emphasize global developments. ``Research at the Times shows that international news is of great interest to readers,'' he said. Coffey and Gerald Garcia, editor and publisher of The Knoxville (Tenn.) Journal, also urged development of a multi-ethnic reporting force to keep up with interests of a diverse reading audience. Coffey called it ``the polycultural newsroom.'' Consultant Ronald Brown, president of Banks, Brown Inc. of San Francisco, noted that the interests of that city's Chinese-Americn population are underrepresented in its newspapers All panelists agreed that improved education would improve readership of newspapers.

DOC.HEAD: Head Start Officials Say Their Teachers Need More Money
DOC.TEXT: Beginning Head Start teachers are paid so little that they could qualify for Medicaid and other welfare programs while working an average of 1,311 hours a year, officials of the pre-school program said Tuesday. Ron Herndon of Portland, Ore., president of National Head Start Director's Association, said Head Start's ``greatest debt is to the dedicated staff, primarily women, who have endured nearly poverty wages to help others escape poverty.'' He said the program's success could not continue at the expense of its staff. The administration has proposed a $1.9 billion budget for Head Start. That includes a $500 million spending increase to allow enrollment to grow to 667,000 children, or 70 percent of those eligible. The program now enrolls between 20 percent and 39 percent of the eligible children _ depending on the statistics used. Herndon said a 1988 federal study found that 47 percent of Head Start teachers earned $10,000 per year or less. The overall average salary of a Head Start teacher in 1988 was $12,074 per year; with a bachelor's degree, the average Head Start teacher earned $15,043. To be eligible for Head Start's comprehensive services _ which include breakfast and lunch, and medical and dental check-ups _ the family income of 3-5-year-olds must be $12,100. The Medicaid eligibility of a family of four is $16,093. Herndon said the turnover rate for the program is between 17 percent and 20 percent. Board member Sarah Greene of Bradenton, Fla., said low pay is the reason 95 percent of the staff quit. ``We're saying (the administration's position) is shortsighted,'' Herndon said.

DOC.HEAD: New Method Developed To Make Digestible Milk
DOC.TEXT: Scientists have developed a more efficient way of breaking down a sugar in milk that can't be digested by many adult Americans, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. An enzyme in the human body normally breaks down milk sugar _ lactose _ in dairy products, but blacks, Asians and American Indians tend to have a low level of this enzyme, said George Somkuti of the department's Agricultural Research Service. One solution is to add something to dairy products that does the work of the human body's natural enzyme. Somkuti said researchers have developed a new source of the enzyme that is ``better than those now being used as additives because of its food-grade nature.'' The new source is an altered form of an organism, Streptococcus thermophilus, which produces an enzyme that breaks down lactose in dairy products, he said. The Food and Drug Administration has approved S. thermophilus as a natural agent for making products such as cheese and yogurt. Somkuti said the altered bacterium's benefit is that it won't grow when added to milk. However, it splits lactose into two simple sugars, glucose and galactose, he said. The new technique, which is being patented by the USDA agency, could help people with lactose intolerance enjoy dairy products and thereby boost sales by milk producers, officials said. Somkuti works at the USDA agency's eastern regional research center in Philadelphia, Pa. The announcement was issued in Washington by the agency.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Considering Mandatory Recycling For CFSs
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency is considering whether to impose a mandatory recycling requirement for major users of chloroflourocarbons, or CFCs, the agency said Tuesday. The chemical, which is widely used as a refrigerant and as an industrial solvent, is a principal cause of stratospheric ozone depletion and will be phased out over the coming decade in many countries including the United States. But the EPA said it was considering regulatory action aimed at getting users to recycle the chemical, instead of letting it routinely into the air during maintenance and installation. Such releases have been common when mechanics work on automobile air conditioners or during repairs or installation of commercial or home air conditioners. The EPA said among the proposals that it was considering for possible rulemaking is a mandatory CFC recycling program that would be imposed on major users of the chemical nationwide. Another option would be a deposit-refund system where users of CFCs would return cannisters of the chemical for a refund instead of venting the chemical, the agency said. Many CFC users already have announced plans to shift to CFC recycling programs. Several of the major automakers, for example, have said within the next year they plan to provide dealers with equipment that would recycle CFCs used in automobile air conditioners. The commercial air conditioning industry also has said it is developing recycling programs for the chemical.

DOC.HEAD: NY Philharmonic's New Music Director Meets the Orchestra
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Maestro Kurt Masur, a hero of East Germany's revolution, visited the New York Philharmonic on Tuesday for the first time since being named music director of the ``conductor-killing'' ensemble. His five-year contract was announced two weeks ago. It starts in the fall of 1992. ``I don't hear the word `hero' very much,'' the 62-year-old music director of the Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig told reporters. ``I did my deal only to avoid confrontation that brings blood to our streets in Leipzig. We were lucky that everybody felt it shouldn't be a confrontation and it didn't happen.'' Masur held meetings between East German police and people pressing for change. After those meetings, talks were held and bloodshed avoided. Some said that only Masur's international standing as conductor of the Gewandhaus made the meetings possible. Masur said he would remain involved in the politics of Leipzig. But his main concern, Masur said, is the Gewandhaus Orchestra, which he will lead through the 1993-94 season. East Germany, smaller than Massachusetts, has 91 professional orchestras, all state-supported before the revolution. ``The opening of the Wall brings lots of very positive points,'' he said. ``At the moment everybody is a little bit frightened. I don't think it will be very easy to keep it all going. I believe that money from the government will be given but it will not be enough.'' He said that when he first conducted the New York Philharmonic, in 1981, he'd heard its reputation as a ``conductor killer.'' ``After a while I discovered they are wonderful human beings,'' he said. As for changes he intends at the Philharmonic, Masur mentioned closer cooperation with the Juilliard School, which is next door in Lincoln Center. He also wants to start a children's choir, organize longer rehearsals for difficult works and shorter for familiar ones. ``I'm not one of those who is promising everything before the election and then not doing it later,'' Masur said. ``I only can promise you one thing; I will do this as honest as I did everything in my life.'' Asked how he feels about the Philharmonic engaging him instead of an American, Masur said that he has helped many young American conductors who were attempting to establish reputations in Europe. ``This question comes to my heart. My successor should be American born.''

DOC.HEAD: House Condems Liberian Government
DOC.TEXT: The House voted Tuesday to condemn the Liberian government for killing unarmed civilians in a wave of violence that has caused tens of thousands to flee the African nation. The House approved the non-binding resolution 417-0. It includes a request that President Bush consider human rights abuses before resuming any military aid. Liberian President Samuel Doe launched a crackdown on his opponents after a group of insurgents killed several Liberian officials in December. More than 200 people reportedly have been killed by Doe's forces. The United Nations estimates that 140,000 Liberians have fled to the neighboring Ivory Coast and Guinea.

DOC.HEAD: Settlers Accuse U.S. of Interfering in Dispute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 9th graf `The United' to UPDATE with Shamir response to U.S. objections to Jerusalem settlement. Pickup 10th pvs, `Israel captured...'
DOC.TEXT: Jewish settlers Tuesday accused the State Department of interfering in their efforts to retain control of a housing complex in the Christian quarter of Jerusalem's Old City. ``We're disappointed with the interference of the State Department in something which is both an internal Israeli matter and is also under judicial discussion,'' said Rabbi Jonathan Blass, a spokesman for the Neot David settlement.
