His statement came a day after State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler called the settlers' move into the Christian area ``an insensitive and provocative action.'' She also said the Israeli government's funding of the settlement ``is deeply disturbing.'' The Israeli Housing Ministry acknowledged last weekend that it put up $1.8 million toward the purchase of Neot David's lease. The movement of the 150 Jews into the complex near the venerated Church of the Holy Sepulcher on April 11 set off demonstrations by Christian clerics and Palestinians. The four-building complex is owned by the Greek Orthodox Church, which took the settlers to court and won an eviction order. The settlers have appealed, and a hearing is scheduled Thursday before the Supreme Court. The U.S. complaint about Neot David was relayed to Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir by U.S. Ambassador William Brown in a meeting Monday. The United States opposes the establishment of settlements on Israeli-occupied land, saying it is an obstacle to peace. Shamir later said the government gave the settlers funding as part of a general government housing program. ``The case at hand is one of an ordinary commercial real estate transaction,'' Shamir said in a statement. The government, he said, ``does not assist and would even have prevented any action constituting an affront to places sacred to (any of) the religions or holy sites.'' But he also added that ``every Jew has the right to live in Jerusalem.'' Israel captured the Old City from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war and annexed it. Israel captured the West Bank and Gaza Strip in the same war and continues to occupy the territories, home to 1.7 million Palestinians. More than 140 Jewish settlements have been built in the occupied lands. In the West Bank on Tuesday, a Jewish settlement leader suffered a head cut when he was stoned by Palestinians youths. The victim, Rabbi Moshe Levinger, said stones were thrown at him near the Beit Romano settler enclave in the heart of Hebron. He said he put his hand on his gun and the stone-throwers fled. ``I did not fire because I didn't see exactly who threw the stones,'' Levinger said. Levinger currently is on trial for manslaughter for allegedly shooting to death an Arab shoe salesman after he was stoned in Hebron on Sept. 30, 1988. Also Tuesday, eight masked Palestinians armed with axes and knives stabbed a Gaza Strip taxi driver to death, Arab reports said. They said the victim was suspected of collaborating with Israel. He was identified as Nabil Mohammed Aloush, 35, of the Jabaliya refugee camp. His death raised to 209 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs in the 28-month-old uprising against Israeli rule. Most were suspected of collaborating with Israel. In addition, 676 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians, and 43 Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Extends Jamming of Radio Marti Past Sunrise
DOC.TEXT: Cuba began jamming the U.S. government's Radio Marti broadcasts between 6 a.m. and noon on Tuesday, said a spokeswoman for the Voice of America, which runs the service. VOA spokeswoman Beth Knisley said the agency deplores the action taken against Radio Marti, which began broadcasting five years ago. The jamming denies the Cuban people ``access to uncensored news and information,'' she said. She quoted a Cuban government statement as saying that the jamming was a ``new step toward a definitive solution of the problem.'' She said the broadcast operation can still be heard on shortwave radios. Until this month, Cuba had not interfered with Radio Marti except for a humming sound that impaired the quality of the broadcasts. Cuba started jamming the station during the pre-dawn hours last week and then shifted the interference on Tuesday to the post-sunrise period when the audience is much greater. The actions appear to be related to the advent of TV Marti, the televised version of Radio Marti. TV Marti tests began last month during the early morning hours and have been jammed consistently by Cuban transmitters. There have been some reports, however, that TV Marti has been seen in most of the island's 14 provinces. At a news conference three weeks ago, President Fidel Castro suggested that the TV Marti tests could provoke a crackdown on Radio Marti. Castro said it is unacceptable for the United States to transmit radio programming unilaterally to Cuba. One possible solution, he said, is for the two countries to reach an agreement governing mutual broadcast rights. The United States has defended both Radio and TV Marti on grounds that the Cuban people have not had access to objective news since Castro assumed power 31 years ago. Castro has called TV Marti a ``gross instrument of subversion'' that violates national sovereignty and international law. The Bush administration has said the station is consistent with international law.

DOC.HEAD: INS Plans Program to Release Some Detainees
DOC.TEXT: Federal immigration authorities said Tuesday they plan to launch a pilot program to allow the release of 200 refugees who have been detained while seeking political asylum in the United States. Under the program expected to be announced this week, some refugees detained in Miami, New York City, Los Angeles and San Francisco would be released on bond if they meet certain qualifications. The program is expected to be formally announced by Immigration Commissioner Gene McNary after discussions with the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, a New York-based group that advocates improved treatment of refugees. Arthur Helton, head of the organization's refugee project, said the pilot program would affect 200 of the more than 500 refugees detained because they arrived at the U.S. border without a passport or visa. These refugees, many from Haiti, Sri Lanka, Iran, Afghanistan and Somalia, often languish in detention centers for years while their applications for asylum are processed, he said. Those released would be required to post bonds between $500 and $2,500 and agree to report monthly to INS offices, Helton said. INS spokesman Verne Jervis confirmed that the agency is putting the final touches on the program. He said INS agreed to the pilot program ``to see if we can release these people under certain conditions so we won't have to keep so many people in detention at our expense and their unhappiness.'' If the program proves successful, Helton said his organization would ask the INS to revise its automatic-detention regulations for refugees in the category.

DOC.HEAD: Members of Congress Ask Reinstatement of High-Tech Chief
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 2 grafs with Pentagon comment
DOC.TEXT: Eleven lawmakers asked the Pentagon on Tuesday to reinstate Craig Fields as head of the Defense Department's high-technology research and development agency. ``Firing and silencing such a key player in the U.S. competitiveness debate is at best short-sighted, at worst a major breach of our future economic security,'' the bipartisan group said in a letter to Deputy Defense Secretary Donald Atwood. Fields had been head of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency for a year until he was transferred Friday. The agency, DARPA, provides money to private industry to develop high-technology goods with military uses. Supporters of Fields contend he was removed because he advocated spending money on so-called ``dual-use'' technologies _ technology that has civilian as well as military applications. The agency has a $1.2 billion budget, about half of which goes to dual-use technologies, said Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif., at a news conference to announce the drive to reinstate Fields. DARPA-funded projects include super computers, artificial intelligence, software, semiconductor manufacturing technology and biotechnology. Levine, whose home state is a high-technology center, is co-chairman of the Congressional High-Technology Caucus. Levine is also chairman of Rebuild America, a public-policy group that promotes high-technology industries. Levine said he is drafting legislation that would put DARPA under control of the Commerce Department and require that funds be spent only on dual-use technology except in special cases. Although DARPA is in the Pentagon, it is one of the few government programs developing civilian technologies. The administration is divided over the role of government in helping private industry. Conservatives arge that such funding would interfere with the free market place and that private industry should fund such research. Among those disagreeing with that conservative stance are Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., who signed the letter. ``Other countries are engaged in national economic strategies to advance their own commercial interests through government cooperation and financial support on the technological level,'' said Heinz. ``DARPA is the only strategy that we have in the entire federal government. ``Why am I here as a Republican? Because I do not want George Bush to go down in history as the president who presided over the economic decline of the United States of America because he and members of his administration were blind.'' Another Republican who signed the letter and helping lead the drive to reinstate Fields is Rep. Don Ritter of Pennsylvania, who is chairman of the congressional Technology and Policy Task Force as well as ranking member of the commerce and competitiveness subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. Other signers are House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo.; Reps. Les AuCoin, D-Ore.; Norman Mineta, D-Calif.; Edward Markey, D-Mass.; Nicholas Mavroules, D-Mass.; Marcy Kaptur, D-Ohio, and Helen D. Bentley, R-Md.; and Sen. Albert Gore Jr., D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Commerce subcommittee on science, technology and space. At the Pentagon, a statement was released saying that Victor Reis, the deputy director of DARPA, has been named acting director pending the appointment of a new director. The statement also said that Fields would begin serving in his new post on May 6, in which he is responsible for ``evaluating and recommending actions to streamline the large and complex research and development laboratory infrastructure'' of the Defense Department.

DOC.HEAD: Presidential Aide Who Was Slain in Nigerian Coup Attempt Buried
DOC.TEXT: President Ibrahim Babangida's personal aide was buried with full military honors Tuesday, two days after he was killed by rebels during a coup attempt. Babangida narrowly escaped death when insurgents opened fire on his residence, killing his top aide, Lt. Col. Usman Bello. Bello was buried Tuesday in his native state of Niger in central Nigeria. More than 150 soldiers and 177 civilians have been arrested for participating in the uprising against Babangida and his military government, which came to power in a bloodless coup in August 1987. On Monday, an army spokesman described the fighting as the heaviest in any attempt to overthrow Nigeria's government. Officials have yet so divulge any casualty figures. Dozens of people died in coups in 1966 that triggered ethnic violence in which thousands more died and ultimately caused the crippling Biafran war. The rebellious soldiers who joined the latest coup attempt captured the national radio station at one point and said they wanted to overthrow Babangida to end the traditional domination of the country by Moslems from the north. The southern states are mainly Christian and animist. In a message broadcast Tuesday to mark the end of the Moslem fast month of Ramadan, Babangida said, ``Nigerians have cause to be grateful to God that the coup failed because the unity of the nation would have been wiped out if the coup had succeeded.'' More than 600,000 people died in the 1967-70 Biafran war, an effort by easterners to secede from the federation. The easterners, mostly Christian or followers of traditional African religions, also alleged that northerners were dominating the nation.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms On The Plains, Snow In Rockies
DOC.TEXT: More thunderstorms developed over the central part of the nation Tuesday after a night of severe storms, and deep snow headed for the mountains of Colorado and Wyoming. Thunderstorms developed along a cold front mainly over South Dakota during the afternoon. A severe thunderstorm watch was issued for parts of Minnesota and Wisconsin. Showers were widely scattered from southeastern Kansas to northeastern Texas, and from the upper Great Lakes to the central high Plains. Thunderstorms over Minnesota during the morning produced hail an inch in diameter at Royalton, about 20 miles north of St. Cloud. From late Monday into early Tuesday, thunderstorms produced severe weather in the southern Plains with 36 reports of severe weather in western Texas and western Oklahoma, the National Weather Service said. Thunderstorms spawned three tornadoes in Texas, and large hail was reported, the weather service said. Overnight thunderstorms also produced very heavy rain in extreme southeastern Minnesota. Many areas received more than 2 inches of rain in 24 hours, with 3 to 6 inches reported around Austin and Rochester. Snow was expected to develop Tuesday and into Wednesday morning over some of the higher elevations of Colorado and Wyoming. As much as 5 to 10 inches of snow was expected in Wyoming's Big Horn, Absaroka and Wind River mountains. The snow level in Colorado was expected to drop to 7,000 feet during the night, with up to 6 inches of snow possible at higher elevations. Elsewhere, showers and thunderstorms spread over the southern tip of Florida. Showers associated with a cold front were scattered from Arizona to southern Idaho, with snow showers in the mountains of Arizona that left an inch on the ground at Flagstaff. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 24 at Houlton, Maine.

DOC.HEAD: Police Slay 15 Guerrillas in Jungle Battle
DOC.TEXT: Fifteen Maoist guerrillas were slain by police in fighting outside the jungle town of Mazamari, in the tropical lowlands 200 miles east of Lima, the Interior Ministry said. Police suffered no casualties in the fighting Monday night, the ministry said, but 20 others in the Shining Path rebel column escaped into the jungle. Shotguns, an assault rifle and pistols belonging to the rebels were confiscated, along with dynamite and propaganda from the Maoist-inspired radical group, the ministry said. The government Tuesday extended for 60 days the state of emergency in eight Peruvian departments, covering more than half of Peru's 24 million residents. The emergency decree allows police and military to detain suspects and search homes without warrant. Since the Shining Path took up arms in 1980 against the government, more than 18,000 people have died in political violence, the government says.

DOC.HEAD: Program Exports Should Do Well, GAO Says
DOC.TEXT: The coming of high definition television won't reduce demand for American movies and television programs overseas, a report to Congress said Tuesday. The General Accounting Office said, however, that a single standard for over-the-air transmission was necesssary to make U.S. broadcasters and television manufacturers competitive with Japanese and European satellite transmission of the new technology. High definition television or HDTV offers a wider and sharper television picture than traditional television by increasing the number of horizontal lines that make up the picture. Television systems worldwide use different production formats and transmission standards because efforts to agree on a standard have been unsuccessful. Similarly, there has been no agreement on standards for high definition television. International broadcasters met last year but declined to adopt the standard developed by the Japanese _ the so-called 1,125-60 standard, 1,125 lines per picture renewed 60 times per second. Current U.S. television pictures use 525 lines per picture renewed 30 times per second. ``The absence of such a standard will not negatively affect the U.S. entertainment industry's ability to successfully market its movies and television programs,'' said the GAO, the congressional investigative arm. The GAO said representatives of the U.S. entertainment industry were confident there would be no impact on international marketing ``because they sell their programs primarily on content rather than picture quality.'' The U.S. industry, the largest producer worldwide of theater and television programs, is likely to continue to produce movies and television programs using 35mm film, the report said. ``According to motion picture and television industry officials, film is the highest quality production format currently available with about 2,000 lines of resolution. As a result, it converts well to all current television standards, and according to motion picture industry officials, will also convert well to HDTV standards,'' the report said. However an over-the-air transmission standard ``is needed to allow U.S. broadcasters and television manunfacturers the opportunity to participate in HDTV,'' GAO found. The lack of a transmission standard ``could be a competitive disadvantage with cable and satellite companies'' for American broadcasters who are constrained by regulatory and technical limitations of over-the-air transmission, the report said. U.S. exports of movie and television programs now contribute about $1 billion a year to the nation's balance of payments.

DOC.HEAD: The Russians Are Coming ... to Wyoming
DOC.TEXT: A team from the Soviet Union will visit F.E. Warren Air Force Base in Wyoming this week to observe a demonstration designed to help expedite the START arms control negotiations, the Pentagon announced on Tuesday. The observer team will view procedures for on-site verification of the number of re-entry vehicles on an intercontinental ballistic missile, the statement said. ``This demonstration is designed to facilitate and expedite agreement in the on-going Strategic Arms Reduction Talks on procedures to verify the number of warheads loaded on strategic ballistic missiles on both sides,'' the statement said. The demonstration Wednesday and Thursday is a result of President Bush's call in June for cooperative efforts to facilitate a START agreement and the U.S.-Soviet agreement of Jan. 22 to commit both nations to such demonstrations, the statement said. F.E. Warren Air Force Base has the 10-warhead MX missile. The Pentagon statement did not say what missile would be used in the demonstration.

DOC.HEAD: KGB Sends Border Guards to Lithuania, Which Denounces U.S. Stand
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with gunfire attack, anti-blockade commission formed, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto VIL2
DOC.TEXT: The Kremlin reinforced KGB border guards in Lithuania on Tuesday, and Lithuania's president accused the United States of selling out his rebellious Baltic republic in its confrontation with the Soviet government. The Soviet news agency Tass reported a gunfire attack Monday night on a Soviet army barracks in Vilnius, Lithuania's capital, but said no one was hurt. President Bush said in Washington he will not impose sanctions on the Soviet Union at this time over its crackdown on Lithuania. He said he feared sanctions might prompt Moscow ``to take action that would set back the whole case of freedom around the world.'' The Soviets have cut off oil, drastically curtailed natural gas and curbed other supplies to Lithuania in trying to force the republic to halt its six-week-old drive for independence. Earlier, Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Vadim Perfiliev warned that U.S. sanctions could have ``negative consequences.'' Perfiliev did not state directly that the Soviet Union might retaliate but said ``any actions taken which could pull apart the sides of the argument of course could have negative consequences, not only for the Soviet Union but for the international situation.'' After Bush's announcement, President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania issued an angry statement from Vilnius. ``Can the freedom of one group of people be sold for the freedom of another? What then is the idea of freedom itself?'' he said. ``This is another Munich.'' He was referring to the 1938 Munich Pact, in which France and Britain allowed Nazi Germany to take control of Czechoslovakia. The treaty was widely viewed as caving in to Adolf Hitler. The pact became a symbol of appeasement. Tass and Soviet TV's nightly newscast reported Bush's announcement. Tass also quoted Soviet army Maj. Alexei Kirichenko as saying a shot was fired at an open window at about 10 p.m. when soldiers were already inside the barracks. It said the bullet smashed a window on the opposite wall, and that ballistics experts believe a combat weapon, and not a hunting rifle was used. The agency also reported from Vilnius that the Lithuanian parliament on Tuesday set up a commission to ``prepare anti-blockade measures'' and named Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene as commission chief. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's advisers refused on Tuesday to receive a five-member Lithuanian delegation sent to Moscow to discuss the plight of the republic after a week of enduring the Kremlin economic blockade. Lithuania hopes to make up for some of the supplies Moscow has cut with imports from abroad. But the KGB's announcement that it was adding personnel and equipment to guard the republic's border appeared designed as a warning against such a step. Lt. Anatoly Parakhin of the KGB, whose forces are responsible for Soviet borders, did not specify in a Moscow briefing what the secret police were looking for, but indicated weapons were on the list. ``Control has been established over possible contacts between Soviet and foreign ships in territorial waters and within the borders of the economic zone of the U.S.S.R. to avert the transfer of weapons and ammunition to Lithuania,'' Tass quoted Parakhin as saying. ``The movement through the border of all cargo and means of transportation is being most carefully controlled. ``All coastal fishing ships, without exception, are being inspected by border details.'' He said the stepped-up control was justified by an April 12 incident in which 240,000 rounds of hunting ammunition were found aboard the Soviet ship Marat Kozlov, Tass said. It was sailing to Lithuania from West Germany. The increased border patrols were in line with a March 21 Kremlin statement calling for increased security on the Lithuanian section of the Soviet border. Moscow began tightening its economic vise last week after Lithuania refused to rescind laws bolstering its March 11 declaration of independence. Mrs. Prunskiene returned to Moscow from Scandinavia on Monday on a trip to seek foreign support, especially oil. V. Mosolov, an official of the State Supplies Committee in Moscow, told the news agency that railroad tanker cars needed to transport imported oil in Lithuania belong to the Soviet Railways Ministry, and not the republic. He seemed to imply the republic would not be allowed to use ministry facilities.

DOC.HEAD: Black Factional Violence at Peak in South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Black factional fighting last year was the worst in modern times and 4,000 people could die by year's end if violence continues at its present level, an official reported on Tuesday. An increase also was reported in white right-wing violence. White supremacist groups oppose government moves toward sharing power with the disenfranchised 28 million black majority. On Tuesday, the government banned all police from belonging to any political party. The Conservative Party and white right-wing groups claim wide support among the security forces. Conservative Party members objected to the ruling, which was announced in Parliament by Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok. Vlok announced a pay raise for police on Monday. Hundreds of police resigned after the government legalized the African National Congress this year and began allowing marches and political protests by blacks. John Kane-Berman, executive director of the independent South African Institute of Race Relations said Tuesday black factional fighting was going on in all four provinces. He said that in 1989, black factional fighting killed 1,403 people, with more than 90 percent of the death occurring in Natal province. Supporters of the African National Congress and its allied organizations are in conflict there with the Inkatha party headed by Zulu leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi. Deaths in the first quarter of 1990 ranged from 574 _ the official total _ to 966, a figure based on information from groups monitoring Natal violence. Vlok told Parliament police can either resign their jobs or resign membership in political parties, movements or organizations, including the governing National Party. ``You can't belong to a political party and be a policeman. It's as simple as that,'' said Vlok. He said police would continue to watch and note the activities of political parties as part of their duties. Vlok also announced that a black man identified as a ``trained terrorist'' apparently attached to the ANC was arrested Sunday in connection with the April 15 murder of a white policeman in Natal province. Vlok said police also seized 18 mini-limpet mines, 17 hand grenades, two AK-47 assault rifles and ammunition. Government officials said last week they were concerned about reports that the ANC's military wing, Spear of the Nation, had begun openly recruiting in black townships. ANC Deputy President Nelson Mandela called Sunday for intensified ``armed struggle'' against the white government, and said recent police shootings of black protesters showed the ANC's guerrilla fighters were still needed. In its daily unrest report Tuesday, police said over the previous 24 hours a black woman was ki8lled when set afire by a mob and the body of a black man was found after black political fighting in Natal province. Security police detained 10 alleged dissident ANC members when they arrived on an Air Malawi airplane from Tanzania on Tuesday, government-run radio said. Police suspected one member of the group, Mwezi Twala, was a former ANC military commander who was tortured by the ANC after leading a rebellion in Angola in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: European Leader Sees Hope for Accord on Farm Subsidies
DOC.TEXT: President Jacques Delors of the European Commission said Tuesday he hoped to reach an agreement with the United States by the end of July on the long-disputed issue of subsidies to farmers. The commission is the joint executive of the 12 countries in the European Common Market, which has taken the position that it is unrealistic to talk about ending subsidies. President Bush has adopted the position of the Reagan administration that subsidies should be phased out by the year 2000. Europe and the United States both spend billions on these subsidies every year. ``If we leave on the side the war over principle, it's possible in a pragmatic approach to find a solution which reduces on both sides the amoount of subsidy to agriculture _ but all the subsidies, not only the subvention to export but also deficiency payments,'' Delors told reporters as he left the White House after meeting President Bush. ``We have taken the decision to have bilateral discussions and to find a solution, I hope before the end of July.'' ``Deficiency payments'' are direct payments to raise the incomes of poor farmers. The more usual subsidies to farmers take the form of government help to keep up the level of prices for farm products. U.S. and European authorities compete for sales in other areas by subsidizing exports as well. The dispute over farm subsidies is one of the major issues in the Uruguay round of trade negotiations, in which about 100 countries are taking part under the sponsorship of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT. Some progress was made at a meeting of cabinet ministers from 29 countries last week at Puerto Valarta, Mexico. Afterwards Jules Katz, the deputy U.S. Trade Representative, said they agreed to deal with access to markets and price supports as well as with export subsidies. After the Bush-Delors meeting, Bush spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said ina statement: ``The president reiterated to Commission President Delors that the United States is firmly committed to improving the multilateral trading system and strengthening the GATT through agreements reached during the Uruguay Round GATT negotiations scheduled to conlcude in Brussels next December, and that the cooperation of the (Common Market) is essential, particularly in the agricultural area.''

DOC.HEAD: French Commandos Hold Mock Raids on Nuclear Plants, Newspaper Reports
DOC.TEXT: Commandos of the French secret service twice broke into nuclear power plants in 1987, in one case leaving behind two fake bombs as proof of lax security, a newspaper reported Tuesday. Le Canard Enchaine, a satirical weekly known for its investigative reporting, ran a photocopy of a letter apparently written by the state power company's security chief, reporting to his superior about the second raid. According to the letter, two secret service agents carried out an undetected mock sabotage raid in October 1987 on the nuclear plant at Bugey, near Lyon. They climbed over an electrified fence, placed two dummy bombs inside a cooling tower, then set up a rocket launcher outside, the letter said. The other raid was conducted in March 1987 on the nuclear plant at Nogent-sur-Seine, near Paris, with agents gaining access to the control room, the newspaper said. The paper also published a photocopy of a letter _ apparently from an Interior Ministry official _ informing officials in charge of the nuclear industry that a former member of the Red Brigades, the Italian terrorist group, had been employed as a cleaner at a French nuclear plant. There was no immediate official response to the weekly's report. Last week, after Le Canard Enchaine published a less detailed article on the same subject, electric company official Lucien Bertron said a test raid was conducted at Bugey in 1985-86 and described other parts of the report as ``pure fantasy.''

DOC.HEAD: People `Fed Up With Crime' Support Handyman Accused in Booby Trap Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of setting a booby trap that killed a burglary suspect in a crime-plagued warehouse is getting plenty of sympathy from a public fed up with crime, supporters said Tuesday. ``I think we are getting demoralized here, and generally losing control of our community,'' said T.J. Scranton, a one-time schoolteacher. ``We've reached a place where the police can't handle it.'' Scranton is one of more than 100 people who have voiced support for handyman Philip Connaghan through letters to newspapers and calls to radio talk shows. Connaghan is accused in the April 14 death of Michael McComb, 19, who was killed by a blast from a 12-gauge shotgun propped inside a warehouse. Connaghan, 46, of suburban Arvada, was released Monday on $5,000 bond after he was arrested for investigation of first-degree murder. Denver District Attorney Norm Early has said he will decide by Thursday whether to file charges. Connaghan has denied knowledge of the booby trap, which is illegal under city ordinances. The warehouse has been burglarized eight times since 1987. Each time, the burglars have targeted Connaghan's valuable shop tools. The warehouse also has housed vehicle parts, pickup camper shells and acetylene torches. Last July, Connaghan told police he lost more than $7,000 in tools during a burglary. The case has triggered overwhelming public support for Connaghan among residents who are ``fed up with crime,'' said Kris Olinger, news director at KOA-AM radio, an all-talk and news station. ``They can empathize with what Phillip Connaghan is going through in terms of being burglarized,'' she said. By a 9-1 margin, callers are saying Connaghan should not be charged, Olinger said. In addition, the station has aired comments from an undetermined number of callers who said ``he should be able to protect his business and livelihood, and especially if he couldn't get any help from the police,'' she said. On Sunday, letters to the editor in Denver's two newspapers were primarily in favor of property protection. A dozen letters appeared in both papers with only one opposing the use of booby traps. One reader wrote `It seems that Michael McComb got a taste of old-fashioned American justice.'' Among those who are opposed to booby traps and threatening property protection devices are public safety officials who might have to break into buildings to assist in emergencies. ``I am confident that the emotions of the community would be very different if a fireman or policeman had been killed by a booby trap while performing his duties,'' one writer to a newspaper said. Connaghan's case hit close to home for Scranton, 46, a music teacher whose Denver home was damaged by a fire set by burglars. Scranton has taken his frustration one step further, by proposing a revision in Colorado's so-called ``Make My Day'' law to include property protection. The law, nicknamed after a line from a Clint Eastwood movie, allows homeowners to use deadly force to defend themselves in life-threatening situations. Scranton said he is starting a petition drive to change the law to allow homeowners to set up what he calls ``life-threatening security devices'' to protect property.

DOC.HEAD: New Jerseyan, Others Tapped for Jobs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Tuesday he will nominate James S. Halpern, a partner in a Washington law firm, as a judge on the U.S. Tax Court. If confirmed by the Senate, Halpern would succeed Meade Whitaker. In other personnel decisions, Bush: _Said he will nominate Ming Hsu to be a federal maritime commissioner for the remainder of a term expiring June 30, 1991, succeeding Elaine L. Chao. She is director of the New Jersey Commerce Department's division of international trade, and is the governor's special trade representative. _Reappointed Andrew Camp Barrett to the Federal Communications Commission. _Accorded the rank of ambassador to Robert L. Barry of the State Department during his service as special advisor for East European assistance. _Said he will nominate Steven E. Steiner, onetime director of defense and arms control for the National Security Council, as ambassador during his service as the U.S. representative on a commission dealing with arms verification.

DOC.HEAD: United Airlines Flight Attendants Ratify Contract Tied To Employee Buyout
DOC.TEXT: The union representing 14,000 United Airlines flight attendants ratified a new contract Tuesday that is dependent upon success of a $4.38 billion employee buyout of the airline, the union announced. The ratification vote by mail ballot is one of the steps required before the employee buyout is completed. The United takeover, announced earlier this month, calls for 71,000 employees to give $2 billion in concessions over five years. Flight attendants, pilots and Machinist union members all are involved in the deal which has not yet received financing. Contracts with the Air Line Pilots Association and the International Association of Machinists have yet to be ratified. The employee stock ownership plan is to include allocated shares for each flight attendant after one year of service, and a union representative on the United Airlines Board of Directors, the union said. The contract eliminates a program designed to prevent flight attendants from being overweight, according to the announcement. ``Throughout the airline industry, flight attendants have been subject to weight programs tied to appearance, not performance,'' the union said in a statement. The flight attendants' current contract remains in effect until the buyout is completed. Negotiations for a new contract have been going on since September 1987. Flight attendants rejected a tentative contract in November 1987. Susan Bianchi-Sand, union president, noted that flight attendants, formerly called ``skygirls'' or ``stewardesses'' and ``stewards,'' have worked on airplanes since 1930. ``Sixty years later, the United flight attendants can now pride themselves on being new aviation pioneers as they take the bold steps toward owning their airline,'' said Ms. Bianchi-Sand. Union members flying with United make up about half of the union's membership, with the remainder working for 17 other airlines.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Resistance Movement Leader Assassinated in Geneva
LaserPhoto GEV4
DOC.TEXT: A leading member of an Iranian opposition movement was shot to death Tuesday outside a lakeside town near Geneva as he was driving home, the movement said in a communique. Kazem Rajavi of the Mujahedeen Khalq, a Baghdad-based Iranian exile group, was killed by one or two assailants in Coppet, 7 miles east of Geneva, the movement said. He was the brother of Massoud Rajavi, leader of the Mujahedeen resistence movement. Swiss police did not immediately identify the victim, but said several 9mm shells were found at the scene. In a communique from the Iraqi capital, the Mujahedeen claimed Dr. Kazem Rajavi, the organization's Geneva representative, was assassinated by ``the (Ayatollah Ruhollah) Khomeini regime's terrorist agents.'' Rajavi had been in Geneva several years to publicize Iranian human rights violations. He often appealed to U.N. representatives to investigate Iran's rights situation and held several press conferences during a February-March session of the U.N. Human Rights Commission. Massoud Rajavi in a statement from Baghdad charged that ``the Khomeini regime's embassy in Switzerland, acting on direct instructions from (Iranian leader Hashemi) Rafsanjani, carried out this crime.'' In a statement from Washington, Reza Pahlavi, son of Iran's deposed Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlavi, said the assassination ``once again illustrates the unchanged and continuing terrorist nature of the regime in Tehran.'' A February report issued by U.N. Special Representative Reynaldo Galndo Pohl listed the names of 700 people allegedly executed by Iran but also listed 39 people believed killed by the Mujahedeen. The report also cited evidence of torture and other violations along with government denials. The report was denounced by the Mujahedeen as a ``whitewash.'' The Mujahedeen were first allied with Khomeini in the struggle to topple the late Shah. But in 1980-81, a year after Khomeini took power, he turned on the group and other leftist factions, killing and imprisoning tens of thousands of people. The Mujahedeen and their military wing, the National Liberation Army, receive training and support from Iraq. The group is estimated to have 20,000 fighters.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's First Astronaut to Board U.S. Space Shuttle Selected
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to CORRECT Hokkaido not main Japanese island. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The first Japanese astronaut to board a U.S. space shuttle is a former assistant professor of nuclear engineering, the National Space Development Agency announced Tuesday. Mamoru Mohri, 42, was selected for the mission in June 1991 from among three final candidates, NASDA officials said. The three were chosen from 533 applicants in 1985. Since then, Mohri and the two other finalists _ Takao Doi, 35, a researcher at NASA's Lewis Research Center in Ohio, and Chiaki Naito, 37, a cardiosurgeon _have undergone training in Japan and the United States. Mohri will be the first Japanese astronaut to ride on a U.S. space shuttle. An eight-member screening committee, set up in February and led by NASDA Vice President Kenji Funakawa, conducted a series of meetings to evaluate each of the Japanese candidates on the basis of health, ability to operate the experimental equipment, and English-language ability, the officials said. ``I waited a long time to be chosen for the leading role in this next stage of riding on the space shuttle,'' Mohri said in a televised news conference. ``I still intend to pursue further training.'' Mohri and the two other Japanese candidates will leave for the United States on April 29 to participate in a year of NASA training. Doi and Ms. Naito will undergo the training as ground-support crew members. The Atlantic shuttle is scheduled to be launched June 17, 1991, with six U.S. astronauts joining Mohri. Mohri, who majored in surface physics and ultra-high vacuum science at Hokkaido University, is a native of Yoichi, on the Japanese island of Hokkaido. He formerly taught nuclear engineering at Hokkaido University.

DOC.HEAD: Longtime Dissidents Refuse to Leave Italian Embassy in Albania
DOC.TEXT: Six siblings living as refugees for more than four years in the Italian embassy in Albania have refused an Albanian offer to emigrate, saying they do not trust the government, a diplomat reported Tuesday. The Popa family members, two brothers and four sisters aged 52 to 65, walked into the Italian embassy in the capital Tirana on Dec. 12, 1985, and demanded asylum. They told diplomats they had been confined almost 20 years to Kules, a village west of Tirana, because a brother had defected to the West. It was the first known case of Albanians seeking shelter in a Western embassy. On Monday, the official Albanian news agency said the six were free to emigrate after they received Albanian passports and visas. Albania is a hard-line Stalinist state that has been loosening some of its controls in recent months. But the siblings have rejected those terms, apparently fearful of what could happen after they leave the safety of the embassy to apply for the passports and visas. ``The problem lies in the formalities requested by the Albanian government which directly concern the Popa brothers,'' said Paolo de Nicolo, first secretary of the Italian Embassy in Tirana. ``They would have to spend one or two days outside the mission under Albanian sovereignty.'' He said the siblings have also refused to apply for standard emigration visas. ``This they refuse to do,'' de Nicolo said. ``They consider themselves political refugees eager to leave the country at once.'' De Nicolo said Italy and Albania were continuing to work on an acceptable solution to the standoff.

DOC.HEAD: New Lebanese Group Threatens Attacks on Americans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADD 5 grafs to UPDATE with House action, Jerusalem background. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A group calling itself Islamic Jihad Movement-Jerusalem said Tuesday it would launch attacks against Americans unless the U.S. Senate reverses a motion endorsing a united Jerusalem as Israel's capital. The group made the threat in an Arabic-language typewritten statement delivered to Beirut's An-Nahar newspaper. ``The American Senate should reverse its decision in 10 days, or else every American inside and outside Moslem countries will be a target of terrorism and revenge,'' said the statement. The U.S. Senate, on a voice vote, passed a motion March 22 endorsing a united Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. The motion is non-binding and is opposed by the Bush administration, which does not recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital. The communique said the U.S. move has ``encouraged the Zionists and made them capture ... a building belonging to Greek Orthodox Palestinians ... as a step which will be followed by others.'' Some 150 Jews occupied a 72-room building complex in the heart of the Arab Christian quarter of old Jerusalem earlier this month. The Greek Orthodox church has filed a lawsuit against the new settlement, claiming the four buildings it occupies are owned by the church and were illegally sold by a former tenant. The United States has denounced the settlement as well as the use of U.S. aid money to finance it. No details were available on Islamic Jihad Movement-Jerusalem. A group calling itself Islamic Jihad-Beit al-Maqdis, or Islamic Holy War-Jerusalem, claimed responsibility for a bus attack in Egypt in February that killed nine Israelis. But the leader of Islamic Jihad-Beit al-Maqdis, Assad Bayoud al-Tammimi, told The Associated Press in Amman that his group was not responsible for the latest threat. ``I'm not aware of it at all and have not heard of such a movement,'' he said. Hours after the statement was released in Beirut, the U.S. House of Representatives approved a non-binding resolution identical to the Senate measure recognizing a united Jerusalem as Israel's capital. The 378-to-34 vote came despite arguments the move would stir resentment among Arab states and complicate administration efforts to achieve peace. Senate Minority Leader Robert Dole, R-Kansas, complained after a trip to the Middle East this month that the Senate move damaged peace efforts and said he regretted supporting it. Jerusalem is regarded as a holy city by Christians, Moslems and Jews. Israel annexed Arab east Jerusalem after the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, and declared the united city as its ``eternal capital.'' But U.S. policy holds that Jerusalem's status must be determined through negotiations among all parties. The U.S. Embassy to Israel is in Tel Aviv.

DOC.HEAD: Enumerators Ready to Count Heads
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Census Bureau, under heavy criticism for missing millions of people when it mailed forms to John and Jane Q. Public, on Tuesday was preparing an army of counters to hit the streets and find more. Across the country, census workers _ ``enumerators'' in census lingo _ were handed cardboard briefcases and told to have their No. 2 pencils ready for the mammoth job they face when they begin knocking on doors Thursday. They began three days of training on Monday. ``Don't take anyone with you and don't talk to anyone about census results _ except your crew leader,'' Cozella Brown cautioned her crew of seven at a training session Tuesday. ``If (residents) refuse to answer, tell them you're coming back,'' she said. Persistence might be what's called for, given that just 63 percent of U.S. households had returned census forms mailed to their homes as of Tuesday, said Rudolph Brewington, a spokesman at Census Bureau headquarters in Suitland, Md. The 1990 response rate compares with 75 percent of U.S. households mailing in forms in 1980 and falls short of the Census Bureau's own prediction that 70 percent would drop their census forms in the mailbox this year. At its peak in the next several weeks, the Census Bureau estimates 330,000 enumerators, 5,000 in Chicago alone, will be knocking on the doors of the previously uncounted. Critics say that even with the large number of enumerators hired for this phase of the census _ called ``non-response follow-up''_ many Americans may still fall through the cracks. ``How many (enumerators) are bilingual? They don't take that into account,'' said Maurice Sone, Midwest Census Coordinator for the Mexican-American Legal Defense and Education Fund. ``Enthusiasm to participate is there,'' said Sone. ``The biggest problem we've had is people who didn't get the forms. ... There is a real danger of undercount.'' Brewington said, however, that a greater percentage of Hispanics have responded to the census than of any other population group. ``This is a great surprise,'' he said. ``Hispanics are leading ... and closely behind Hispanics are blacks. ``The people who are really not responding are suburban white households,'' he said. Workers were told at Miss Brown's session that residents won't have an easy time avoiding the census. Should an enumerator fail to get a response after three attempts, Miss Brown herself will make three tries. If she fails, her boss then will try three more times. ``Be friendly, yet firm,'' a workbook urges census workers. Even so, Miss Brown's field supervisor, Leobie Jackson, conceded some people will remain uncounted. ``There are 100 reasons why people might not want to send their forms in,'' Jackson said. ``I can see very easily that there could be an undercount. We try to enumerate every person _ that's all we can do.''

DOC.HEAD: Spraying of Medflies Ordered in 16-Square-Mile Zone
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Five of...' to UPDATE to six Medflies found, sted five, picks up 5th graf, `Conner said...'; SUBS 11th graf, ``The bad...' to CORRECT name of environmental group. Picks up 12th graf, `It's not...'
DOC.TEXT: Florida's agriculture commissioner announced Tuesday the state will begin aerial pesticide spraying to combat an infestation of Mediterranean fruit flies. A malathion compound will be sprayed by helicopter beginning Thursday in a mostly residential, 16-square-mile area, commissioner Doyle Conner said at a news conference. The spraying will continue for four weeks followed by the release of millions of sterile Medflies over a 75-day period to break the breeding cycle. Fruit quarantine boundaries have not yet been established. Six of the crop-destroying pests have been discovered near Miami International Airport, including two on Tuesday. Conner said the eradication program has proven successful and is the best approach, despite environmental concerns raised over similar sprayings in California. Consumer activists and local governments in Southern California have protested the repeated spraying of malathion-laced syrup on suburban neighborhoods. The Medfly has spread from suburban back yards to orange and grapefruit groves in some of the region's richest farmland. ``Those who advocate deviating from accepted scientific procedures, you run into the grave risk of getting into the predicament California is in,'' Conner said. ``We don't want to stay in this program a day longer than necessary.'' Bobby McKown, executive vice president of Florida Citrus Mutual in Lakeland, said Monday the 12,000-member growers' organization supports ``immediate action to control and eradicate the Medflies so they don't expand beyond residential areas.'' Medflies, considered one of the world's most serious agricultural pests, are about half the size of houseflies. They do not sting and pose no threat to humans, but the larvae hatching inside more than 250 varieties of fruits and vegetables can turn it to inedible mush. Conner said the 2.4 ounces of malathion to be sprayed per acre with a syrupy insect food bait posed no health risk, but an environmentalist blasted the announcement. ``The bad thing about using these kinds of chemicals is that they wipe out all the insects in an area _ the good and the bad,'' said Lee Emerson, vice president of the environment group Friends of the Oleta River. It's not the kind of balanced, environmentally sensitive approach we should be taking these days,'' he said. The zone to be sprayed covers suburban Miami Springs, Virginia Gardens, part of Hialeah and unincorporated areas northwest of downtown Miami. The latest fly was found Tuesday in Virginia Gardens. The Florida Medfly Advisory Group, which includes Medfly experts from the U.S. Department of Agriculture, expanded the area of intensive trapping Monday from 81 to 106 square miles and beefed up the inspection staff. Traps were set in fruit trees by state agricultural inspectors around Dade County following the discovery April 16 of a lone male Medfly near the airport. Two more males were found last weekend in sour-orange trees in Miami Springs and Hialeah, and one female in a calamondin tree in Miami Springs. Some 60,000 gallons of malathion in a stronger concentration, about 3.1 ounces per acre, are used annually throughout Florida for mosquito control. The last Medfly infestation in South Florida was in 1987 when five males were found in Hialeah. The last major outbreak to affect Florida's commercial groves spread across 28 counties in 1956.

DOC.HEAD: Armed Forces Honored for Role in Liberating Death Camps
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Holocaust Memorial Council awarded a special medal Tuesday to Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Gen. Colin Powell in honor of the American soldiers troops who helped liberate Nazi death camps 45 years ago. In a ceremony in the Capitol Rotunda, the council presented Powell with the Eisenhower Liberation Medal, named for the former president and supreme commander of the allied forces in Europe. Powell, in his speech, remembered the men of the 4th Armored Division who liberated the concentration camp at Ohrdruf. Powell described the men as ``tough, fearless. They felt they were invincible.'' Yet when they came upon the mass destruction of humanity, that included 3,200 bodies in shallow graves, they were overwhelmed. In a cable to Washington, Eisenhower talked about the ``unspeakable conditions. ... For most of it, I have no words,'' Powell said. The audience that filled the Rotunda included Holocaust survivors, members of Congress and officials from the council, which is building the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum near the Mall in Washington, D.C. Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack Kemp told the audience that ``we all must recommit ourselves to the integrity of memory and the truth of history.'' Kemp warned against playing politics with the survival of Israel, saying any attempt its enemies to destroy the country is finishing the work of the Holocaust. As part of the memorial ceremony, members of Congress joined with survivors of the death camps in lighting six candles to remember the six million Jews and millions of others killed by the Nazi regime in Germany from 1933, when it came to power, until its defeat in 1945.

DOC.HEAD: WHO Warns of Dramatic Increase in Diarrhea, Other Food Infirmities
DOC.TEXT: The World Health Organization said Tuesday that serious cases of diarrhea and other food-related infirmities are increasing dramatically and already kill more than 4 million children each year in the Third World. The WHO also said 20 percent to 50 percent of the almost 2.6 billion people who traveled to countries other then their place of residence last year suffered from diarrhea. In a new food safety guide, the agency said diarrhea kills 4 million to 5 million children under age 5 each year in developing countries. The children usually die of dehydration as a result of diarrhea. ``In the first two years of life, as many as 15 out of every 1,000 children die from diarrhea,'' the pamphlet said. Diarrhea cases still account for at least 30 percent of pediatric hospitalization in many areas of the world, according to the guide. The WHO said ``that in many countries, the incidence (of diarrhea) has dramatically increased over the past several years.''

DOC.HEAD: Center-Right Party Leads in Croatian Elections
DOC.TEXT: Franjo Tudjman said Tuesday he was confident his center-right Croatian Democratic Union party would emerge with a majority from Croatia's first free elections in 50 years. Preliminary results of Sunday's elections showed the party leading in races for 111 of the 196 seats in two chambers of the three-house parliament. ``I am confident that the CDU will win more than 60 percent of parliamentary seats after the second round of the vote,'' to be held in two weeks, Tudjman told journalists at a news conference. With about 70 percent counted of the nearly 2.8 million votes cast, the governing reform Communist Party _ renamed the Party for Democratic Reform _ led in races for 50 seats and the centrist Coalition for National Accord, 14. In about 20 of the 111 constituencies in which the CDU led, however, a combination of communists and their left-wing allies, who are certain to field joint candidates in the run-offs, were actually ahead in total number of votes. No results were available for the remaining constituencies nor in Monday's voting for the third house of parliament, the 160-seat Labor Chamber. The third house is a remnant of Yugoslavia's communist-style constitution. Tudjman said that once his party assumes power, its first tasks will be to prepare a new, Western-style demoncratic constitution for Croatia and to discuss Yugoslavia's future with other states in the federation. He told journalists Yugoslavia could continue to exist only if it becomes a loose alliance of semi-independent states. Tudjman's party waged a campaign based largely on national sentiments. Ranged against the CDU were Serbs, who comprise about 10 percent of Croatia's 4.8 million people. The CDU has been accused in Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest, communist-ruled state, of being ``fascist and separatist.'' Serbia and Croatia, the second-largest state, have been rivals since they united in Yugoslavia in the aftermath of World War I. Yugoslavia is currently a loose federation. Slovenia and Croatia now have held Yugoslavia's first post-World War II multiparty elections. Macedonia and the republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina plan similar elections later this year. Communist-ruled Montenegro and Serbia have not legalized opposition parties. Tudjman said his party would strive to ``enlist other democratic forces'' in forming Croatia's new government. He left open the possibility of inviting representatives of the Serbian community to serve in the administration. A CDU government ``will stop the extraction of Croatia's ... wealth'' by Belgrade, Tudjman said. Belgrade serves as both federal capital and Serbia's capital. Croatia says Serbia unfairly dominates federal authorities. Tudjman said his party's economic program would be one ``based on a market economy in which no ideology will be allowed to interfere ever again.'' He said private and joint stock companies would receive support, but his party would not allow wholesale privatization of state firms.

DOC.HEAD: Paper: No More U.S. Hostages Freed Until Israel Frees Jailed Arabs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 8 grafs SUB for grafs 10-14 to UPDATE with four prisoners released, but militia insists no tie with hostages. Picks up 15th pvs, `A pro-Syrian...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Hostage Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The independent Beirut newspaper An-Nahar said Tuesday that pro-Iranian kidnappers will not free any more U.S. hostages unless Israel releases Arab prisoners. It said the Shiite Moslem militants also expect the release of 15 radicals from a Kuwaiti prison for bombing the U.S. and French embassies in Kuwait in 1983 before ``another goodwill gesture'' is made and more captives are freed. Sunday's release of Robert Polhill, 55, of New York, after 39 months in captivity raised hopes another Western hostage could be freed. Polhill and fellow U.S. educators Jesse Turner of Boise, Idaho, and Alann Steen of Boston were abducted in Beirut on Jan. 24, 1987, by a group known as Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine. Freedom for the Kuwaiti prisoners has been the key demand of another organization known as Islamic Jihad, or holy war, which holds American hostages Terry Anderson and Thomas Sutherland. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was kidnapped on March 16, 1985, and educator Sutherland, 58, of Fort Collins, Colo., on June 9, 1985. Five other Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman are also missing and believed held in Lebanon. The United States refuses to pressure Kuwait on the hostage issue. An-Nahar said Polhill's release was ``of a humanitarian nature and not related to any secret deal with Washington.'' The Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militia reportedly released four prisoners Tuesday to mark the Moslem holiday of Eid al-Fitr, sources in south Lebanon said, but they denied it was part of a deal to free Western hostages. Israel television said the four were from south Lebanon and were not involved in guerrilla attacks. Israel also plans to free prisoners for the holiday, but Israeli officials insisted this had nothing to do with demands for ``goodwill gestures.'' Even so, such gestures could be read as a positive sign by radical groups holding the hostages. Sources close to the 2,500-member SLA, speaking on condition of anonymity, said SLA commander Antoine Lahad will free perhaps 12 prisoners from the 300 Lebanese Shiites and Palestinians held in Khiam prison in south Lebanon. The sources said such releases are traditional during the holiday. They denied Lahad would free up to 40 prisoners, as reported by the Independent daily newspaper in London. Israel freed about 700 prisoners in 1985 following the release of 37 Americans held by Shiite extremists who hijacked a TWA jetliner. Israel denied that was linked to the Americans' release. Arab sources said it was. A pro-Syrian militia leader, Mustafa Saad of the Popular Nasserite Organization, meanwhile said he was working for the release of kidnapped Swiss Red Cross workers Emmanuel Christen and Elio Erriquez. Saad's militia controls Sidon, 25 miles south of Beirut. Christen and Erriquez were kidnapped on the edge of Sidon Oct. 6. No group claimed responsibility. Police and other security sources, however, blamed the Fatah-Revolutionary Council group of Palestinian terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal. They said the abduction was linked to the imprisonment in Switzerland of Hussein Hariri, 22, a Lebanese Shiite hijacker who belonged to the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God. The sources believe Hezbollah and Fatah-Revolutionary Council carry out terrorist operations on each other's behalf. Abu Nidal's Libyan-backed movement denied involvement in the abduction of the Red Cross workers, but admitted in November 1987 it holds four Belgians seized aboard the yacht Silko as it sailed off Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip. The Sunni Moslem newspaper Al-Liwa, in an unattributed report, said a deal has been worked out between Belgium and Abu Nidal's faction to release the four next week in return for freeing Palestinian terrorist Said Nasser from a Belgian jail. Nasser is serving 20 years for a 1980 grenade attack on a synagogue in Belgium that killed a Jew. Al-Liwa said under the deal, Nasser would be released by May 17. Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi asked this month for the release of all hostages in Lebanon. The Fatah-RC of Abu Nidal _ whose real name is Sabri al-Banna _ on April 10 released three other hostages, a European couple and their daughter, arising from the yacht seizure.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Militia Clamps Sea Blockade on Aoun's Forces
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with heavy artillery battles. Pickup 4th pvs, `A police...'
DOC.TEXT: Christian militia chieftain Samir Geagea imposed a sea blockade on Gen. Michel Aoun's forces in the latest escalation of their 3-month-old power struggle, police said Tuesday. The rival Christian forces also exchanged heavy artillery and mortar fire Tuesday, striking residential areas of east Beirut and towns throughout the Christian enclave. Police said one person was killed and four wounded in earlier shelling, but there were no reports of casualties from the latest fighting. At least 894 people have been killed and 2,399 wounded since Jan. 30 when the two sides began their fight for control of Lebanon's Christian enclave. A police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing regulations, said Geagea's boats began the blockade Monday and were preventing even fishing boats from sailing off the three-mile stretch of coast held by Aoun's troops. Security sources said the Lebanese Forces have one gunboat, one patrol boat and about 20 speedboats fitted ith machine guns and rocket launchers. Aoun is reported to have two crippled gunboats hidden somewhere near Dbaye, a coastal village north of Beirut which is the only outlet to the sea for his forces. The Lebanese Forces' blockade was clearly aimed at preventing Aoun from shipping in ammunition and weapons through Dbaye. On Monday, the Lebanese Forces boats intercepted a passenger boat and refused to let it dock at a makeshift port operated by Aoun's troops near Dbaye, the police spokeman said. A militia communique said the boat was not carrying any passengers. It did not say how many crewmen were on board or give the boat's registry. The militia boats also intercepted an unidentified motor launch that had left the Dbaye area and was heading north, the police spokesman said. He said the two vessels were escorted by the militia boats to the port of Jounieh, 12{ miles north of Beirut. Geagea's 6,000-strong militia, which has a reserve force of 30,000 men, controls the northern and southern edges to Aoun's narrow enclave and holds most of the Christian enclave's 28-mile-long coastline. The Lebanese Forces have used howitzers and rocket launchers to fire on vessels approaching Aoun's territory. The 310-square-mile Christian enclave, about one-tenth of Lebanon, is ringed on its landward sides by Syrian troops and their Moslem militia allies. Aoun, with some 19,000 troops, moved against Geagea in January in a bid to crush his only serious challenger for control of the Christian enclave. But Geagea's militia held on, and the rival armies have fought each other to an inconclusive standstill in the bloodiest clash between Christian rivals since Lebanon's civil war erupted in 1975. Aoun refuses to recognize President Elias Hrawi, a Maronite Catholic, or accept an Arab League-brokered peace treaty that Hrawi is supposed to implement. Aoun contends the treaty legitimizes the occupation of Lebanon by 40,000 Syrian soldiers. Geagea has recognized the Syrian-backed Hrawi.

DOC.HEAD: Newspapers May Be Close To Winning Battle With Telecom Companies
DOC.TEXT: Newspaper publishers may be close to winning a 6-year-old ``guerilla war'' with the Bell telecommunications companies over who can transmit electronic information in the future, a publisher said Tuesday. Robert M. Johnson, publisher, president and chief executive officer of Newsday Inc. of Melville, N.Y., reported that Congress is likely to pass a bill soon setting a telecommunications public policy. ``We think we are in as strong a position as we've ever been,'' said Johnson, who has testified in Congress on behalf of the American Newspaper Publishers Association. His report was given at a luncheon of the ANPA's 104th annual convention at the Century Plaza Hotel. Johnson said the Bell companies have set aside a $25 million ``war chest'' to fight for the right to publish information on its electronic circuits. He said Bell seeks to launch an ``electronic Yellow Pages'' which would compete directly with newspaper advertising. Such actions would violate a 1984 federal court decision that set out the principle of diversity in dividing AT&T into separate companies, he said. Citing antitrust laws, U.S. District Judge Harold Greene held that those who control telecommunication lines should not also control the information that goes over those lines, Johnson said. ``For the next six years we were engaged in guerilla war,'' he said, recounting how Bell companies lobbied for exceptions and ``in some cases they just violated the consent decree.'' Johnson said that in the past year a task force of the ANPA has worked with Congress ``to see if we can come up with a legislative solution. ``The result of those long negotiations was a new draft bill,'' he said. ``It is from our point of view the best piece of legislation we've seen emerge from Congress to protect the diversity principle.'' However, the bill has not yet been passed, and a court appeal of the original federal order has sent that back to Greene for reconsideration, Johnson said. The outcome will determine whether ``the newspaper industry is going to face a whole new group of competitors in the electronic information services,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: 1000s Flock to Gallipoli for 75th Anniversary of WWI Battle
DOC.TEXT: Scores of World War I veterans have come to this small town to mark the 75th anniversary of the Gallipoli campaign, one of the British empire's worst defeats in the war. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke and the governor general of New Zealand, Paul Reeve, will join about 70 veterans, ranging in age from 90 to 103, to mark the anniversary Wednesday. On Friday, 46 Australian veterans flew to Turkey aboard a jet specially equipped with a mini-hospital to care for the veterans in case of medical emergencies. For the first time since World War I, two Australian warships, the Tobruk and the Sydney, have dropped anchor in the area. Aboard are 160 soldiers who will take part in the ceremonies. More than 400 tourists are also expected to witness the ceremonies. The nine-month Gallipoli campaign was designed to seize the area around the Dardanelles, capture the imperial capital of Istanbul _ then called Constantinople, and force the Ottoman Empire, which had joined forces with Germany and Austria-Hungary, out of the war. But the campaign failed in the face of stiff Turkish resistance and the allies, mostly soldiers from New Zealand and Australia, were forced to withdraw their forces. It is estimated 76,000 allied troops died as well as 250,000 Ottoman soldiers. Allison Russell, a psychiatric nurse from Melbourne, said she came to Gallipoli because ``so many of our men came here and so many did not come back.'' For the Turks, the staunch resistance of the Ottoman soldiers at Gallipoli was the first victory in a war that eventually led to defeat and the collapse of the Ottoman empire. The commander of the Ottoman armies at Gallipoli, Kemal Attaturk, later went on to establish the Turkish republic.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Finds No Common-Law Marriage
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court on Tuesday unanimously upheld a state judge's decision that Oscar-winning actor William Hurt did not have a common-law marriage with a woman who subsequently bore his son. Sandra Jennings, a former New York City Ballet dancer and mother of 7-year-old Alexander Devon Hurt, lived with the star of ``The Accidental Tourist'' and ``Kiss of the Spider Woman'' from 1981 to 1984. She sought to prove a marriage existed so she could sue for divorce and a share of Hurt's assets, estimated during a six-day trial in June at $10 million. Trial testimony revealed Hurt, 40, paid Jennings $65,000 annually and let her live in an apartment he owns in Manhattan. New York abolished common-law marriages in 1933, but South Carolina still recognizes them. Jennings' claim was based on the 10 weeks she and Hurt lived together in South Carolina in late 1982 while he was filming ``The Big Chill.'' Justice Jacqueline W. Silbermann rejected her claims on Oct. 3, saying the evidence was insufficient and questioning Jennings' credibility. The decision was unanimously upheld by a five-judge panel of the Appellate Division of state Supreme Court, the trial-level court, in Manhattan. Jennings' lawyer, Richard Golub, claimed after Silbermann's verdict that the judge was ``star-struck'' and ``madly in love'' with Hurt. ``Let five judges who are men decide this, not one woman who's impressed by a movie star,'' he said in announcing his appeal. All five appellate judges were men. Reached Tuesday at his office, Golub refused to comment on his previous statements other than to say, ``I take the responsibility for everything I do.'' He said he would seek to appeal the decision to the state's highest court. Jennings, 33, who had been teaching dance in Puerto Rico, was en route to New York on Tuesday and could not be reached, Golub said. Hurt's attorney, Martin Shelton, said Hurt was filming in Portugal and could not be reached. Hurt, who divorced his first wife, actress Mary Beth Hurt, after meeting Jennings, remarried in March 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Turn Out for Animal Research Rally
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead and UPDATES arrests in 4th graf. Minor edit. Picks up 6th graf, `The protesters...'
DOC.TEXT: Animal research supporters marked the 35th anniversary of the Salk polio vaccine Tuesday by wheeling an iron lung to a rally by opponents of animal experimentation. The iron lung was once used to treat patients of the disease, which was finally conquered by a vaccine developed from animal research. The machine stood in the midst of an angry confrontation at the University of California-Berkeley, where hundreds of sign-wielding scientists and students on both sides of the issue clashed. At least 28 protesters were arrested. The rally included a rowdy march around the campus to mark World Laboratory Animal Liberation Week. About 250 of the animal-research opponents chanted during the burning in effigy of an anonymous researcher with a blood-red dollar sign on its white jacket. The protesters _ vegetarians against vivisection, purple-haired punks wearing chains, veterinarians, humanities professors and students holding pictures of mutilated monkeys _ confronted a row of police in riot gear at a $14 million animal research facility under construction. Some tossed stink bombs at police while others knocked down a chain-link fence. Shortly afterward, a half-dozen protesters chained themselves to the fence of a psychology building where other research is conducted. Several windows were broken. ``Stop the testing and torture,'' some signs read. ``Vivisection, the sacrifice of creatures we regard as `inferior' beings, differs little from concentration camps or slave traders,'' read another. The protesters, claiming UC-Berkeley researchers use and destroy 80,000 animals a year, passed out leaflets accusing five professors of ``irresponsibility, negligence and cruelty.'' One of those cited, Dr. Charles S. Nicoll of the Department of Integrative Biology, strongly defended animal research. ``No question about it,'' Nicoll said. ``A small percentage of animal research is pretty horrid, pretty gruesome. But these animals are anesthetized. They're not treated without care and concern. It's not very nice to take a healthy animal and cause it to have brain damage. But it is a less nice thing to do to not try to help the 500,000 humans who suffer brain injuries every year. ``Unless we do animal research on things like brain damage, we will never be able to help brain-injured humans recover,'' he said. Nicoll said scientists learn a lot from research on animals, most of which causes the subjects no discomfort. Researcher Sharon Russell, a physiologist, said the protesters mean well but are ``misguided.'' ``We love animals and we don't want to torture them and see them mistreated, and we don't allow that,'' Russell said. ``There are firm rules (about research methods). I feel good about my work.'' She noted how animal research led to development of the Salk polio vaccine, saving millions of children from what was an epidemic in the 1950s. But Dr. Elliot Katz, a San Rafael veterinarian and member of In Defense of Animals, said researchers then had fewer alternatives. ``We have other ways of testing the effectiveness and safety of vaccines now,'' he said. Also Tuesday, 27 protesters in Maryland were arrested during a midday demonstration by about 300 opponents of animal research at the National Institutes of Health, authorities said. Charges included trespassing, assault on a police officer and resisting arrest. After speeches criticizing the institutes' role in animal experimentation, the group marched to the Veterinary Resources Branch. NIH security officers formed a line around the building, and protesters were warned that anyone crossing police lines would be arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Wallop: Air Force Proposes Cutting Missiles to Meet Budget
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. Malcolm Wallop confirmed Tuesday the Air Force wants to cancel deployment of MX missiles on rail cars and slow Midgetman missile production, but said the proposal ``will not prevail.'' ``This is something that was forwarded to Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney and will not be approved,'' Wallop, R-Wyo., a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said in a telephone interview. The Air Force suggested the cuts after Cheney requested the armed services develop defense priorities within the constraints of the 1992 budget, Wallop said. ``It was produced by an Air Force staff person over the Easter break,'' Wallop said. ``These are selections of the Air Force's priority. They will not be the priority of the Bush administration or the secretary of defense.'' The Los Angeles Times reported Tuesday the Air Force also wants to cut its B-2 stealth bomber force in half to meet the budget constraints. The Times, citing unidentified Pentagon sources, said the Air Force wants Cheney to shift the U.S. nuclear arsenal from land missiles to bombers and submarines. The Air Force recommended a fleet of 65 B-2 stealth bombers, rather than the 132 radar-evading planes originally sought, the newspaper reported. If approved, the cutback of land-based missiles would be a break with Bush administration policy to modernize all the nuclear arsenal. Wallop did not name the soure of the recommendations, but the Times said Air Force Secretary Donald B. Rice sent them to Cheney on Friday. Defense officials also said Cheney and top Pentagon advisers would resist. Cheney has argued that the United States must respond to the Soviet Union's modernization of its weapons. But Cheney also has told the military that budgets for long-range nuclear weapons will fall by 3 percent to 5 percent annually over the next five years. Once source told the Times that ending the MX ``rail-garrison Peacekeeper'' program and going slow with Midgetman production could save as much as $15 billion. Cheney is expected to tell congressional committees on Thursday that he will recommend B-2 bomber production, but will adopt the Air Force's proposal to reduce their numbers. The Air Force said the 10-warhead MX missiles should be based in silos built to house older missiles, rather than ride the nation's rail system on special cars. Construction of the rail-garrison project is scheduled to begin this June and be operational by June 1992. The single-warhead Midgetman missile would not go into full production before the end of the century. The proposed force of 500 Midgetman missiles would replace the MX in silos scattered across Wyoming and Nebraska. The Midgetman originally was to be ferried across the western United States on trucks. The Air Force also would cancel a request for more than $2 billion that Cheney proposed to spend on rail cars for the MX, the Times said. Pentagon sources said the Air Force recently urged Cheney to approve production of five to 10 B-2s a year for at least the next five years. Such a plan would keep annual spending on the B-2 program below $8 billion. That would affect growth plans by the plane's manufacturer, Northrop Corp., which hopes to increase annual B-2 production to 30 aircraft by 1995. Officials said the Air Force's plans for slowed nuclear missile modernization resembles a package of proposals advanced by Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Derailment Blaze Extinguished As Pollution Heads Downstream
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, `Sodium hydroxide...' with 6 to UPDATE with quote from witness, commission officials saying untold numbers of fish killed, crews trying to remove last eight cars and oil estimate. Picks up 16th graf pvs, `The oil-chemcical...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PG2
DOC.TEXT: Burning crude oil from derailed railroad tank cars was extinguished Tuesday, and environmental officials tried to contain a goopy mixture of chemicals and oil that spilled into an Allegheny River tributary. Fires began after 29 cars of a 97-car freight train owned by Buffalo & Pittsburgh Railroad Inc. derailed Sunday in a steep ravine 45 miles north of Pittsburgh. Two tank cars carrying crude oil exploded late Monday, and workers barely escaped injury. A ``major assault'' was launched Tuesday morning after flames had died down sufficiently for foam retardant to suffocate two fires burning at the site along Buffalo Creek, a popular trout stream, said Don Grafton, fire chief of the Worthington Volunteer Fire Department in Armstrong County. ``Everything really looks super. It looks like we have it licked,'' Grafton said.
