Investigators from the Federal Railroad Administration and National Transportation Safety Board did not know what caused the derailment, which forced the evacuation of 200 people. Janet Burke, one of some 50 people still out of their homes Tuesday, said she, her husband and 17-year-old son were home Sunday night when ``the house started to shake.'' ``They said, `Run just as fast as you can run,''' she said. ``You could see the train going down the tracks. There were sparks everywhere, and then there was an explosion. The whole woods were on fire.'' Mrs. Burke said she saw the vinyl siding on her home begin to melt and she had no idea Tuesday if her home was still intact. ``The cars were in our yard. The railroad cars were that close,'' she said. ``It was such a scary thing.'' The crash released an undetermined quantity of crude oil and sodium hydroxide, a caustic chemical used to clean drains, into the creek, which joins the Allegheny 10 to 15 miles downstream. The Allegheny supplies drinking water to several communities in the Pittsburgh area. Crews were able to remove 21 tanker cars Monday, but the remaining cars were either on fire or too close to the flames to move. Firefighters sprayed the tankers with water to keep them cool, but stopped later that day when state environmental officials discovered 30,000 to 50,000 gallons of the water-and-oil mixture was spilling over makeshift dikes and into the creek. Shortly after they stopped the spraying, the two tank cars exploded. ``The only thing we saw _ in front of us, back of us, on top of us _ was fire,'' said John Kaus, fire marshal in neighboring Allegheny County and deputy coordinator of its Emergency Management Agency. It was ``like walking through hell.'' Sodium hydroxide also leaked into the stream from the saturated ground, killing thousands of fish, state Fish Commission officials said. ``There's too many to count,'' said Emil Svetahor, a commission official. ``This will be a long-term recovery.'' Railroad vice president John Bell said 15,000 gallons of the chemical was unaccounted for. ``We believe a substantial amount of that is still in the ground or has been picked up'' by booms, he said. ``But we know some of it got in the creek.'' Crews worked Tuesday to remove the remaining eight cars from the site. Kaus said four of the cars contained a total 55,000 gallons of crude oil. The oil-chemical mixture was ``floating along the surface in clumps, not like a sheen,'' said Betsy Mallison, spokeswoman for the state Department of Environmental Resources. However, much of the oil from Sunday's crash burned, she said. Communities along the Allegheny braced Tuesday for possible problems to their water supplies when the mixture passes their water intakes. Fifty Craigsville residents stayed with friends and family or at the Worthington Fire Hall while waiting for an evacuation order to be lifted.

DOC.HEAD: University President Investigated For Phone Calls, Reports Say
DOC.TEXT: Outgoing American University President Richard Berendzen is being investigated by northern Virginia authorities for allgedly making obscene telephone calls from his office, two televison stations said Tuesday. Stations WUSA and WRC said Fairfax County police traced obscene calls made to women who advertised babysitting services to Berendzen's office in Washington. Unidentified sources were quoted as saying that the investigation began a month ago and that through the use of telephone recording and tracing devices, the source of the calls was found to be a telephone in Berendzen's office. Fairfax Police issued a one-sentence statement saying that Berendzen had not been arrested. Authorities declined further comment, saying that they do not discuss investigations in progress. Fairfax Commonwealth's Attorney Robert Horan said that police were ``looking into certain complaints made against Dr. Berendzen,'' but would not discuss the nature of the complaints. Horan said no charges had been filed and none was expected soon. The Fairfax probe began when a county woman got what she claimed was a ``filthy and frightening'' telephone call after placing an advertisement in The Washington Post saying that she would provide day care for children in her home, the television stations said. She immediately went to police, who arranged the recordings, according to the accounts. Berendzen, 51, resigned April 10, cited exhaustion as the reason. He said he wanted to continue in his position until the end of the academic year. He came to the university in 1974 as dean of the College Arts and Sciences, became provost three years later and president in 1980. But Edward Carr, president of university's the Board of Trustees, Monday issued a statement that said Berendzen was stepping aside because of what Carr called allegations of ``improper behavior'' not connected with his role as president. Carr said Tuesday he had nothing to add, and Berendzen was in hiding.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead in 3rd item to CORRECT Mrs. Johnson oversaw program for two decades, sted two years.
DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Harry Helmsley, who avoided prosecution on federal tax charges because he was found mentally incompetent, must submit to a new test before a decision on similar state charges is made. Gerald B. Lefcourt, attorney for the 81-year-old real estate magnate, argued Monday in state court that there was ``no point'' to a new exam, and that the stress from it could endanger the life of his client. But Justice John A.K. Bradley ordered him to make an appointment immediately for an examination after prosecutors said that Helmsley and his wife, Leona, recently had flown to Florida for a vacation. The exam was scheduled tentatively for May 9 and results are to be submitted to the court May 23, said Leslie Gersing, a spokeswoman for the state attorney general's office. The Helmsleys face state charges that they falsified $3 million worth of business and tax records from 1982 to 1986. Mrs. Helmsley, 69, was convicted last year of federal income tax fraud and sentenced to four years in prison, but is free on bond pending appeal.

Stars including Paula Abdul, Randy Newman, B.B. King and Alice Cooper, will appear in a video promoting recycling based on the Coasters' 1958 hit ``Yakety Yak.'' Sponsored by the Take It Back Foundation, ``Yakety Yak, Take It Back!'' also will feature Quincy Jones and Bugs Bunny, according to the foundation's publicist, Lee Solters. The video will sport a song based on ``Yakety Yak'' to encourage recycling by urging listeners to ``separate your papers from the trash.'' It is to be filmed in June at A&M Studios and will be co-produced by the foundation and Warner Communications. Thirty- and 60-second public service announcements also will be distributed to radio and television stations, Solters said Monday.

Lady Bird Johnson, whose name has been synonymous with highway beautification for decades, is bowing out of a state landscape award program she has overseen for 20 years. The former first lady established and funded the Highway Maintenance Foreman's Awards, which presented cash to highway workers responsible for stretches of Texas roads judged to have the best wildflowers, picnic areas and landscaping. Mrs. Johnson said she had accomplished much of what she intended in the program and wants to spend more time with her family. ``I really and truly am tired, and to find open days and free time, oddly enough, has become increasingly difficult,'' Mrs. Johnson, 79, said in a recent letter to Bob Dedman, state highway commission chairman. ``Second, after 20 years it seems to me that whatever impression, impetus, enthusiasm for aesthetics along the highways _ whatever we can do _ has been done, if indeed it was do-able,'' wrote the first lady, whose campaign to improve roadside scenery began in the early 1960s while her husband, Lyndon Johnson, was president. State highway officials said they will try to continue the program without Mrs. Johnson, using state funds to pay the prize money to people responsible for the most beautiful stretch. The winner receives $1,000 and the runner-up $500.

Real estate tycoon Donald Trump is fishing for a Japanese buyer for his Trump Princess, one of the world's most luxurious yachts. Trump is asking $115 million for the yacht he bought three years ago for a reported $29 million and then spent $9 million more refurbishing. ``I think the prospects of finding a Japanese buyer are good, especially if you consider recent Japanese purchases of works of art,'' J. Jeffrey Walker, a Trump Organization senior vice president, said Tuesday. ``We just need to find someone with the right mentality.'' The Princess, which arrived in Tokyo on Sunday, left its home port in Atlantic City, N.J., four months ago. Along the way, the 282-foot yacht called in at Singapore, Taipei and Hong Kong. Trump is building a new 420-foot yacht to replace the Princess, and Walker said the expected cost is more than $200 million. Buying the Trump Princess would make good business sense, Walker said. ``If I were to call a meeting to discuss the Trump Organization at a hotel, only a handful of people would come,'' Walker told touring prospective buyers. ``If I have one here, everybody comes, and they want to come again.'' ``The price is too high, but there are many Japanese out there with money to burn, so you never know,'' said Akio Kato, manager of the Marine Sales and Project Development Department of Ishikawajima-Harima Heavy Industries.

Violinist Itzhak Perlman is giving advice on restoration of a 64-year-old theater and concert hall. Perlman, who was stricken with polio at age 4 and wears leg braces, is suggesting ways to make the theater accessible to disabled people. Problems at the Garde Arts Center were apparent to Perlman when he performed a benefit concert there with the Eastern Connecticut Symphony in October. ``It's no secret that the Garde, built in 1926, has some problems relating to access,'' restoration committee Chairman Carl Stoner said Monday. Committee members met recently at Perlman's New York City apartment to go over their master plan. ``He was so anxious to be a part of it, as though he was a member of our committee,'' Stoner said. Committee member Steve Sigel said Perlman told group he is always upset to see how theaters build a special ``Perlman ramp'' to accommodate him and then remove it the next day. ``He said they miss the point,'' Sigel said. ``The audience needs to use this as much as the performer.''

DOC.HEAD: Billy Graham Cancer Check Negative
DOC.NOTE: Eds: St. Marys in 2nd graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Billy Graham has been released from a hospital following surgery in which part of a rib was removed to check for cancer, the Mayo Clinic said Tuesday. No cancer was found. Graham was released Monday from St. Marys Hospital and will continue as an outpatient at the Mayo Clinic for the next week or two, the clinic said. Graham, 71, entered the Mayo Foundation hospital April 10 after clinic doctors observed a rib lesion on X-rays taken several weeks after he fell. Graham had complained of persistent pain in his left rib cage and upper back. Surgery was performed April 11 to remove part of the rib and check it for cancer. ``It is felt that the lesion was related to the fall, that he had fractured a rib and that was part of the healing process,'' Mayo Clinic spokeswoman Nancy Skaran said Tuesday. Graham's doctors have recommended he limit his schedule for an undetermined length of time, saying he needs complete rest, followed by gradual exercise. ``He was already physically weakened prior to surgery as a result of an exhaustive schedule which included two recent trips to Berlin,'' the clinic said in a statement. ``Mr. Graham is deeply grateful for the many letters, telegrams, cards and flowers he has received,'' the statement added.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Publishers Told to Start Recycling to Avoid Regulation
DOC.TEXT: Newspaper publishers must move rapidly to recycle newsprint to prevent the government from moving in and imposing regulations, the chairman of a publishers' task force said Tuesday. Frank A. Bennack Jr., president and chief executive officer of the Hearst Corp., New York, offered a report on recycling in his role as chairman of the American Newspaper Publishers Association Newsprint Resource Task Force. In an address to the ANPA's 104th annual convention, Bennack painted a grim picture of vanishing landfills to absorb the nation's increasing output of solid waste. He said publishers have resolved to double the amount of recycled newsprint used in the coming year, reaching a total of 4.6 million tons. Aggressive movement on recycling will prevent government intervention, he said. ``We believe efforts to control newsprint can mean efforts to control the press,'' he said. ``The prospect of dealing with a regulated newsprint industry calls up an array of terrifying unknowns.'' Bennack said that at least two states have already mandated that newspapers use recycled newsprint, but he insisted such official orders will be unnecessary if publishers act on the recycling issue voluntarily. He said 35 percent of newspapers currently are recycled, and publishers aim to bring that up to 50 percent. ``Our goal must be reached if newspapers are to deal with the irrevocable closing of landfills,'' he said. Bennack said the nation had 18,000 landfills available in 1979. Today only 6,500 remain, and that figure will diminish to 4,200 by 1995, he said. ``In 15 to 20 years, the last existing landfills will be closed,'' he said, ``but this society will be producing thousands of tons of solid waste.'' Bennack stressed that although newspapers are among the most visible recyclable items, they make up only 8 percent of solid waste going into landfills. He said newspapers already are the second largest recycled material in the country.

DOC.HEAD: Acquit 14 Ethnic Albanians in Yugoslav Political Trial
DOC.TEXT: The former Communist Party chief of troubled Kosovo province and 13 other prominent ethnic Albanians were acquitted Tuesday of inciting anti-government protests. ``This is a victory for justice in Yugoslavia,'' said the teary-eyed ex-party leader, Azem Vlasi, as he embraced his wife. The six-month political trial was Yugoslavia's biggest in decades. Chief Judge Ismet Emra ruled lack of evidence. Public Prosecutor Spasoje Zamfirovic indicated he would ask a retrial, Tanjug news agency reported. Belgrade radio said thousands of ethnic Albanians celebrated the 43-year-old Vlasi's release, chanting ``Azem, Azem!'' and singing nationalist songs, while minority Serbs in the province were ``shocked by the outcome of the trial.'' The acquittal was seen as a setback for Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic, who pushed for holding the trial and for strong-arm policies in Kosovo, which is part of the Serbian republic. Politicians and the news media in Yugoslavia's western republics of Slovenia and Croatia denounced it as a ``show trial'' staged by the Serbian leadership to intimidate Albanians in Kosovo. Human rights groups also criticized the trial. Vlasi was arrested in March 1989. Heavy riot police forces patrolled major towns in Kosovo late Tuesday, fearing street celebrations could trigger intercommunal clashes. The only incidents reported, however, was some minor stone-throwing involving Vlasi supporters and police. A state of emergency imposed in Kosovo in March 1989 was lifted this month, after Kosovo's police force came entirely under Serbian control. The 14 defendants were originally accused of counter-revolutionary activities for allegedly instigating a wave of protests by ethnic Albanians in winter 1989. According to the indictment, the protests culminated in an ``armed insurrection'' in Kosovo that left numerous people dead. Last week, the charges were modified to remove the threat of capital punishment. Kosovo, where ethnic Albanians are a 90 percent majority, has been rocked more than a year by violent protests over constitutional amendments in Serbia that gave Yugoslavia's largest republic almost complete control over the province. At least 60 people died in protests the past year. Kosovo previously enjoyed broad autonomy. The amendments were said to be needed to protect Slavs in Kosovo from alleged harassment by ethnic Albanians. During the trial, Vlasi denied charges he instigated the unrest and claimed the trial was staged by Milosevic, his political archrival.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Opens Fire in Mall, Killing One, Wounding Four
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with hospital documents; RECASTS lead to reflect man `homicidal and suicidal'; details on gun, where gun bought; man booked; DELETES 14th graf, `WAGA-TV to remove redundancy; picks up 15th graf pvs, `A 24-year-old...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos AX7, AX10, XGWIN1; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: A smiling gunman who was released from a mental hospital despite homicidal and suicidal tendencies opened fire in the food court of a suburban shopping mall Tuesday, killing one man and wounding four people. The man tried to reload the .38 caliber revolver but tossed it into a trash can before calmly walking out and surrendering, police said. James Calvin Brady, 31, surrendered to DeKalb County police outside the mall just after shootings, said police spokesman Chuck Johnson. ``He held up his hands and said, `I'm the one you're looking for,''' said police Col. M.F. Ferguson. Police said Brady was charged Tuesday night with one count of murder and four counts of aggravated assault. He was being held without bond, and other charges may be filed. A document found in Brady's pocket said he was released Monday from Georgia Regional Hospital in Atlanta. He was admitted to the state hospital April 13, but the document did not say why he was released, said DeKalb police Col. M.F. Ferguson. The document ``said he had homicidal and suicidal tendencies, and suffered from delusions,'' Ferguson said. Brady ``can be hostile, threatening, and has a history of alcohol abuse,'' he quoted it as saying. Marchant Roach, a spokesman for the state Department of Human Resources, which runs the state hospital system, said the department would not comment on any patient. During questioning, police said Brady talked of God and about a ``mechanical device'' inside him that controls his actions. ``He's suffering from hallucinations. He was probably having one when he fired,'' Ferguson said. Officers said Brady bought the revolver and 12 rounds of hollow-point ammunition, a type designed to expand on impact and cause particularly severe wounds, for $129 at a pawn shop in Atlanta on Monday. ``He looked like a businessman with his left hand in his pants pocket,'' said Carol Gravdahl, manager of Sweaters Etc. at Perimeter Mall, a few miles north of the city. ``His right arm was straight out with a pistol, shooting it off randomly. He was coming around with it until I guess he emptied it _ and he was smiling. ``He just walked in and started shooting,'' she said. ``He was very casual. He just stood there. He just moved his arm like somebody would be picking out some people for a team _ you and you and you and you.'' After emptying his gun, Brady walked to a table, unloaded the empty shells and was about to reload when an unidentified person standing nearby talked him out of it, Johnson said. ``We still don't know who that person was,'' he said. DeKalb Public Safety Director Thomas Brown said the gunman muttered, ``You don't know what all these people have done to me,'' as he was led away, but no motive had been established. ``We don't believe it was directed toward the individuals who were shot; we think it was directed toward people in general,'' Brown said. A 24-year-old man was wounded in the chest and died later at Northside Hospital, Johnson said. Police identified the man as Michael Gregory Music of Norcross, an Atlanta suburb. Johnson said three people were taken to Shallowford Community Hospital. Police identified them as: Craig E. Bruno, 23, of Roswell, shot in the abdomen and listed in critical but stable condition. Lucille Huey, 74, of Decatur, wounded in the right side and listed in critical but stable condition after surgery. Judy Shell, 53, of Roswell, shot in both legs and listed in stable condition. James McDonald, 30, of Alpharetta, treated and released for a gunshot wound to the ankle. Among the witnesses were two visitors from Soviet Georgia, here on a Friendship Force exchange. ``We heard shooting, ... six times, seven times. ... I didn't understand what was happening,'' said Tamriko Maisuradze, 39, who was sitting in the food court with her husband, Alexander ``Kuchi'' Chubabira. ``My husband said, `Let's run.' ... Everybody was running.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush To Speed Medical Aid to Nicaragua
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf pvs, The Senate, with 2 grafs further elaboration on makeup of bill, overall total
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will invoke emergency authority to send $2.6 million in medical aid to Nicaragua in time for the presidential inauguration Wednesday of Violeta Chamorro, congressional and administration sources said. The move was timed to give Vice President Dan Quayle the chance to deliver good news when he represents Bush at the swearing-in ceremony in Managua, the sources said. Quayle also will report progress toward sending previously promised food and other aid for the new government, the sources said. Bush's request for $300 million to begin economic recovery in Nicaragua, part of an $870 million aid request that also includes Panama, had been stalled on Capitol Hill by a dispute over unrelated legislation. That snarl was resolved late Tuesday, but it remained unlikely the full aid package would be approved immediately. Failure to approve the full aid package by Chamorro's inauguration should not be seen as an embarrassment, said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. ``It is a matter of procedures here,'' he told reporters. ``We have procedures that obviously have to go forward, and I think eventually that aid package will be voted.'' The administration aid request for Nicaragua is designed to help that country _ now among the poorest in the hemisphere _ recover from a decade of civil war and U.S. trade sanctions. It includes money to meet immediate needs for planting of crops and for fuel. Officials of the new government acknowledge they face a thorny challenge in meeting the expectations of the electorate for a better standard of living. Mrs. Chamorro was elected overwhelmingly in February elections to replace President Daniel Ortega of the leftist Sandinista party. Her coalition was supported by the United States. The medical assistance would be the first direct U.S. aid to the Central American country in nine years, since President Reagan cut off aid shortly after taking office in 1981. Bush is seeking $300 million as a first installment of aid for the country, along with $500 million for Panama. But the aid package, a version of which has been passed by the House, had been held up in the Senate by a dispute over child-care legislation. The dispute was settled late Tuesday, and the Senate Appropriations Committee approved the money measure with the full $300 million for Nicaragua and $420 million for Panama, the same amounts previously approved by the House. The panel voted 15-14 against an effort by Chairman Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., and Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., to cut the Panama aid to $300 million and use the money saved to help U.S. businesses compete in Eastern Europe. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said he expected the money measure to be on the Senate floor Wednesday, but could not predict how long it would take to complete action. The Senate committee's version of the bill, totaling about $3.4 billion, also included domestic spending for programs like disaster relief, the Census Bureau, food stamps and Head Start. And it included $10 million for use if the United States wants to establish an embassy in Lithuania. The measure was nearly $1 billion more expensive than the House version, but also included larger cuts in Pentagon spending to pay for the increase. Bush made the urgency of the supplemental money bill the top item on his agenda when he met with congressional leaders at the White House on Tuesday, participants said. House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., said Bush sought to ``turn up the heat'' on Mitchell to schedule action on the measure. Later, speaking to a group visiting the White House, Bush asked: ``If you have any spare time, please call your friendly senator and tell them to get going and get this legislation passed. Because we are a symbol up here for these countries in our own neighborhood.'' The stopgap medical aid is being provided under a little-used section of the foreign assistance law that permits the president to use up to $10 million a year for ``any emergency purposes,'' so long as Congress is notified. The administration began making those notifications late Monday, the sources said.

DOC.HEAD: First Black Career Ambassador Dies
DOC.TEXT: Clifton Reginald Wharton, the first black American to reach the rank of career minister and ambassador in the U.S. Foreign Service, has died at the age of 90. The cause of death was not released. Wharton, who died Monday, rose through the ranks of the service in his 40-year career and ultimately was appointed ambassador to Norway under presidents Eisenhower and Kennedy. He also was an alternative representative of the United States at the United Nations in the early 1960s. Wharton was the first black to be assigned as minister to a non-black country, the first to attain the rank of career minister and the first to become an ambassador through the career service. Born May 11, 1899, in Baltimore, he earned several degrees from Boston University and was the first black to pass the Foreign Service exam in 1925. He soon was appointed vice consul and second secretary in Liberia. From 1930 to 1941, he served as consul in Las Palmas, Spain, and from 1936 to 1942 held four temporary assigments to Liberia as charge d'affaires. He went on to serve as a consul in Tananarive, Madagascar, a maritime consul in the Azores, Portugal, and consul general and first secretary in Lisbon. Eisenhower named Wharton envoy extraordinary and minister plenipotentiary to Romania in 1958. Kennedy named him ambassador to Norway in 1961, and he retired in 1964. He is survived by four children.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Tell World that Rigid Central Control of Economy a Bust
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union said Tuesday that economic problems will not be solved by rigid central control but by encouraging market forces and guaranteeing social justice. Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Ernest Y. Obminsky told a special U.N. session on economic coperation that ``each country bears the major responsibility for its own development.'' His speech, on the second day of a six-day session on helping sick Third World economies, was considered a major statement reflecting Moscow's new views on liberalizing the Soviet economy and coordinating foreign aid with market reforms in recipient nations. Like speakers from industrialized and developing nations, Obminsky struck a balance between the need for poor nations to undertake economic restructuring and for better-off nations to help them where they need it _ in debt relief, commodity prices, inflation and trade. Because of the Soviet Union's own economic woes, Moscow is less enthusiastic about pouring money into poor, leftist Third World nations where the aid may be mismanaged under rigid, central control. But Obminsky reaffirmed the Soviet Union's long-standing and continuing commitment to helping less fortunate nations. He said that despite difficulties faced by the Soviet economy, the government continues to provide major Third World aid. But he said awareness is growing that economic objectives may be achieved most efficiently ``not through rigid centralization, but rather through encouraging market mechanisms managed by economic methods, while ensuring adequate social guarantees for the population and equality of all forms of property.'' In the Soviet Union, he said, the government is developing a new package of laws to speed transition from a state-controlled economy to a regulated market economy. He said Soviet plans include reform of the financial system and the pricing system, establishment of commodity exhanges and eventually, stock exchanges. On Monday, industrialized nations called upon the developing world to bear the primary responsibility for galvanizing their own stagnating economies, but said the West stands ready to deliver major aid to market systems. Also at the United Nations on Tuesday: _Pakistani Foreign Minister Sahabzada Yaqub-Khan accused India of using ``massive and indiscriminate'' force to suppress Moslem secessionists in Kashmir and asked India to stop it. His statement came on the eve of a meeting with Indian Foreign Minister Inder K. Gujar to discuss the turmoil in Kashmir, claimed by both nations. India is overwhelmingly Hindu. _The United States, Canada, the European Community and others urged the Ethiopian government and rebels to observe an immediate cease-fire to ensure distribution of food and prevent mass starvation. Famine threatens an estimated 4.5 million Ethiopians in northern Wollo, Tigre and Eritrea. Donor nations have committed food aid, but civil war prevents supplies from reaching the people. _The Arab League condemned the U.S. congressional vote recognizing a united Jerusalem as capital of Israel and called the non-binding move ``reckless and irresponsible.''

DOC.HEAD: Party Suspends Ex-President for Accepting Bribes from Drug Suspect
DOC.TEXT: The ruling party said Tuesday it was barring former President Daniel Oduber from politics for one year for secretly taking a campaign donation from an American accused of drug trafficking. Oduber was chairman of the party's national political committee and one of Costa Rica's most influential figures. He was not available for comment and aides said he was vacationing in Europe. The general secretary of the ruling National Liberation Party, Walter Coto, said Oduber did not informed party authorities when Lionel Casey donated $12,000 to a 1985 campaign fund. Casey, 65, from Miami, is in a San Jose jail awaiting extradition to Florida on charges of drug trafficking. ``The party's ethics committee, after an investigation, determined that ex-President Daniel Oduber is suspended for a year from his functions and offices and as a representative of the National Liberation Party,'' Coto said. Under party rules, Oduber, who served as president 1974-78, should have informed the party leadership of the donation and turned the money over to the party treasurer, Coto said. After serving a five-year term, Oduber was succeeded by fellow party member, Oscar Arias. By law Oduber could not run for re-election. Arias won the 1987 Nobel Prize for a Central American peace plan and is scheduled to leave office May 8. He will be succeeded by Rafael Calderon Fournier of the opposition United Social Christian Party.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Arabia Says Ramadan to Continue until Thursday
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia's top religious body announced Tuesday that the crescent moon heralding a new Moslem month had not been sighted and the month of Ramadan fasting would continue until Thursday. The decision by Saudi Arabia's ruling clerics has strong influence in the Moslem world because of the prestigious place the kingdom holds as home to the religion's holiest shrines in Mecca and Medina. The delay means most of the world's estimated 1 billion Moslems will end their monthlong dawn-to-dusk fast on Thursday, rather than Wednesday as was expected. Islamic months end when a crescent moon can be sighted by eye. The months can last 29 or 30 days. The fast month of Ramadan commemorates the time when Islamic tradition holds that the Angel Gabriel gave the Moslem holy book, the Koran, to the prophet Mohammed more than 14 centuries ago. In some countries, such as Iran and Egypt, Ramadan started a day later and can be expected to end Thursday or Friday.

DOC.HEAD: State Says Pipe that Leaked Had Been Damaged
With AM-Exxon Spill
DOC.TEXT: The Exxon Corp. pipeline that leaked 567,000 gallons of heating oil into a busy waterway between New York and New Jersey had cracked a long time before the spill, state officials said Tuesday. The report contradicted Exxon's contention that recent damage caused the underwater pipe to burst and foul the Arthur Kill waterway on Jan. 1. However, Exxon issued a statement Tuesday saying the report confirmed its conclusions that the pipe had been damaged and was not corroded. The state-commissioned study, conducted by Battelle Co. of Columbus, Ohio, concluded that the pipe suffered a 10-foot dent ``a substantial period of time before the final leak occurred.'' The damaged pipe didn't rupture earlier because oil was pumped through it at a relatively low pressure between Exxon facilities in Bayonne and Elizabeth, the study said. Exxon's statement said the pipeline was pressure-tested four times a year, the last time on Dec. 18, 1989. ``This type of rigorous test would have detected a small leak in the line,'' the statement said. An Exxon spokesman said the company would have no further comment.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities: Man Who Built Bomb Committed Suicide Within 36 Hours
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling to Petersen sted Peterson throughout. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The man who built a bomb that maimed a 5-year-old girl at a K mart store a year ago committed suicide within 36 hours of the blast, authorities said Tuesday. David L. Swinford, 19, shot himself in the head as he sat in a car on a rural road on April 19, 1989, a few hours after having discussed the bombing with his mother and stepfather, said Charles Petersen, resident agent in charge of the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms in Indianapolis. Swinford, who graduated from high school in 1988, was working at a restaurant at the time of the bombing, Petersen said. Following disagreements, his parents had asked him to move out of the home, he added. Petersen said authorities knew of no motive for the bombing. Swinford, of rural Noblesville, was identified as a possible suspect within days of the April 17, 1989, bombing, but investigators only recently developed conclusive evidence that he built the device, Petersen said. Petersen said Swinford's stepfather, David Whitesell, contacted authorities shortly after the suicide and suggested his stepson may have been responsible for the blast that took off part of the left hand of Erin Bower of Indianapolis. Erin, now 6, picked up the pump-type toothpaste dispenser in which the pipe bomb had been concealed. She now wears an artificial hand and was scheduled this month for a cornea transplant in her left eye, also damaged in the explosion. Her father, Kevin Bower, released a statement Tuesday saying, ``If this individual was in fact responsible, Maureen and I feel sorry for him and for the circumstances which must have been present to lead to such an act. ... ``We would like to get all of this behind us and focus on what lies ahead.'' Petersen said there was no evidence about whether Swinford actually placed the bomb on the shelf. ``He may have had an accomplice,'' he said. Tests on a screwdriver and knife recovered from Swinford's car determined that they were used in making the bomb, Petersen said. He described the bomb as ``a very inventive device'' that was filled with explosive black powder and BBs. Swinford knew about bomb-making and electrical wiring from building crude firecracker devices with friends and from working with his stepfather in electronic installation, Petersen said. ``Certainly he did not expect to hurt a young girl,'' Petersen said of Swinford. K mart officials learned of Swinford's involvement recently from ATF agents, said spokeswoman Leslie Kota at K mart headquarters in Troy, Mich. ``It is obviously a very unfortunate set of circumstances all the way around. It compounds the tragedy for both families,'' she said. Kota said company officials had not decided what would happen to the $20,000 reward K mart offered for information leading to the arrest of the person or persons responsible for the bombing. Separate rewards totaling $30,000 also had been offered.

DOC.HEAD: Source: Gen. Ortega Will Remain as Commander in Chief
With AM-Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Humberto Ortega, one of the leaders of the Sandinista revolution, will remain as commander of the Nicaraguan army after President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is sworn in Wednesday, a source in the incoming government said Tuesday. ``There are some extremists who want the Sandinistas wiped out in one fell swoop,'' the source close to Mrs. Chamorro said, describing some factions in the United National Opposition. ``That can't be. He (Ortega) will be eased out, but not for a while.'' The plan calls for keeping Gen. Ortega as commander in chief of the army and Mrs. Chamorro as defense minister, said the source, who refused to be identified by name. The retention of Gen. Ortega, President Daniel Ortega's brother, as army commander was likely to heighten divisions inside Mrs. Chamorro's coalition and make it more difficult for her to persuade the U.S.-backed Contra rebels to disarm. The Contras and members of the Chamorro coalition have demanded the army be purged of Sandinista loyalists. ``It is unacceptable that members representative of the FSLN (Sandinista Front) remain in high-level posts in the army, Interior Ministry and other government structures,'' UNO's political council said in a statement Tuesday. The council has frequently been at odds with the circle of Chamorro advisers putting her government together. That statement continued, ``If the executive were to take a decision opposite to the previous statement, the political council will not support such a decision nor accept responsibility for the consequences.'' According to the source, Gen. Ortega will remain in charge of the army but answer to Mrs. Chamorro, who as both defense minister and president will be supreme commander of the armed forces. Mrs. Chamorro will keep the defense ministry post ``until an appropriate person can be found to take over,'' the source said. That jibed with a leak in La Prensa, the Chamorro family newspaper, which said Monday that Mrs. Chamorro would take the defense post. Gen. Ortega was one of the most prominent members of the Sandinista party's national directorate until he quit Monday in accordance with an agreement to depoliticize the armed forces. The nine-man directorate, which included both Ortega brothers, had not changed its membership since the Sandinistas overthrew dictator Anastasio Somoza in 1979. All officers in the Sandinista People's Army and the security forces resigned leadership positions in the Sandinista Front, presumably making them eligible to stay on after Mrs. Chamorro takes over.

Despite their apparent help in liberating American hostage Robert Polhill, Iran and Syria will remain on the State Department's list of countries that sponsor terrorism, U.S. officials say. Remaining on the terrorism list means Iran and Syria will continue to be deprived of U.S. backing for international bank loans and sophisticated American technology. The department's annual terrorism report is due to be released next Monday. It was finished two weeks ago, before Polhill was freed by the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine. The report could have been revised. But a U.S. official said, speaking Monday on condition of anonymity, ``we are not calling it back from the printers.''

After concluding an aid agreement with the Peruvian military to curb narcotics trafficking, the Bush administration is about to complete similar pacts with Colombia and Bolivia, U.S. officials say. The $35 million aid package with Peru was announced over the weekend in Lima and will involve the Peruvian military in the anti-drug effort for the first time. Negotiations with the three Andean countries have taken place since shortly after President Bush announced his anti-drug strategy last September and disclosed his intention to increase military cooperation with each country. Consistent with earlier announcements, the Colombian program will be $40.3 million and Bolivia's will be $33.7 million. The U.S. officials, who insisted on anonymity, said the signings of the agreements are imminent.

A winter of discontent has turned into a dry spring for New York Republicans seeking a credible candidate to challenge Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo. No major GOP figure has been willing to step forward to take on Cuomo's expected re-election bid. The New York Democrat is widely viewed as a potential 1992 presidential contender should he survive the 1990 state election. ``I'm not a kamikaze,'' Sen. Alfonse D'Amato said last August as he became the first of many Republicans to keep their hats out of the ring.

Impossible as it sounds, a food scientist says he's invented just what the world's been waiting for: Ice cream that's good for you. Not only does this stuff contain almost no fat, it might actually lower the body's cholesterol level instead of raising it. The secret ingredient is a fluffy white powder made from that darling of the food conscious, oat bran. Its principal inventor, George E. Inglett of the U.S. Department of Agriculture's research labs in Peoria, Ill., calls it Oatrim. If his predictions are correct, in two or three years it will be an ingredient in all sorts of otherwise high-fat foods, including mayonnaise, cheese spreads, salad dressings and margarine.

``I yam what I yam,'' says Popeye the Sailor Man, but the peace-loving Quakers don't like his brawling ways and object to the use of the cartoon character in ads for Quaker Oats. Not only that, toot toot, but Olive Oyl is too submissive, say members of the Religious Society of Friends, better known as the Quakers, a longtime champion of women's rights. Popeye began popping up last year in TV commercials and in comics inserted in instant oatmeal packages, dispatching his nemesis Bluto with a swift swing of an oversized forearm. ``I eats me oatmeal and I'm stronger than steel, I'm Popeye the Quaker Man,'' he sings to an adoring Olive Oyl.

DOC.HEAD: Peter Jennings Revists the Killing Fields of Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: On this month 15 years ago, Phnom Penh fell to Khmer Rouge troops. Thirteen days later, Saigon surrendered to North Vietnamese forces. The Vietnam War was over. But as an ABC News special coming up Thursday reminds us, the Khmer Rouge's takeover of Cambodia marked the beginning of a murderous four-year reign of terror in which an estimated one million Cambodians were killed. The Vietnamese drove the Khmer Rouge out, but fighting continues. Guerrillas from a coalition of two non-communist groups and the communist Khmer Rouge are battling those of Cambodia's government. Reported by Peter Jennings, ABC's special, ``From the Killing Fields,'' examines if the United States, in supporting that anti-government alliance, might be helping the Khmer Rouge come back. Jennings, anchorman of the top-rated ``World News Tonight,'' spent a week in January traveling to Cambodia and Vietnam for the special. He also flew to Beijing for an interview with the nominal head of the anti-government coalition, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former Cambodian ruler whose overthrow in 1970 by American-backed forces was followed five years later by the Khmer Rouge takeover. ``I found him to be sad in some cases, very defensive on other issues,'' the anchorman said. ``When I asked him about the conventional wisdom that he's a puppet of the Khmer Rouge, he became extremely defensive. He said he's in charge.'' Jennings' Vietnam trip was his first since 1965, when he was on his first tour as anchorman of ABC's weeknight newscasts. He was a veritable kid then as anchors go, sent for two months to cover the early part of the long U.S. military involvement in Vietnam. His dossier now is full of foreign-correspondent credits. But on his first time in Vietnam, he candidly says, he didn't really know much about the subject and was ``more than a dilettante than anything else.'' Still, his return to Vietnam contained its share of deja vu experiences, softened by time and nature. When he flew from Bangkok over Cambodia and Vietnam to what now is Ho Chi Minh City, Jenning said, he found that from the air, the only visible remnants of the war ``are the craters left by B-52 bombings.'' ``They're all over the place, some filled with water, some planted (with rice),'' he said. He also took a drive that would have been a suicide run during the war, motoring up Route One from Ho Chi Minh City to Phnom Penh, passing through the so-called Parrot's Beak area 30 miles west of Vietnam's capital. A battleground during the war, it's quiet now, he said, and ``you can walk around there day and night'' without fear. Not so the so-called ``liberated zones'' of the Cambodian guerrillas near the Thai border. ``All the fighting is being done on the western side of the country,'' said Jennings, whose Cambodian travels took him to Khmer Rouge-controlled refugee camps and two contested border towns, Sisophon and Batdambang. He shook his head when asked if any Cambodian with whom he spoke in Phnom Penh mentioned the 1984 movie that dramatized the bloody nightmare of the Khmer Rouuge takeover, ``The Killing Fields.'' ``No, they'd been through the real ones,'' he said. ``We're fortunate, however, in the fact that a great many Americans saw the movie.'' That may give many viewers ``a base of knowledge'' for understanding Thursday's special, he said: ``I think people know the Khmer Rouge have the title of the worst barbarians since the Nazis.'' The special, shown in the same week as Time magazine's cover story on Vietnam and Cambodia, marks the second time this year ABC and Time have simultaneously done major stories on the same subject. The double coverage is the result of an informal agreement by the two organizations, although the ABC and Time stories are journalistically separate efforts, says Tom Yellin, executive producer of ABC's special. Time and ABC are, however, collaborating on a live follow-up forum, anchored by Jennings, that ABC will broadcast at 11:30 p.m. EDT after the special. Scheduled guests on the 90-minute forum include Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., a Vietnam veteran and Medal of Honor recipient who recently visited Cambodia. Henry Kissinger, a key figure in President Nixon's Cambodia policy during the war, also was to have appeared, ``but he's just dropped out for reasons that apparently have nothing to do with us,'' Yellin said Monday.

Elsewhere in television ... A GOOD READ: Morley Safer, who helped cover the Vietnam War for CBS, has a new book out, ``Flashbacks,'' which he wrote after returning to Vietnam last year for ``60 Minutes.'' The book is well-written, with sharp insights and moments of humor and irony. Safer is compassionate for those who fought and suffered in the war, regardless of whose side they were on. Not so for those in the halls of power during the war. He particularly fulminates against such diverse people as Barry Goldwater, Bill Moyers and Hanoi's military genius, Vo Nguyen Giap.

DOC.HEAD: Spanish Television Networks Launch Shows in Battle for Bucks, Ratings
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The two major U.S. Spanish-language television networks are Americanizing their programming with lively new shows in a battle for increasing Hispanic viewership and advertising dollars. Telemundo and Univision officials say the push for new programs, many patterned after popular English-language shows, coincides with a surge in Spanish television viewers in major markets, particularly Los Angeles. The programming is a fresh alternative to the time-honored mainstays of Spanish television: melodramatic soap operas _ or novelas _ shoot-em'-up Mexican movies and Sunday variety shows. This year alone, Univision has introduced ``Fama y Fortuna (Fame and Fortune),'' a ``Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous'' clone; ``Cita con el Amor (A Date With Love),'' a Hispanic version of ``The Dating Game;'' and ``Cristina,'' a talk-show takeoff of Oprah Winfrey. The network also began airing a talk show featuring Hispanic comedian Paul Rodriguez in March. Telemundo has countered with a MTV-produced rock video program in Spanish and a variety of new game shows _ ``Uno Nunca Sabe (One Never Knows),'' a ``Candid Camera''-style game show; ``Adivinelo con Senas (Guess It With Signs),'' a charades game show featuring two teams of celebrities; and ``La Feria de la Alegria (The Fair of Happiness),'' a variety and game show featuring an assortment of contests and entertainment. The push comes at a crucial time, particularly for cash-strapped Univision, which in February was unable to make interest payments of about $10 million due on $270 million in junk bonds it had issued. Hallmark Cards Inc., which owns 63.5 percent of Univision, earlier this year had offered to pay $131 million for the bonds. It said at least 90 percent of each issue must be tendered before it would be obligated to buy any of the securities, and that Univision was authorized to file for bankruptcy if the tender offer was not successful. Hallmark announced on April 17 that it was dropping that requirement of the offer and had accepted $251.9 million of the bonds for payment, averting the possibility of bankruptcy. A recent Los Angeles Arbitron survey showed Spanish television viewership jumped 52 percent in February from the same month the previous year, according to Maureen Schultz, audience research manager for KMEX, Univision's Los Angeles affiliate. Hispanics now make up about 28.5 percent of Los Angeles-area residents, and Hispanic households account for about 21.4 percent of all Los Angeles-area households with televisions, according to research figures from both networks. Nationwide, there now are more than 20 million Hispanics, accounting for nearly 10 percent of the country's total population, network officials said. ``Our 1990 programming lineup, coupled with the rapidly growing Hispanic population _ which is increasing five times more rapidly than the general population _ will make advertisers stand up and take note,'' said Rosita Peru, a Univision vice president and programming director. Along with new network programs, local affiliates have beefed up news coverage in an attempt to attract new viewers and develop viewer loyalty. For national and international news coverage, Univision depends on its own correspondents, and Telemundo contracts with CNN for specially prepared Spanish programming. An especially competitive news war has erupted in Los Angeles, where Univision affiliate KMEX goes head-to-head with Telemundo affiliate KVEA. ``It really is very competitive,'' said KVEA spokesman Martin Quiroz. ``That's what makes it fun and what forces us to do better.'' Both stations have new general managers and news directors. ``News sets the station's whole image,'' said KMEX General Manager Emilio Nicolas Jr. Univision officials hope a new multimedia service launched in late March, which Telemundo is not involved with, will help more advertisers reach the Spanish-speaking market by magazine, television and telephone. Whittle Communications of Knoxville, Tenn., said 90 percent of the $10 million advertising time and space for one year had been sold when the new service was started. Whittle has predicted the new service will reach an estimated 500,000 Hispanic magazine readers and nearly 90 percent of Hispanic homes with televisions. Sponsors include American Airlines, Procter & Gamble, AT&T and Kinney Shoes.

Elsewhere in television ... STUTTERING PROTEST: Responding to complaints from the National Stuttering Project, ABC has agreed to trim, ``where possible,'' Kevin Kline's mockery of Michael Palin's stuttering in the movie ``A Fish Called Wanda.'' ABC has purchased the 1988 film, for which Kline won a best supporting actor Academy Award, for broadcast at a later date.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tues PMs, April 26

For release PMs Wednesday, April 25
DOC.HEAD: Yes, Japan Market Can Be Penetrated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: John Cunniff is on vacation.
DOC.TEXT: Bill Totten says he is proof that foreigners can crack the Japanese market with the same formula that works elsewhere: hard work and concern for customers. But the computer software executive says those who succeed generally keep quiet, not wanting to invite competition. Totten, in contrast, has been contributing articles to major newspapers and magazines overseas and appearing on Japanese television to challenge the commonly held belief that Japan is a closed market. ``My experience has been that this has been a very open country,'' contends the American, who has lived in Tokyo 21 years and speaks Japanese. Far from encountering any trade barriers, he says, ``I've found it easier to do this business in Japan than to do it in my own country or for a Japanese to do it here.'' He is president of one of Japan's largest software firms, K.K. Ashisuto, which reported sales of more than $59 million in 1989 and claims a 50 percent share of the independent software market. ``Go talk to Coca-Cola, who sells 70 percent of the soft drinks sold here in Japan, and find out what bad things they say about Japan. Go talk to Du Pont and ask what their complaints are. Schick sells 70 percent of the razors sold in the country. Do they bad-mouth the Japanese?,'' he said in an interview. Totten arrived in 1969 as the representative for a U.S. software company. But after its headquarters rebuffed his attempts to sell packaged software to the Japanese, he quit and started his own firm with two Japanese partners in 1972. Totten says he never studied much about doing business with the Japanese. But he has sweated to make all his products usable in the Japanese language and adapted them to Japanese tastes. The 6-foot-4 American puts in 12 hours at work most days and calls on hundreds of customers a year. Last fall, Totten's firm plunged into the market for personal computer software with five packages at $60 each, a fraction of the cost of competing brands. More than 160,000 packages have been sold, and all five types are on the best-seller lists. Totten, who so far has been mainly distributing American-made software after adapting it for the Japanese market, says he fears that the U.S. software industry may be beginning to lose its edge. Ashisuto revenues' dependence on imports from the United States fell from 99 percent in 1988 to 95 percent last year, and is expected to decline to 80 percent this year, he says. Totten says American firms have refused to spend time adapting or marketing their products in Japan, and are getting pushed out by a new generation of high-quality Japanese products. U.S. and Japanese government negotiators have been busy in recent months in talks on opening Japan's market wider to American supercomputers, satellites and forest products, and on changing deep-seated business practices. Japan has promised, among other things, to make it easier to open large stores in Japan, spend more on public works, pressure corporate groups to reduce the emphasis on personal ties in making purchasing decisions, and try to solve soaring land costs. To Totten, however, such trade frictions only reflect ``two silly governments fighting with each other.'' He says private citizens should become involved before the two countries are at each others' throats. ``I consider both countries my country. I love the United States and I love Japan,'' he says. On one hand, he adds, ``I would not want to see the U.S. lose its software industry out of ignorance or silly mistakes, and I'm trying to talk to my friends in the industry that we've got to correct things.'' On the other, ``I have two children who speak only Japanese. I want the Japanese economy to remain a healthy economy for my children.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Wednesday PMs April 25

DOC.HEAD: Austrians Keep Non-Communist Hammer and Sickle
DOC.TEXT: Communist symbols are vanishing from Eastern Europe, but Austria is keeping its hammer and sickle, which had nothing to do with communism in the first place. Because neighboring nations in what used to be called the Soviet bloc have been stripping wheat sheaves, red stars and other Communist symbols from their coats of arms, the question also arose in Austria. In 1919, Austrian legislators met in Vienna to create a republic from the ruins of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. They adopted a coat of arms in which the Austrian eagle expressed commitment to the common man by holding a hammer, for workers, and a sickle, for farmers, in its claws. In 1945, Parliament voted to add broken shackles dangling from the eagle's legs, symbolize release from Nazi domination. The debate about what to do now has been spirited, both in Parliament and outside. Popular sentiment appears to be against removing the implements from the eagle's claws. Of 24 letters from readers printed by the mass-circulation tabloid Kurier in March, only five were in favor. Josef Riegler, one of the five, said: ``Even during my first visits abroad after World War II ... I was often asked whether the Soviet occupiers had forced us to include the hammer and sickle in our state emblem. I heard similar questions later from visitors to Vienna.'' Some of those opposed to change expressed anger at what they considered an attempt by politicans to magnify a small issue. Others, like Brigitte Michalko, were defiant. ``Those who considered us Communists up to now because of our coat of arms can continue to do so as far as I care,'' she wrote. The broken chains added in 1945 added to the existing confusion. Some saw them as an echo of the Communist Manifesto, which exhorts the proletariat to rise because ``you have nothing to lose but your chains.'' In February, the right-leaning Freedom Party began efforts in Parliament to discard, at least, the hammer and sickle. They are ``symbols for contempt of humanity, death camps and suppression,'' the party's resolution declared. If they remained on the national emblem, it said, Austria would be the only non-communist country in Europe ``whose state symbol symbolizes communism.'' Although the measure received wide publicity, it initially was considered more symbolic than serious. The Freedom Party has only 18 members in the 183-seat chamber and few people thought the motion would receive the necessary two-thirds vote. The issue gained extra weight when a group of legislators from the Austrian People's Party, partner with the Socialists in the governing coalition, presented a similar motion. Sides were taken. The People's Party split on the issue and the Socialists opposed any change. Felix Ermacora, a sponsor of the People's Party motion, said in an interview that changing the emblem ``could avoid misunderstandings abroad.'' ``There is the occasional misconception when people look at our coat of arms on our passports, for instance, and see the hammer and sickle,'' he said. People's Party spokesman Anton Wressnig said the action by Ermacora's group was independent. Changing the emblem is ``not an official concern'' of the party, he said in a telephone interview, and described the issue as ``relatively unimportant.'' Heinz Fischer, a senior Socialist Party official, said: ``If we didn't change it in 1956 and 1968, there is no no need to do it now.'' Soviet invasions crushed an ant-Stalinist uprising in Hungary in 1956 and a reform movement in Czechoslovakia in 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Three Major African Nations Committed to One-Party Rule
DOC.TEXT: The tide of democracy sweeping Eastern Europe is being felt in black Africa, but one-party rule still predominates and three of the major states have publicly committed themselves to it. Tanzania has had only one party for 26 years and said this month the policy will not change. Kenya did the same and Zimbabwe's leader, Robert Mugabe, declared his intention to install one-party rule. ``If we have many political parties, we will have chaos as different tribes rush to form theirs,'' President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya told trainee teachers at Laikipia in central Kenya. ``Tribal inclinations and consciousness is still paramount in the minds of many Kenyans.'' ``For now, I say no to the multiparty system, at least until we are cohesive enough as a nation,'' he said. Kenya has 40 tribes in a population of 22 million. Ethnic feuding is common in Parliament, at public rallies and in the press. Moi, a 66-year-old a former teacher from the minority Kalenjin tribe, inherited the one-party system in 1978 from the late President Jomo Kenyatta, the nation's founder. Kenyatta had banned opposition parties nine years earlier. Kenyatta created a de facto one-party state by locking up his political opponents. Moi made it constitutional in 1982. The president's statement was his first on the subject since some other African states began considering more liberalized political systems this year. He spoke after weeks of debate in Nairobi newspapers about whether Kenya should restore the style of democracy bequeathed to Kenyatta when he led the former British colony to independence in 1963. Writers supporting the status quo argued that Kenya had prospered under the current system, without tribal strife. They said a return to the old order might cause ethnic violence and drive away tourists and investors. Those who wanted change said Kenyans were politically mature enough for competition, that recent reforms in eastern Europe should be used as an example and that a parliamentary opposition would help check official corruption, mismanagement and nepotism. Neighboring Tanzania, a nation of 100 tribes, also was a British colony until independence in 1961 under Julius Nyerere. Unlike its wealthy capitalist cousin, Tanzania followed socialism based on Eastern European models. Both Nyerere and Ali Hassan Mwinyi, who succeeded him as president in 1985, have admitted the policies were flawed. Mwinyi, 65, has adopted radical economic reforms prescribed by Western lenders, but has rejected suggestions that they be accompanied by political change. ``While a multiparty system would be suitable for Europeans, it might not be the same with Tanzania,'' Mwinyi told reporters in Dar es Salaam. ``What Africans want is a fair return for their sweat through a new international economic order. ... This cannot be solved by the creation of 100 parties, which can bring chaos instead of progress.'' He said Tanzanians had voted consistently for a single party as a way to guarantee national unity. He did not mention a statement Nyerere made in February that multiparty democracy now may be possible. Nyerere, still chairman of the ruling Chama Cha Mapinduzi Party, remains a powerful political figure five years after he resigned as president. Only a few of the 50 member nations of the Organization of African Unity have Western-style democracies. Zimbabwe is one, but President Robert Mugabe declared after an overwhelming victory in recent national elections that he will transform the former British colony of Rhodesia into a one-party state. Mugabe, who led Zimbabwe to independence 10 years ago, said the elections were a mandate from the 4.8 million registered voters to get rid of the opposition. His opponents accused Mugabe, 66, of seeking a dictatorship. They noted that only 54 percent of the electorate voted and opposition parties got 20 percent of the votes, although they won only three of the 150 Parliament seats. President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire said this week he would lift a 20-year-old ban on opposition parties and his Popular Movement for the Revolution, since 1970 the only official party, no longer would have special status. He said the constitution of the former Belgian colony would be rewritten and an interim government would be installed by April 24, 1991, to prepare for elections. Benin, a former French colony, is pledged to eliminate one-party rule, Gabon is debating the question and there is pressure in the Ivory Coast for a freer political order. Cameroon and Niger, scenes of recent political upheavals, have rejected multiparty politics. Significant signals of change are coming from unlikely quarters. Ethiopia and Mozambique have abandoned their hardline Marxist ideologies, and the Marxist leaders of Angola have committed themselves to peace talks with U.S.-backed guerrillas that, if fruitful, could lead to open elections.
