DOC.HEAD: Adv for Weekend Editions, April 28-29

DOC.TEXT: Frustrated by U.S. regulatory delays, Sir James Goldsmith's Hoylake Investments Ltd. ended its acrimonious nine-month takeover battle for the British conglomerate BAT Industries PLC. The decision announced Monday marks a major defeat for Goldsmith, whose group's $22 billion all-securities offer for BAT would have been the world's second-largest takeover after the $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc. last year. BAT, whose U.S. companies include the Saks Fifth Avenue department stores, has been restructuring by selling its retailing and paper businesses to concentrate on tobacco and financial services.

Michael Milken won't face government questioning until after he is sentenced for securities felonies, but experts said they expect the financier's role in the multibillion-dollar thrift crisis to be a hot topic. A hearing was set for today before U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood at which Milken was expected to plead guilty to six criminal counts and promise to pay $600 million to settle the biggest financial fraud case in history. Milken agreed to the plea deal Friday after more than three years at the center of a highly publicized and contentious assault on Wall Street crime that began in 1986.

A new program to attract business travelers and restore a dialogue with union leaders are among the early steps in an arduous journey back from bankruptcy protection for Eastern Airlines, the court-appointed trustee said. ``I believe Eastern can achieve a financial turnaround,'' Martin Shugrue, who was appointed last week by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland to take control of the Miami-based carrier, said Monday. But Shugrue declined to give a timetable for a financial reorganization plan or a labor agreement with pilots or striking Machinists.

Thirteen months later and 3,200 miles away, the Valdez oil spill again will wash over the nation's largest oil company Wednesday as shareholders consider six environmental proposals seeking to make Exxon Corp. more ecologically responsive. Management opposes all six proposals, which range from requiring Exxon to report annually on its environmental performance to promising to eliminate or reduce carbon dioxide or toxic chemical emissions.

Oil giant Exxon Corp. reported that its net income declined 29.3 percent in the first quarter due to an accounting change, while fifth-ranked Amoco Corp. said its profit edged up 1.7 percent. Meanwhile Monday, Ashland Oil Inc. posted net income of $1 million for the second quarter of its fiscal year, compared with a $14 million loss a year earlier. Amerada Hess Corp. said its first-quarter profit plummeted 82 percent. For the three months ended March 31, Exxon's profit fell to $1.28 billion, or $1.01 a share, from $1.81 billion, or $1.41 a share, in the first quarter of 1989.

American Express Co. Chairman James D. Robinson III told shareholders the company's troubled Wall Street subsidiary Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. was ``well positioned'' to return to profitability. Shearson last week reported a $915 million first-quarter loss _ the largest in securities industry history _ in large part to pay for 2,000 layoffs and business cuts initiated by American Express. American Express lost $620 million in the first three months of 1990 because of the troubles at Shearson. ``It's the price we paid to put Shearson's major problems behind us,'' Robinson told shareholders at American Express' annual meeting Monday.

General Motors Corp. said it plans to close a Pontiac, Mich., truck plant in 1993, moving production to New Jersey and potentially putting 2,300 people out of work. GM said Monday it planned in late 1992 to move assembly of newly redesigned two-and four-door S-trucks, now called Chevrolet Blazer and GMC Jimmy, from the Pontiac West plant to the Linden, N.J., plant, which makes its popular Chevrolet Corsica and Beretta cars. The automaker is shifting production because the 1.8 million-square-foot Pontiac West plant does not have enough assembly space to keep up with anticipated demand for four-door models, a GM spokeswoman said.

West Germany agreed to give East Germans a bigger share of Western wealth as their struggling nation is merged with its rich neighbor. In a surprising concession, West Germany said Monday it would exchange each virtually worthless East German mark paid to workers and pensioners for one strong West German mark. The 1-1 rate would apply to wages and pensions and to savings accounts of up to 4,000 marks, or around $2,300, said a spokesman for West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

Government food scientists looking for a healthier way to satisfy forbidden cravings said they have created the ultimate in guilt-free desserts _ oat bran ice cream. Actually, calling it ice cream is stretching it a bit, for it has none of the fat-filled cream that is an essential ingredient of the real thing. Instead, it gets its creamy consistency from a tasteless, fat-like gel that's made entirely from oats. Its principal creator, George E. Inglett, calls this secret ingredient Oatrim. He said it could take the place of fat in many cold foods.

The stock market declined broadly for the fourth straight session Monday, extending a losing streak blamed largely on interest-rate worries. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 29.28 points to 2,666.67. Bond prices slipped, pushing interest rates higher. The dollar strengthened against most major currencies. Gold prices were mixed. Prices of most pork belly futures contracts surged the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound; hog futures rallied while cattle futures were mixed; orange juice futures fell sharply; oil futures rose; cotton was up; precious metals were mixed; and grain and soybean futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Rates Rise
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities rose at the latest auction to their highest level in several weeks. The Treasury Department sold $8.2 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.78 percent on Monday, up from 7.71 percent last week. Another $8.2 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.91 percent, up from 7.75 percent last week. The rates were the highest since three-month bills sold for 7.80 percent on April 9, and six-month bills averaged 7.92 percent on March 19. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 8.05 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,803.30 and 8.35 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,600.10. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, rose to 8.41 percent last week, up from 8.29 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Plea Expected; No Cooperation Until After Sentencing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Court proceedings set to begin 11:30 a.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Michael Milken's plea bargain resolves his securities fraud charges, but it remains unclear to what extent the junk bond pioneer will have to help federal investigators uncover other white-collar crime. Milken heads to court today for a proceeding at which he is expected to plead guilty to six criminal counts and agree to pay $600 million to settle the biggest financial fraud case ever brought against an individual. The former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. executive approved the plea deal Friday after more than three years at the center of a highly publicized and contentious assault on Wall Street crime that began in 1986. Milken, 43, had staunchly maintained his innocence, but reversed course in the face of a threatened new government indictment replacing the 98 fraud and racketeering counts brought in March 1989. Sources have said the plea includes no insider trading or racketeering charges. In an arrangement unusual for a major figure in the Wall Street fraud crackdown, Milken will not be required to provide investigators with information to build cases against other figures as part of the plea bargain, sources said. Rather, he will be questioned by federal officials after sentencing, an individual familiar with the deal confirmed Monday. That arrangement would reduce the government's leverage by making it impossible for prosecutors to recommend a stiffer prison term if Milken does not cooperate. However, the government still could control his prison conditions or parole date if investigators were unsatisifed with his help. If he refused to testify under immunity before a grand jury, Milken could face contempt charges. While the nature of Milken's future cooperation remains unclear, observers said the government was likely to seek details about extensive and possibly unlawful links with the nation's savings and loans. Milken controlled a complex network of thrifts and corporate clients that bought and sold each other's bonds, financed deals and made investments together. Thrifts were among Drexel's largest junk bond customers. The Securities and Exchange Commission, the House Banking Committee and the Resolution Trust Corp., which is charged with rescuing the nation's thrifts, are examining savings and loan failures expected to cost taxpayers hundreds of billions. SEC Enforcement Director William McLucas declined to comment on the reported Milken settlement. He did say the commission has formed a unit on thrift and banking that is examining compliance with securities laws. Asked what area Milken is most likely to be questioned about, John C. Coffee Jr., a securities law professor at Columbia University, said, ``I think it would chiefly be the savings and loan people because the government would love to get the S&Ls.'' The government isn't likely to get much useful information because of the terms of the deal, Coffee said. He suggested the government may have agreed to the ``cosmetic cooperation'' in order to obtain the plea and save face following a series of light sentences in related Wall Street cases. Milken is expected to receive about five years in prison, although he faces up to 28 years. ``I think the government wants to offset these rather equivocal Pyrrhic victories with a final round that shows this was a true crime,'' Coffee said. He said the government may have been willing to trade away Milken's assistance in nabbing other Drexel and Wall Street figures in exchange for his guilty plea because ``they're Rosencrantz and Guildenstern off in the wings and he's Hamlet.'' The plea deal leaves unresolved charges against former Drexel trader Bruce Newberg, who was named in the original 98-count indictment, and cases against individuals who were expected to be named in a new indictment.

DOC.HEAD: Valdez Spill On Minds Of Exxon Shareholders
DOC.TEXT: The Valdez oil spill returns to haunt Exxon Corp. Wednesday when shareholders vote on a six resolutions calling for America's largest oil company to be more sensitive to the environment. The company _ whose public image has been blackened by the Alaskan spill and numerous other accidents in the last year _ opposes all the proposals, saying it already has taken steps to increase awareness and responsiveness. Not so, said Anne Chapman, a shareholder in Denver who wants the company to report annually on its environmental performance. ``I don't think they've learned much at all, and I hope that at the shareholders meeting that it will come home to them that there are people who really care,'' Mrs. Chapman said from her home in Denver. Wednesday's meeting in Houston is the first chance shareholders have had to present Valdez-related proposals, although the spill dominated last year's four-hour meeting attended by some 2,000 shareholders and another 250 demonstrators outside. That meeting was held less than one month after the Exxon Valdez ran aground in Prince William Sound, spilling 11 million gallons of crude in the nation's worst oil spill. Altruism isn't the only factor motivating the shareholder proposals. Reducing toxic chemical emissions ``is in the best interests of Exxon management and Exxon shareholders ... not only from an environmental and community relations standpoint, but from the financial and legal liability that toxic and pollution-related incidents could bring to the company and its shareholders,'' says one proposal. Another resolution calls on Exxon to create an environmental affairs committee of directors to show the company's high-level concern in hopes of reducing any corporate liability. Other proposals would have Exxon: _Hold to its pledge to clean up Prince William Sound and ``show real leadership'' in dealing with the damage. _Follow the Valdez Principles, established by a coalition of institutional investors, setting out corporate environmental goals and policies. _Reduce carbon dioxide emissions. Exxon rejects the resolutions as duplicative and unnecessary. ``The corporation's longstanding policy is to adhere to all environmental, health and safety laws and regulations that are applicable to its business,'' Exxon says in its proxy statement. There also are four proposals involving shareholders' rights or doing business in South Africa or Northern Ireland. ``Generally, I would like them to be responsible for their actions and to know there are shareholders who care more about integrity and responsibility than total profit,'' said Mrs. Chapman, who wants Exxon to report annually on all measurable hazardous emissions and include a hazardous risk assessment. ``Profit is important, but it is not the be-all and end-all,'' she said. Most of the proposals come from individuals. However, state pension funds from California, Massachusetts and New York City recently sought assurances from Exxon that company would protect its earnings by taking steps to prevent another disaster like the Valdez spill. The funds' holdings account for slightly more than 1 percent of Exxon's outstanding shares. The company on Monday said net earnings for the first three months of this year fell 29.3 percent to $1.81 billion, or $1.41 a share. The decline reflected a big, one-time gain from an accounting change in the first quarter of 1989. Revenues rose 20.3 percent to $26.7 billion from $22.2 billion. Exxon's profit dropped 34 percent to $3.5 billion for all of 1989 because of the $2 billion it spent on the Valdez spill. Some environmentalists have accused Exxon of meeting in Houston in search of friendly ground and hoping to avoid some of last year's demonstrators. Exxon officials deny that, pointing out that Exxon's domestic subsidiary is based in Houston and the city is home to many employees and shareholders. Previous meetings in Houston drew 1,300 in 1986 and about 1,200 in 1981. Criticism of Exxon has continued since last year's meeting, especially after the company cut back cleanup efforts during the winter. Exxon also has been indicted on two felony charges and three misdemeanors stemming from the Valdez spill; has further blackened its image through numerous smaller spills and other accidents, including a refinery explosion; announced it was moving its headquarters from New York City to a Dallas suburb; and been the focus of numerous media reports of low morale in the executive suite.

DOC.HEAD: Head of President's Economic Advisers Predicts Easing Interest Rates
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's chief economic adviser says a ``peace dividend'' will help automakers and other manufacturers meet the high costs of clean-air legislation, although they won't see the money directly. Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said the administration is trying to quash some proposed clean-air requirements, such as a severe clampdown on auto tailpipe emissions, that it thinks would hurt the economy more than clear the air. Even so, he said, costs of pending clean-air legislation will top $20 billion a year nationally. ``There will be job losses because of this bill, and there will be some economic dislocation,'' Boskin said Monday in an address to the Economic Club of Detroit. But the economy as a whole will be healthy, he predicted. ``While we're keeping a wary eye on inflation to make sure we don't let the genie out of the bottle, we do believe ... inflation will abate as we move forward in the next several months,'' Boskin said. ``We also believe that over the course of the year, it is likely that interest rates will abate.'' Interest rates would have eased sooner except for the dramatic changes in Eastern Europe and demand for capital to rebuild the former communist bloc countries, Boskin said. The relaxing of political tension has let the administration budget for a reduction in military spending of 2 percent a year, or a total of 10 percent over the next five years, Boskin said. The top priority for those funds will be cutting the federal deficit, he said. The administration considers that the best way, in the long run, to help automakers and other manufacturers faced with big spending to meet pollution controls and improve productivity, he said. ``It's a lot easier to do that if interest rates and the cost of capital are down,'' Boskin said. ``A substantial reduction in the budget deficit will help accomplish that _ make it much more affordable for American industry to retool and upgrade and enhance its productivity.''

DOC.HEAD: United Flexes Political Muscle in Fight for Japan Route
DOC.TEXT: United Airlines is counting on a well-known Chicago commodity _ political clout _ to help it fend off arch-rival American Airlines in a battle for non-stop jet service from Chicago to Tokyo. The U.S. Department of Transportation is scheduled to start hearings today to pick six new U.S.-to-Japan air routes. On Monday, United boasted that its bid was supported by five state governors, two state congressional delegations and the Nebraska Legislature _ all in the interest of better service for their constituents. American countered that endorsements from politicians should not be important. The Dallas-based carrier says it should be awarded the route to preserve and nurture competition in the airline industry. The contested route is between Washington's Dulles International Airport and Tokyo, with a stop at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport. United said in a statement that its supporters had written to John J. Mathias, a Transportation Department administrative law judge. Mathias will conduct hearings expected to result by Oct. 1 in the selection of six new U.S. ``gateways'' for non-stop flights to Japan. A gateway is a departure point for a non-stop flight. Chicago would be the U.S. gateway for the contested flight. American has applied for a total of six different routes linking U.S. and Japanese cities, said Barry Clark, manager of American's international route strategy. United spokesman Joe Hopkins said United is concentrating on only one route. The tussle amounts to an all-out effort by the hometown carrier to block American, which recently pulled ahead of United as the nation's biggest airline. ``We're putting all of our efforts into this one,'' Hopkins said. United is based near Chicago in Elk Grove Village. American, a subsidiary of Dallas-based AMR Corp., exceeded United in sales and market share last year to become the biggest U.S. carrier. American has made O'Hare the hub for its extensive European connections. And the airline has been advertising aggressively here in the past year, trying to make a splash while the management of United was caught up in a battle for control of the carrier's parent, UAL Corp. UAL's board recently agreed to sell the company to its employees for about $4.4 billion. Financing for the sale hasn't been arranged yet, though. United already is the leading trans-Pacific carrier among U.S. airlines, which Clark cited as a good reason for the government to award the Chicago-Tokyo route to American. ``In a situation like this,'' Clark said, ``the DOT should be looking for the maximum increase in competition ... which does not, in our view, support giving additional route authority in Japan to the carrier that is already the biggest carrier between the United States and the Far East.'' As for United's political connections, ``we obviously hope it's not that terribly important,'' Clark said. Northwest Airlines and Japan Air Lines already fly between Chicago and Tokyo, the airline officials said. The proposed route would add another carrier and a Washington connection. Supporting United are Illinois Gov. James R. Thompson, Indiana Gov. Evan Bayh, Kentucky Gov. Wallace G. Wilkinson, Nebraska Gov. Kay A. Orr and Virginia Gov. L. Douglas Wilder. Other politicians backing United's bid include Chicago Mayor Richard M. Daley, the 24-member Illinois congressional delegation, Indianapolis Mayor William H. Hudnut III, the Nebraska Legislature and the 12-member Virginia congressional delegation.

DOC.HEAD: Trustee Predicts Financial Turnaround at Eastern
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Martin Shugrue jokes that he packed a magical Irish shillelagh to help him conjure profits from Eastern Airlines. He also brought a wealth of experience and a large dose of optimism as he began working toward the goal of bringing Eastern out of bankruptcy protection. He may need both wits and wizardry to turn around Eastern's chronic losses and embittered labor relations in the wake of a strike by unions that nearly grounded the carrier last year. ``I believe Eastern can achieve a financial turnaround,'' Shugrue, who was appointed last week by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland to take control of the Miami-based carrier, said Monday. ``The bedrock upon which a viable and profitable company can be built is already in place here.'' Shugrue would not dismiss the possibility that Eastern might be sold eventually. ``The immediate objective is to restore this airline to viability. From there, you obviously investigate other alternatives,'' he said, adding that several parties have already made initial inquiries about the carrier. But he added, ``I did not come here to liquidate this airline.'' The man who replaced Texas Air Corp. Chairman Frank Lorenzo at Eastern's helm previously served as president of Eastern's sister Continental Airlines, a post he resigned under pressure in February 1989. Shugrue _ described as holding ``the hottest seat in corporate America'' by one Eastern official _ declined to give a timetable for a reorganization plan or a labor agreement with pilots or striking Machinists. He urged quick government approval of the proposed sale of Eastern's Latin American routes to American Airlines. But he said he would review all other agreements, including those involving computer reservation systems and a $285 million asset transfer settlement recently agreed to by Texas Air. Eastern's chief labor negotiator Thomas Matthews resigned on Saturday and will be replaced by Alan C. Gibson, a 25-year Eastern employee, Shugrue announced. The resignation of Eastern President Phil Bakes was announced on Friday. ``I don't expect any other imminent changes,'' said Shugrue. Talks have begun with Machinists union leaders, who have expressed a desire for a quick back-to-work settlement. But Shugrue admitted that integrating strikers into the 18,000-employee work force may be impossible at current operation levels. Eastern has signed a back-to-work pact with flight attendants and is negotiating with the Air Line Pilots Association. Both unions ended their sympathy walkouts in November. Eastern filed for Chapter 11 protection five days after the strike began March 4, 1989. Eastern spokesman Robin Matell said a new promotion aimed at business travelers should begin at the end of the month. Eastern, which expects to lose $330 million this year, has been operating between 65 percent and 70 percent capacity on its flights. Shugrue said he forsees Eastern remaining close to its present size and retaining its Atlanta hub. Any relocation of company headquarters from Miami to Atlanta is ``a low-priority concern at this time,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: GM Truck Plant in Pontiac Closing in 1993
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers union says General Motors Corp.'s plans to close a Michigan truck plant and move its products to a New Jersey plant now making cars is a ``game of musical chairs.'' GM said Monday it would close its Pontiac West truck plant in 1993, threatening the jobs of the plant's 2,300 workers. UAW officials said they would work to find a vehicle for the plant north of Detroit to keep its employees on the job. ``It's hard to see how greater efficiency and high worker morale can result from GM's continuing game of musical chairs with the lives of our members and their families,'' said Stephen P. Yokich, vice president in charge of the UAW's GM Department. The giant automaker said it was moving production of its S-trucks, called Chevrolet Blazer and GMC Jimmy sport-utility vehicles, to its Linden, N.J., plant. GM's most popular car, the Chevrolet two-door Corsica and four-door Beretta _ now are made there. Corsica and Beretta production will be consolidated at Wilmington, Del., where they also are assembled now. Some tooling will be added later to GM's car plant in Lansing to enable it to make one of the two cars, GM spokeswoman Kari Hulsey said. Corsica and Beretta sales are third behind the Honda Accord and Ford Taurus through March 31 of this year. The Linden plant will be shut down for about six months to retool for a redesigned S-truck. Hulsey said she didn't know if the Blazer and Jimmy names would be retained. Hulsey said the Linden plant has about 2.5 million square feet of assembly space and the Pontiac factory had about 1.8 million. Auto industry observers have speculated that although sport-utility sales are running flat this year, the market segment will grow as the number of four-door versions of the vehicles increases. Pontiac West will continue operating as usual while the Linden plant, along with GM's Moraine, Ohio, and Shreveport, La., plants, are prepared for production of the redesigned truck, she said. Moraine and Shreveport now make S-trucks. The cost of renovating the plants for the new truck was not available, Hulsey said. Employment at the Linden plant was recently cut in half by the elimination of one of two shifts, leaving it with about 1,800 hourly and 300 salaried employees, Hulsey said. When truck production reaches full steam in Linden, Hulsey said, GM plans to return to two shifts with a total of about 2,500 hourly workers. Guy Messina, shop chairman of UAW Local 595 in Linden, praised the announcement of increased employment. ``We have produced employment and security for our members and that's what it's all about,'' he said. When the shift is complete, it will leave the city of Pontiac with one plant making full-size pickups. As recently as 1987, GM operated four assembly plants making three kinds of trucks and a car in Pontiac, about 25 miles north of Detroit. Pontiac Mayor Wallace Holland was in meetings and was unavailable for comment, said a woman who answered his office phone. The current contract between GM and the UAW allows the shuttering of a plant only when sales of its products slump. But the Pontiac West plant will close after the current agreement expires Sept. 14, so it doesn't fall under the restriction. Since 1987, when the current GM-UAW contract became effective, the automaker has closed or announced plans to close five plants in as many states, putting more than 14,000 people out of work. Chrysler Corp. closed a plant in Detroit in February and plans to close one in Missouri later this year, affecting about 5,600 workers. Ford Motor Co. has closed no plants during the current UAW contract.

DOC.HEAD: Reebok Investor, 13, to Get Special Treatment at Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Reebok stockholder Graham Dixon had to get permission from his mother and an excused absence from school before he could travel to Los Angeles for the company's annual meeting today. At 13, Graham may be Reebok International Ltd.'s youngest stockholder, having invested $500 in February for 30 shares of the athletic-shoe company's stock. The seventh-grader will attend company board meetings and sit with executives on the stage during his first stockholders meeting. Graham earned the money to buy the stock by making and peddling souvenir-style buttons with his 18-year-old brother, Jonathan. He also took other odd jobs. ``I had the money in a savings account, but I wanted to do something with it _ invest in something,'' Graham said. After meeting with a stockbroker and reviewing various stocks, Graham chose Reebok ``because it's a good, solid company ... and anyway, I do like their shoes.'' Graham said he already has received one dividend check _ for $2.25. ``We framed that one,'' said his mother, Jane Dixon. ``But when the checks start getting bigger, we'll cash them.'' Mrs. Dixon was hesitant about letting her son make the trip to Los Angeles. ``I asked my mom if I could go,'' Graham said, ``but she told me, `No way _ that meeting's in California. And besides, you'll be on the back row.''' When Graham persisted, his mother decided to call Reebok's chief executive officer, Paul Fireman. ``The company did some checking,'' Mrs. Dixon said, ``and found out that Graham was the youngest stockholder. So, Mr. Fireman was really interested in seeing him come to the meeting as the company's special guest.'' Pat Christopher, an assistant in Reebok's corporate communications office, said Monday she could not confirm whether Graham is indeed the company's youngest stockholder. Graham was scheduled to travel to Los Angeles alone. An investor, after all, can't be taken seriously if he has his mother in tow. ``He's shy anyway because pimples and braces are his biggest worry,'' Mrs. Dixon said of her son. ``He certainly didn't need me tagging along.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Pennzoil Judge Paid $25,000 By Law Firm Before Texaco Appointment
DOC.TEXT: A Texaco attorney says he would have challenged the qualifications of a judge that approved an $11 billion judgment against Texaco if he'd known the judge had worked for the opponent a few months earlier. Texas Lawyer, a legal trade publication, reported Monday that retired state district judge Solomon Casseb Jr. was paid $25,000 by one of Pennzoil Co.'s law firms for work on a case unrelated to the 1985 fight between Pennzoil and Texaco Inc. The payment, which Casseb received while working in a private practice, was not disclosed to either side during the trial. Casseb awarded Pennzoil $11.1 billion. During an appeal, Texaco and Pennzoil later settled the case out of court for $3 billion. Legal experts quoted by Texas Lawyer said the payment to Casseb should have been disclosed, although it did not violate ethical canons. ``Surely there must be a judge who could be appointed to complete this case who had not just finished a very substantial relationship with one of the lead counsel on the other side,'' Texaco attorney Richard Miller said Monday by telephone from his Houston office. William Barnett, managing partner for Pennzoil's law firm, Baker & Botts, told The Associated Press none of the attorneys working on the case were aware of the payment. Barnett said the payment on Feb. 14, 1985 was made on behalf of a client in another case. ``There's no way anyone could have forecast'' Casseb would be appointed to the Texaco-Pennzoil case, Barnett said from Houston. Casseb, a retired judge and attorney in San Antonio, did not grant an interview to Texas Lawyer and did not return telephone calls from The Associated Press. Pennzoil sued Texaco in 1984, claiming it illegally interfered in a planned merger between Pennzoil and Getty Oil Co. when Texaco itself acquired Getty. Eight weeks into the trial, Judge Anthony J.P. Harris stepped down citing poor health. On Oct. 22, 1985, administrative Judge Thomas Stovall appointed Casseb to take over the case. Casseb had served as a judge until 1968, when he returned to private practice. Texas Lawyer said he qualified as a retired judge, agreeing to sit as a visiting judge anywhere in Texas, in May 1985. In November 1985, a jury awarded Pennzoil $10.53 billion, and Casseb approved the verdict. With interest, the total judgment was $11.1 billion. An appeals court later reduced the punitive damages and in 1987, when Texaco lost attempts to avoid posting $10 billion bond, the company filed for federal bankruptcy court protection. In December 1987, Texaco and Pennzoil agreed to settle the case for $3 billion.

DOC.HEAD: BAT Presses Ahead with Efforts to Boost Share Price
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, The shares ..., with one graf to UPDATE with midday stock price. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `It's obviously ...
DOC.TEXT: BAT Industries PLC says it will press ahead with its massive asset sales program even though Sir James Goldsmith has dropped his hostile $22 billion takeover bid for the British conglomerate. BAT drew up the restructuring plan hoping to boost its stock price and fight off the Anglo-French financier's all-paper bid of 878 pence a share, or the equivalent of $14.31. The plan calls for BAT to sell its retailing and paper businesses _ including Saks Fifth Avenue and the just-sold Marshall Field's _ in order to concentrate on tobacco and financial services. It also includes the repurchase by the company of up to 10 percent of its stock. Goldsmith's withdrawal, announced after the stock market closed Monday and blamed on regulatory frustrations involving BAT's U.S. insurance subsidiary, was expected to depress BAT's share price. The shares fell 24 pence, or around 39 cents, to 700 pence, or $11.41 on London's Stock Exchange at midday today. The news of the withdrawal came after Monday's close. ``It's obviously going to be a little bit unsettled in the short-term,'' said Jack Jones, an analyst with the brokerage UBS Philips and Drew. But Kishore Bangor, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities in London, said investors would turn their attention to BAT's fundamentals and the stock would look relatively cheap. The offer by Goldsmith's Hoylake Investments Ltd. would have been the world's second-largest takeover after Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co.'s $25 billion purchase of RJR Nabisco Inc., completed early last year. Hoylake launched the offer in July, then suspended it in September while it sought regulatory approval. Two weeks ago, California's insurance regulators decided to bar a change of control of BAT's Farmers Insurance Group Inc. of Los Angeles. The offer needed approval from the commissioners of a total of nine states where Farmers operates. Hoylake abandoned its bid because of delays caused by the U.S. regulatory process, said a London source close to the company. ``We have always felt we could achieve a favorable position but it could take quite a while,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``We didn't feel it was in the best interests of the shareholders given the uncertainties.'' Hoylake had planned to sell Farmers for $4.5 billion to the French insurance group Axa-Midi Assurances. Axa-Midi announced in Paris Monday that it has dropped its bid. BAT Chairman Patrick Sheehy welcomed Hoylake's withdrawal in a statement. ``Shareholders gave overwhelming support to our reshaping proposals last October,'' he said, referring to a shareholder vote backing the restructuring plan. ``Today's overdue decision by Hoylake does not alter our resolve to see that program through to its completion and to continue to maximize value for our shareholders.'' Last week, BAT announced the sale of its U.S. retailer Marshall Field's to Dayton Hudson Corp. for $1.04 billion. The company also has put Saks Fifth Avenue on the auction block. Goldsmith and other shareholders have complained that BAT's stock price does not reflect its value because it is dragged down by the slower growth of the tobacco businesses, which include Brown & Williamson in the United States. Goldsmith and his Hoylake partners, who included British merchant banker Jacob Rothschild and Australian businessman Kerry Packer, had wanted to ``unbundle'' BAT by selling off all its non-tobacco operations. In its statement Monday Hoylake said, ``The directors of Hoylake wish BAT and its unbundled offspring great success within their new structures.''

DOC.HEAD: Toyota to Produce Cars in Pakistan
DOC.TEXT: Toyota Motor Corp., Japan's largest automaker, said Tuesday it will build an automobile manufacturing plant in Pakistan by early 1993. Toyota spokesman Yoshiharu Tateishi said the plant will be capable of producing 20,000 cars annually. He said about 3,000 Corollas would be produced in the initial year, with production increasing later to 10,000 a year. Toyota may also add commercial vehicles later, Tateishi said. Toyota will join with local interests and invest around $66.5 million for the plant, which will be built in Port Qasim, about 25 miles east of Karachi.

DOC.HEAD: BNP To Buy Banking Arm Banque Nagelmackers 1747 SA
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Banque Nagelmackers 1747 is cq
DOC.TEXT: Banque Nationale de Paris, France's largest commercial bank, has agreed to buy the banking assets of Banque Nagelmackers 1747 SA, Belgium's oldest bank, for $123 million, it was announced Tuesday. Nagelmackers said it would propose to a shareholders meeting splitting its assets into two entities, a banking company and a real estate and portfolio investment company.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Lets Suit Continue
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. must continue to defend a nationwide suit by some owners seeking damages for defects in diesel engines after their warranties expired, the U.S. Supreme Court decided. The court refused Monday to review a 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruling that consumers can be protected beyond time limits set by the manufacturer by an ``implied warranty'' that a product is fit for its ordinary purpose. GM lawyers charged that the lower court's August 1989 ruling ``will have intolerable consequences for manufacturers of consumer products throughout the United States.'' GM and the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association said the ruling could trigger a wave of lawsuits by ``anyone who suffered repair costs at any time,'' and could extend to all consumer transactions. Lawyers for consumers said GM's arguments were exaggerated. The Supreme Court let stand the appeals court's ruling that GM must defend against a suit by 600,000 owners of 1981-85 cars and trucks with 5.7-liter diesel engines who made claims for defects after their warranties expired. GM's warranties covered the engines for two years or 24,000 miles for 1981-82 models and three years or 50,000 miles for 1983-85 models. Lawyers for the vehicle owners charge GM knew but didn't disclose that its diesel engines would fail prematurely.

DOC.HEAD: Employment Costs Jumped 5.5 Percent Over the Past Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 6-7, Allen Sinai ... with comment.
DOC.TEXT: Wages, salaries and other benefits paid to American workers shot up 5.5 percent over the past year, the largest jump in six years, the government reported today. The Labor Department attributed much of the increase in its Employment Cost Index, one of the best measures of wage inflation, to the continued soaring cost of health insurance and other benefits. Health insurance alone increased 12.1 percent for the year ending in March, following the 13.4 percent rise registered for the 12-month period ending in March 1989. The 5.5 percent rise in overall employment costs was the largest 12-month surge since March 1984, when wages, benefits and salaries increased by 5.9 percent, the government said. A year ago, employment costs had gone up 4.8 percent for the same period. Economists have been concerned that tight labor markets are pushing labor costs higher and worsening the nation's inflation problems. Last month, the nation's already relatively low unemployment rate fell a notch to 5.2 percent. Allen Sinai, chief economist for the Boston Co., called the report a ``big negative on the inflation outlook.'' ``It shows that we have a rock hard, high employment cost lump facing American business that is being passed on at the retail level,'' Sinai said. Today's report showed that wages and salaries rose 4.2 percent over the year ending in March, the same as the increase from a year earlier, while benefit costs jumped 7.2 percent, compared with a 5.4 percent rise a year before. The jump in benefit costs was blamed on higher health insurance and an increase in social security taxes, up from 7.51 percent to 7.65 percent. Workers in the service sector of the economy fared slightly better than the manufacturing sector in pay gains. Service industries saw wages and salaries go up by 4.2 percent in the past 12 months compared to a 4.0 percent rise for the manufacturing sector. The gain reflects the fact that service industries have been more affected by shortages of workers in the past year. However, there was a wide split in pay gains in the services category. At the low end, wages in food stores and banking rose just 2.8 percent while wages at hospitals and health care clinics shot up 6.3 percent. Non-union workers continued on a six-year pattern of gaining better wage and salary advances than their union counterparts. Over the past 12 months, wages and salaries rose 4.4 percent for non-union workers while increasing 3.4 percent for union workers. With benefits included, compensation costs rose 5.4 percent for non-union workers while increasing 4.3 percent for those in unions. State and local government workers gained 5.6 percent increases in wages and salaries over the past year, compared with the 4.7 percent increases gained a year ago. Health services workers received the highest increases, 6.7 percent. Private industry workers in the Northeast fared the best in terms of wage and salary gains. Workers in that region saw their wages and salaries increase by 5.4 percent, compared with a 3.5 percent rise for workers in the Midwest and a 3.4 percent gain for those in the West. Southern workers enjoyed gains of 4.3 percent.

The stock market advanced in the early going today, reversing a four-session losing streak with the boost from a strengthening bond market. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 4.73 at 2,671.40 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange issues, with 655 up, 334 down and 490 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 22.12 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. ``It's a fairly positive opening,'' said Hildegarde Zagorski, a vice president at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., noting that the Dow has lost nearly 100 points in the past four sessions. Stocks were supported by strength in the bond market, where prices were lifted following the government's release of a stronger-than-expected 6.7 percent rise in durable goods orders or March. Zagorski said stock prices responded with a ``technical bounce. The market's been down a long way and it's entitled to some kind of bounce, but we don't know how long it's going to last.'' Among actively traded blue-chip issues, Philip Morris was unchanged at 41|, AT&T was up [ at 40{, IBM was up [ at 109{ and Digital Equipment was up { at 83}. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.54 to 182.47. At the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index was up 0.94 at 345.89. On Monday the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 29.28 to 2,666.67, extending its loss since last Tuesday to 99.10 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by nearly 4 to 1 on the NYSE, with 330 up, 1,223 down and 420 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 136.15 million shares, down from 174.26 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Agreements Average 3.3 Percent So Far This Year
DOC.TEXT: Contracts settled through collective bargaining in the first three months of 1990 gave workers average annual wage increases of 3.3 percent over the life of the pacts, the government reported today. The last time parties covered by those settlements negotiated, usually in 1987 or 1988, average wage gains were smaller, averaging 2.2 percent over the contract term, the Labor Department said. Part of the gains reflect wage increases where there had been cuts or freezes in previous agreements, such as in the steel industry, the department said. In addition, wage gains were larger than pay raises negotiated in previous agreements, particularly in petroleum refining and food stores, the government said. For the 12-month period ending in March, settlements that were reached provided wage adjustments averaging 3.4 percent a year over the contract life, compared with 2.3 percent when the same parties previously bargained. The average annual wage gains over the contract life has been increasing since the low of 1.7 percent for a 12-month period, which occurred for the year ending in September 1986. The collective bargaining report, like the Labor Department's broader Employment Cost Index that also was released today, showed workers in the fast-growing service sector winning larger wage gains than manufacturing workers. Service workers received an average annual gain of 3.4 percent over the contract life while manufacturing workers received an average boost of 3.2 percent. The average construction worker received gains of 3.8 percent a year over the life of the contract, the report said. The Labor Department said the 74 collective bargaining agreements it analyzed covered about 318,000 workers. The government tracks agreements covering bargaining units with at least 1,000 workers. The government said 186 such agreements covering about 590,000 workers are scheduled to expire or reopen for wage negotiations during the April-June 1990 period, with many of those jobs in the construction industry. In addition, there are about 695,000 workers under 111 contracts that had expired or been reopened, but not renegotiated or ratified, prior to the end of March. More than half those workers are railroad employees.

DOC.HEAD: Dow Chemical Quarterly Earnings Drop
DOC.TEXT: Dow Chemical Co. reported Tuesday that its first-quarter profit fell 38 percent over a year ago as rising material costs and sagging prices of some products offset an increase in sales. For the three months ended March 31, Dow netted $462 million, or $1.71 per share, compared with earnings of $743 million, or $2.72 a share, in 1989. Quarterly sales rose 9 percent to $4.90 billion from $4.49 billion. Chief Executive Officer Frank Popoff attributed the lower profit partly to a drop prices in some ethylene-based products and to higher feedstock costs. But he remained optimistic about the rest of the year. ``As we enter the second quarter, feedstock costs are declining and prices for several large-volume products are increasing,'' Popoff said in a statement. ``Our value-added businesses continue to show sales and earnings growth and provide a solid profit base for the company.'' Dow, a global manufacturer of basic chemicals, plastics, pharmaceuticals and household products, reported net income of $2.49 billion for 1989 on sales of $17.60 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Monsanto Profits Fall 13 Percent in First Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Monsanto Co. reported Tuesday that its first-quarter profit fell 13 percent from last year because of soft conditions in the automotive industry and a seasonal slowdown in agriculture. For the quarter ended March 31, the chemical and agricultural products giant had a profit of $194 million, or $2.95 a share, down from a record $222 million, or $3.24 a share, earnings in 1989. Sales for the quarter were flat, $2.28 billion compared with last year's $2.26 billion. Chairman Richard Mahoney said, ``Despite the fact that earnings were below those of last year's record first quarter, we're confident about the prospects for the rest of the year. We expect to make 1990 another record year for Monsanto.'' Monsanto produces a wide variety of chemicals including compounds that are used in automobile dashboards, windshields and tires. The company also manufactures pesticides and animal feed supplements. Mahoney said earnings from agricultural chemicals fell in the first quarter because farmers were either waiting to buy some chemicals in bulk or were choosing lower-priced formulations. Monsanto's chemical segment had slightly lower operating profits, but considering that the automotive industry was soft, Mahoney said the segment performed well. ``We think the worst is behind us in these auto markets,'' he said. Monsanto's drug subsidiary, G.D. Searle, showed a $4 million profit compared with an $8 million loss in the first quarter of 1989, and The Nutrasweet Co., which is also owned by Monsanto, had slightly lower profits because of the cost of introducing its new frozen dairy dessert, Simple Pleasures.

DOC.NOTE: EDS: the Dow figure in 2nd graf is correct and is identical to 10 a.m. figure.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market was higher in moderate trading today, reflecting gains in bond prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 4.73 at 2,671.40 at 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 5 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange issues, with 662 up, 529 down and 534 unchanged. Stocks were supported by strength in the bond market, where prices rose following the government's release of a stronger-than-expected 6.7 percent rise in durable goods orders in March. But bonds began to ease after investors digested the report, and stock prices retreated in tandem from their early highs. ``The bond market is continuing to pressure the stock market as it has for the past several days,'' said C. Beth Cotner, a vice president at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. ``Rising interest rates lower stock valuations'' and make corporate borrowing more expensive, she noted. Still, many analysts are expecting the stock market to rebound after the Dow lost nearly 100 points in the previous four sessions. ``The market's been down a long way and it's entitled to some kind of bounce,'' said Hildegarde Zagorski, a vice president at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Among actively traded blue-chip issues, Ames Department Stores was off | at 1] on report that the chain might seek bankruptcy court protection; Philip Morris was unchanged at 41|, Citicorp was down [ at 22\; IBM was up ] at 109}; and Sears Roebuck was off | at 35~. The retailer reported lower first-quarter profits. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.44 to 182.37. At the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index was up 0.24 at 345.19. Volume on the Big Board came to 45.72 million shares at midmorning.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 421.51 up 1.43 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Control Data Reports First-Quarter Profit
DOC.TEXT: Control Data Corp. said Tuesday that its first-quarter profit nearly doubled from a year ago because of a huge after-tax gain from its restructuring, but revenue of the scaled-down computer company declined sharply. Net income for the first three months of 1990 totaled $6.8 million, or 16 cents a share, compared with earnings of $3.5 million, or 8 cents, in 1989. Revenue were more than halved, to $421.6 million from $843.5 million. The latest results included a $5.8 million gain from the company's restructuring. Control Data sold or discontinued several operating units, including its Imprimis disk drive subsidiary and its maintenance business. It also laid off 7,750 workers last year, and replaced its chief executive officer, Robert M. Price. Lawrence Perlman, who took the helm of Control Data in January, said, ``Apart from restructuring gains and charges, Control Data has now been profitable for three consecutive quarters. ``Although the first quarter traditionally has not been a strong one for Control Data, earnings were stronger in several businesses than we had anticipated. Business Management Services sustained its revenue and earnings growth, and Computer Products continued to make progress.'' The company posted a net loss of $680.4 million in 1989, the worst in its 32-year history.

DOC.HEAD: Divided Senate Panel Starts Work on 1991 Budget
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Sasser saying he doubts White House-congressional budget reduction summit would work. Picks up 6th graf pvs Despite this ... A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee said today that Congress must craft its own 1991 budget because the Bush administration isn't giving it serious attention. Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., told the committee that he hoped to draft a $1.2 trillion budget by having members consider at least three alternatives with deficit reduction ranging from $50 billion down to $37 billion. Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, the senior Republican on the panel, promised to cooperate, but said he didn't think Sasser's strategy would work. ``The missing link is the president of the United States,'' he said. But Sasser said ``at this point, at least, the administration isn't serious'' about the budget. ``I have very severe doubts that negotiations with the White House are the way to go,'' he said. Before today's meeting, Sasser had worked for weeks without success to find a consensus among the 10 Republicans and 13 Democrats on the committee for a deficit-reduction plan. Domenici contended today that having Congress adopt a budget on its own, almost certainly supported only by the majority Democrats, ``dooms the resolution to either a partisan piece of paper or an inoperative document.'' Two of the panel's Democrats _ Sens. Ernest Hollings of South Carolina and Charles Robb of Virginia _ also appear unhappy, saying deeper cuts are needed. Their defections would leave Sasser one vote shy of being able to send a measure to the full Senate. Despite this, Sasser expressed confidence that the committee would eventually approve a budget, perhaps by week's end. ``I can't believe that members of the majority will want to sit around and let Gramm-Rudman necessitate cuts, which is what would occur unless we go about our business here,'' he said. The Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law sets a target of a $64 billion shortfall for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. Under current projections, that would mean that at least $37 billion in savings must be found. If they are not, the law automatically triggers spending cuts in many government programs. White House budget director Richard Darman said last week that because of the economy's poor recent performance, the amount of deficit-reduction needed to satisfy Gramm-Rudman now ranges from $45 billion to $57 billion or more. All of Sasser's proposals would shift some of the money Bush wants to spend on defense to domestic programs. Sasser favors limiting next year's defense spending to $292 billion _ $15 billion below the amount needed to stay even with inflation and $4 billion below spending this year. Bush has proposed $304 billion for the military. The plans Sasser put forward provide defense expenditures ranging from $287 billion to $292 billion. They each rely on $13.9 billion in new tax receipts, the same amount Bush has requested. They vary in the amount of savings that would come from domestic program cuts and new fees from $8.3 billion to $16.1 billion. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, proposed last week that defense spending be limited to about $297 billion. Last Thursday, the House Budget Committee approved a budget that would hold military spending to $295 billion. That Democratic-written spending plan, approved on a strict party-line vote, could go to the House floor by Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Recovering
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices were recovering in early trading today as some investors moved to buy securities at cheap levels. The Treasury's closely watched 30-year bond was up \ point, or $2.50 for every $1,000 in face value, at around midday. Its yield, which falls when the price rises, declined to 8.93 percent from 8.96 percent late Monday. By Monday, the 30-year bond had plunged more than $41 per $1,000 over the previous seven trading days in response to signs of increasing inflation, a stronger economy and worries about upcoming bond issues, including the Treasury's quarterly refunding auction set for next month. Higher inflation and an economic upturn could prompt the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates high. Higher rates erode the value of fixed-return investments such as bonds. Today, ``the market was ready to do a little better,'' said John Sebastian, an executive vice president of Clayton Brown & Associates in Chicago. ``People are doing some bottom-fishing in here.'' Sebastian noted that bond prices recovered despite a government report this morning that orders to U.S. factories for durable goods jumped 6.7 percent in March, the sharpest increase in more than a year. The data gave support to the idea of a strong economy, one of the bond market's current fears. The market also is looking toward Friday's report on the U.S. gross nationalet for Economic, Social Unification

DOC.HEAD: MUCH ADO ABOUT NOTHING: Shakespeare Clan Marks Bard's Birthday
DOC.TEXT: LONDON _ Some people might think that making a fuss over a name is much ado about nothing, but those people aren't named Shakespeare. Of those who are, about 115 turned up to celebrate the Bard's birthday Tuesday at the site of the new Globe Theatre. It was the largest gathering of Shakespeares since 1964. Slug AM-Shakespeares. New. Stands. 600 words. By Sydney Rubin.

The stock market gained ground in moderate trading today as bargain hunters left the sidelines and bought equities. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 7.20 at 2,673.87 at noon on Wall Street. DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down; Gold Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with late European rates and midday New York rates.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar retreated against most major currencies in European trading Tuesday. Gold prices rose. Foreign exchange dealers said the West German mark's move through 93.20 Japanese yen _ a key technical chart point _ kicked off a flurry of activity in afternoon European dealings. By late in the European day, the mark was quoted at about 93.67 yen, up from 92.92 yen late Monday. It had moved briefly above 94 yen before retreating in late dealings. Otherwise, dealers said, there was little buying or selling interest in the currency markets. ``Everybody is range trading and looking at technicals,'' said Laudy Bahl, head of corporate dealings at Bank of Tokyo in London. Late in London, the dollar was quoted at 1.6930 marks, down from 1.6960 marks late Monday in London. Also in London, the British pound was quoted at $1.6345, compared with $1.6365 late Monday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.60 yen to a closing 158.15 yen. It was quoted at a higher rate of 158.59 yen later in London. Selected midday dollar rates in New York included: 1.6935 West German marks; 158.625 Japanese yen; 1.48585 Swiss francs; and 1.15925 Canadian dollars. DOC.HEAD: Keating Re-Elected AP Chairman, Daniels Chosen as Chairman-Elect
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with board reorganization; new material, reorganizes throughout.
DOC.TEXT: William J. Keating was re-elected chairman of the board of directors of The Associated Press today, and Frank A. Daniels Jr. was elected vice chairman and chairman-elect by the board. Keating is chairman and publisher of The Cincinnati Enquirer. His term as a director will expire in 1992. Daniels is president and publisher of The News & Observer of Raleigh, N.C. Louis D. Boccardi was re-elected president and general manager at the board's reorganization meeting. On Monday, at the annual meeting of the news cooperative, David J. Whichard II of The Daily Reflector of Greenville, N.C. was elected to the AP board, and five incumbents were re-elected. James K. Batten, J. Stewart Bryan III, Ruth S. Holmberg, Tom Johnson and Joe D. Smith Jr. were elected to new three-year terms. Today's reorganization meeting also included the election of two new vice presidents to one-year terms _ William E. Ahearn, AP executive editor, and James R. Williams, director of AP Broadcast Services. Other management officers re-elected to one-year terms, in addition to Boccardi, were James F. Tomlinson, vice president and secretary; Patrick T. O'Brien, vice president and treasurer, and vice presidents Claude E. Erbsen, Walter R. Mears, John W. Reid and Wick Temple. Also re-elected from the AP were assistant secretaries Lilo Jedelhauser and Lee Perryman, and assistant treasurers Frederick R. Barberi, Paul H. Jenssen and Roger P. Sturm. In Monday's balloting by AP members, Whichard, president and editor of the Greenville newspaper, was elected to represent a city of under 50,000 population, succeeding retiring director John O. Emmerich Jr. of The Greenwood (Miss.) Commonwealth. Emmerichwas not eligible for re-election because he served the maximum of three consecutive three-year terms on the board. Of the re-elected incumbent board members, Batten is chairman and chief executive officer of Knight-Ridder, Inc., based in Miami; Bryan is chairman and publisher of the Richmond (Va.) Times-Dispatch and The Richmond News Leader; Holmberg is publisher of The Chattanooga (Tenn.) Times; Johnson is chairman of the Los Angeles Times, and Smith is president of the Alexandria (La.) Daily Town Talk. The board of directors also reappointed Robert Morse of WMAQ-TV, Chicago, as a representative of the broadcasting industry. He will serve a two-year term.

DOC.HEAD: Richmond Council Scuttles 20-Cent-Per-Pack Cigarette Tax Plan
DOC.TEXT: The City Council has unanimously rejected a proposed 20-cents-a-pack cigarette tax in this city where tobacco giant Philip Morris Companies Inc. is the largest private employer. ``I felt it was not appropriate for the city of Richmond to do this because tobacco has been a major industry since the city's beginning,'' said Mayor Geline B. Williams, who introduced the proposal that effectively killed the tax. The tax, which was defeated Monday night, would have raised $3.2 million. It was one of several proposals in City Manager Robert C. Bobb's proposed 1990-91 budget aimed at shifting the tax burden from property owners to consumers. Twenty-nine localities in the state impose a cigarette tax, but Richmond was viewed by cigarette manufacturers as a place where they needed to prevail. New York-based Philip Morris employs 11,000 people at a cigarette manufacturing plant here. Tobacco industry representatives argued that the tax would generate far less revenue than predicted because consumers would leave the city to buy cigarettes elsewhere. Bill Daunhauer of the Bakery, Confectionary and Tobacco Workers International Union, AFL-CIO, said tobacco company employees give more than $1 million a year to the local United Way campaign, exclusive of corporate gifts. ``It would seem an injustice to these workers for the city to pass any legislation that may cost them their livelihood,'' he said. Anne Morrow Donley, executive director of the Virginia Group to Alleviate Smoking in Public, said the non-smoking majority of Richmonders have to subsidize the industry through increased insurance rates and tax rates. ``Until the tobacco industry is willing or required to make reparations for the harm their products cause, it makes sense to require those who use the product to bear the cost of it to society,'' she said. The council directed Bobb to find a way other than the cigarette tax to raise the money.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts From Michael Milken's Admission of Guilt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from a statement made by ex-Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. financier Michael Milken in Manhattan federal court Tuesday, when he pleaded guilty to six felonies in the biggest securities fraud settlement against an individual in history: ``I was the founder and head of the High Yield and Convertible Securities Department at Drexel. In pioneering the creation of new instruments for the financing of companies, most of which did not have access to the capital markets because they did not have investment-grade ratings, and in making markets in such securities, we operated under unique, highly demanding, and intensely competitive conditions. But I do not cite these conditions as an excuse for not conforming to all of the laws that governed our highly regulated business. I am here today because in connection with some transactions, I transgressed certain of the laws and regulations that govern our industry. I was wrong in doing so and knew that at the time and I am pleading guilty to these offenses. ``One of the accounts we did business with was the (Ivan) Boesky Organization, which also did business with many other firms. Drexel did some financings for and trading with the Boesky firm, but Drexel's business with the Boesky Organization never approached one percent of the business of our department. He traded in stocks; I traded primarily in bonds, or their equivalent. But because he was a major factor in the securities markets, he had the potential to become a more significant account. We were not social friends, and had little in common. The relationship started as an arms length and correct one. Unfortunately, however, certain of our transactions involved reciprocal accommodations, some of which violated the law... ``Because of the tremendous amount of publicity that has surrounded this case, I wish to make clear that my plea is an acceptance of personal responsibility for my own failings and actions, and not a reflection on the underlying soundness and integrity of the segment of the capital markets in which we specialized and which provided capital that enabled hundreds of companies to survive, expand and flourish. Our business was in no way dependent on these practices. Nor did they comprise a fundamental part of our business and I regret them very much. ``This investigation and proceeding are now in their fourth year. This long period has been extremely painful and difficult for my family and friends as well as myself. I realize that by my acts I have hurt those who are closest to me. I am truly sorry. I thank the Court for permitting me to add this apology and for its fairness in handling this complex case.''

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Sets Up $1 Million Credit Education Fund
DOC.TEXT: Less than a month after entering the credit card business, AT&T said Tuesday it will donate $1 million over four years to start a consumer credit education fund. The fund is ``designed to increase consumer understanding of credit and its proper uses,'' American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said in a statement. The fund is being set up jointly with the National Coalition for Consumer Education, a non-profit group formed in 1981 to promote consumer credit education programs in schools and communities, AT&T said. The group is supported by grants from corporations, foundations and individuals. On March 26, AT&T launched its Universal Card, which combines the features of its traditional phone charge card with either a MasterCard or Visa card.

DOC.HEAD: Mid-April Sales Tumble
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.NOTE: Eds: An AMer expected by 6 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Sales of North American-made cars and light trucks by the nation's Big Three automakers plummeted 20.5 percent in mid-April compared with last year, when incentives were far more generous, the companies said Tuesday. The companies said they sold an average of 30,742 cars and light trucks a day during the April 11-20 period this year compared with a rate of 38,686 a day during the same time last year. Car sales dropped 23 percent and truck sales were off 16.6 percent. At the end of March and the beginning of April last year, General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. introduced new incentive plans that boosted cash rebates and slashed loan interest rates. Because of the packages, people flocked to showrooms, boosting the April sales rate to one of the highest in 1989. But this year, the incentives didn't work as well. Since Jan. 1, car and truck sales by the Big Three were 6.4 percent behind last year's pace. The automakers sold a daily average of 31,452 for the entire year this year compared with a 33,612-vehicle-a-day rate during the same period last year. A 9.2-percent decline in car sales was softened by a 1.9 percent drop in truck sales. Chrysler has suffered the most as the sales rate slows this year. During mid-April, its combined car and truck sales were 36.2 percent behind last year's rate. The company's car sales were down 38.4 percent and truck sales were off 33.9 percent. So far this year, Chrysler's cars and trucks were selling at a pace 10.8 percent slower than last year. Ford said its mid-April car and truck sales were down 19 percent this year compared with last year as car sales dipped 22.7 percent and truck sales fell 13.1 percent. For the entire year, Ford's combined vehicle sales were down 8.7 percent. GM said its car sales in mid-April fell 18.9 percent and truck sales tumbled 9.6 percent, combining for a 15.9 percent decline in vehicle sales. So far this year, GM's car and truck sales were down 3.1 percent, despite a 2.3 percent rise in truck sales. GM's year-to-date car sales were down 5.7 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Empathy and Cynicism Over Milken's Admission of Guilt
With PM-Milken
DOC.TEXT: Junk-bond pioneer Michael Milken's cathartic guilty plea to securities fraud today provoked reactions ranging from sympathy by defense lawyers to scornful snubs on Wall Street, where many say his prolonged bout with the law helped taint the integrity of the financial markets. ``The Milken case was like a cleansing process that should restore investor confidence,'' said John Eric Smith, a floor official at the New York Stock Exchange, when word broke of Milken's tearful admission to six felony counts in a packed Manhattan federal court. The 43-year-old former head bond trader for now-bankrupt Drexel Burnham Lambert, which revolutionized the securities industry with the use of high-yield ``junk bonds'' that financed the takeover boom of the 1980s, had insisted he was innocent for more than three years before changing his mind. Most of the counts to which he pleaded guilty were related to Drexel's relationship with speculator Ivan Boesky, the convicted felon who provided much of the information for prosecutions of Wall Street corruption in recent years. It was Boesky's revelations about insider trading and other crimes that helped humble Drexel and eventually drive it into bankruptcy court earlier this year, putting 10,000 people out of work. Milken faces a maximum 28 year prison term and must forfeit $600 million in fines and restitution to defrauded investors, but it will still leave him one of the nation's wealthiest individuals. ``I don't think we'll have to pass the hat for the guy. You know what I mean?'' said a middle-aged NYSE worker queried in lower Manhattan's financial district. He declined to identify himself by name. Lawyers familiar with the Milken case speculated the hardest thing for him to do was stand up in open court and admit he was a felon after insisting he was innocent for so long. ``I think it was a fairly tragic and humbling proceeding for Milken,'' said Theodore Wells, a lawyer who has represented other white collar defendants in fallout from the Boesky-Drexel scandal. ``Hopefully, people will remember all of the good that he did for the financial markets and not focus exclusively on these apparent aberrations.'' Some said the charges in the plea agreement, drastically fewer and less serious than the 98-count racketeering-fraud indictment Milken faced had he not pleaded guilty, did not mean the government had let him off easily. Many believe Milken will have to do some prison time. ``Whether it's six counts or 26 counts, it doesn't make a difference in the end and the message is the same,'' said Paul Fischer, a securities law attorney in Washington and former Securities and Exchange lawyer who helped develop the investigation that eventually led to prosecutions of Boesky, Drexel and Milken. ``Six felony counts are six felony counts. The exposure he has is still 28 years,'' said Ira L. Sorkin, a former SEC administrator in New York who now is in private practice. ``It's silly to play the game of who got the better deal,'' Sorkin said. ``The fact of the matter is Mr. milken is a convicted felon. Federal prison, minimum or maximum, is not a very pleasant place.''

The stock market failed to hang on to early gains today, mirroring a decline in bond prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 2.03 at 2,664.64 at 3 p.m. on Wall Street. DOC.HEAD: Hitachi Opens Biotechnology Lab at UC Campus
DOC.TEXT: Hitachi Ltd. is believed to be the first Japanese company operating a research lab at an American university now that it has opened a biotechnology center at the University of California here. Hitachi officials said Monday they hope the $16.5 million laboratory, called Plumwood House because of its plum color, will allow the company to advance in areas like neuroscience and biochemistry, where it has traditionally been weak. ``Hitachi has been devoting (research) in recent years to biotechnology, but we are not advanced in this area,'' said Hiroshi Sumiyama, who heads the lab. ``That's why the company decided to locate the facility in the United States, (which) is more advanced in biotechnology research. UCI gave us the opportunity to do this,'' he said. UCI leased 1{ acres to Hitachi for 40 years. In return, UCI researchers can use 15,000 of the 40,000-square-foot building called Plumwood House. ``The university is getting great laboratory space at no expense to the taxpayers,'' said John Wasmuth, one of three UCI researchers assigned to the lab. The lab will be used by 60 Hitachi and UCI researchers. State officials noted the venture will benefit both the university and Hitachi, while any discoveries by lab researchers will go to UCI. ``It's not going to succeed if the general public does not benefit before Hitachi,'' said Allan Melkesian, director of the state Office of Foreign Investment. ``There is going to be a lot of scrutiny as there ought to be. It is a sensitive area.'' Foreign investment on college campuses is not new. A consortium of German companies built a computer science building at the University of California, Berkeley campus, and a Japanese pharmaceutical company is constructing a lab at the UC San Diego campus. Four U.S. corporations, including Texas Instruments, have established laboratories at Japanese institutions. Another Japanese electronics giant, NEC Corp., plans to open an artificial intelligence laboratory in Princeton, N.J., next month. NEC is spending $75 million for the project, and company officials say they intend to recruit researchers from Princeton University. Joint ventures between Japanese companies and American universities are likely to grow, according to Richard King, a Los Angeles-based international trade consultant. ``I think we will find many more of these kinds of ventures where the Japanese want to tie in with research and development and high-technology endeavors and the universities welcome that, because it's a private-public sector relationship where benefits accrue to both sides,'' King said.

DOC.HEAD: Hi-Tech Italian-Japanese Facsimile Venture Opens
DOC.TEXT: Italy's Olivetti and Japan's Sanyo and Mitsui on Tuesday opened a factory to produce facsimile machines, the first hi-tech joint-venture involving Italian and Japanese firms in southern Italy. Carlo De Benedetti, chairman of Olivetti, Italy's largest computer group, said that the plant could ``integrate Olivetti's extensive European commerical operation with high-level Japanese technology.'' Sanyo is an industrial giant which markets electrical products worldwide, while Mitsui is one of Japan's largest trading companies. Both are engaged in joint ventures with other European firms. The new plant, called the Olivetti Sanyo Industriale factory, was completed in nine months. It will produce 200,000 facsimile machines a year, the officials said. Eluchii Hori, chairman of Mitsui and Co. Europe, said that the new plant was set up easily because of Olivetti's expertise in dealing with Italian bureaucracy. Officials said the plant in Italy's economically depressed south will employ about 330 people. Over the next four years Olivetti intends to invest 770 billion lire, or $616 million, in the region, officials said. This is the second time that De Benedetti has sought to blend Italian entrepreneurial skills with Japanese technological know-how. In 1987 Olivetti joined with Canon to produce copiers at Ivrea in northern Italy. Italy and Japan are keen to expand industrial relations. Last year Japanese and Italian experts met in Tokyo to discuss improving scientific and technological ties. Italian officals called then for an increase in co-operation on computers and robots.

Stock prices fell today for the fifth-straight session as a late round of computer-triggered selling wiped out initial gains. The market advanced on the opening, boosted by rising bond prices. Stocks appeared to mirror the seesawing of the credit market for much of the session and struggled to hold on to gains once bonds came under pressure. Government bonds yielding close to 9 percent proved an attractive alternative to equities. But some analysts noted that with a substantial amount of cash on the sidelines, investors were not forced to sell stocks to buy bonds. Trading was moderate. Alfred E. Goldman, a vice president at A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis, called the market's performance ``a little disappointing because it tried to go up _ both the generals and the troops.'' He was encouraged that although bond prices fell, they were down only fractionally and the market seemed to be stabilizing. Stocks recently have been taking their cue from bond prices, which fall when interst rates rise. Higher interest rates lower stock valuations and make corporate borrowing more expensive.

DOC.HEAD: Milken Pleads Guilty To Six Charges; Will Pay $600 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 new graf after 17th graf pvs, ``We believe... to UPDATE with comment from Breeden news conference.
DOC.TEXT: Junk bond giant Michael Milken tearfully pleaded guilty today to six criminal charges and agreed to pay $600 million to settle the biggest Wall Street fraud case ever against an individual. ``I realize by my acts I have hurt those who are closest to me. I am truly sorry,'' Milken said, breaking down and crying as he read a statement in court. Included were guilty pleas for aiding speculator Ivan Boesky in several securities law violations; for aiding another trader in filing false income tax returns; and for conspiring to violate securities laws. Milken did not plead to any charges of insider trading or racketeering, which were the most serious in the government's original, broad indictment of him. Sentencing was set for Oct. 1. Milken faces a possible maximum total of up to 28 years in prison. Milken, 43, entered his guilty plea at 12:42 p.m. before U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood in a courtroom packed with about 250 people in lower Manhattan. The move capped the stunning decline of the former head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s high-yield bond department, who gained notoriety for engineering financing for some of the biggest corporate takeovers of the 1980s and then for allegations of widespread wrongdoing. Milken was the main target of the government's lengthy investigation of Wall Street crime that resulted in more than 30 convictions, and he was the last to fall.
