Milken was linked to a large insider trading network headed by Boesky, who paid $100 million and was sentenced to three years in prison in exchange for providing information against Milken, Drexel and others. After three years of rumors and press leaks, the Justice Department in March 1989 indicted Milken, his brother, Lowell, and former Drexel trader Bruce Newberg on an unprecedented 98 counts of fraud and racketeering.

Under the plea deal, all charges were dropped against Lowell Milken, a lawyer and key aide to his brother at Drexel. The case against Newberg was not resolved. After the hearing, Lowell Milken issued a statement repeating his claim of innocence and calling it ``one of the saddest and most frustrating days of my life.'' ``The pain inflicted on our families cannot be undone. I am proud of my brother and nothing that has happened here today has changed that,'' the statement read. Michael Milken pleaded guilty to counts of conspiracy; aiding and abetting failure to meet federal securities disclosure regulations; securities fraud; aiding and abetting a regulated broker-dealer to violate securities reporting requirements; mail fraud; and assisting in filing a false tax return. The first five counts carry a maximum five years each in prison and the tax count has a maximum three year setnence, for a possible total of 28 years. Milken agreed to pay $200 million in penalties to the government and $400 million to set up a fund for reimbursing investors defrauded by his actions. ``We believe that this prosecution and the fact that Mr. Milken has admitted to guilt will send the right message to the financial community,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney John K. Carroll told the court.

Richard Breeden, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told a news conference in Washington: ``Mr. Milken has been portrayed as wrongly accused, and as having simply devoted himself to the financing of small or emerging business. Despite the efforts to mold public opinion, Mr. Milken's admissions today demonstrate that he stood at the center of a network of manipulation, fraud and deceit.'' Milken, wearing a blue suit, white shirt and blue polka-dot tie, read a lengthy statement detailing the crimes that he pleaded guilty to. He summarized his work as head of Drexel's high-yield bond department, which helped reshape corporate America by pioneering the wide use of its so-called ``junk bonds'' to raise money for small companies and finance corporate takeovers. The original indictment had charged the defendants with illegal securities trading, stock manipulation and other fraudulent activity, some in connection with a series of corporate mergers and acquisitions. Milken had pleaded innocent and repeatedly said he would fight the charges at trial, but reversed his position after months of negotiations between the government and his attorneys. He had faced a much longer prison term and possible forfeiture of his wealth, said to be more than $1 billion, under the original charges. The plea deal was reached Friday after the U.S. Attorney's Office said it would bring a broader indictment as it had been threatening to do for nearly a year if Milken did not settle. Milken told the court he violated the law in doing business with Boesky in 1984, when Boesky acquired more than 10 percent of the stock of Fischbach Corp., a takeover target at the time. As part of his dealings, Milken told Boesky that Drexel would cover any losses Boesky suffered in trading the stock, in violation of federal disclosure requirements.

Milken also admitted to securities fraud in an arrangement with Boesky involving the sale of MCA Inc. stock by Drexel client Golden Nugget Inc. in the fall of 1984. In the tax-related count, Milken said he helped Drexel client David Solomon, head of Solomon Asset Management, engage in illegal trading and create fictitious losses for tax purposes. Milken broke down as he finished his statement. His attorney, Arthur Liman, placed his hand on his back for support as Milken finished reading. Milken is required to answer questions about the government's continuing insider trading and savings and loan investigations but he does not have to provide specific information to help develop other fraud cases. He will not be questioned until after sentencing, limiting the government's control over the impact of his cooperation. After his indictment, Milken set aside about $700 million to guarantee payment in the event of conviction. It was unclear whether that money would be used to pay the new penalties. Milken, the son of an accountant, is widely regarded as the nation's most important financial figure since J.P. Morgan dominated the banking and securities industries in the early 1900s. Milken is credited with reshaping American finance in the 1980s through junk bonds used to provide billions of dollars in capital to small- and medium-sized companies and to finance hostile corporate takeovers. Junk bonds grew from an obscure form of debt to a $200 billion market almost entirely because of Milken, who controlled a wide network of buyers and sellers and wielded enormous power. Under an agreement with Drexel, Milken was paid more than $1.1 billion from 1983-87, including $550 million in 1987 alone. Milken, Drexel and others were accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission in September 1988 with sweeping civil insider trading charges. Drexel settled its case last year by pleading guilty to six felonies and agreeing to pay $650 million in fines and restitution. Drexel was required to sever ties with Milken, who quit last June after 19 years at Drexel. Drexel itself collapsed and is liquidating after its parent company defaulted on debt payments and filed for bankruptcy court protection in February.

DOC.HEAD: RJR Nabisco Reports Strong Operating Earnings Growth
DOC.TEXT: RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp. said operating earnings from its tobacco and food businesses rose 50 percent during the first quarter, although the company recorded a net loss as it continued to pay down the debt from its $24.53 billion leveraged buyout. RJR Nabisco said it lost $222 million during the quarter, compared with a loss of $239 million in the same period a year earlier. The privately-held company did not report per-share results. The loss was attributed to interest costs from last year's takeover of the food and tobacco firm by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. RJR Nabisco reported $830 million in interest and debt expenses for the quarter. However, the company said its operating income increased to $602 million from $402 million in the first three months of 1989. Sales rose to $3.2 billion from $2.93 billion a year earlier. RJR Nabisco said it was able to repay approximately $2.2 billion of its debt during the quarter. The company's junk bonds advanced on the news as investors reacted positively to the results _ particularly the strength of RJR Nabisco's operating earnings. The bonds had slipped in recent months amid concerns about the firm's cash flow, which is crucial for paying down its debt. RJR Nabisco's 13.71 percent bonds due in 2007 rose } to 68[, while the company's 13.71 percent bonds due in 2009 rose | to 81|. The securities closed down from their highs of the day, but outperformed a lackluster junk bond market. The company reported a 15 percent gain in worldwide sales by its R.J. Reynolds tobacco businesses to $1.86 billion. The company said the decision to eliminate excess inventories in the second half of 1989 was largely responsible for the increase. The firm's cigarette brands include Winston, Salem and Camel. RJR Nabisco's food businesses reported sales of $1.34 billion, up 3 percent from a year earlier despite the loss of several product lines divested to help lower the company's debt load. The company's food divisions include Nabisco Brands Inc. and Planters LifeSavers Co., and its products include Oreo cookies and Ritz crackers, Planters nuts and LifeSavers candies.

DOC.HEAD: Coca-Cola Chief Highest Paid CEO On Forbes List
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release after 6:30 p.m. Eastern; time set by source.
DOC.TEXT: Coca-Cola Co.'s chief executive officer, Roberto C. Goizueta, received $10.8 million in salary and other compensation last year, making him the highest-paid CEO among the nation's largest companies, a survey in Forbes magazine shows. The 58-year-old Goizueta leads a list of the highest-paid executives to be featured in the May 14 issue, Forbes said Tuesday. The list is limited to executives from companies on Forbes ``Super 50'' ranking of the nation's largest companies as measured by their sales, profits, assets and market value. Goizueta realized $5.9 million in stock gains, in addition to $2.5 million in cash salary and bonus and other compensation of $2.4 million during the year, the magazine said. Roger B. Smith of General Motors Corp., the nation's largest company as measured by Forbes, ranked 22nd among the CEOs in total pay, with $2.1 million. The lowest-paid CEO among the group was billionaire Laurence Tisch of Loews Corp., whose total pay was $249,000 in 1989, the magazine said. Eleven of the ``Super 50'' CEOs made more than $3 million last year in total compensation. In addition to Goizueta, Forbes said the highest-paid CEOs were: David D. Glass, Wal-Mart Stores Inc., $6.8 million; Hamish Maxwell, Philip Morris Cos., $6.5 million; Maurice R. Greenberg, American International Group, $5.1 million; David O. Maxwell, Federal National Mortgage Association, $4.8 million; James W. Kinnear, Texaco Inc., $3.94 million; Rand V. Araskog, ITT Corp., $3.93 million; John D. Welch Jr., General Electric Co, $3.6 million; James D. Robinson III, American Express Co., $3.5 million; John A. Young, Hewlett-Packard Co., $3.2 million; and John C. Marous, Westinghouse Electric Corp., $3.1 million.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Down; Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar declined against all major currencies Tuesday except the Japanese yen, which weakened considerably. Gold prices finished lower at home after moving higher abroad. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for April delivery settled at $375.90 a troy ounce, or $3 below Monday's close. Later, Republic National Bank of New York quoted a troy ounce of gold bullion at $375.75 as of 4 p.m. EDT, down $2.90 from Monday's late bid. Foreign exchange dealers said trading was moderately active and most of the attention was directed toward the yen. Japan's currency slumped across the board, benefiting the West German mark, the Swiss franc and other currencies. ``It was a yen story today. The yen resumed its terribly weak posture,'' said Richard Levine, a vice president of foreign exchange and precious metals at Elders Futures Inc. in New York. There was no fundamental news from Japan to account for the heavy yen selling. Dealers said an underlying bearish outlook for the yen, which had been temporarily suppressed, resurfaced. The low level of that country's interest rates relative to those of its trading partners accounts for some of the yen's troubles. The dollar's losses against everything but the yen came despite a strong report on orders for durable goods. March bookings for durables, which are expensive items designed to last three or more years, posted the best showing in more than a year, jumping 6.7 percent. But the report had little influence on the dollar and traders were said to be more interested in Friday's reading on the gross national product, which will be the first comprehensive assessment of economic activity during this year's first quarter. In European trading, the West German mark's move through 93.20 Japanese yen _ a key technical chart point _ kicked off a flurry of activity. By late in the European day, the mark was quoted at about 93.67 yen, up from 92.92 yen late Monday. It had moved briefly above 94 yen before retreating in late dealings. By late in London's afternoon, the dollar was quoted at 1.6930 marks, down from 1.6960 marks late Monday. It stood at 1.6980 marks late in New York, lower than Monday's late level of 1.6995. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.60 yen to a closing 158.15 yen. It was quoted at a higher rate of 158.59 yen later in London. In New York, the dollar ended at 158.95 yen, up from 157.55 yen on Monday. Also in London, the British pound was quoted at $1.6345, compared with $1.6365 late Monday. Later in New York, sterling dipped to $1.6347 from $1.63565 on Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's late quotes, included: 1.4875 Swiss francs, down from 1.4935; 5.698 French francs, down from 5.7020; 1,244.75 Italian lire, down from 1,246.75; and 1.15955 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16155. Selected dollar rates late in Europe compared with late Monday's levels were: 1.4865 Swiss francs, down from 1.4925; 5.6795 French francs, down from 5.6930; 1.9100 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9090; 1,241.00 Italian lire, down from 1,244.00; and 1.1590 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1610. Gold and silver both gained in European and Asian trading before posting losses in the United States. In London, gold traded at a late bid of $378.25 a troy ounce, up from $376.25 late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $377.50, up from $375.85 late Monday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.99 to close at a bid of $378.97. Silver's decline in U.S. trading brought the precious metal below $5 an ounce. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery fell to $4.994 a troy ounce from Monday's settlement of $5.093. Silver traded in London at a late bid price of $5.10 a troy ounce, up from $5.09 late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Five Companies Form Software Group To Manage ``Corporate Knowledge''
DOC.TEXT: Four major corporations and a computer software company said Tuesday they formed an alliance to develop software that will allow them to better manage ``corporate knowledge,'' or the skills and know-how of their employees. The five companies _ Digital Equipment Corp., Ford Motor Co., Texas Instruments Inc., U S West Inc. and Carnegie Group Inc., a Pittsburgh-based software company _ said they contributed $10 million to the initiative, which they began in 1988 but did not announce at the time. The alliance, called the Initiative for Managing Knowledge Assets, is aimed at developing a next-generation software that will capture the skills and knowledge of a company's employees and make it available to others through a computer system. ``The ability to manage these assets, just as companies manage their capital or financial assets, is one of the most important ways in which companies can retain a competitive advantage in our increasingly competitive world,'' said Ted Smith, technical director of U S West Advanced Technologies Inc., a division of the Colorado-based regional phone company. Among knowledge skills of employees are design experience, engineering skills, financial analysis, marketplace knowledge and knowledge of a company's policies, practices and goals, the alliance said. The group calls the computer technique it intends to develop ``knowledge processing.'' The five companies said they will use the software they develop in their own operations and sell products based on it. Smith invited other companies to join the non-profit group. Smith said the companies hope the software they develop will help them bring products to market faster and improve customer service. The group already has spent a year in engineering development of the software, it said. The group said it will use concepts developed in artificial intelligence research, such as expert systems programs, but that the software will not be an artificial intelligence application per se. Artificial intelligence is a type of software than attempts to mimic the way humans think. Expert systems programs attempt to capture the knowledge of a human expert, such as an engineer or doctor, and make it available through a programming technique called inference, in which conclusions are drawn about a problem or question through a series of logic questions, such as if-then clauses. The companies said they decided to form the group after they found nothing on the market to provide the type of computer program they need. The group said it plans to have its core technology available for testing by this fall. Michael L. Schneider, a computer analyst at the research firm Gartner Group Inc., said the alliance represents the first time a group of end-users of computer services has decided to set the standards for a new computer technology at its infancy. Currently, he said, expert-systems programs are not standardized. Under the software the group intends to develop, ``it means everybody will be speaking the same language,'' which could speed the growth of such programs, he said. Gibbs R. Moody, a software analyst at the San Francisco brokerage Hambrecht & Quist, said Texas Instruments, Digital, U S West and Carnegie Group have been working on artificial intelligence systems on their own. Moody said the alliance ``sounds like a small, significant step but nothing earth-shattering.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Fall, Gasoline Futures Advance
DOC.TEXT: Crude and heating oil futures declined and gasoline futures advanced Tuesday on largely technical factors. The June contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, slipped 7 cents to close at $19 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The May contract for delivery of home heating oil dropped 0.47 cent to settle at 52.65 cents a gallon. However, the May contract for unleaded regular gasoline advanced 0.85 cent to close at 64.39 cents a gallon. Analysts said crude oil futures opened higher in response to gains on overseas markets, but prices fell back after meeting resistance at about $19.50 a barrel. Gasoline futures continued to recover from recent low levels as traders looked for and found bargains. Richard Redoglia, an analyst with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures, said there was no fundamental news to affect the market. He said many traders were awaiting next month's meeting of OPEC's price monitoring committee. The gathering was called by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in hopes of shoring up oil prices that have skidded as cartel members exceeded their production quotas. Oil analysts have estimated the 13-nation cartel is pumping more than 24 million barrels of crude a day, well over its self-imposed ceiling of 22.1 million barrels a day. Meanwhile Tuesday, natural gas for June delivery closed at $1.555 per million British thermal units, unchanged from Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Junk Bond Pioneer Pleads Guilty; To Pay $600 Million in Penalties
LaserPhotos NY27, NY30, NY129
DOC.TEXT: Michael Milken, the billionaire financier who reshaped Wall Street in the 1980s but fell in its biggest scandal, pleaded guilty Tuesday to breaking federal securities and tax laws and agreed to pay a record $600 million in penalties. Milken, 43, broke down and sobbed before the packed Manhattan courtroom as he finished a lengthy statement outlining his crimes, which included illegal trading with stock speculator Ivan Boesky and others from 1984-86. ``I realize by my acts I have hurt those who are closest to me. I am truly sorry,'' Milken said. He had to be supported by his attorney and his voice cracked when he pleaded, ``Guilty, your honor.'' Milken faces a maximum 28 years in prison at his scheduled Oct. 1 sentencing before U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood, although legal experts expect a term of around five years. The plea marked a stunning victory in the government's crackdown on Wall Street crime that has included more than 30 convictions and targeted Milken and his former employer, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., from its outset in 1986. Milken widely is regarded as the most important American financier since J.P. Morgan Jr. in the early 1900s and he came to symbolize the bounty and excesses of a booming Wall Street. His personal fortune is said to exceed $1 billion. Milken pioneered the use of high-yield debt securities known as junk bonds that gave small companies access to billions of dollars in capital and also made possible the wave of hostile corporate takeovers that characterized the dog-eat-dog 1980s. But his downfall began after he was linked to an insider trading network by Boesky, who received a three-year prison term and was fined $100 million in November 1986 to settle his own case. Milken was indicted on 98 counts of fraud and racketeering in March 1989, but vigorously maintained his innocence. He reversed course last week and agreed to the plea bargain, avoiding a long, costly trial and the prospect of a much stiffer prison term. Richard Breeden, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said in Washington that Milken's admissions ``demonstrate that he stood at the center of a network of manipulation, fraud and deceit.'' Milken pleaded guilty to conspiracy, securities fraud, mail fraud, helping others violate federal securities regulations and assisting in the filing of a false tax return. Far less severe than the original indictment, the counts do not involve rackteering or unlawful securities trading based on inside information. The racketeering charge carried a minimum 20-year prison term and possible forfeiture of Milken's wealth. ``The charges are a far cry from the lurid, irresponsible and prejudicial accusations against Michael that have been made by anonymous sources to the press for the past 3{ years,'' Milken attorney Arthur Liman said after the plea. ``It is Michael's hope that ... history will see his violations in context and judge him not just on the basis of his lapses but on the basis of the contributions that he made to the economy and to the American people,'' he said. Under the settlement, Milken agreed to pay $200 million in fines to the Justice Department and to $400 million for a civil fund for reimbursing investors defrauded by his actions. The penalties are the largest against an individual in U.S. history. The government dropped all charges against Milken's brother, Lowell, who was named in the indictment. The status of former Drexel trader Bruce Newberg, also part of the original case, was not yet resolved. Milken also is required to cooperate with the government after his sentencing. The deal settles civil SEC charges and bars Milken permanently from the securities industry. ``We believe that this prosecution and the fact that Mr. Milken has admitted to guilt will send the right message to the financial community,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney John K. Carroll told the court. Carroll said that after sentencing is completed, the public ``should conclude that justice has been done.'' Milken, wearing a blue suit, white shirt and blue polka-dot tie, was composed as he described the work of Drexel's Beverly Hills, Calif.-based junk bond department and his unlawful actions. He broke down in discussing his personal struggle during the four-year investigation. In addition to conspiracy, Milken admitted to: _Violating federal disclosure requirements by failing to record a deal compensating Boesky for trading losses in Fischbach Corp. in 1984. Boesky had acquired more than 10 percent of the takeover target on Milken's recommendation and Milken promised to to cover any trading losses. _Securities fraud involving the sale of MCA Inc. stock by Drexel client Golden Nugget Inc. in the fall of 1984. Milken said he arranged illegal trades to cover losses by Boesky, who agreed to buy blocks of MCA stock to mask sales of large positions and create the appearance of market demand. _Violating federal net capital standards by forcing Drexel to buy more than 1 million shares in Helmerich & Payne Corp. in early 1985 from Boesky's firm, which agreed to buy back the stock at a later date. The transactions were not recorded on the books of Boesky's Seemala Corp. Milken said he was not involved in buying the stock but learned of it later and approved the deal. _Illegal securities trading with Drexel client David Solomon, head of Solomon Asset Management, to recoup some commissions paid by Drexel to a fund managed by Solomon in 1985 and 1986. _Creating short-term capital losses through a series of bond transactions in American Adventure Inc. and Patient Technology Inc. to benefit Solomon's personal income tax liability. Milken said his plea was an admission of personal responsibility ``and not a reflection of the underlying soundness and integrity of the capital markets in which we specialized.'' ``Our business was in no way dependent on these practices,'' he said. ``Nor did they comprise a fundamental part of our business and I regret them very much.'' Junk bonds grew from an obscure form of debt to a $200 billion market almost entirely because of Milken, who controlled a wide network of buyers and sellers and wielded enormous power. The market virtually dried up last fall because of problems involving several large defaults and Milken's departure from the scene. Drexel settled related civil and criminal charges last year by pleading guilty to six felonies and agreeing to pay $650 million in fines and restitution. Milken quit Drexel last June after 19 years to form his own consulting firm. Drexel itself collapsed and has been liquidating since its parent company defaulted on debt payments and filed for bankruptcy court protection in February.

DOC.HEAD: Mobil, Texaco, Shell Report Earnings Declines; Chevron, Phillips Up
DOC.TEXT: Mobil Corp. on Tuesday reported a 7 percent decline in net income in the first quarter, mainly reflecting lower petrochemical earnings, while Texaco Inc.'s net income plummeted 77.4 percent and Shell Oil Co. posted a 44 percent decline. But Chevron Corp. said its first-quarter net income jumped 51 percent while Phillips Petroleum Co. reported a 36.3 percent increase. Nearly all the companies said they benefitted from higher prices of crude oil and natural gas during the quarter. In many cases, the declines in net income were due to special accounting features, while actual proceeds from oil and gas rose. Mobil, the nation's second-largest oil company, said its earnings slipped to $400 million, or 94 cents a share, from $429 million, or $1.04 a share, in the first quarter of 1989. New York-based Mobil said its chemical division had sharply lower earnings, reflecting a worldwide drop in petrochemical prices from record levels a year earlier. Earnings from petroleum operations rose sharply, on the other hand, mainly due to higher crude and gas prices. First-quarter revenue rose 6.4 percent to $14.9 billion from $14.0 billion. Texaco, which ranks third behind Exxon Corp. and Mobil, said its net income fell to $328 million, or $1.15 a share, from $1.45 billion, or $5.91 a share, in the first quarter of 1989. However, results for the year-earlier quarter included a one-time net gain of $1.19 billion resulting mainly from the sale of Texaco Canada Inc. Excluding the restructuring gain, Texaco's first-quarter net income rose 23.8 percent to $328 million from $265 million. ``Texaco's steady performance in the first quarter showed strong (exploration and production) earnings reflecting the higher crude oil and natural gas prices prevailing during the period,'' James W. Kinnear, Texaco's president and chief executive, said. ``However, there has been a weakening in these prices in the second quarter.'' First-quarter revenue declined 4.7 percent to $9.16 billion from $9.61 billion. Fourth-ranked Chevron credited its strong earnings performance to a worldwide increase in the production of oil and gas. Net income for the quarter jumped to $473 million, or $1.33 a share, from $313 million, or 91 cents a share, a year earlier. Chevron's first-quarter revenue rose 20.8 percent to $9.3 billion from $7.7 billion. ``We were able to produce natural gas at record levels, reflecting in part the development of Gulf of Mexico properties purchased from Tenneco in 1988,'' said Chief Executive Officer Ken Derr. The outlook for the second quarter remains unclear because of continued volatility in crude prices, Derr said. Chevron, based in San Francisco, also is working on finalizing several sales of assets that could yield significant net gains this year. Shell, the sixth-largest U.S. oil company with headquarters in Houston, is wholly owned by the Royal Dutch-Shell Group of Companies, a British-Dutch enterprise. It does not report per-share earnings. Shell said the drop in its first-quarter earnings _ to $203 million from $362 million _ was largely due to a $70 million insurance settlement gained in the year-earlier quarter. Revenue increased 11.5 percent to $5.8 billion from $5.2 billion. Phillips, ranked eleventh, said its net income jumped to $259 million, or $1.06 a share, from $190 million, or 78 cents a share. Earnings in the first quarter of this year include a net gain of $148 million from an accounting change and other one-time features. Revenue rose 0.1 percent to $3.13 billion from $3.10 billion.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market stumbled Tuesday when a late round of computer-triggered selling wiped out initial gains and pushed the key index down for the fifth consecutive session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 12.17 to 2,654.50. Since last Tuesday the index has lost 111.27 points. Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 833 down, 652 up and 506 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 137.36 million shares, up slightly from 135.15 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 169.11 million shares. Interest rates continued to be the market's key focus, with stocks mirroring the credit market for much of the session. When bond prices advanced in the early going despite the government's better-than expected report on March durable goods orders, stocks advanced. But when bond prices faltered, their yields rising in tandem, stocks struggled to hold onto initial gains. An hour before the closing bell, computer-triggered sell programs kicked in and took the stock market down. ``Given how light the volume is, the market couldn't recover from that little straw,'' said Dennis Jarrett, chief market analyst at Kidder Peabody & Co. Higher interest rates lower stock valuations and make corporate borrowing more expensive. Alfred E. Goldman, a vice president at A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis, called the market's performance ``a little disappointing because it tried to go up _ both the generals and the troops.'' With plenty of cash on the sidelines, investors so far have not had to dump blocks of stocks in order to buy bonds. But there is concern that the selling of stocks could accelerate if yields go higher. Government bonds yielding close to 9 percent proved an attractive alternative to equities. ``It's a portfolio decision,'' Jarrett said, and ``it could have an impact on our market.'' Some analysts were heartened that the selling was not heavy. ``It did not get nasty,'' said Goldman. He drew encouragement from the fact that bond prices were down only fractionally, an indication that the market seemed to be stabilizing. Ames Department Stores, the most actively traded Big Board issue with 3.8 million shares changing hands, fell | to 1]. The chain hired a bankruptcy lawyer and was reported to be considering seeking Chapter 11 protection from creditors. Elsewhere inthe retail sector, Sears was off 1[ at 35]; the company reported a 59 percent decline in first-quarter profits. Among other actively traded issues, IBM was down { at 108~; Philip Morris was unchanged at 41|; Dupont was down } at 35, and Chrysler was unchanged at 15~. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $6.79 billion, or 0.21 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slipped 0.42 to 181.51. Standard & Poor's industrial index slipped 0.76 to 384.45, and S&P's 500-stock composite index lost 0.69 at 330.36. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 0.89 to 419.19. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 343.89, down 1.06.

DOC.HEAD: Sprint Announces First Product From Partnership With British Firm
DOC.TEXT: US Sprint and London-based Cable & Wireless PLC on Tuesday announced an international business phone service, the first service to come out of a partnership they formed last year. The companies said they will begin offering in September a service that will allow customers in the United States, the United Kingdom and Hong Kong to reach each other with seven-digit numbers, eliminating the international calling codes usually needed. ``It will be just like making a local call,'' said Sprint spokesman Jim Crawford. He said other countries would be added this year to the system, called a virtual private network, but did not name them. Sprint, the No. 3 U.S. long-distance company, and Cable & Wireless, a telecommunications company operating in 40 countries, formed a partnership last year to offer joint telephone services. The companies are joint owners of a trans-Atlantic fiber optic phone cable. The next step in the partnership, Crawford said, will be phone cards available later this year that will allow customers to charge calls to and from participating countries. Sprint cards now only allow customers to charge international calls made from the United States, he said. Kansas City-based Sprint's side of the partnership will be operated by its international subsidiary, Sprint International, based in Reston, Va. Cable & Wireless will operate the partnership through its Mercury Communications Ltd. subsidiary in Great Britain at its Hong Kong Telecom division. Howard McNally, director of AT&T International Communications Services, said AT&T began offering a similar seven-digit dailing service between Great Britain and the United States last June. He said AT&T would add more countries to that service before the end of the year. NcNally said AT&T cards already allows customers to charge calls to the United States from 150 companies. Phone cards from MCI Communications Corp., the No. 2 U.S. long-distance company after AT&T, also offer international calling to and from the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Ames Refuses Comment on Report That It Has Hired Bankruptcy Specialist
DOC.TEXT: Ames Department Stores Inc. maintained silence on its financial woes Tuesday, refusing comment on a report that it has hired a bankruptcy specialist to prepare a court filing to protect Ames from creditors. William Roberts, an Ames spokesman, said the Rocky Hill-based retailer would not comment on a report in The Hartford Courant that said Ames has hired Michael Cook, a bankruptcy specialist at a prominent New York law firm, to begin the paperwork for a filing under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Act. The filing would allow Ames to continue operating while trying to work out a plan to repay its debts. Analysts said bringing in Cook indicates how deep the retailer's fortunes have sunk since it acquired the Zayre discount chain in late 1988. ``When you have a severe stomach ache, you go out and get yourself the best gastric man you can, and at this point, they're looking for someone to get them out of this pickle barrel,'' said Alan Millstein, publisher of The Fashion Network Report, a monthly newsletter for retailers and manufacturers. Jeffrey Branman, managing director for Financo Inc., a New York investment bank that specializes in retail industry transactions, said hiring a bankruptcy specialist could signal an irreversible slide toward Chapter 11. ``It's a terrible sign because it means people are preparing for it,'' said Branman. ``Once you start heading down the slippery slope, it's hard to avoid (Chapter 11).'' Ames bought 392 Zayre discount stores in late 1988, hoping to solve their problems and convert them into a format similar to the successful one used for Ames. Instead, Ames has been suffering from major losses and cash flow shortages since then, and has been trying to negotiate new financing with its bankers since announcing two weeks ago it would post a loss of about $228 million for the fiscal year that ended Jan. 27. Ames officials have maintained a strict silence for the last two weeks on the company's financial problems, and continued that stance Tuesday. ``All I can tell you is we're having discussions that are continuing with our bankers,'' said Roberts. Roberts also refused comment on reports that some manufacturers have suspended shipments to Ames because they fear they will not be paid. The Gitano Group Inc., a New York-based manufacturer of jeans and sportswear, confirmed Tuesday that it had stopped shipments to Ames about three weeks ago when it became concerned about reports of the company's cash flow problems. ``We've taken some pro-active steps to reduce our exposure with Ames,'' Gitano President Haim Dabah said. ``We have stopped shipping goods until the dust clears.'' Another supplier, Pepsi-Cola Co. _ the soft drink division of Pepsico Inc. _ denied earlier reports that it has refused to deliver to Ames unless it is paid in cash. Tod MacKenzie, a spokesman for Pepsi-Cola, said Tuesday that the company is still making regular deliveries to Ames. ``It's business as usual with Ames,'' he said. Retail analysts said Ames made a number of mistakes in the Zayre acquisition, problems that were intensified by a sluggish retail environment in the Northeast, where many of the stores are located. Sales at the Zayre stores have plummeted in recent months, causing a major cash shortage for Ames. The Courant reported that Ames's discussions with its bankers have deteriorated, leaving the company little choice but to seek refuge in bankruptcy court. Roberts, however, insisted that the talks are continuing. According to the Courant, 20 institutions that own about $100 million of Ames's bonds have formed a committee, hired a financial adviser, and proposed that they meet with the company's investment bankers to begin negotiating a repayment plan or debt restructuring. The Courant also reported that Citibank, the lead bank in a group of 20 that has granted $900 million of credit to Ames, has hired Keen Realty Consultants of Long Island, N.Y., to begin evaluating the value of leases Ames holds on its 680 discount department stores. The retailer operates stores in 20 states and Washington. Analysts said Ames still has a chance to avoid bankruptcy if some agreement can be reached in the next few days for the company's banks to provide cash to the retailer.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T To Offer Digital Dial-Up Calls to France
DOC.TEXT: AT&T said Tuesday it would expand its international dial-up digital phone service to France on May 15. American Telephone & Telegraph Co. already offers the digital service, called the Integrated Services Digital Network, to Great Britain and Japan. The digital lines are used to send computer data, video conferences, high-speed fax and high-fidelity audio. ISDN also allows users to send digital data, such as a computer file, at the same time they are having a phone conversation.

DOC.HEAD: Insurance, Merchandising Losses Send Sears Earnings Skidding
DOC.TEXT: First-quarter earnings at Sears, Roebuck and Co. plunged nearly 59 percent because of higher-than-normal catastrophe claims for Allstate Insurance Group and a loss in the Sears Merchandise Group, the company said Tuesday. Sears reported first-quarter net income of $106.3 million, or 31 cents per share, compared with $257.7 million, or 70 cents per share, in the same period a year earlier. Revenue rose 3.7 percent fo $12.61 billion from $12.16 billion in 1989, with all business groups reporting record revenue. Sears Merchandise Group lost $37.4 million in the first quarter of 1990, compared with income of $33.8 million for the same period last year, despite a 1.3 percent increase in revenue. ``Although lower merchandising results were expected, pressure on gross margins as well as higher selling costs resulted in an unsatisfactory performance,'' said Sears chairman Edward A. Brennan in a news release. The revenue increase was offset by rising payroll costs, added spokesman Douglas A. Fairweather. Allstate reported first-quarter income of $193.2 million, compared with $243.9 million in the first quarter of 1989. ``Those losses were mostly due to the earthquake (in California) and the freezes in late 1989 in the Southwest and the Southeast,'' Fairweather said. ``With events like that, you can't really get a totally accurate handle on your costs immediately,'' he said. ``In the case of a freeze, you have to wait for a thaw to assess damages, and the thaw came in the first quarter of this year.'' The Dean Witter Financial Services Group had first-quarter income of $60.7 million, up 62 percent from last year. That increase was sparked by a 76 percent jump in income from Discover Card operations, to $35.4 million. The Coldwell Banker Real Estate Group reported a loss of $33.5 million, compared with a loss of $16.2 million loss in the first three months of last year.

DOC.HEAD: Precious Metals Futures Slide On Interest Rate Rise
DOC.TEXT: Precious metal futures prices fell Tuesday, reflecting a general lack of investor interest in gold and silver in the face of rising interest rates. On other commodity markets, copper futures rose sharply, grains and soybeans retreated; energy futures were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Gold futures settled $3 to $3.10 lower on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in April at $375.90 a troy ounce; silver was 10 cents lower across the board with May at about $5 a troy ounce. Platinum futures fell $6.50 across the board on the New York Mercantile Exchange, where the contract for July delivery settled at $487.80 a troy ounce. The retreat followed a strong rally Monday in the platinum market, which was linked to speculation that South African political activist Nelson Mandela was preparing to take a more militant stance against apartheid, posing a threat of possible platinum supply disruptions. The Mandela rumors were discounted Tuesday and as platinum futures fell, the gold and silver markets followed, said William O'Neill, research director with Elders Futures Inc. in New York. The gold and silver markets kept tumbling, though, even after platinum selling dwindled. O'Neill said the weak tone reflected the outlook for higher interest rates, which tends to discourage investor demand for precious metals. Government bonds yields of close to 9 percent are ``a major negative for the precious metals,'' O'Neill said. ``Some of the optimism about rates that existed a few weeks ago is completely by the boards now,'' he said, nurturing a bearish attitude that is ``steadily weighing on and eroding the precious metals.'' Copper futures climbed strongly on the Commodity Exchange amid a resurgence of buying interest by copper users on indications of tight supplies of the metal available for delivery against the April contract, which expires Thursday. Further buying was inspired by a report that officials of Chile's Codelco copper company had lowered their estimate for 1990 production from the country's state-owned copper mines to 1.2 million to 1.25 million tons from an earlier estimate of 1.29 million tons. Copper futures settled 1.8 cents to 4.9 cents higher with April at $1.24 a pound. Grain and soybean futures prices fell substantially on the Chicago Board of Trade, led by a technically inspired sell-off in the soybean market, analysts said. Wheat futures settled 2{ cents to 5 cents lower with May at $3.67} a bushel; corn was { cent to 2 cents lower with May at $2.76 a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1\ cents lower with May at $1.57 a bushel; soybeans were 4 cents to 7\ cents lower with May at $5.98{ a bushel. Oil futures finished mixed on the New York Mercantile Exchange ahead of the American Petroleum Institute's weekly stocks report. The report, released after the close, showed an expected increase in U.S. refinery activity, a fairly large 1.2-million-barrel increase in U.S. crude oil stocks, a 926,000-barrel drop in gasoline stocks and a 752,000-barrel decline in heating oil stocks. The build in crude stocks extends a pattern of oversupply that has been linked to overproduction by the OPEC nations. But the higher refinery activity is a seasonal factor that may offset the market impact of the rise in oil stocks. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 7 cents lower to 14 cents higher with June at $19 a barrel; heating oil was .47 cent lower to .30 cent higher with May at 52.65 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .15 cent to .85 cent higher with May at 64.39 cents a gallon. Cattle futures fell sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange amid weaker cash markets for cattle and beef; pork futures ended mixed on profit taking after Monday's strong gains. Live cattle settled .35 cent to .95 cent lower with June at 73.07 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .75 cent lower with April at 83.85 cents a pound; live hogs were .28 cent lower to .12 cent higher with June at 61.82 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .65 cent lower to .50 cent higher with May at 64.40 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Chairman: Milken Stood at Center of Fraud Network
With AM-Milken Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Michael Milken's future cooperation with federal investigators is expected to yield valuable information for other cases, the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission said Tuesday. But Richard Breeden declined to specify the particular areas in which investigators would seek information from the financier, who hours earlier pleaded guilty to tax and securities law crimes as part of a plea bargain with the government. ``This case clearly does involve some significant ramifications,'' Breeden told a news conference. ``We do expect that the testimony and cooperation that we will receive will be valuable in the context of other ongoing proceedings and proceedings that may be commenced.'' Milken, former head of the high-yield ``junk'' bond operation of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., also agreed to cooperate with investigators under the plea bargain that settled the wide-ranging criminal indictment against he and his brother, Lowell. The deal also settles civil charges brought by the SEC, which barred both Milkens permanently from the securities business. Michael Milken will pay fines and restitution totaling $600 million, including $400 million to a civil fund for reimbursing investors defrauded by his actions, and faces up to 28 years imprisonment. Breeden said that under Milken's agreement the financier might have to take the witness stand in other proceedings that might stem from his cooperation with prosecutors. There has been speculation that one area of interest would be the thrift industry, where a number of troubled institutions were clients of Milken and Drexel. Breeden was asked whether the government's probe would extend to Milken's dealings with the thrifts, but said he could not specify how investigators would use the information Milken provided. He said both the SEC and Justice Department expected much of the information generated by their investigations of the Milkens would prove useful. ``...But I would not be willing speculate on which specific cases or what area of the financial market they might involve,'' Breeden said. In its civil case, the SEC in September 1988 accused Milken, his brother, Lowell, and several others of a scheme that included allegations of insider trading, securities fraud and other violations. Among other allegations, the SEC charged that Milken and Drexel had ``a secret arrangement'' with Ivan Boesky, the convicted stock speculator who linked them to his insider trading network. ``Mr. Milken has been portrayed as wrongly accused, and as having simply devoted himself to the financing of small or emerging business,'' Breeden said, noting the public relations campaigns Milken and Drexel had waged in fighting the government's charges. ``Despite the efforts to mold public opinion, Mr. Milken's admissions today demonstrate that he stood at the center of a network of manipulation, fraud and deceit,'' said Breeden. ``The key question is always `Does the penalty fit the crime?''' said Breeden. ``In this case we are extremely pleased with the result. We're extremely pleased with an admission of six felonies and the potential here that the perpetrator of these crimes will face up to 28 years in prison. We think that's a good settlement.'' He said if the case had gone to trial, it would have taken years before victims saw any compensation. Breeden also noted that Milken faces up to 28 years in prison and ``contrary to some reports, the government will not recommend concurrent sentences.''

DOC.HEAD: USW Opposes Icahn's USX Plan
DOC.TEXT: The United Steelworkers of America said Tuesday it opposed Carl Icahn's proposal to break up USX Corp.'s steel and energy assets. ``The Icahn proposal would represent, in our view, another erroneous step away from USX's traditional corporate purpose,'' the union said in a statement. ``The USWA believes that such a step is not in the long-term interest ofthe employees or shareholders of USX.'' Icahn, USX's largest shareholder, has proposed spinning off the company's steel business, saying two separate companies will be worth more than one to shareholders. The plan will be put to a non-binding vote of stockholders at the company's annual meeting May 7 in Findlay, Ohio. The union's statement was approved April 18 by 46 union local presidents representing 18,000 members employed by USX. It was reviewed by the Securities and Exchange Commission before being released. ``The Icahn proposal, in our view, would continue the USX's steady surrender of its interest in steel production _ creating a weaker steel company which would be far more susceptible to cyclical downturns in the economy and less able to modernize and profit substantially during upturns,'' the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Milken, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are the six federal securities and tax law violations outlined in financier Michael Milken's guilty plea in U.S. District Court on Tuesday:
DOC.HEAD: COUNT ONE
DOC.TEXT: Conspiracy. The government said Milken, former stock speculator Ivan F. Boesky, Drexel client David Solomon of Solomon Asset Management and others conspired to violated federal tax and securities laws. The conspiracy involved transactions detailed in the five other counts, including illegal stock trades hidden from federal regulators, secret records kept separate from Drexel's official books, tax evasion and federal securities rules violations. The government said Milken and the others profited from transactions while investors were cheated.
DOC.HEAD: COUNT TWO
DOC.TEXT: Aiding and abetting the filing of false documents with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The government said the violation was designed to help Boesky by concealing his stock holdings in Fischbach Corp., a construction business that was the subject of a takeover attempt by Pennsylvania Engineering Corp. Milken admitted that he failed to record a deal compensating Boesky for trading losses in Fischbach from April 1984 to February 1985. Boesky had acquired more than 10 percent of Fischbach on Milken's recommendation and Milken promised to to cover any trading losses. The government said Boesky lost several million dollars buying Fischbach stock, which Drexel more than made up for under the secret arrangement.
DOC.HEAD: COUNT THREE
DOC.TEXT: Securities fraud. Milken admitted to arranging a secret purchase by Boesky of MCA Corp. stock held by Drexel client Golden Nugget Inc. from March to November 1984. Golden Nugget, a Las Vegas-based casino operator, had purchased $99 million in MCA stock during a planned takeover of the entertainment giant. the government said Milken induced Boesky to buy about 875,000 shares of MCA stock to try to hide from the market that Golden Nugget was dumping its position. The move was designed to prop up the price of MCA stock, which would have fallen if word of the large sales by Golden Nugget became public. Boesky's illegal purchases created the false appearance of wide market demand.
DOC.HEAD: COUNT FOUR
DOC.TEXT: Aiding and abetting the violation of SEC reporting requirements for broker-dealers. The government said Drexel in 1985 bought about 1 million shares of Helmerich & Payne Corp. stock worth more than $20 million from Boesky and agreed to hold the stock for Boesky, who in turn promised to to make up any losses suffered by Drexel. Drexel later sold some of the stock back to Boesky. The deal allowed Boesky to cheat on his taxes, free up cash to buy more stock and overstate the amount of net capital in his Seemala Corp., the government said. By failing to report the stock sales, Milken helped Boesky violate federal laws, the government said.
DOC.HEAD: COUNT FIVE
DOC.TEXT: Mail fraud. Milken said he persuaded Solomon to become a manager for Finsbury Group Ltd., a Drexel-organized international investment fund. Drexel's junk bond department in Beverly Hills, Calif., paid fees to salesmen who marketed the Finsbury shares, and Solomon then funneled money back to the junk bond department by setting up deals between Drexel and Solomon's clients. The government said Milken adjusted transaction prices to provide cash that could go back to Drexel, but Solomon's clients were kept in the dark about the arrangement. The arrangement involved transactions from 1984 to 1986.
DOC.HEAD: COUNT SIX
DOC.TEXT: Aiding and abetting the filing of a false tax return. Milken admitted setting up prearranged trades that allowed Solomon to claim short-term capital losses and reduce his 1985 tax liability. Milken and Solomon set up the deal with an understanding that Milken would pay back Solomon for his losses the following year. Milken in 1986 let Solomon acquire a limited partnership interest that Solomon sold for a profit that was higher than the earlier, bogus losses, the government said.

DOC.HEAD: Commodore Announces Multimedia Software, Networking Products
DOC.TEXT: Commodore Business Machines Inc. on Tuesday announced a multimedia computer software that the computer company says will make it much easier to compile computer presentations that combine text, graphics, video and sound. The software, called AmigaVision, is aimed at teachers, presentation and exhibit professionals, computer-based trainers and others who lack intensive computer know-how. The software, which will be priced at $149 and available in May, is for use on Commodore personal computers only. Commodore, based in West Chester, Pa., also announced here a new model in its Amiga personal computer line, the Amiga 3000, and its first line of products to link Amiga computers in a network.

DOC.HEAD: Friends Were There For Milken in Poignant Courtroom Moment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Deletes extraneous words in lead
DOC.TEXT: While friends and family watched, Michael Milken's voice stumbled and cracked as one of the financial world's most prominent figures confronted his own words: guilty. It was a stunning and poignant moment of truth even for veteran visitors to Manhattan federal court, where towering figures ranging from John Mitchell to Leona Helmsley have been digested and spit out as felons. ``It's a tragedy to see history's greatest financier so humbled,'' said Theodore Wells, a prominent defense attorney and one of many Milken supporters who witnessed his admission that he broke the law. ``I believe there was an injustice done,'' said Lorraine Spurge, a longtime Milken colleague at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s junk bond department in Beverly Hills, Calif., who works at his new consulting firm. ``I believe he is a very brave man.'' The atmosphere was hushed and solemn. Spectators sat on the edge of the benches, straining to hear Milken sobbingly plead guilty to six charges securities and tax law violations. About 250 reporters, sketch artists, lawyers and friends waited for more than an hour in the hallway and then crammed into the U.S. District Court in lower Manhattan. It was the same courtroom in which Milken, flanked by his attorneys, Arthur Liman and Martin Flumenbaum, pleaded innocent to a 98-count racketeering and fraud indictment on March 29, 1989. Then, Milken promised to fight what he called spurious allegations through the criminal justice system. On Tuesday, he did the opposite. The 43-year-old son of an accountant entered the courtroom from a rear door and answered in a firm voice Judge Kimba Wood's questions about whether he understood he was giving up his constitutional right to a jury trial. It was later, when Milken ended his 10-minute statement to the court with an apology, that he broke down in sobs. ``This investigation and proceeding are now in their fourth year,'' he said, choking on the words. ``This long period has been extremely painful and difficult for my family and friends as well as myself.'' Liman placed his hand on Milken's back to support the fallen financier. Milken then slumped into a chair and took a few minutes to compose himself, sipping water from a plastic foam cup. He stood again, and Wood asked: ``Mr. Milken, how do you plead to the charges ... guilty or not guilty?'' Milken's voice cracked on the first word. ``Guilty, your honor.'' ``After being charged with 98 counts and four years of being harassed, it's very difficult for anyone to stand that kind of situation,'' Martin Klein, a bankruptcy attorney and Milken friend, said later. The only levity occurred when Wood asked Assistant U.S. Attorney John Carroll whether the $600 million Milken agreed to pay covered the cost of the government's investigation. ``If you see my W-2 form, it does by a long shot,'' Carroll said, prompting some laughter. Milken's arrival and departure from the courthouse were chronicled by a throng of photographers and camera crews lining the courthouse's steps. Milken _ with wife Lori on his arm _ appeared dazed as he stepped out of his black car. Several marshals helped the couple through the crush, shoving away photographers who surged forward. Other family members in court were Milken's mother, his father-in-law and his brother, Lowell, who was cleared of all wrongdoing as part of the plea deal. On the courthouse steps, one young man who said he worked in the financial sector but declined to give his name said he was a Milken fan. ``He's a financial wizard,'' he said. ``He just got greedy.''

DOC.HEAD: First-Qtr Profit Declines at USX, Bethlehem Steel
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. said Tuesday its first-quarter profit fell 40 percent from results that included one-time gains a year ago, while Bethlehem Steel Corp. reported its earnings for the quarter tumbled 67.1 percent. USX, a Pittsburgh-based oil and steel giant, said it earned $176 million, or 66 cents per share, in the latest three months compared with $296 million, or $1.09 per share, a year earlier. Its sales rose 4.4 percent to $4.7 billion from $4.5 billion a year earlier. Reults for the first quarter of 1989 included favorable special items of $197 million in operating income and a $74 million pre-tax gain from asset disposals, the company said. ``Excluding these 1989 special items, income before tax improved by $71 million from the first quarter of last year,'' Chairman Charles Corry said in a statement. He said the company's Marathon Oil subsidiary had a strong quarter, while the company's steel operations improved as the quarter progressed. ``Our steel order book has been stronger than anticipated since the end of February,'' he said. Corry said first-quarter results demonstrate the success of a restructuring program that began a decade ago. ``The energy and steel combination that has emerged has permitted the company to perform well under widely varying business conditions ... Steel earned more operating income than energy in 1988 and in 1989 the reverse was true,'' he said. Carl Icahn, USX's largest shareholder, wants to spin off the company's steel business, saying two separate companies will be worth more than one. The plan will be put to a non-binding vote of USX stockholders at the company's May 7 annual meeting in Findlay, Ohio. USX's operating income for the first quarter was $354 million, compared with $514 million in the first quarter of 1989. USX's energy segment reported operating income of $237 million on sales of $3.3 billion in the first quarter. That compared with operating income of $388 million on sales of $2.8 billion in the same period last year. USX's steel segment reported first-quarter operating income of $60 million on sales of $1.3 billion. In the first quarter of last year, the segment posted operating income of $99 million on sales of $1.5 billion. The declines in steel operating income and sales were primarily attributed to lower steel prices and the effects of the sale of Lorain Works in Ohio to a 50 percent-owned joint venture in the second quarter of last year, USX said. Bethlehem Steel said slumping steel markets and higher operating costs resulted in the decline in its profit. The Bethlehem, Pa.-based company said it had net income of $21.3 million, or 20 cents per share, in the quarter, down from $64.7 million, or 78 cents a share, a year ago. Net sales fell to $1.22 billion from $1.40 billion last year. Steel shipments were 19 percent lower than a year ago and raw steel production dropped to 70 percent of capacity from 82 percent. Income from basic steel operations was $29 million this past quarter, compared with $137 million for the same period last year. ``Steel demand was particularly strong in early 1989, and the lower shipments in the first quarter of 1990 resulted from weaker demand, primarily from the construction and automotive markets, reduced shipments of semifinished steel to other steel producers, and competitive pressures in the structural products market,'' chairman Walter F. Williams said in a statement. Increased costs were attributable to modernization and repair projects at the Sparrows Point plant and blast furnace interruptions at Burns Harbor, the company said. A new contract with the United Steelworkers of America that began June 1, 1989 boosted employment costs, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Approves Relaxing Limits on Computer Sales to East Europe
DOC.TEXT: A House panel on Tuesday approved legislation to relax restrictions on the sale of computers and other high-tech items to Eastern Europe. ``At a time when an already impatient Germany is reunifying, merging Europe's greatest industrial power with the nation that had the closest ties to the Soviets, we must reconsider the structure of our export control system,'' said Rep. Sam Gejdenson, D-Conn., chairman of the House subcommittee on international economic policy and trade. The measure, which now goes to the House Foreign Affairs Committee, would allow the sale of many items, but it would draw a clear line between munitions and other technologies. It would also clarify the role of the Defense Department and it would increase penalties for willful violation of the act.

DOC.HEAD: Government Approves Michelin Acquisition of Uniroyal Goodrich
DOC.TEXT: The government has decided to allow Michelin Group to proceed with its scheduled $1.5 billion acquisition of Uniroyal Goodrich Tire Co., Uniroyal Goodrich said Tuesday. The tire maker said the U.S. Justice Department's antitrust division had informed Uniroyal Goodrich that Michelin Group could acquire the company as scheduled. The French-based Michelin announced last Sept. 22 that it would pay $1.5 billion to acquire Uniroyal Goodrich and create the world's largest tire maker. Michelin paid $690 million and assumed $810 million in debt in the takeover.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Back Bill to Consolidate Housing Program Grants
DOC.TEXT: Two Northeast senators said Tuesday they would sponsor a bipartisan bill combining nine major housing programs into a single grant that would be distributed to states and cities. Sens. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., and Chris Dodd, D-Conn., said they were offering their proposal as a way to speed up rehabilitation and construction of subsidized housing and give local governments more control. Their proposal ran into a cool reception from Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack Kemp. Kemp's spokeswoman, Mary Brunette, said the idea was ``kind of at odds with our approach.'' She said giving the money directly to local governments comes as HUD is seeking greater federal oversight over local public housing authorities. Their proposal would combine money from nine categorical HUD programs into a new Housing Grant Action Program. The consolidated programs include the 202 elderly and handicapped housing program, the scandal-plagued moderate rehabilitation program, public and Indian housing programs, and the Housing Development Action Grant program. They program would not provide increased federal money but would continue them at current levels, totaling $7.1 billion. The money would be distributed by formula, with 70 percent to local governments and 30 percent to states.

DOC.HEAD: 1st-Qtr Profit Down 33 Percent at Times Mirror as Ad Revenue Falls
DOC.TEXT: Times Mirror Corp. said Tuesday its first-quarter profit fell 33 percent, largely because of an advertising slowdown that hit its Northeastern newspapers, consumer magazines and broadcast TV operations. For the quarter ending April 1, Times Mirror's earnings fell to $46 million, or 36 cents per share, down from $68.8 million, or 53 cents per share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 3.3 percent to $875.2 million from $846.9 million. But Times Mirror said its slide in earnings was partially attributable to higher promotional costs and higher circulation that pushed up operating costs at the Los Angeles Times. ``Although our professional publishing and cable television operations achieved solid earnings growth during the quarter, their performance only partially offset the marked deterioration in our newspaper publishing segment,'' said Robert F. Erburu, Times Mirror's chairman and chief executive. Ad volume was slow at the Northeastern newspapers, with Newsday and New York Newsday suffering from a depressed New York economy, Times Mirror said. The 1990 first quarter also had one less Sunday than the year-earlier period, which reduced revenues. Despite increased revenues at the Los Angeles Times, a surge in circulation increased operating costs, contributing to a 38 percent decline in operating profit from newspapers. Times Mirror said its companywide circulation, as reported to the Audit Bureau of Circulations but not yet verified, rose 4.1 percent for the daily papers and 3.2 percent on Sunday over the past six months. At the Los Angeles Times, daily circulation during the same period rose by 8.1 percent to 1,210,077, with Sunday circulation up 5.7 percent to 1,504,540, the company said. Publisher David Laventhol estimated half the increase was from former readers of the now-closed Herald Examiner. New York Newsday grew by 11.6 percent to 217,514 daily circulation during the six months, and The Hartford (Conn.) Courant reported a 2.2 percent rise to 230,358, the company said. Although consumer magazines also were affected by the advertising slowdown, the book, magazine and other publishing segment still had a 13.6 percent increase in quarterly revenues and 21.7 percent growth in operating profit due to gains by the legal publishing, flight information and training businesses.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices End Mixed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf pvs, `Yields on... to CORRECT change in discount rates; PICKS UP 15th graf, `A basis...
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices finished mixed Tuesday, as short-term issues declined while longer-term issues were unchanged to slightly higher. The Treasury's closely watched 30-year bond edged up 1-32 point, or 31 cents for every $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which falls when prices rise, slipped to 8.95 percent from 8.96 percent late Monday. Through Monday, the 30-year bond had plunged more than $41 per $1,000 over seven trading days in response to signs of increasing inflation, a stronger economy and worries about upcoming bond issues, including the Treasury's quarterly refunding auction set for next month. Higher inflation and an economic upturn could prompt the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates high. Higher rates erode the value of fixed-return investments such as bonds. Analysts said bond prices recovered Tuesday morning but later were driven lower by unconfirmed rumors that the Fed planned to tighten interest rates in the near future. Jay Goldinger, a principal of Capital Insight Inc. in Beverly Hills, Calif., described the market as ``very jittery''. ``Behind every buyer they think there's the ghost of another seller,'' he said. The government reported Tuesday that orders to U.S. factories for du part of a personal vendetta within the commission staff. Stello, in two confirmation appearances before the Senate Armed Services Committee last fall, strongly denied that he acted improperly. He asserted that nuclear safety was his primary concern in 24 years as a regulator. The Armed Services Committee had been set to recommend Stello's confirmation in January but balked upon learning that he was the focus of an investigation by David Williams, the inspector general of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Williams is investigating allegations that Stello and other officials pursued a vendetta against Roger Fortuna, a commission official in charge of investigating wrongdoing at nuclear plants. The allegation was that Stello felt Fortuna was too hard on the industry. The results of the Williams probe have not been made public, but in his letter to Bush, Stello noted that the Armed Services Committee planned to hold up further consideration of his nomination until it reviewed the results of Williams' investigation. ``My experience over this past year has lead me to the conclusion that final action by the Senate on my nomination will not take place in the foreseeable future,'' he wrote. Stello also wrote that ``aspects of my personal health'' also played a role in his decision. He suffered serious injuries in a skiiing accident in January. ``This accident has given me an opportunity to more sharply focus on those matters which I consider of significant personal importance,'' he wrote without elaborating. Stello said he believed it was important that Bush find someone who can quickly be confirmed in the job of weapons chief, in order that work under way to resuscitate the aging bomb-production complex not be hindered by political bickering. ``In my view, it is in the interest of our country for you to identify another nominee for this critical position,'' he wrote. Energy Secretary James D. Watkins had no immediate comment on Stello's decision to withdraw, said Catherine Kaliniak, a department spokeswoman. Last fall, Watkins told the Armed Services Committee at the outset of Stello's confirmation hearings that he could find no other qualified individual willing to take the job, which he called ``one of the toughest jobs in government.'' Olson said he could not comment on whether Watkins had found a nominee to replace Stello.

DOC.HEAD: Santa Fe Pacific to Spin Off Oil, Realty Subsidiaries
DOC.TEXT: Santa Fe Pacific Corp. said Tuesday it plans to spin off its energy and real estate subsidiaries to shareholders by the end of the year, leaving the company focused on its railroad operations. The company plans to sell its stake of over 80 percent in Santa Fe Energy Resources and Santa Fe Realty Co. in the third quarter of this year, Orval Adam, vice president and chief financial officer, said at the company's annual shareholder meeting. ``We've been trying to separate those companies so shareholders would have the benefit of separate management and separate investment possibilities,'' Adam said. ``We've had a gas and oil exploration company, a real estate company and a railroad. When you invest in a company, you like to know what you're investing in. If you want to invest in real estate, your money should go into real estate.'' The spinoffs are contingent on the company refinancing a $780 million payment-in-kind debenture and a ruling from the Internal Revenue Service that the spinoffs constitute a tax-free dividend, the company said. Santa Fe Pacific will continue to operate the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway. The spinoffs are unrelated to recent poor performance by the railroad, which announced Monday it would lay off 850 workers nationwide due to downturns in shipments of automobiles and grain, Adam said. ``The last couple of months here have not been up to snuff and we're looking toward making some expense cuts,'' Adam said. ``But the spinoff has been a longer-term objective in our restructuring. Poor performance in one month or a couple of months won't affect that.'' Santa Fe Pacific Realty, a San Francisco-based developer, holds about 2 million acres of developed and undeveloped land in 13 states, Adam said. The company holds 10.7 million square feet of developed industrial, office and retail space, has 1.8 million square feet under construction, he said. It plans to develop nearly 27 million square feet in the next five years, he added. Santa Fe Energy Resources, based in Houston, is an independent oil and gas company. It had reserves of 251 million barrels of oil equivalent at the end of 1989, Adam said. Daily production in 1989 averaged more than 50,000 barrels of oil and almost 82 million cubic feet of natural gas, he said. Following the spinoffs, Santa Fe Pacific will continue to own and operate the railway and Santa Fe Pacific Minerals Corp., and will retain its 44 percent interest in Santa Fe Pacific Pipeline Partners, Adam said. After the stockholders meeting, Richard D. Foley, chairman of the American Employees Stock Ownership Association, announced the filing of a shareholder suit against the company. The suit seeks recovery of fees and costs arising from a proxy fight in 1988 protesting the company's shareholder rights plan. The fight resulted in a revision of the plan that would allow fully financed offers if they receive approval from 80 percent of the shareholders. Jerome F. Donohoe of Santa Fe Pacific's legal department said the company had rejected a request from Foley for about $600,000 in fees and costs.

DOC.HEAD: Syndicate Owner Says He Required Features Transfer
DOC.TEXT: A Universal Press Syndicate owner said Tuesday he insisted The Dallas Morning News take all of his company's features that had been appearing in the rival Dallas Times Herald. ``Old Harry S. Truman said, `The buck stops here,''' UPS co-owner John McMeel testified in Harris County District Court. ``I'll take the heat. The buck stops here.'' McMeel testified at the trial over the Times Herald's $33 million antitrust lawsuit against the Morning News. The Times Herald said the UPS deal with the Morning News unfairly turned over to its larger competitor features and comics that included Doonesbury, Dear Abby and Erma Bombeck. McMeel said he made his request as UPS was negotiating a joint television venture with the Morning News and its parent company, A.H. Belo Corp. Although Morning News Editor Burl Osborne for years had been inquiring about the availability of two UPS comics _ Doonesbury and The Far Side, which were appearing in the Times Herald _ McMeel said he would consider the joint venture only if the newspaper took all 26 features. ``I had to make it very plain,'' McMeel said. ``I was not going to just take two features out of the Dallas Times Herald. I just wasn't going to do it. This (television opportunity) was a project we had been waiting for. I said everything had to get out so we can evaluate the whole package.'' The Times Herald is seeking $33 million in actual damages, plus unspecified punitive damages in the trial, which is in its fourth week. The case is expected to go to the jury next week. The Times Herald contends the comics transfer was a deliberate move by The Morning News and Belo to build a monopoly in Dallas and drive the Times Herald out of business. The Morning News and Belo have denied any wrongdoing. The joint venture, known as Universal Belo, is producing television programs based on characters appearing in comic strips syndicated by Kansas City-based UPS. In his second day of testimony, McMeel said competing syndicates already were involved in television programming and the joint venture was ``a matter of survival.'' McMeel said he also feared a ``hostile environment'' at the Times Herald if UPS canceled only Doonesbury and The Far Side. Asked if the loss of the features could help close the newspaper, he replied: ``Absolutely not.'' McMeel said the Times Herald was not given a chance to bid on the television project because the venture was breaking new ground. ``The objective was to create an entity and you don't bid on an entity,'' he said. ``This was something new.'' Under cross examination by Times Herald attorney Wayne Fisher, McMeel said he could not enter a television deal with Belo while UPS features remained in the Times Herald. ``Belo Corp. was not going to be enthusiastic about superstars being created across the street at the Dallas Times Herald,'' he said. Fisher tried to show that at the time the joint venture discussions took place, the features remained under contract with the Times Herald. He also alleged that Osborne proposed the transfer, but McMeel disputed that contention.

DOC.HEAD: Tampa CPA Named GDC Examiner
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge named an examiner to probe some of the tangled affairs of General Development Corp., which has admitted overpricing homes and deceiving buyers about their value. The examiner is Kathleen Durdin, a certified public accountant and a vice president of Peterson and Company, a Tampa managment consulting firm. David Bird, assistant U.S. Trustee for the Southern District of Florida, told U.S. Bankruptcy Judge A. Jay Cristol on Tuesday that the GDC creditors' committee settled on Durdin after interviewing 11 applicants Monday. General Development filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy April 6, claiming a severe cash shortage after failing to secure $60 million in short-term credit. The Miami-based developer and its two top executives pleaded guilty last month in federal court to mail-fraud conspiracy for overpricing thousands of homes and lying to the buyers. Last week, Cristol approved a plan that allows GDC to receive $10.5 million in temporary financing for six weeks while it arranges permanent financing. General Development already owes $175 million to the eight banks who guaranteed the interim financing. In making the appointment official, Cristol said Ms. Durdin ``was not to take over the management or the creditors committee'' of GDC but was to work with the court-appointed officials to bring about a reorganization. Cristol also said he has recommended that U.S. District Judge Lenore Nesbitt, who is scheduled to sentence GDC officials and the company on May 22, delay sentencing until after July 4 to allow more time for the formulation of a restitution agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Hallmark Says It Accepted 93 Percent of Univision Bonds Under Tender Offer
DOC.TEXT: Hallmark Cards Inc. said it had accepted for payment 93 percent of the $270 million in junk bonds issued by its Univision Holdings Inc. subsidiary under a tender offer that is part of a debt restructuring.
