Hallmark said Tuesday it had accepted $161.7 million of Univision's senior subordinated discount notes due 1998, or 98 percent of the issue outstanding, and $89.9 million of the company's 13] percent subordinated debentures, or 86 percent. Under its offer, Hallmark is paying $131 million for the two series of junk bonds on which its 63.5 percent-owned Univision unit had missed interest payments. It has agreed to defer interest payments on the securities it purchases under the tender offer for five years. Hallmark, a privately held greetings card company based in Kansas City, Mo., last week extended its offer period until Tuesday after dropping a requirement that at least 90 percent of each issue be tendered before it would buy the issues. Hallmark also announced last week it had reached agreement with Univision's bank lenders to restructure the subsidiary's bank debt. Univision, based in New York, operates an eight-station Spanish-language TV network that reaches an estimated 92 percent of Hispanic households in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Hostile-Takeover Bill on Way to Governor
DOC.TEXT: Despite a last-minute attempt by opponents to buy more time, the Pennsylvania House on Tuesday sent Gov. Robert P. Casey a bill that would enact the nation's toughest curbs against hostile takeovers. After a brief debate, the House approved the bill 183-17. The Senate gave its final backing to the measure Monday. Casey has said he would sign the bill. Administration spokesman John Taylor said the governor has 10 days to act on it. Supporters of the measure praised its protections for workers and said it would help business thrive in Pennsylvania. Rep. Marvin E. Miller Jr. said the bill would ``serve as the fundamental basis for economic development for the future.'' ``By passing this we're sending a loud and clear message that people can't make simple, quick chop shops out of our corporations,'' he said. The Republican lawmaker represents the city of Lancaster, whose leading employer was the target of a takeover attempt that spawned the bill. The Belzberg family of Canada last year tried to take over Armstrong World Industries Inc., a floor and tile manufacturer. Under the bill, a raider who tried to sell shares within 18 months of a takeover bid would be forced to give up short-term profits. The bill also would deny raiders voting rights until a majority of a corporation's stockholders approved. Passage came easily despite gloomy warnings the bill would make Pennsylvania less competitive with other states and would protect bad managers. ``This is bad for labor in Pennsylvania, bad for Pennsylvania business and bad for the state of Pennsylvania,'' said Rep. Robert Godshall. ``This would strip any basic and fundamental rights of stockholders.'' The bill also would allow management to weigh the interests of employees, customers or the community, rather than just shareholders, when considering takeover bids. If corporate ownership changes hands, labor contracts would have to be honored and severance would be paid to laid- off workers. Up to 90 days after the law takes effect, corporations would be able to exempt themselves from the legislation. Members of the investment community, including the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, have criticized the bill, saying it would entrench management and deny shareholders' rights. With the junk bond market in shambles and takeovers on the wane, some critics have argued that the legislation is overkill. But supporters, including state business and labor interests, argue it will protect jobs and communities while giving shareholders long-term stability. William Titelman, lawyer for the Belzberg family, predicted the bill would scare investors from putting money into Pennsylvania corporations. ``I think it's a very sad day, a dangerous day, because we are now confronted with a bill that has been properly perceived by investors across the country and even overseas as a piece of legislation which tells them that Pennsylvania is not a good place to invest,'' Titelman said.

DOC.HEAD: Milken Foundations Say They'll Weather Wall Street Scandal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 16th graf, `Even in ...' with California probe of charities; picks up 16th graf pvs, `Richard Riordan ...'
DOC.TEXT: The charitable foundations Michael Milken and his brother endowed with hundreds of millions of dollars will carry on, and the notoriety of his Wall Street fraud case probably will generate even more demands for help, their director said. Skeptics question the motives for the Milkens' philanthropy, which became more high-profile after the government revealed its investigation of him for alleged racketeering and other crimes. But friends and beneficiaries of Milken's largesse say his charity work began long before the probe and was performed with an intensity mirroring his deal making, particularly when children were involved. ``Some people make snide remarks and say, `He's just trying to atone,''' said Melba F. Coleman, the principal of 102nd Street School in Watts. ``I say look at the record. He didn't just start this when he was indicted.'' Milken taught math at the elementary school for a day recently, bringing along pop star Michael Jackson as a treat for the children in the economically depressed area. Milken brought in fruit, vegetables and calculators to illustrate his lessons and had to be dragged away from the students at the end of the day, said Mrs. Coleman. He called back to volunteer again even before she'd written him a thank-you note, she added. ``I tell the kids, `You need to dream big _ you need role models,''' Mrs. Coleman said. ``I'm sure he made a difference for them.'' Jules Lesner, the director of the Foundations of the Milken Families, said their operations will be unaffected by Milken's guilty plea Tuesday to six felonies. Publicity about those pleas and the $600 million in fines and restitution Milken agreed to pay will mean ``just an increase in the number of requests,'' Lesner said. ``More people are aware we're here and what we do.'' Milken and his brother Lowell have established four foundations in all, with endowments that now total nearly $400 million. Operating out of offices not far from Milken's home in the San Fernando Valley, they fund educational programs and awards to educators, health care, cancer and epilepsy research, child care, museums, job retraining, sports programs. A Jewish community center in the West San Fernando Valley was built with millions of dollars in foundation money. Children at the Los Angeles Zoo can enter a cave to learn about pallid bats and ringtail cats and a desert area to study sidewinders and gila monsters, thanks to a $1 million donation. Another $1 million went toward the Museum of Tolerance, the Jewish Holocaust education facility under construction at the Simon Wiesenthal Center in West Los Angeles. ``His involvement with our charity goes back many years, to at least 1983,'' said Rabbi Marvin Hier of the Wiesenthal Center. ``Whenever we asked him to do something, it was always a personal involvement, never just sending a check. ``When Michael Milken would speak to you about charitable projects, he would make it sound as if you were the most important person in the world, and you were the only person he was concerned with at that moment,'' Hier said. Even in charity, Milken's activities were questioned. Rep. John D. Dingell, D-Mich., who heads the House subcommittee on oversight and investigations, asked the California attorney general's office to determine if Milken illegally benefited from the foundation's trades or assets. After a nine-month probe, investigators reported last August that he had not. Richard Riordan, a friend of Milken's who is a lawyer and fellow philanthropist, said Milken genuinely loves dealing with children, especially minority children. ``His attitude is sort of an underdog _ it's a bit of the Jewish culture, the underdog culture, the ethic that they have to give to others. But there's something very special about him. Anything he does he's hands-on,'' Riordan said. Riordan said he expects Milken to continue his charitable work from behind bars if he goes to prison. At the 102nd Street School, Mrs. Coleman said some teachers had gone out of their way to make sure she heard their criticism of Milken, accusing him of self-promotion for his visit. The children felt differently, she said. ``Today, some of them seemed kind of sad,'' she said. ``They were saying `Will he come back, will he have to go to jail?'''

DOC.HEAD: Harsco Board Rejects Carlyle Proposal
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with board meeting, letter to Carlyle rejecting proposal; picks up 7th graf pvs, `Harsco's defense ...'
DOC.TEXT: Harsco Corp.'s board of directors on Tuesday rejected a Washington investment group's suggestion that it sell its defense divisions and borrow $300 million for a special dividend. The 11-member board met privately and late in the day issued a copy of a letter sent to Frank Carlucci, vice president of The Carlyle Group, which had called for the steps. The letter said the board has considered and rejected such strategies before, but said Carlucci could meet with Harsco representatives to discuss the matter further. Carlucci was defense secretary late in the Reagan administration. Calls to Harsco and Carlyle for comment on the letter went unanswered late in the day. Before the director's meeting, Harsco's president and chief executive told shareholders at the annual meeting that the company was not considering any offers to sell its defense divisions in York, Pa., or Marysville, Ohio. ``I want to state emphatically that no part of the defense group has been sold, and that we are not now engaged in discussions to sell any part of the defense group,'' Malcolm W. Gambill told shareholders. Harsco's defense group also includes BMY-Wheeled Vehicles in Marysville and Tactical Truck Corp., a joint venture with General Motors. TTC has won a U.S. government contract to develop new 2.5-ton and 5-ton trucks, which Harsco expects will be produced at Marysville. Fifteen prototypes are being tested by the Army. Gambill said the company feels it has a considerable potential for international sales of its current military truck produced at Marysville, and intends to boost daily production to 40 a day. The company now makes 30 trucks a day. Since 1988, Harsco has cut 39.3 percent of the workforce, 1,019 salaried and wage employees, at the York plant. But Gambill told stockholders the cost cutting and improvements made over an unprofitable military earth-moving vehicle, known as ACE, will return the York division to a nominally profitable operation in the near future. Problems with the ACE vehicle cut 1989 earnings from $2.56 a share to 43 cents a share. The defense group lost $44.4 million in 1988 and $71.9 million in 1989. ``We now know what it takes to efficiently build this vehicle,'' said Gambill, adding that Harsco is negotiating with an international customer for a large order of the vehicles. By a 57-10 margin, stockholders rejected a proposal by the New York State Teachers' Retirement System to withdraw from an investment in Heckett South Africa Ltd., which it co-owns with South African Iron and Steel Industrial Corp. Ltd. Harsco said in a statement that it feels it was influentual in eliminating race-based wage and salary discrepancies at HSA and helping it adopt non-discriminatory policies on housing loans, educational assistance, job training and company restaurants. The company said the proposal would result in abandoning black employees rather than benefiting them.
